name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to propose to the Plenary that we start in five minutes because, due to the demonstrations around Parliament, many Members are still arriving as cars could not get out of the garage.I therefore propose that we resume sitting in five minutes to allow as many Members as possible to arrive in Parliament.I apologize to Commissioner Malmström and thank you for your understanding towards your colleagues.In five minutes we will resume the session.(The session, suspended at 9.05 am, resumed at 9.15 am)

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is, in joint discussion, - the recommendation by Artis Pabriks, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other (10975/2016 - C8-0438 / 2016 - 2016/0205 (NLE) (A8-0009 / 2017), - the Commission statement on the conclusionof the CETA EU-Canada (2017/2525 (RSP), and - the recommendation of Charles Tannock, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the agreementstrategic partnership between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Canada, on the other (14765/2016 - C8-0508 / 2016 - 2016/0373 (NLE) (A8-0028 / 2017).

name: Artis Pabriks
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, sometime before 2009 in one of the major provinces of Canada, Quebec, the idea of CETA was born. Today is the day when we can decide how to go forward with this deal. I would say it is a judgment day, because since 2016 we have discussed in the European Parliament – more than18 times in different large groups – what this trade deal really means for us. We have been taking into account most, if not all, of the concerns that have been raised by analysing the previous trade deals with other countries, and I think that we can say with great confidence that this trade deal, is in many ways, a golden standard for future trade deals in the world.  I would also like to say that CETA is a litmus test for our European Union policies. We are standing at the crossroads, and we can take one of two directions. The first direction is protectionism, provincialism, decline and the building of walls. Do we really want it? I do not think so – at least, I do not want it. The second direction is openness to the world, it is leadership, it is effective decision making, it is growth, and finally, also, the bringing of wealth to our Union and each and every nation and Member State here on the European continent. Of course, the CETA trade deal is not a cure, a medicine, for each and every disease. We must understand that. It is comprehensive, but it will not solve all the problems that our workers, small and medium enterprises and people are facing. It is not meant to do this, and this is why I would like to say to those who are not listening to the facts but following the alternative news and not trying to go into depths of the analysis of this trade deal: please do not bark up the wrong tree. Try to find other solutions for other existing problems, but go forward with this deal. As regards CETA, it has two very important aspects for us included in this deal. One is the geopolitical aspect, another is the purely trade and economic aspect. As regards geopolitics are concerned, the Canadian nation has always stood for the same values that we stand for here in Europe. There is no other nation outside the European Union so like us as the Canadians. Sometimes, I think they are even closer to us than some of our Members from time to time (that was a bit of a joke). They have been sending their soldiers since the First World War to defend our freedoms and our liberties. They died in the Second World War for our freedoms and liberties, and even now, when the European Union is facing security challenges at its external borders, Canadian soldiers are again on our sandy beaches in northern Europe. Thank you to Canada for this.  Secondly, if we are speaking about the economy, there is a number of things that this trade deal will deliver. It will deliver trade in goods and decreased tariffs. It will deliver additional possibilities for services. It will give us the possibility to join procurement in Canada, which has not happened before. Geographic indications, a lot of geographic indications for many of our producers, and of course the investment part. So from that perspective, I would say that every country, just like my small country, Latvia, will benefit from this. Our products which are now sold in Canada – Latvian products, for instance, and also Swedish or German or French products – will be between 8% and 12% cheaper after the trade deal is passed. It is a good thing. The world is watching us. The world is watching the European Union and which direction we will take. Will we take the direction of protectionism and closedness, or will we fight for liberal democratic values, for growth and for the new golden standards of international trade? It is a unique chance for the European Union now to take again a leading position in the global economy and global politics, and in many ways the vote for CETA will decide this. Never before has the world needed such a strong Europe at this moment, and it needs guidelines for good trade. CETA is like a lighthouse for these guidelines, for many who are searching for wealth and trade. Please do not switch off this light. Vote for CETA.

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, Canada enjoys one of the closest possible relationships with the European Union. It is a country that shares a common culture –‘c’est un pays bilingue’ – with two EU languages as national languages, and that has a healthy respect for democracy and the rule of law. That we are set to ratify the Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA) and Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) later today demonstrates the value that we in the European Union place on that strong, traditional and lengthy relationship. Canada, with its similar levels of GDP per capita, as an advanced economy and a NATO Member State further cements ties and mutual interests. For example, there are two extracts from the SPA that, to my mind, sum up exactly what this is all about and what it stands for. The first reads, ‘The Parties shall implement this Agreement based on shared values, the principles of dialogue, mutual respect, equal partnership, multilateralism, consensus and respect for international law.’ The second extract reads, ‘Recognising that sustainable globalisation and greater prosperity can only be achieved through an open world economy based on market principles, effective regulations and strong global institutions [...]’. I think these two passages sum it all up, illustrating exactly what the SPA and CETA are all about, namely ambitious, free-trade, liberal multilateralism. These are the values that they seek to embody and defend, at a time when they need defending more than at any other time in the European Union’s recent history. Whilst my main area of concern, as rapporteur, is the SPA, it is important that we consider this alongside CETA and the wider international political climate in which we now find ourselves. Whether we look to the election of President Donald Trump in the United States or, in my personal view, the regrettable decision of my country, the United Kingdom, to leave the European Union, or the rise of populist, protectionist parties across Europe, it is clear that the merits of free trade, multilateralism and the liberal international world order are, unfortunately, being questioned by many, and we must stand up and fight for them. Such questions can be answered only by concrete results. This means increasing trade, creating economic growth, providing jobs and creating a safe and secure world. The SPA and CETA will, hopefully, do exactly these things, and I can illustrate what can be achieved by defending these values that they are based on. To focus on some of the main headlines of the SPA in the areas where coordination of efforts is envisaged, I will take a few areas of particular interest. Preventing nuclear proliferation; ensuring the effective working of the International Criminal Court, now increasingly challenged; strengthening counterterrorism efforts and combating the financing of international terrorism; enforcing consumer protection; fighting the trade in illicit drugs; tackling cybercrime; and discussing the High North Arctic Strategy, increasingly threatened by an expansionist Russia – these are just a few examples of what is envisaged in the SPA. Much of what we see in the SPA is, in fact, the development of long—standing links and coordination. I am proud to say that 2017 marks the 40th anniversary of the initial political agreement between Canada and the European Union, all the way back to 1977, a testament to the long and enduring links between the two sides. It was only a year later that, as a student, I found myself living for several months, in 1978, in Canada and appreciating at first hand the strong bonds and common culture that bind us together. Existing cooperation between Canada and the EU and its Member States spans a number of key policy areas: for example, the Europol Agreement, active since 2005, which provides a valuable vehicle for the sharing of data and information in the fight against international crime and terrorism; Canada’s consistent military contributions to the common security and defence policy of the European Union; and our frequent meetings with Canadian parliamentarians when they participate in joint electoral observation missions with the OSCE and NATO parliamentary assemblies. Furthermore, the visa liberalisation agreement, in place since 2015, will now be completed and extended to the entire European Union, as agreed. Trump’s attitude to NATO and to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) will also bind Canada closer to the European Union on both defence and commercial policies. The EU already enjoys close political and trade relations with Mexico, making it a reliable ally against any US attempts to undermine NAFTA. Although the United Kingdom is, unfortunately, leaving the European Union, Malta and Cyprus will still provide an important Commonwealth link. To conclude, the SPA comes at a time of increasing scepticism about free trade and multilateralism among certain elements of the political class and voters. I believe that the strong relationship and record of cooperation between the European Union and Canada can therefore be a much-needed poster child for those values at this critical time, and that the benefits and prosperity brought by increased trade and cooperation fostered by these agreements are in both Europe’s and Canada’s interest. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: As you know, the rules are always the same for everyone.If I am flexible in certain debates towards some parliamentarians, I am also flexible towards others.It has always been like that and it will be like that today.Please certainly do not abuse the flexibility.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to extend my deepest sympathy to the Canadian people for the terror attack they suffered two weeks ago. Je suis québecoise, nous sommes tous québecois. With Canada, we share the democratic values of openness and tolerance. We cooperate in tackling common challenges such as migration, sustainable development, climate change and terrorism. The two agreements that we are discussing here today – the free trade agreement (CETA) and the Strategic Partnership Agreement – together offer an opportunity to upgrade our EU—Canada relationship. Those agreements strengthen both our economic relations and our geopolitical alliance, reflecting our partnership, which is both unique and distinctive, making that partnership deeper and more powerful, reaffirming our fundamental values and political principles and using them to shape globalisation, with an institutional framework that allows for deeper exchange, to help each side serve its citizens in the 21st Century.  CETA will benefit EU citizens and business. Exports to Canada today support around 900 000 European jobs. But the 70 000, or perhaps a little more, EU companies who export to Canada face many obstacles. These obstacles are particularly burdensome for small and medium-size companies, which make up about 80% of the total. CETA helps those companies in many ways. It removes almost all tariffs from day one. Exporters stand to save over EUR 500 million a year, and that is a lot of money, especially for the small companies. It also cuts red tape, the lengthy customs and duplicative certification procedures which small businesses can ill afford. It opens up markets in services and public procurement on all levels, and it protects over 140 of the most traded geographical indications, helping European farmers sell more of their high—quality products in Canada. Trade policy is about opening markets, but it is also about our values, so CETA is a progressive agreement with a progressive partner, upholding our standards and protecting our sensitivities. Nothing in this agreement undermines a government’s right to regulate in the public interest; nothing in this agreement affects the safety of food we eat or the products we buy; nothing prevents governments from providing public services or bringing these services back to the public domain if they have been privatised; nothing requires privatisation of water or healthcare, and nothing changes the prerogative of EU lawmakers to set EU rules under EU procedures. In particular, decision—making in the CETA joint committee cannot circumvent or derogate from EU Treaty requirements, particularly the role of the EU institutions in making policy. CETA will not change food safety standards or any other EU requirements; only the EU institutions can do that, and Member States may also adopt relevant legislation for that. The Commission will fully abide by EU internal processes, as defined by the Treaties, before taking any position in the CETA committee, and there can be no doubt that the role of this Parliament will be both fully respected and your contribution is also welcomed.  I know this Parliament has concerns and had concerns about the private ad hoc arbitration known as the Investor-State Dispute Resolution (ISDS), so we have reformed it. Your role here has been critical in shaping the new investment court system. This new system guarantees a government’s right to regulate; it uses public courts, qualified judges, transparent proceedings, an appeal mechanism and a strict code of ethics, and this Parliament will be involved in selecting its tribunal members, similar to its involvement for ECJ judges. As you know, with Canada we are right now working on the international scene to promote the idea of a multilateral investment court.  CETA is a modern, new kind of agreement, promoting our values of free, fair and sustainable trade. Canada and the EU pledge to effectively implement major international agreements on labour and the environment. These provisions are ambitious, but they are also binding and legally enforceable, and they are having an effect: Canada is on the path to ratify the last outstanding core labour convention on collective bargaining. The agreement contains a mechanism to review these provisions, notably on enforcement, and I commit, as I have written to you in letters, to set in motion this review mechanism soon after CETA is provisionally applied. To feed into this review, I intend to open a broad and inclusive debate on sustainable development provisions in our free trade agreements, involving all stakeholders, including of course this Parliament.  The Strategic Partnership Agreement accompanies and complements CETA, reinforcing our partnership, deepening contacts and coordination in areas like foreign security and defence policy, migration, counterterrorism, human rights, sustainable development and climate change – areas where we can work, and where we are already working together, to make life better for our citizens and promote a progressive international agenda rooted in our principles. Honourable Members, we are at a time where many stand against what the EU stands for – openness, international cooperation, freedom to trade, etc. – and those who oppose those principles often also question the foundation and the future of the EU itself. Against those trends, we have the chance to work with like-minded partners to show that protectionism does not work: that putting up barriers and building walls is not the answer. Good, efficient fair trade agreements with like-minded partners are the answer, and we have this opportunity today by consenting to the two agreements.  I would like to end by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Pabriks, and of course Mr Tannock on the Strategic Partnership Agreement, the shadows, and many more who have worked for a long time on this agreement. I am looking forward to the debate, and hopefully a successful vote. Thank you very much.

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, as I have already mentioned, the Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA) will have an important role within security. We saw attempts for the Passenger Name Record Agreement to go before this Parliament, and it was referred to the ECJ. I hope that eventually comes to fruition. There is also the creation of a Joint Ministerial Council and Joint Consultative Council for the first time, which will enable senior policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic to exchange ideas. On how to mitigate the effects of climate change, Canada and the European Union will have to look at this very carefully, particularly with the risk of the melting of the ice sheets in the High North and the increased migratory pressures from Sub—Saharan Africa impacting on the EU with climate change, a very important common shared challenge. President Trump’s repeated threats to pull America out of the Paris climate change agreement means an additional threat to global stability which the EU, together with Canada, will have to face together. Lastly, the SPA and CETA will become the model for the European Union to conduct future advanced close trade and political relations with third—country partners, including, in all probability, the so-called bespoke deal with the European Union currently envisaged with the UK and the British Government after Brexit. So let us hope that this is a successful model, so that the UK itself can negotiate something similar after Brexit.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs in its opinion of 8 December last, stressed that decent job creation, balanced wage increases and expanded entrepreneurship possibilities must be the defining criteria for giving consent for the conclusion of CETA. The Committee found, however, that the agreement seriously fails and falls short on all three scores.  Real world models and assessments indicate no more than a 0.018% increase in overall EU employment over six to ten years, with significant sectoral dislocations and increases in long-term unemployment. Income gaps are projected to widen between skilled and unskilled workers. There is no single chapter with specific measures in favour of SMEs, and finally, the privileged status of investors under the Investment Court System stands in stark contrast to the mere consultations envisaged for protecting labour interests and rights.  Hence the Committee’s recommendation to Parliament is to decline to give its consent for the conclusion of CETA. (Applause)

name: Bart Staes
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety advises by a large majority to approve CETA. As rapporteur, I tried to evaluate CETA in a fair but critical way. I took our April 2015 resolution on TTIP as a starting point. And in my opinion, CETA does not meet four conditions. One, there is no explicit mention for the precautionary principle. Two, regulatory cooperation, while voluntary, is not limited to specific sectors where the EU and Canada have an equal level of protection. Three, CETA contains provisions on public and social services that affect the Member States' discretion. Fourth, CETA contains provisions that will eventually undermine our GMO legislation. In addition, there is the ICS arbitration mechanism, which provides parallel jurisdiction for foreign investors, undermining the sovereignty of member states. Furthermore, as rapporteur, I expressed concerns about the provisions on chemicals legislation, the negative list on public and social services, the undermining of the standards on pesticide residues, the regulations on endocrine disruptors, the threat to the pick-to-fork approach in food safety and the bad provisions affecting our climate and energy policy. An overwhelming majority of colleagues in the ENVI Commission did not listen, despite the objections of millions of citizens. I must therefore recommend that you, as rapporteur, approve CETA, I myself may vote against.

name: Presidente. –
text: Today is a particularly sensitive debate.Everyone will have the opportunity to express their ideas and positions.So please respect the speakers who hold different theses from yours on both sides.It is not up to the President to decide what Parliament's position should be, it will be the Sovereign Chamber, today during the vote, that will decide what Parliament's position will be.Let us now turn to the interventions on behalf of the groups.The first is that of the Hon.Weber for the European People's Party.

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! In the first few minutes we can feel what it's all about today. It's about the discussion between feelings, between creating fear and between facts. Afterwards we will listen to Mrs Le Pen - (heckling) everyone can express their opinion here, and everyone can listen, okay? If Mrs Le Pen takes the floor afterwards, she will be afraid of trading. She will say she rejects Canada. She will say she opposes Australia. She will say she rejects New Zealand. It wants to bring about a complete isolation of France, and it scares the people - the farmers, the workers, as we have seen it. I say: These models already existed. In Europe there have already been countries that have completely isolated themselves, for example Albania under a dictator who has completely built up all borders. Le Pen wants to turn France into a large Albania that is not led into the future, but wants to isolate itself. We in the EPP Group believe in the facts, we believe in facts. And if we look at South Korea, for example, the last agreement we concluded five years ago - dear colleague Le Pen and dear colleagues - led to an export increase of 55%, EUR 17 billion more was exported, which is 14 000 new jobs created. A total of 30 million jobs in Europe depend on export. These are facts. You can of course counteract that with emotions. We as the EPP continue to believe in the facts. I would like to thank Commissioner Malmström for her hard work. That is a great agreement that you have presented to us today. Thanks to public participation, consumer protection associations and the trade unions, it was possible to take up the worries and also to dispel many worries. And I also have to make it clear: with whom should we still hold talks? Can we, if we cannot hold talks with Canada, a highly developed democratic country based on partnership, and conclude these talks accordingly? (Applause) Dear colleagues! Unfortunately, I also have to become a bit partisan in the debate, because of course we need to know who leads this Parliament and who leads into the future of this continent. And Gianni, unfortunately I have to say that the social democratic group is deeply divided. The Socialist Group cannot give any guidance on how things will continue in Europe. Half are for CETA, the other half are against CETA. And the Greens must allow themselves to be asked very critically whether they are in good company when they are at the same time campaigning against CETA with Le Pen and the communists. One must be able to ask this question. I believe that the Greens and consumer groups have had many important debates, but now they should also recognize that we are on the right track and that the agreement is a good deal. Finally, two quick points. One is the decision-making process. I think we have to realize, when we consider CETA, that we will need clear responsibilities in Europe in the future. The discussion about Wallonia - we as the EPP respect every parliament in Europe, federalism and regionalism are important to us. But we need responsibilities that are clear in the future, so that people know when Europe is discussing free trade, then the European Parliament must be the place where CETA will be the only and final vote in the future. Finally, the big picture is that we have Donald Trump. And Donald Trump has terminated TPP. He wants to build walls. And we as Europeans want on this day, with this vote today, to make it clear that we don't want to build walls, we want to build bridges, we want to Partnership.And that is why my group will be voting for CETA.(Applause and boos)

name: Presidente. –
text: During the interventions of the representatives of the groups I will not grant "blue cards", because I repeat that it is a delicate debate and I invite everyone to respect the ideas of others.Each group will have the right to express their ideas and positions.This is democracy and therefore please respect your colleagues, even if they express different ideas from yours.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have heard triumphal tones which I do not share. And I have listened, lastly, to the provocations of my colleague Weber, which are not respectful of the free, frank and close debate that has taken place in the Socialists and Democrats group. My group demands respect. We are not a barracks and we never will be. I want to say right away that for us Socialists and Democrats, CETA is not a model, it is only the beginning of a change in European trade policy. There are those who think that what is happening in the world should not condition and influence our reflections, that we can go on putting our heads in the sand. We are not among them. Trump is not Obama, and we must reflect on what is happening. Trump took advantage of a naïve view of globalization. Trade agreements are meant only for the interests of large companies. Our voters are turning against this vision of globalization. We support CETA as part of an awareness that a new trade policy is needed. We must acknowledge that in recent months we have been committed to improving CETA and also thanks to our work today we have a better agreement than in the past. We have overcome the ISDS which, if not modified, would have been the Trojan horse with which multinationals would have undermined our legal systems. In its place there is now a mechanism with an appeal, with judges above any conflict of interest, and it is also thanks to our work as Socialists that public services will not be affected, as well as workers' rights. We were able to achieve these improvements also thanks to the work of the Commissioner and above all thanks to a partner, Canada, to which we are bound by common values ​​and hopes, a country with which we share the ambition to build a new, more democratic multilateral system, a positive globalization different from that pursued until now. I thank Premier Trudeau, who we know is with us in this battle against the viruses of populism and isolationism. This agreement is the beginning for us, but we need a broader and clearer progressive international trade agenda, on the basis of which we will evaluate future agreements, starting with the one between the European Union and Japan. We will no longer cast our vote unless there is a new progressive trade policy agenda, and we will never again tolerate ISDS-like dispute resolution tools. We want more transparency in the negotiations and we want adherence to the most advanced standards of workers' rights to become the norm. In short, our support is not a vote to keep, but a vote to change. It is a way to listen to the concerns of our citizens. We want to change this globalization, we don't want to suffer it.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, what is the Canada-EU Trade Agreement (CETA) really about? It is about new jobs created by Polish fruit exporters or Italian tie makers facing lower barriers to selling their products in Canada, it is about cheaper prices and more choice for consumers, and it is about allowing our small businesses to bid for public procurement contracts in Canada. My ECR Group supports CETA and other trade agreements because international trade is between willing sellers in one country and willing buyers in another country.  Opponents of international trade will often highlight the losses, but they fail to point to the often larger gains which are dispersed across a nation or across international borders. I am not saying that we should ignore these legitimate concerns. We should encourage lifelong learning programmes for workers in declining companies and sectors to retrain for new roles in the face of globalisation and new technology. We should address the concerns of both Canadians and citizens of EU countries who accuse each other of having lower environmental and labour standards. Both cannot be right. And we should also remind the anti-capitalists over there, and the anti-globalisation movement over here, that they are in fact the true friends of the multinationals, for it is often the multinationals with their armies of lawyers and lobbyists who call for, or shape, the regulatory barriers which keep smaller businesses confined to their local markets.  (Applause) So the ECR Group will vote for CETA, as an opportunity to show the world that the EU is open for business, an opportunity for small businesses to create more jobs and opportunities for everyone, not just a privileged few or the large multinationals, to benefit from open trade. We support CETA.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - With our debate today, we conclude seven years of hard work and negotiation for a result that we can be proud of. We need jobs and growth and CETA provides opportunities for European companies through market access. We wanted guarantees that high standards protect the environment, people and consumers, and we got them. We pushed for drastic overhaul of investment protections and we see that a new model works much better and Canada embraced it fully. We have put an end to bureaucratic red tape for small, but also large companies. We have zoomed in on every detail to do justice to the many questions, requests, concerns and wishes of civil society organizations, companies, experts and citizens. But let's also zoom out and keep the context in which we vote today clear. With President Trump in the White House, a clear American change of course is set in motion, and leadership for open economies, open societies and a strong multilateral system must now come from us in Europe. Too many major powers would prefer that globalization and trade can be done without fair standards or fair competition or respect for people and the environment. But it is precisely now that we must seize this moment to continue working on an ambitious trade agenda, deeply rooted in the values ​​that we all cherish. We cannot imagine a better partner than the Canadians, the most European country outside the Union, certainly under the leadership of Prime Minister Trudeau. While we visited Canada with the International Trade Commission, Brussels was hit by the disgusting terrorist attacks and I will never forget the massive support of the Canadians. Entire ice hockey stadiums full. This only confirms that our alliance is not only deeply rooted in history, but is still very personally experienced today and is certainly future-proof. Finally, I would like to emphasize how much CETA is a liberal success, but I would like to thank everyone who stuck their neck out and worked on this treaty, often against the grain, for that: Commissioner Malmström from the Commission, but also all Canadians for the patience they have had to show over these seven years of hard work.But the result is there.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - These are a few signatures of the 3.5 million people who oppose CETA and that is only part of the millions who have demonstrated against CETA. Not to mention the 150,000 people who have objected to any form of arbitration and the more than 2,000 municipalities and regions that have declared themselves CETA and TTIP free. No one has even directed one unkind word against Canada. But you don't make such a bad deal with friends, based on mistrust and at the expense of a lot of people. I am genuinely concerned about this treaty. It is a treaty that assumes that any rule restricting trade is a wrong rule and should be scrapped, putting food safety rules under pressure. Our public health is under threat, environmental protection is under threat and our regulatory autonomy is also under pressure. We supply ourselves to multinationals. This not only weakens our rule of law, we also jeopardize our democracy. That's not just my opinion. It is also what we have heard from judges, lawyers and lawyers, from trade unions, consumer organizations and interest groups for small and medium-sized businesses, from farmers, conservationists and environmental organizations, from NGOs, who have researched flows of money, transparency and development cooperation. CETA is a threat to all of us and I do not understand the liberals that they are undermining democracy and the rule of law. I do not understand that the EPP is letting farmers and small and medium-sized businesses go to waste. And I certainly do not understand the Social Democrats, who do not oppose these kinds of treaties, which do not offer any guarantee of success, which pose many risks and which also have dozens of open questions. CETA is a bad treaty. It is only good for multinationals and we are not through that elected.We have been elected by the millions of people who ask us to defend their interests.People before profit.Stop CETA.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there would therefore be the nice Canadians with whom we are going to have the most beautiful agreement that Europe has ever signed. Better still, a coincidence of history, we are signing this agreement when a xenophobic, racist and sexist leader rules the United States. I would like to remind you, Mr. Weber, that Mr. Trump is a Republican-elected conservative, so he is part of your international political family. On the other side, there would be workers and their unions, consumers and their organizations, civil society and its millions of people who have signed petitions. There would be the SMEs and there would be these parliamentarians unfit for the happiness you offer them, stunted in themselves, withdrawn into the old world and old space. But have you forgotten who negotiated this deal? It is Mr. Harper, climate skeptic, who now advises multinationals; it is Mr Barroso, former President of the European Commission, who now advises Goldman Sachs; it is Mr De Gucht, former trade commissioner, who now advises multinationals. The culmination of this process of deregulation and privatization of the norm is precisely the government of Mr. Trump, where it is not the commissioners and former prime ministers who pass to the multinationals, but the multinationals who are in Trump administration. We are at a too precious and too rare moment in our history not to look at what justifies and explains Brexit, what explains Trumps ... It is the globalization that you are building that partly explains this. You feed the fire that feed the far right to say how bad globalization, the other, the difference is. We absolutely have to build, Commissioner, a globalization of regulation if we do not want Europe continues to fall apart. If we don't want Brexits, if we don't want more Trump, more far-right, we have to make Europe the pillar of public regulation of globalization. It means human rights, social rights and the environment above trade and investment rights. TAFTA and CETA are exactly the opposite. You tell us that you protect jobs: you yourself, in the hearing of the Committee on International Trade and that of Employment and Social Affairs, you said "we do not know if this will create jobs. ". The only study that exists counts on less than 100,000 jobs in Europe. You claim to be defending the climate with Mr. Trudeau. However, Mr. Trudeau, two days ago, was with Donald Trump to restart the Keystone XL pipeline project, which Barack Obama had canceled because he considered it to be "climaticide". It is your Commission, Madam, which refuses to legislate and regulate endocrine disruptors to protect health. So, yes, we want a partnership with Canadians, with Americans, with all the others, but on the climate, on social rights, on the fight against tax havens, on banking supervision, and of all that, there there is nothing in these agreements! Defend democracy, defend democratic sovereignty, defend European legal sovereignty, defend a major European project to counter deregulatory globalization, a globalization that concentrates power in the hands of a few multinationals and a few multibillionaires. Let’s do something else with Europe, otherwise it will fall apart, which is what you are contributing to today.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, CETA is not a free trade treaty, it is a covert institutional reform, conceived in secret chambers by unelected technocrats and disguised as an international treaty. For three years the 5 Star Movement has been trying to warn you, but it hasn't helped. It did not help to tell you that CETA will bring a negligible growth of 0.01% per year, which will cause 200 000 Europeans to lose their jobs, which will lead to a contraction in real wages between EUR 300 and EUR 1 300. There is no point in reminding you that imports of wheat, meat or corn will soar three, four, seven times, or that a Canadian farm is twenty times larger than a European one, with all due respect to our small farmers. Commissioner, after today's vote, CETA will enter the lives of our citizens. Europeans will find it at the table. A colossal rip-off, given that in Canada 81% of corn and 80% of wheat are GMOs, meat contains ractopamine and other substances currently banned in Europe, but which will be very easy to make legal in the future thanks to CETA. If CETA officially promises not to let GMOs in, in reality they will all go through the back door, because the treaty incorporates the same lock pick already successfully used by American corporations to attack the European blockade on meat with hormones, that is the very dangerous rules. health care of the World Trade Organization. In addition, water, health and services that are public today will be subjected to a wave of irreversible privatization and liberalization and no one will be able to oppose it because CETA will establish a supranational court with the power to condemn states that dare to put a spoke in the wheels of corporations. and their profits. A shameful private justice to which three quarters of American companies operating in Europe will have access by triangulating lawsuits through their branches in Canada.But above all, CETA is a blank check.Colleagues, perhaps you think you know what you are about to sign but you don't.CETA creates a technocratic and unelected body that will be able to interpret the protocols of the treaty at will, and it is not just a few pages but 75% of the 1,500 pages that make it up, some of which have been deliberately left blank.All this without any, I repeat no, democratic control.For this reason, colleagues, I will tell you once more: CETA is not a treaty, it is not an agreement, but it is a silent coup d'état, it is an institutional reform disguised as a treaty and we must stop it.

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, after seven years of negotiations, this treaty between the European Union and Canada, twin brother of the transatlantic treaty, will be refused or accepted by this Parliament. The CETA treaty has been carefully hidden from all citizens. It has hardly ever been discussed in front of the big debating bodies of the media because neither of you is willing or able to defend it publicly. Ah! Voting, hidden in the shadows, you like it, but to debate in broad daylight, you hate! Worse, members of the Socialist Party, who are often very indulgent about CETA in this Parliament, pretend to oppose it in a few confidential media. The French UMPs all voted for CETA in committee but say they are opposed to it when asked. When the people understand all these lies, they will never trust you again. This is why this treaty is a villainous treaty vis-à-vis the peoples of Europe. It eliminates almost all customs duties on products traded between the European Union and Canada and will destroy, once again, hundreds of thousands of jobs in Europe, tens of thousands in France. Agriculture and animal husbandry, already damaged by all the free trade treaties you have already signed, will continue their descent into hell. Our breeders, put in competition with 35% cheaper Canadian breeders, risk closing the curtain en masse. I solemnly ask you: are you not ashamed to destroy those who nourish you in this way? To level the playing field for multinationals, you are giving away our right to regulate and aligning standards with those of Canada, denying our citizens the protection they expect from their political representatives. Unfortunately for them, the profits of multinationals are more important to you than the protection of citizens and the environment. The various committees that you set up as these obscure regulatory cooperation mechanisms are supranational in nature, are not controlled by anyone, so much so that great French jurists are asking themselves the question of their constitutionality. To complete it all, you create an exceptional private justice to allow multinationals to attack states so that no more regulation displeases these new lords of modern times. Those who will do justice in this tribunal are not judges, neutral public officials, they will most often be business lawyers in international law, in conflict of interest because they have received fees from these same multinationals or their sisters. Finally, the public services that are so important for the middle and popular classes will have to operate in a purely commercial logic, with the exception of a few sovereign services. This is the disastrous picture of the CETA treaty. If this treaty is voted in a few hours, it will demonstrate, once again, to all Europeans your inability to defend them and the crucial importance for each people to regain its sovereignty, its ability to freely decide its future. The only reassuring thing is that the French people will have a possibility to reverse this treaty and all the other rogue treaties, with the presidential election of May 2017, as it is true that it is up to the nations to negotiate their trade policy and not to an unelected structure which only represents its own interests and not those of the peoples.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, CETA serves the interests of the monopolies and is a single market plan to further increase capitalist profits, with significant geopolitical implications. The big business groups of the European Union and Canada seek to gain a profit advantage over their competitors. The United States groups play a particularly important role in these competitions, with their strong position in Canada. CETA paves the way for the challenge and abolition of any labor rights that remain unresolved, with mass redundancies on both sides of the Atlantic. In the name of protecting investors and entrepreneurship, the maximum possible freedom of movement of capital, goods and services is guaranteed, including crushing small and medium-sized farmers, repealing basic environmental regulations and any minimum levels of food safety and environmental protection. today. The last obstacles for the monopolies, for the liberation of state and other services, are removed, signaling their unhindered delivery to capital. The custom setting up of investment courts aims to secure guaranteed profits for monopolies, not only directly from their investments, but also through compensation. The responsibilities of the SYRIZA government in Greece are serious and its mockery is great, that while it has co-signed CETA in the European Council, SYRIZA executives are presented as protesters. The Communist Party of Greece is voting against this unpopular agreement, which can neither be recommended nor corrected. The struggle against the agreements and the interests of capital is part of the struggle to eliminate the causes of capitalist exploitation, to satisfy the needs of the people.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: - Dear Madam President! Today is a good day for Europe, Canada and the world. We are helping to shape the world today. Why are we doing this We do this because globalization is taking place. However, we do not want the richest, the greatest, the most unfair to decide what to do in an increasingly intertwined environment; we want the power of law to apply in a world that is growing together. That is why it is a good day for our citizens, for Europe and the world, when free democracies in Canada and Europe shape globalization and set international law. But we also notice that many people have worries. They worry about their future. You are worried about the ever faster changes. They are concerned about the many half-true and untrue claims that are being made about this trade deal. I would therefore like to say once again very clearly what it is about and what it is not about: it is about growth and employment and it is not about lower environmental, social or consumer protection standards. It is about better market access for our small and large companies and it is not about the forced privatization of municipal services of general interest. It is about protecting our citizens from discrimination abroad, and not about restricting the freedom to make political decisions or disempowering national courts. That is why our result as an EPP is: We say yes to CETA, because foreclosure only produces losers on all sides. We say yes to CETA because we want to realize the opportunities that lie ahead. We say yes to CETA because we finally want to give globalization rules. In these uncertain times, people are looking for support and guidance. It is time to give it to them, and CETA is a good building block here. (Applause)

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have reached the final stage of a lengthy and difficult process of exercising democratic scrutiny over the negotiation and approval of CETA. The S&D Group has followed closely, as have many colleagues in this House, the negotiations since before what I would call its first conclusion in September 2014. We have voiced concerns, demanded changes and achieved most of those already on the occasion of what was effectively the second conclusion of the negotiations in February 2016. The most important of these was the removal of the old, toxic, ISDS from the Treaty and its replacement with a public system, the new ICS.  In the past year, we have also contributed to, and closely scrutinised and debated, what became the new CETA package submitted to the European Parliament for consent today. We welcome, as a Group, the fact that many of the citizens’ concerns have been addressed through clarifications and commitments from the Commission and the Canadian authorities, through the joint interpretative instrument and the other instruments in the package. CETA is not perfect, far from it, but it is an important step in the right direction: a more progressive trade policy where the benefits are widely spread among all citizens.  The S&D Group has tabled its own consensual resolution which clarifies what we mean by progressive trade agreements by spelling out clearly what we like about CETA, and what we do not like about CETA and expect to be further corrected in CETA where agreed, or in future trade agreements more widely: better provisions on sustainable development and a sanctions-based approach; further improvements to the ICS system and full European Parliament involvement in the designation of judges; better forms to cover the protection of public services; and improved transparency for all trade agreements in future.  The S&D Group has decided to vote in favour of CETA. This is because most of us believe CETA is good for our economy, particularly for SMEs, and it does not threaten our choices, values or laws. But it is also an act of trust and an offer of partnership towards the EU institutions, notably the Commission and the Council, with which we want to work together for a better trade policy, and towards Canada, which is a country that shares our values, our objectives and our hopes for a better future.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Madam President, today marks a milestone, when the European Parliament votes on, and I earnestly hope approves, the most ambitious, modern and largest trade agreement with a developed nation that the EU has ever concluded. As ECR Group shadow rapporteur on the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), I have worked for years on this, as have others like my colleague, Charles Tannock, on the parallel Strategic Partnership Agreement. The CETA trade deal will eliminate 99% of non-agricultural tariffs, saving EU exporters almost EUR 500 million a year immediately, and will deliver near-complete market access both ways. This includes the best-ever services deal and it will also give European companies access to Canadian procurement markets for the first time. In addition, it contains mutual recognition of professional qualifications for midwives, architects, lawyers and doctors, but there is no free movement and no access fees payable either way. It would make a very good template for Britain. Once fully implemented, the agreement is expected to increase bilateral trade in goods and services between the EU Member States and Canada by 23% or GBP 19 billion. It has, however, taken too long (seven years) to get to this point. Two years were wasted on EU human rights demands, and another two years on the question of investor disputes, with the unacceptable Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) system being replaced by the better Investment Court system. The EU must reflect on the time it takes to get agreements with any major trading partner negotiated if they are going to be taken seriously in future. If CETA fails, any credibility the EU has in negotiation will be lost, including with Britain, so this is a vital vote from all our perspectives. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- We have heard from you and also from your colleagues at EPP that all of your considerations are based on facts.I would just be interested now to know what facts support the fact that this agreement with Canada, which will accelerate and intensify trade in both directions extremely, is beneficial in the context of the fight against climate change?Where can we infer from this agreement that we will contribute to the CO2 emissions reductions in Europe and Canada?

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the fact, as with all free trade agreements, is that it is better for people on the high street. It actually reduces the cost of food, for example seafood and meat coming from Canada. That is good for the poorest people in Europe. So that is what these free trade agreements are about. It is good for jobs, our ability to sell services to Canada, and to break into provincial government in Canada. It is good for that, and all of this comes without actually selling out in terms of workers’ rights, or social or environmental protection. So it is a good deal. For heaven’s sake, support it, otherwise we will not get any other deal done by the EU.  (Applause)

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Parliament has been debating this CETA agreement for months and it can be said that, unfortunately, CETA has gained a bit of a bad reputation when it is always linked to the TTIP agreement and seen as a mere Trojan horse, when in fact it is a completely separate entity. Canada is not the same thing as the United States, Canada is Canada, this may be a good thing to remember when going through this agreement. This CETA agreement offers European SMEs the opportunity to find new markets in Canada and facilitate trade in services in many areas. At the moment, the European Union needs a progressive trade agreement, the European Union needs a global market. We need like-minded, like-minded partners like Canada. At CETA, these things come together, and I sincerely hope that colleagues will still find a traditional EU-minded trade policy, the idea that we are not leaning against the Green Left for 'Trump' thinking, but that we want to develop and create rules for trade globally and pioneer the world trade order. when creating. (The speaker promised to answer a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- CETA is good for small and medium-sized enterprises, according to you, CETA is good for European exporters.I don't know if you think CETA is bad for multinationals?Or maybe it is worth saying openly that it is really their interests, not entrepreneurs in Europe, not our farmers, not Europeans?

name: President. –
text: I did not get the entire English translation and I gather colleagues had a problem. Was there a problem with the English booth and could we have a translation of the question please? Could I get some guidance from the booths as to whether they heard the question or do I need to repeat it? Could you perhaps repeat it briefly, Mr Jurek?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- You spoke about small and medium-sized enterprises that you believe will benefit from the CETA agreement, about advantages for European exports.Why did you not talk about international concerns, the main beneficiary of this arrangement?Do you think international concerns located in Canada will lose out on this?

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: the answer to the blue card question.- Thank you for this question, and I would say that when there is one minute, not all things can be raised in it.But I would say that large companies, multinationals, are already doing well.They have their own global networks, but small and medium-sized enterprises - they also need better access to the market to export their own products, and this is a big problem at the moment.They don’t have the funds or the military army to get into that market.On the other hand, as I said, this is needed for employment.It is good to remember that free trade creates jobs.Automation, robots and artificial intelligence take them.We need healthy free trade, and it is SMEs that are the focus.

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! There is a lot to be said and I would have loved to put my speech aside to address the arguments that have been exchanged here. But let me reaffirm that the agreement still contains serious shortcomings, even though you, Commissioner, tried to negotiate away the major deficits of the De Gucht era and / or to close the greatest gaps in uncertainty. The logic of special rights for foreign investors remains despite reforms on your part in the ISDS system. The inclusion of negative lists, for the first time for the EU free trade agreements, opens the way for further liberalization in all economic sectors, including for small and medium-sized companies. The sophisticated clauses on regulatory cooperation leave the thwarted right to regulate on very thin ice, precisely because CETA has been agreed as a so-called living agreement. So we are still living on a construction site, despite seven years of negotiations and 1,600 pages of text. However, since CETA is more than a trade agreement, it will also have a major impact on how we will produce in future with regard to climate change and the necessary changes to our economy, including Industry 4.0, I can only say: it is not subject to approval.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the millions of people all over Europe and in Canada who have been mobilising around this agreement. I want to say to them: you have achieved, at least, reforms, even though we think they are far from enough, and you have ensured a Europe-wide debate on trade. This is a big achievement, and without you we would never have got that far. The Commission and many colleagues say that the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) is a new-style agreement, but beware: it is not. It is an agreement of the very old sort. It is an agreement for putting investor rights over people’s interests, for liberalisation without end, and for harming the climate, the environment and also social standards. On transparency it is even worse than the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). And to all who think that Canada is a beacon of liberalism, well, as was mentioned, CETA was not negotiated by Prime Minister Trudeau. It was negotiated by his predecessor and by your predecessor, Commissioner, Mr De Gucht, along with Mr Barroso – and if I were a Social Democrat I would get pretty nervous around that. But anyway, if the idea is that we like CETA because Canada is nice, then we should all be aware that the Commission is negotiating on many fronts, with many countries. So who are colleagues then willing to reject because they are less nice? I think we need cooperation with countries, especially with nice countries like Canada, and we need to trade and not just for the maple syrup. But we need to do it differently. Trade needs to be good for workers and employees, for consumers, for small-scale enterprises, for society as a whole, and not just for the super-big companies. And agreements need to set good standards, and – especially in these times – we need to work together for climate change, as this is our last chance to uphold international law because it is being challenged. All this we need and all this is not in CETA, and therefore the Greens/EFA Group is rejecting CETA. But no matter how the vote goes today, this is only the beginning of a struggle for fair trade and good cooperation, and we are ready for it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mrs Keller, you very often criticize all trade agreements, and we are used to your rhetoric.But you are making, quite, I would say, false arguments, for example in your speech you said that CETA is in the interests of investors and not the interests of the people.I could ask you: Investors are not people?Are they not ordinary people who want to live too, are they not their taxes, from which you are paid here in this institution?

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for that question, because indeed, I do believe investors are very normal people: they need to have rights like everybody, like all of us, like everyone in Europe and in Canada and elsewhere. That is why investors should have exactly the same rights as people and also be able to claim those rights before the courts – courts that we can all go to, but not special courts where only investors can go, because investors have rights but they should have not have more rights than us normal people, the people in Europe and in Canada and elsewhere.

name: President. –
text: Before I give the floor to our next speaker, could I just say that there were two requests for blue cards. I will take one and I may indeed have to drop the blue cards if our time is running out. So just bear that in mind.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I will begin by quoting from an earlier speech I made on TTIP: trade should be about economic benefits, not political goals, and yet the Commission consistently exploits trade agreements in order to advance its own political agenda. And I refer you to Commissioner Malmström, who is here for once. At the confirmation hearings, there the Commissioner stated in prepared remarks that trade is a powerful foreign policy tool and that it must support Europe’s wider international goals. The intention is clear: Member States are being forced to barter and – if you can forgive the pun – trade away their sovereignty in order to support the EU’s foreign policy. This is sheer vanity. The EU should not manipulate the trade of the Member States in order to promote the foreign policy pretensions of a wannabe European superstate.  (Applause from some quarters) Now, to the detail, and this is particularly important: in CETA, there is no clause, none, that confers freedom of movement on the citizens of Canada, nor freedom of movement into Canada for citizens of the EU Member States. It is a fact that the European Union has well over 100 trade agreements if you include GSP and GSP+, and all of these it is only the EFTA countries, of which there are four, whose specific form of trade agreement with the EU has a clause that confers freedom of movement. Nevertheless, it is endlessly asserted that any access at all to the EU single market requires freedom of movement. The facts are clear: this is wrong. This is completely untrue. It is erroneous; it is total tosh. And it is a tragedy for the integrity and credibility of our politics that many of those who stand in the way of Brexit persist in putting forward this false fact. That is fake news; that – Labour MEPs in particular, and they know who they are – that is the big lie.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card question. – Do you not agree with me that the whole basis of negotiating a trade agreement would be that you actually put somebody in charge who knows what they are doing. Why have we got a former socialist sociology lecturer from Sweden negotiating on behalf of the UK, which will bind us after Brexit? She’s not qualified to do the job.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – If I may say so, I would point out that, at the hearings, three political groups voted against the confirmation of the present EU Trade Commissioner, and if only the ECR had joined us she probably wouldn’t have happened. As it is, we have somebody who is completely unqualified, and that is the person who the 27 other Member States are unfortunately stuck with.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, let me just say that the Commissioner was approved by Parliament and that is why she is in this position. There is no need to wave, I can see you, sir. Could you just listen? Please sit down. I have made the announcement and I think we can defend the Commissioner’s right to be here. We will now continue with our list of speakers.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am not speaking to the useless members of the European Commission, who are deaf, but I am speaking to the Italian and European citizens who are following us out of this building. Today you are complicit in yet another gift to multinationals and finance. About 200 000 workers will lose their jobs in Europe: factory workers, farmers, small entrepreneurs. Today you choose to bring hormone meat and GMO wheat to our children's tables, perhaps treated with pesticides banned in Europe, after the rice of Burma, the oil of Tunisia, the tomatoes and oranges of Morocco, you, in the name of the advantage of a few, filled the tables with the crap of just as few, moreover allowing the arrival in Europe of all the fake “Made in Italy”, the fake Parma ham, the fake Parmigiano Reggiano, the fake mozzarella. Give your kids that crap! We would like everyone to be able to eat what the land and the sea and the good Lord gave us. Forty thousand jobs in Italy, forty thousand jobs in France: the usual losers will always be the losers, you will win. But I tell you that Brexit, Trump and the elections in Holland, France, Germany, Italy and Austria are showing that the peoples are waking up. So hurry up and get your little friends the last few gifts, because the peoples are coming to get you. Get ready to pack your bags to either Canada or China, which await you with open arms. (The speaker refused to answer a "blue card" question from Hilde Vautmans (Rule 162, paragraph 8, of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President!The arguments of CETA supporters are demagogic, false and false.The arguments of CETA's opponents are demagogic, false and false.Aristotle said democracy was the rule of donkeys led by hyenas.The level of discussions in this Parliament shows that it is much worse.Since the devil is in the details, I am only concerned that this treatise is shrouded in a fog of ambiguity.This is especially true of the most important point of the treaty, namely arbitration.I agree that private arbitration is better than state courts that are prone to corruption and political pressure - I am especially surprised by Polish MPs who do not leave a dry line in Polish courts - but I would be calmer if the treaty stipulated that the super umpires must come from Switzerland, Japan orother countries where honesty still prevails.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: President. –
text: Again, just before I give the floor to the next speaker, we are very tight on time and the vote is long and must begin at 12.00. So I will not take any more blue cards, in order to give colleagues who have indicated that they wish to speak an opportunity to do so at the end of the debate.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the world is watching. Make no mistake: we are going to do a lot more today than just agree on CETA. For one thing, we are going to prove our credibility. With the conclusion of these negotiations we are going to prove that during difficult geopolitical times, when populism triumphs, we can set and support good international trade practices. With this Agreement we show that we are going to set certain rules that can be established for future agreements on trade around the world. If we can agree with Canada, if we can push forward to improve trade relations with Canada, if we can show the positive impact on citizens, on industry and on employment, this Agreement will show that this is the way to go. I believe that is why we should support it, because it is just one step towards reshaping the world in a positive manner.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - Madam President, we must give this debate a bit of perspective and, by the way, respect for divergent positions, less arrogance on the part of some of the spokespersons. The truth is that Europe is at a crossroads, at a very critical moment and is facing a protectionist and hostile challenge, for the first time, from the Trump administration. We face a territorial and political challenge from Russia, an unstoppable rise of China and its model, a neighborhood mired in instability and a rampant national populism in the European institutions themselves. What remains for Europe but to consolidate or try to consolidate a block of common values? And what country can do better, with Europe, than Canada? We don't have as many fellow travelers who share our values ​​in today's world. I do not believe that this Agreement is a panacea for anything or the best possible agreement. It is what we have achieved today. By the way, with many modifications that we have also introduced, the Socialists. It is one more step in a direction that I believe is the right one, although it is by no means our goal. We socialists do not want unchecked globalization, nor do we want to build protectionist walls. Faced with both extremes, we want a world open to exchanges, but with democratic rules, with public control. We want trade to be free, yes, but fair.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I represent the Czech Republic here, a small, export-oriented country. Our trade with Canada amounts to billions of crowns and 60% of our exporters are small and medium-sized enterprises. They are not large corporations. We export engineering products, electrical products, plastic products, rubber products, motor components, optics products, medical products, medical equipment and also food products. All this will, of course, be facilitated, trade in these commodities, if the CETA agreement enters into force, because all surcharges, tariffs, tariffs will gradually fall to zero. So it is quite clear that I will lobby here for this agreement, because it is in the interest of my country, its economy, our employees and employers for the agreement to enter into force, and I think that for once, the European Parliament has a good opportunity to do something. positive, to approve this agreement. I am very much in favor of that.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Madam Commissioner for not giving up, for being determined and, Commissioner, for all your efforts invested in the successful conclusion of this agreement. It is also thanks to you that we can today take this important step and give our clear ‘yes’ to the economic and trade agreement between the EU and Canada, the most comprehensive agreement concluded so far. It will create new business opportunities for EU businesses, especially SMEs. Not only that, it will facilitate access to public tenders at federal, provincial and local level in Canada. It will take care of European geographical indications, including Czech beer.  Madam Commissioner, the EU needs to show now, more than ever, that it has not resigned, unlike some others, on the liberalisation of trade at international level, but not only that, the EU should stand ready to shape it. Instead of closing our borders with protectionism we have to lead by example and make sure that there can be more such agreements with our key trade partners.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a popular clamor surrounds Parliament today, but the deafness of many of you will lead Europeans to believe even less in this institution, giving wings to those who break Europe, those who want to build walls and those who want to resurrect the fascism again. Today, the House of Democracy sells democracy to multinationals. You are blind to our bosses, the citizens. There are more than three million firms, more than two thousand municipalities and regions, unions, judges, NGOs, consumers, farmers, ranchers, public workers, environmentalists and small businessmen who say no! to CETA. Can they not hear them? Who do you listen to? And now I am addressing my fellow socialists, my colleagues from the socialist group, and especially my compatriots from the PSOE, whose own union, the UGT, is asking them to vote against. Do you realize the enormous betrayal that you commit to the workers? With whom is your loyalty today? Are they looking for a seat on a board of directors? Today is a sad day, but democracy will make its way into the States. We are still standing, loud voices, saying no! to the constitution of multinationals, no! to CETA.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!What has happened with CETA in recent years is unworthy of a democracy.The negotiations were secret, not even we as elected MPs were allowed to look at the documents, but the corporate lobbyists played a vigorous role.CETA is peppered with paragraphs that have nothing to do with trade, but with the dismantling of democracy and restrictions on labor law.CETA demands arbitration proceedings that draw billions out of our taxpayers' pockets.Of course, the corporations also want to use the money that we in the communities spend on services of general interest - for schools, waste management, power supply.CETA is further reducing our social system.CETA therefore gives big money more and more power over us.Finally stop working against the citizens, reject CETA!It counts: people before profit.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, I support the CETA agreement on a free trade area between the European Union and Canada.The agreement mainly removes tariffs and barriers to mutual trade, and I think it is great that the European Union will have less money from customs duties and that this money will remain in people's pockets.Our citizens will be able to buy Canadian goods and Canadians goods from the EU cheaper, ie without duties.This will increase people's freedom and living standards by a bit.It is a much better agreement than the infamous TTIP agreement, especially when it comes to arbitration.I am in favor of free international trade and I sincerely assume that an independent United Kingdom will negotiate a very similar agreement with Canada.And if my country, the Czech Republic, was an independent state, I would support having a similar agreement with Canada as well.We may be able to negotiate an even shorter and better agreement, but I support the principle of international free trade.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: - I offer my condolences to the people of Canada and the EU Member States on this agreement.CETA is the next step towards dictatorship and poverty.Dictatorship, because the multinational corporations are in control.Every EU directive and every national law that affects the economy can henceforth be seen as erecting a trade barrier.And poverty, because the multinational companies have their products made in the cheapest countries, cheap in terms of wages and cheap in terms of environmental and working conditions.The advantage of low prices for citizens is being offset by the disappearance of jobs and lower wages.But there is hope.More and more citizens in the EU are seeing through the lies of the established order and are joining the patriots.We represent the people.We fight for their freedom.The end of the EU is approaching and CETA will not reverse its demise.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, faithful to the demands of big international capital, multinationals and the ideology of globalization, you will vote today on a failed trade agreement. In fact, because the Commission knows that the agreement will not be voted on in all national parliaments, it is trying to enforce it through the Trojan Horse of provisional implementation. You are not at all interested in the fact that in this way you will give another blow to small businesses. You do not care that bio-wrestlers will not be able to withstand the attack of multinationals. After all, they do not have lobbyists and huge sums for donations and funding to influence decisions, they do not have the media to constantly propagandize. They only have their vote, no matter how much it bothers you and you wish you could remove it. But it is the people's vote that will make your vote irrelevant today. Fortunately, there will soon be national governments in many European countries and CETA will be just a piece of paper with no power. Only citizens should be patient and try to endure, as long as you implement it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, much is mocked at the alternative facts that the Trump administration uses to evoke its truth. However, they were invented for a long time by NGOs, collectives and extremes, here on CETA. No matter how much you present the facts of the agreement with clear statements, arguments are unfortunately out of place. The French EPP delegation, for its part, sought in detail the guarantees that this agreement, which is good, is also well applied, because that is the essential. But one concern remains: the beef industry is suffering from a crisis and CETA should not amplify it in any way. What guarantees do you provide on the safeguard clauses? The vigilance of the French right will be at its maximum on the reactivity of the Commission in the event of distortion or fall in prices. As such, Canada has planned a $ 350 million aid program to offset the negative effects of CETA on its dairy sector. I would therefore like, Commissioner, on behalf of my delegation to request that such financial arrangements be made available for the European beef sector.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Sure, the CETA agreement is not perfect. But we Social Democrats in particular have taken up the concerns and fears of the people here and fought for improvements. I believe that one has to evaluate this in order to say: this agreement is a step in the direction of shaping globalization. We made sure that private arbitration tribunals are thrown on the rubbish heap of history. We have ensured that services of general interest are secured and that remunicipalisation is not affected by the trade agreement. We have ensured that the universal labor law and the core labor standards of the International Labor Organization are anchored and made enforceable. We have made sure that our precautionary principle is guaranteed, so that no hormone meat and no GMO food come to Europe through this agreement. So, that's a benchmark for all agreements - for future agreements, but also for existing ones. I believe the private arbitration tribunals must also disappear from all other agreements. But I also believe that this agreement is not the end of the story. We must keep fighting for sensible agreements. For example, for improving the feasibility of sustainability, for fighting corruption, for global sustainability goals. That must also be included in future agreements. In the face of a global situation where there is more and more protectionism, where more and more the law of the strong applies, we need stable rules. We cannot abolish globalization. We have to shape globalization fairly.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say this: ‘O Canada’, how long the EU has kept you waiting. After seven long years, the champions of free trade have battled through, and now we are at the final furlong.
