To be clear, CETA is an ambitious, modern and comprehensive trade agreement, which will bring tremendous benefits to the EU as a whole and to each one of the Member States. Once fully implemented, it is expected to increase bilateral trade between the EU and Canada by 23%, representing approximately EUR 26 billion per year. It will lead to the creation of jobs and economic growth, allowing small and medium-size enterprises access to the Canadian market, free of barriers. As a champion of free trade, I welcome this Agreement and look forward to seeing a positive vote in this Chamber today. In times of growing protectionism, the EU must not underestimate the benefits of trade agreements like this, especially when we are negotiating with reliable and strategic partners such as Canada who are, and remain, our allies.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first I should say that Trade Commissioner Cecelia Malmström has done very good and serious work in preparing this Agreement. The EU-Canada Trade Agreement is a good and modern trade agreement that will help boost trade and economic activity, and it has many advantages which have all been listed many times here already, including opening markets to goods, benefiting SMEs and opening up their procurement market. It also allows us to promote and protect our shared values. CETA will help create jobs and economic growth which is very much needed.  But this deal also has more significant value. It is the most elaborate deal with a successful OECD country, and in coming to an agreement with Canada we show that this kind of agreement can be done, and this is a very important message. It is also an important deal geopolitically. The EU and Canada must strengthen and hold their alliance in this changing, unstable environment. CETA is a good indication that where there is a will, there is a way.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, those of us who vote for this treaty will bear a heavy responsibility for jobs, the environment, social progress, agriculture and food. They will help to lock the people into a real straitjacket. Indeed, how can we agree to apply such a harmful agreement on a temporary basis without the approval of national parliaments? How can we accept a so-called regulatory cooperation mechanism, which will adapt national and European legislation a priori, that is to say even before their development by parliaments? And to lock the whole thing, arbitral tribunals will condemn states and peoples if they do not obey the orders of multinationals. Our Parliament would grow to say "no" to the constitutionalization of business law against human rights, "no" to this institutional coup in the service of industrial and financial powers!

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: - Madam President!CETA is now about to vote.Unfortunately, the result already seems to be certain.Why else would the Canadian Prime Minister be anchored on the agenda today?And ultimately, our points of criticism remain in the text of the contract, such as arbitration tribunals as parallel justice, such as the so-called joint committees, which undermine our national parliamentary opinion-forming, such as the abolition of the precautionary principle, which harms consumer protection in Europe, and howthe enormous import quotas at low prices that will destroy our agriculture.I say clearly yes to trade, but no to the dismantling of national parliamentary powers, no to circumventing democratic jurisdiction and no to the incapacitation of citizens in Europe.CETA is and will remain a Trojan horse that will threaten and dramatically violate European values.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much for your work: you have the full support of our political group. In these times of uncertainty, it is important that the European Union gives a clear signal that it is committed to openness, to strengthen ties with our partners, to international trade, and what better sign than the ratification of the Agreement with Canada. Together we can lay the foundations for the international trade of the future, a trade based on our principles and values ​​that respects the high standards that both regions share. CETA is a modern, ambitious and balanced agreement, and it would be desirable if it could serve as a model for other trade agreements. The future of the European Union depends on foreign trade, on which a large part of our economic growth and job creation depends. This Agreement is good for Europe, for SMEs, and it is good for the present and the future of European citizens. Those who are against CETA are in favor of Trump's policies.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, even when I disagree with them, I normally understand where my colleagues in the Greens and my friends on the left are coming from, but frankly in relation to CETA I just do not get it.  CETA creates employment opportunities. CETA protects public services, no forced privatisation, no ratchet clause. CETA defends our right to regulate, so no Frankenstein foods in our market, no threat to food safety. It contains an ambitious Labour Chapter. It commits our partners to multilateral environment agreements at a time when Trump threatens the Paris Accord, a vital thing. It kills investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) and replaces it with a modern, fair system of investment protection.  So what is it beyond the rhetoric, beyond the words that this is good for corporations, what is it in CETA that they really object to, because I do not hear it? I hear a lot of words, but I hear no substance in their objection to CETA, and that is what they should be standing up for. We live in a world that faces real dangers of protectionism. With this progressive deal, Canada and the EU are not only keeping markets open, they are keeping those markets open on the basis of common values, and that is something we should applaud.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: - Madam President!I have followed the debate here carefully and have noticed a bizarre coalition: the Greens, Marine Le Pen and GUE are of one mind on CETA.When Mr Jadot delivered his speech, there was frenetic applause from the Marine Le Pen coalition. That is the reality that is here.And we know from history: these are the people who have always opposed openness and free trade.We know that, and we have seen it confirmed here.And then Mr. Jadot attacks Trump sharply with the same arguments that Mr. Trump takes.So he attacks Trump, but plays Trump's card.One should realize that once.My aim is for the enemies of free trade and the friends of protectionism to make their arguments clear to themselves and to explain them themselves.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to begin by congratulating Commissioner Malmström for the extraordinary patience, remarkable competence and availability, above all, which she has shown in dealing, often with excesses and untruths. Because, finally, will CETA force us to eat chlorinated chicken, beef with hormones, GMOs or even to dismantle our public services? Of course not! What is not possible today will not be possible tomorrow. We will remain free to further strengthen our quality standards and develop our public services. Are we giving multinationals an inordinate weight that will harm our legal system? Of course not! The drive to establish a new international court only strengthens our ability to enforce the rules globally and inspire tougher ones if we so choose. Colleagues, if we cannot sign an agreement with Canada, with whom, then, can we still sign one? Who can sincerely believe that a country of 35 million inhabitants, whose democratic performances and social and environmental protections often exceed the criteria of many European states, could deviate the economic, social and political model of the world's leading economic power? ? Those who oppose this agreement and abuse the good faith of citizens deny the social, human and economic progress of free trade, that is the truth. In fact, it is an ideological blockage, nothing more!

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it would be a good joke if it were not a tragedy. It would be a good joke to say that CETA is the progressive response to Trump's protectionism and right-wing populism. You place another form of protectionism as an alternative to Trump's protectionism. Protect the right to profit, establish an unequal right that protects multinationals, protects profit, investments and multinationals before people. We too have a form of protectionism. We want to protect work, the environment, food health, citizens and small towns of Europe. We want to protect democracy. You say that CETA will create jobs. Too bad that studies have shown that 230,000 jobs will be lost, of which 200,000 in Europe alone. Trudeau the environmentalist who gave his green light to the Keystone pipeline in the United States, applauding the infamous Trump. Trudeau who is about to export to Europe the oil extracted from the tar sands and shales that the directive invited us to cut. I want to say one last thing: the Socialists had announced the end of the grand coalition. Today they show us that the grand coalition continues. We remain in coalition with the citizens ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: President. –
text: I hate to say this, but your last words were wasted and, with respect, I did give you extra time. I am trying to be fair to everybody and I need to be strict. I would just like to advise colleagues who have come into the Chamber that we announced earlier that there will be no further blue cards. That is for the information of colleagues who have joined us.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that in a responsible and serious way we must say that today we are discussing a good free trade agreement and we are also finally discussing a European trade policy perspective, a Europe that exists, a Europe which constitutes a model, a point of reference, which realizes the possibility of making it clear that we must be able to overcome challenges if we prepare ourselves for challenges. I mean that this free trade offers the opportunity to come out of the stalemate of the Italian, French, Spanish and European markets, which are in total stalemate. The International Monetary Fund says 90% can be achieved as a development outside Europe's borders. So I believe that the study seriously goes in the direction of understanding how and in what way the internationalization process of our small and medium-sized enterprise, with an adequate size, with an appropriate credit access and with the possibility of manageriality, should be carried out for confront and to achieve these goals. Time is short and of course we as the Italian delegation support this agreement.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Despite all the different opinions on CETA, we should jointly consider our agreement on strategic partnership positively. That is more important than ever: bilateral cooperation in the areas of cultural, foreign and security policy, the fight against terrorism and organized crime, economy and tourism. There will be a joint cooperation committee and regular consultations in the future, and we very much welcome that. It is about common values: freedom and democracy, tolerance and the rule of law, and a clear common position against exclusion and for equal cooperation. I don't have the impression that these values ​​are increasing rapidly at the moment. It is all the more important that we work with friends who stand by these values. Perhaps it has been the case with us in the past that whenever we looked across the pond, we didn't really see the Canadians because such a large United States of America was in between. No, it is time - even after the latest developments - that we get up, then you can overlook some things and you see your true friends. I look forward to this better collaboration with our friends in Canada.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: - Madam President!Polish-Canadian relations are strategic, not cyclical, confirmed by the repeated struggle for our freedom.CETA is not a perfect contract.Besides, there are no perfect contracts.Although her chances were well described by the Czech MP Jan Zahradil.However, he saw this agreement as an additional element of our security architecture.Transatlantic relations strengthen Poland, also in the intra-European system.

name: Sylvie Goulard (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, we must listen to the concerns of the people, but neither should we follow all the anxieties when determining a policy. I wanted to say that Mrs Malmström and the Commission are acting within the framework of powers which have been conferred on them in the Treaties democratically. The national parliaments have accepted that commercial competences are exclusively exercised at European level. There were no tricks, there was debate in all of our countries when we made this decision. I trust not only the Commissioner, but also the Commission, in the future, too, to exercise all the safeguarding duties that will be necessary. Canada, which I want to salute, is a democratic country with rules. It is one of our allies and - I draw the attention of the French to this point - it is also a country which is partly French-speaking and towards which we must show a certain solidarity. France is a country which has great difficulties in terms of foreign trade. We have a deficit of 48 billion euros for the year 2016, so opportunities with a safe country, legally close to us, are always good to take under supervised conditions. We are counting on you to ensure that they are respected, Commissioner.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, this agreement is bad for France and bad for Europe. It is an aggravating contribution to the ecological and social crisis of human civilization, because it does not include the slightest mention of the Paris climate treaty, it encourages the importation of the dirtiest fossil fuels in the world, that it encourages the most brutal, the most cruel and the most unfair agriculture, and that it establishes special courts which allow the big companies to be against the laws of the people, but at the same time it accepts social dumping from a country that has not signed the International Labor Organization bargaining convention. This text could never have been adopted or even negotiated if my homeland had opposed it, and the government of my country bears a special responsibility at this time. Just as here, in this assembly, this agreement would not be accepted if the Social Democratic Group did not give its support. It is ultimately a very bad blow against Europe and against my homeland that will be committed. Future generations will remember this - I want to believe it - at least in the 2017 French presidential election.

name: Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! As Vice-Chair of the Delegation for Relations with Canada, I have followed CETA from the start of the negotiations. After many talks on both sides of the Atlantic, it is high time to cross the finish line and I am confident that we will do our part today. CETA is intended for the future. It's not just for now and for us. We have to position ourselves: as the European Union, as Europeans in a changing world. We want to shape this change, and there is not much else left than to finally act. This is a sign that we can. However, we shouldn't pretend that investment arbitration courts don't yet exist. No, they already exist. Let's not close our eyes to reality: CETA will improve this system. I welcome that. Finally, in this political situation, I am very surprised that right and left use exactly the same arguments and then believe that they are both right.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union and Canada have maintained very good trade and political relations for almost forty years. These must also be deepened in areas not only of business but also of security, climate protection or the environment. From this point of view, the strategic partnership agreement is certainly a benefit for both parties. However, we must not forget that Canada will always have above-standard relations with, for example, the United States or the countries of the former British Commonwealth. It is not possible to abandon the pragmatic approach to negotiating international agreements under the influence of Brexit and Donald Trump's victory. The current Canadian representation may be close to us in value and may be sympathetic to us. On the other hand, we cannot build our relations on it, it is not possible to approach TTIP and CETA with a double meter. Both agreements are badly negotiated and we must have the courage to look for a new version of this trade agreement and to reject this proposal.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: - Madam President! We're talking about CETA today. However, some are using this to wage a proxy war against the consequences of globalization. That is a shame, because CETA is an excellently negotiated trade agreement between two partners who share the same values. In this respect, it is extremely unfair to attach the consequences of globalization, which can actually be viewed critically and where one can also consider how to mitigate them, to the CETA procedure. Globalization is happening whether we want it or not. So we have to shape it as best we can. In my opinion, this is the case with CETA. I would particularly like to thank our Canadian friends very much for their willingness to reopen the negotiations for one part, namely the area of ​​international commercial arbitration courts, even after the negotiations were concluded. That wasn't a given. And as chairman of the EU-Canada delegation, I am particularly grateful for that.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we need to protect European industries and European farmers and to support and protect our SMEs, start-ups and exporters. We also need to protect and promote our service industries, innovation and European IPR. I believe that there is a broad consensus on this both inside and outside this House.  But how can we achieve this? Is protectionism the best protection that we can provide? The history of the global economy and trade in the last hundred years teaches us that protectionism is a poor tool. The cost of protectionist measures has always turned out to be higher than the short—term gain of such measures. The best we can do for European industries, SMEs and farmers is to actively promote their interests. Today that means providing for a fair, modern, 21st century trade agreement with a like—minded partner. Today that means approving CETA.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am of the opinion that free trade agreements should actually be placed at the service of broader objectives, such as employment, human rights, cohesion and sustainable development. I wonder if we can say that CETA responds to these different objectives and I really confess that I have great difficulty in answering this question positively. Second consideration: there seems to be a prevailing opinion in this Parliament that believes that this agreement could become a reference model for the next generation of agreements. I think otherwise and I don't think CETA can be the beginning of a new course. Finally, I want to remind you, Commissioner, that the risks of a return to protectionism and trade wars are not fought by a critical promotion of trade and investment liberalization and deregulation, as you imagine, but by radically changing the approach so far. followed, and that's what we really need to do with voting too.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, CETA has been many years in the making and we are now at the final stage. Canada is a country very similar to ourselves. If we cannot do a trade deal with Canada, who can we do a trade deal with? There are many historical ties between my constituency of Northern Ireland, and Canada, and we have significant economic ties today. For instance the Canadian company Bombardier has operations in Northern Ireland and I hope that once this deal is in place it will strengthen and deepen those ties.  We all know that any trade deal is not perfect and CETA comes with positives and also negatives, we are well aware of that. When the United Kingdom eventually leaves the European Union and embarks on its own trade policy, I hope it takes a balanced approach. The government seems to believe at the moment that we can do deals quickly. I believe quick deals are bad deals for the people. Throughout discussions on CETA, TTIP and Mercosur, I have repeatedly made the point that the European Union must not use agriculture as a bargaining chip, and I will continue to make that case as the United Kingdom embarks on its own bilateral trading relationships.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: - Madam President, CETA is an interesting and balanced agreement. It represents many opportunities for our companies. We have heard the concerns of citizens and that is why we will be monitoring the implementation of the agreement very closely if it is ratified. The Commission will have to respect its commitments and declarations. Safeguard clauses should be triggered immediately in the event of a difficulty in a sector and, in this regard, particular attention should be paid to the agricultural sector. Commissioner, the concerns expressed reflect a growing distrust of the Union's trade policy and must be answered. We must develop maximum transparency around the negotiations. At a time when Donald Trump in the United States has opted for protectionism, we must strengthen our ties with partners who, like Canada, share our values. Finally, I regret that Ms. Le Pen brought up the vote in the Republican MPs committee because she seems to forget that, that day, she was absent and that she did not vote.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner Malmström! We politicians have a simple duty to always strive for better standards, for better protection of workers, the environment, the climate and public health. We must always put people's well-being above the considerations of profit. These are principles, values ​​and attitudes that, for me, are absolutely essential. And so it must be! In the CETA agreement, we have for the first time seriously written these guarantees, yes these values ​​directly into a trade agreement. Together with Canada, we are opening a new chapter for fair and sustainable trade. We are putting the rightly hated ISDS mechanism in the grave, and we are stating with seven-inch nails that companies cannot sue countries because they are losing revenue because of stricter, new national or European rules. Only the people's democratic, elected representatives must make laws, and they must be able to do so freely. That is one of the reasons why, as a Social Democrat, I support the CETA agreement and hope that it will be adopted later today. Thanks for the word.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: - Madam President! After seven years, we are finally here, but I feel divided. I'm glad we're allowed to approve the agreement, but I'm sad that it's so tight inside, that so many extremists here and elsewhere have devoted so much time and energy to trying to stop a cooperation and trade agreement with Canada; that with lies or "alternative facts", as they may be called nowadays, one has tried to kidnap this agreement in order to instead pursue one's own agenda on the right and left of nationalism and socialism. Because this is where you see that they are children of the same spirit. It is when it comes to defending protectionism and setting boundaries that right-wing extremists and left-wing extremists meet. But this is a good deal. It's a very good deal. It removes 99 percent of all tariffs, it creates jobs in the more than 900,000 companies that depend on trade with Canada, and indirectly it creates jobs across Europe. But it's not just about Canada. It's about our credibility on the international stage. If we can not even conclude an agreement with Canada, then we will abandon our ability to influence world trade. Europe cannot afford it, the world cannot afford it and that is why we must vote yes today.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: - Madam President, we are going to decide today which international trade model the European Union defends, if Trump's protectionism, "America first", or the principles and values ​​first through a trade policy that sets rules for globalization to be fairer. A trade policy that is not limited only to removing trade barriers, but to guaranteeing and promoting the social, labor and environmental standards of the European Union in the rest of the world. CETA is not a perfect agreement. No agreement is. There is always room for improvement, and that is our role, but with CETA, thanks to the work of many - also, of course, our Group - we have taken important steps in terms of transparency, sustainable development, participation of the civil society and defense of our welfare state and public services. CETA is an opportunity, because with this Agreement we commit ourselves with our Canadian partners to move towards a more just and supportive globalization. And I tell my Spanish GUE colleagues that being on the left is not being protectionist or nationalist. If they believe that, they are outnumbered by Donald Trump, Marine Le Pen and their anti-European colleagues on the far-right caucus on the left.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - Today we are ratifying a very important agreement that the European Union so desperately needs, the most modern agreement in the history of the European Union, an agreement reached between two democracies, the European Union and Canada, our agreement with Canada, which shares the same values.than human rights in any of our other partner countries with which we have free trade agreements.Criticism of how public services are regulated in this agreement is completely unreasonable (I am talking about education, health and the environment).I have no doubt that, once the agreement enters into force, the citizens, workers and companies of the European Union will soon feel the benefits, as was the case with the agreement between the European Union and Korea.Lithuanian exporters will also benefit.I support this agreement.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the cartoon that there are only two schools of international trade - the school of protectionism, advocated by populists, and the school of ultra-liberalism, shared by a large majority of this Parliament - is unbearable. I would even say that this bipolar conception is suicidal for Europe today. Europe is capable of doing better, Europe deserves better. At a time when everyone is wondering about their future and when the breakdown of confidence in the political and economic systems is at its height, we in this assembly are going to sign an agreement. We are going to vote for a “business as usual” agreement; an agreement that gives more rights to multinationals; an agreement that weakens public services, farmers, SMEs and the least exporting countries; an agreement that places investor rights above social and environmental rights; a deal that is not a next-gen deal, but a deal from the past. This is the reason why I will vote against.

name: Viviane Reding (PPE).
text: - Madam President, dear colleagues, we hear everything and its opposite on CETA. I would like to get back to the facts for a moment, because voting for CETA means guaranteeing reciprocity, supporting our SMEs, promoting quality products, protecting consumers and defending our artists. To vote against is to perpetuate private justice and refuse high international standards in social, environmental and agrifood matters. Voting for CETA means setting the benchmark for future international agreements and regulating globalization in perfect harmony with our values ​​and interests. To vote against is to agree to the lack of reciprocity and the absence of rules. Voting for CETA means protecting and sharing values, concretizing standards and creating jobs. This is why I am voting for CETA, in order to assert Europe's leadership and to endorse an agreement which is in the interest of citizens and businesses, and which solidifies our values ​​and our democratic systems. .

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, CETA is at odds with principles and standards that I believe are absolutely non-negotiable, from the approach to food safety to measures on endocrine disruptors, from the commitments to achieve climate and energy targets at maximum levels for pesticide residues , from the arbitration mechanism to the spaces for private intervention in public services, from the risk of entry of GMO products to the protection of quality productions. In Europe we have 1 300 food products with geographical indication, 2 800 wines and 330 spirits. Of these, CETA will only protect 173. Many denominations of origin, therefore, which we are used to considering indicative of quality products, with a strong link to the territory, will not be protected overseas. It is really a pity that CETA has not marked a break and that Europe has not oriented the negotiations towards greater protection of consumer rights, the precautionary principle and environmental protection clauses. I will vote against it because CETA does not bring any benefit to European citizens.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this Agreement with Canada comes at a very particular time on our calendar, when the first priority of the European Union's trade policy, which was the Agreement with the United States, has fallen. The European Union is the world's main export bloc of goods; It is the main export bloc in the world of services; main investor and recipient of foreign direct investment, and one of the main importing blocks. Contrary to what has been said, this Agreement is a decisive step in the right direction and it is a balanced and fair agreement that will benefit the interests of our citizens, creating prosperity and employment. I would therefore like to congratulate the Commission on this negotiation and, although I wish it could have been concluded in a shorter period of time - seven years is too long - I believe that this Agreement is going to mark a milestone. And therefore I would encourage the Commission, within the remaining term of its mandate before the end of this Juncker Commission, to conclude the pending agreements, and I would like to cite, among a few, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and, of course, Mercosur.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the trade agreement with Canada is of strategic importance for the European Union, especially after Trump, and is the necessary response against the dangerous illusion of isolation and protectionism. This is also a good agreement, an economically balanced agreement, which illuminates tariffs and allows access to the market, and is a new reference for international trade, a progressive agreement for a more regulated globalization. Today, we can say that we have listened to citizens and that this agreement, under pressure from this Parliament and civil society, respects the European Union's environmental and social values, our right to regulate in the public interest. It was under pressure from this Parliament and the socialist group that the private arbitration system was replaced by a new system of public arbitration and it is because this agreement has been improved that its final version deserves the confidence of the citizens and deserves the favorable vote of this European Parliament.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Madam President!Some here say cynically to us, to the supporters of CETA: "You are showing how you defend the citizens of Europe."I will say to this: "You show how cynically you lie to the citizens of Europe, because you present lies and tell nonsense here."To those who say, "We are against CETA because it is the people that counts," I will say, "We are for the CETA because the people matter."CETA is a bridge across the Atlantic connecting friends to work together for a good future.Lower prices, higher quality, security of citizens, protection of democracy, protection of human and labor rights, as well as protection of the environment and climate - this is CETA.These are the values you want to defend here, and at the same time you are against CETA.You have to make up your mind.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the further we advance in this debate on CETA, the more I have the impression that we are in fact discussing an Old World agreement, because, unlike many colleagues, I believe that CETA is not is not at all a model for the future. First, he misses all the great successes of multilateral diplomacy of recent years: the COP 21 on climate, the G20 agreement on tax evasion, he does not talk about it. Above all, to the great challenges of today - climate change, growing inequalities, democratic mistrust - CETA only opposes backward-looking responses. Always more liberalization, always less public services, always more competition, always more power for multinationals ... the moment: "Europe deserves better." Colleagues, some are telling us today that it's either Donald Trump and Marine Le Pen, on the one hand, or CETA, on the other - frankly, we could steer clear of that type of caricature. I think Europe deserves better, it can do better, and fortunately we have tremendous foothold, as evidenced by the mobilization of civil society and the resistance of some governments. So we can go ahead and imagine another trade policy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this agreement, which started in 2009 and concluded in 2014, is, in our opinion, quite complete, modern, transparent, also looking to the future. We believe that, from now on, it will bring benefits to companies, workers and consumers. In addition to eliminating 98% of customs duties, this agreement also provides for the safeguarding of public services, audiovisuals, transport and the most sensitive agricultural products. With this agreement, 143 European geographical indications are guaranteed to be protected, 20 of which are Portuguese. Also important, in our opinion, is the mutual recognition of certification for many products, as well as the recognition of a wide range of professions, from engineers to architects or lawyers, the maintenance of high standards in environmental, food safety, health and consumer rights, always respecting compliance with European rules and regulations is also an aspect we like to highlight. I am sure that the European Union will benefit from this agreement and my country will be no exception, as Portugal currently has over a thousand companies to export to Canada, 89% of which are small and medium-sized companies that provide 12 thousand jobs. That is why I am voting in favor of CETA.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! CETA is not the work of the devil, as many critics are wrong. But CETA is a treaty that was negotiated in a non-transparent manner and which, in my opinion, does not give the right answers to globalization. We have heard the question several times today: How can we make globalization fair? CETA in its present form does not contribute to this. Therefore I cannot agree to CETA. CETA is still not good enough. Well, what does CETA teach us? In any case, that we have to do it differently in the future. Perhaps it would be good to come back to classic trade agreements and regulate regulatory cooperation in sector-specific agreements. However, it is essential to allow the national parliaments, civil society, NGOs and the European Parliament to participate in the negotiations from the start and to provide regular information during the negotiations, to take the concerns seriously, to respect the attitude of the citizens and to participate to be included. Only in this way can European trade policy regain its legitimacy. What went wrong at CETA must not be repeated!

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!We are currently experiencing an argument between taking responsibility and fomenting fears, between regulating globalization and isolating ourselves, between shaping the future and wasting opportunities, between evaluating the negotiation result and fake news, between serious factual debates and an insincere party-tactical double game.I am glad that the majority of MEPs from the European People's Party, the Liberals, the Conservatives and also the Social Democrats take people's concerns seriously and, after an intense debate, decided to vote in favor of the trade agreement because we checked the result and becauseThe concerns and questions of the people in this agreement will be answered on the basis of the community of rights and values of the European Union.Who isolates himself loses.We design.We want to take the chance!

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the agreement is in the interests of European citizens and businesses. It means growth and new jobs without compromising European standards in any area, despite the relentless lies we have heard today from some of our colleagues. The Bulgarian economy depends on exports of goods and services, which is about 80 percent of gross domestic product. It needs foreign direct investment and free access to third country markets. Therefore, Bulgaria, as well as the European Union as a whole, will benefit from the agreement, from visa-free travel, from easier recognition of professional qualifications and better access to the labor market, from lower costs for exporters, from opportunities for Bulgarian companies to participate in public procurement tenders and the opening of the Canadian market. The agreement is not to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises, but to their advantage. The big ones can operate globally even without the agreement. For months, we have been flooded with apocalyptic scenarios: the agreement will flood Europe with GMOs, enslave European nations, lead to economic collapse. When the agreement comes into force, it will become clear how flat these lies were. It is much easier to succumb to populism, but it is more responsible to explain to citizens the benefits of this agreement.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the EU was founded 60 years ago on the principles of four freedoms. Our rapporteur, Mr Pabriks, told us today that the EU has a choice between future openness or protective and angry closing into ourselves. Also, some time ago, Pope Francis spoke to the European Parliament of his impression of a wary and ageing Europe, reminding us of a grandmother, hesitant and defensive, but now also believing in political horror stories. Only opening up will bring wide-ranging success and well-being to the citizens of Europe. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) constitutes a key means of rejuvenating the EU’s dynamics because every additional billion of EU exports supports 14 000 jobs in Europe. It is, in fact, a crucial test of the EU’s credibility, self-respect and reaffirmation of our founding principles of four freedoms. Commissioner Malmström, tack så mycket for your dedication, faith and persistence.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Madam President, is it in order for Members to absent themselves from the debates and leave big placards rather than actually take part in the debate?

name: President. –
text: I do not have the Rules of Procedure, but we take note of your comment.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I want to express my support for CETA and the Strategic Association Agreement with Canada. We share many values ​​and objectives with this country. They are also our partners in NATO and we cooperate closely to address global challenges such as climate change. We are also committed to multilateralism and respect for international law. The Strategic Partnership Agreement will enhance our dialogue and coordination. The CETA agreement is the most modern free trade agreement, as already mentioned, that the European Union has negotiated. It will allow our companies better access to the Canadian market with high purchasing power. In addition to an innovative system for the resolution of conflicts between investors and States, CETA establishes a wide openness in public procurement, which I think is very important, since it will allow European companies to participate in public contracts also at the provincial and provincial level. municipalities in Canada. It is the broadest agreement opened in this matter by this country. CETA will stimulate economic and commercial relations with Canada. In today's world you cannot be against international trade. On the contrary, trade brings prosperity, benefits consumers, and also creates much-needed jobs in Europe.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! The CETA opponents tried to convince us that Canada, with its 36 million inhabitants, is an existential threat to the European Union. A country where the Queen is the head of state, where French is spoken, the state pays for the medicines, where there is a social-liberal government that generously accepts refugees. What a nonsense. If we Europeans fail to conclude an agreement with this country, we can end all other negotiations immediately. I want to make it clear here: I also read the open letter from the Greens, from Reinhard Bütikofer and his colleagues. I think it's both ahistorical and hypocritical to say: Right-wing isolation á la Marine Le Pen or Donald Trump is bad, left-wing isolation á la ATTAC or Verdi is great. Right nationalism à la UKIP is bad, left nationalism à la Jean-Luc Mélenchon is good. There is also no difference between right-wing alternative facts from Donald Trump and left-wing alternative facts from the Left Party and others. Both are lies. Let's agree to this agreement! A cosmopolitan attitude means building bridges across the Atlantic, not building walls. (Applause)

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I will be voting for CETA today.I come from a region with strong exports, from the state of Hesse, that is Frankfurt and the surrounding area.We have a keen interest in seeing trade with Canada improve as well, especially for the small and medium-sized enterprises that have previously had a difficult time gaining a foothold in this country.I am always surprised at the strange constellations that can be found against this agreement.In Germany that is from Sahra Wagenknecht to the AfD chairman, from Donald Trump to Mélenchon, from Marine Le Pen to some German Social Democrats, which I very much regret.I therefore hope that with this agreement we will set an example for a new generation of progressive free trade agreements which can also serve as models for future agreements.I therefore warmly ask everyone to approve this agreement.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as a member of the Committee on International Trade, and of the Delegation for relations with Canada in the last mandate, I have been following this agreement all that time. I must say I am somewhat amazed at the alternative facts which are now in vogue in this establishment and around the world. You could say this is the age of alternative facts.  One of them, which has been flying around my Twitter feed over the last few days, says CETA will put 90 million jobs at risk. That is nearly half the jobs in the European Union and this from a country, Canada, which has only 35 million people itself. These are the facts being perpetrated and which the people out there protesting today believe.  If I thought it was going to cost 90 million jobs I would be against it too. In actual fact, it is the opposite. We are in favour of it because it is going to create jobs. It is going to create jobs in Europe, in Ireland, and that is what we want. The agreement with South Korea created 210 000 jobs, and yet the Canadian agreement is going to cost us jobs? Is this logical? No.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this is a historic moment for the European Union, because it is the first free trade agreement that the European Union has with another major OECD economy. Personally, I believe in the need for trade agreements with other non-European countries, but obviously on a win-win basis. The internal market needs to grow, to internationalize its business, especially SMEs. Always, when you make a deal, you have to think about what you lose and what you gain. You can't claim to win alone. That is why I support trade agreements, at the same time as trade defense measures - and that is the duty of the Commission. My fears at the beginning of the negotiations have been dispelled, those related to product standards and the legal mechanism. In the end, we have to make an economic decision, but also a political one, and we must always know how to choose the best option, because the ideal solution does not exist. So I think we have a duty to support the development of the internal market through good trade agreements, not to close the internal market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, unnecessary dust has been raised around CETA, and left-wing extreme parties and non-governmental organizations have deliberately tied it to TTIP in order to cause public confusion.At its core, CETA is a much more transparent and benevolent agreement, which opens up a rich market for European companies that does not pose any threat to Europe.There is no black script.There will be problems, of course, but don't we have problems in the European Union between the member states?Of course, we are solving these problems through new negotiations, and we can solve them with Canada through a system of disputes.Colleagues, if we are not able to make an agreement with a benign Canada, then who are we with?Free trade between Europe and Canada is an opportunity for both sides.For Croatia, this is an opportunity to connect even better economically with its diaspora in Canada, and I believe that we will be brave and take this opportunity.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, thank you and your team for the great work you have done. We are going to support CETA because it favors SMEs, which are the main job creators in the European Union; because it opens up new exchange opportunities in sectors in which we are world leaders in quality and technology, including high-quality primary productions —which can only reinforce this position—; and because we share with Canada values ​​and principles that are going to be reinforced, growing with an Agreement that makes them more present and stronger in world trade. This is the best answer to other social or environmental standards that, without agreements like this, find it easier to prosper. During this legislature, the European Commission's trade team has shown knowledge, real capacity to evolve realities hitherto immobile - such as the arbitration system - and social sensitivity and dialogue capacity. Opportunities like the ones this Agreement opens up are always much more than a no.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I am here to represent the people and I would imagine most of us are here to represent the people. The problem is that the person who went out and negotiated this agreement has said that she does not take her mandate from the people. What sort of a democracy is this, where we send someone out to negotiate on our behalf and she brazenly says to us that she does not take her mandate from the people? I suppose she is being honest, unlike a lot of the other Commissioners. The Committee on Employment and Social Affairs is against this agreement because it will cost 204 000 jobs, and if Mr Kelly, MEP, thinks this is an alternative fact let him go into the Employment Committee and call them liars. The great irony, though, is that the man who casts doubt on the unemployment that will be occurring actually comes from a party with a leader who is openly a liar, and I can say that because it is official.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would vote in favour of CETA if I could judge that the balance of interests is correct, but I do not think so. I think it weighs heavily on the side of enterprises and investors but, having said this, I look very much forward to working with the Commissioner on the new trade agreements where this balance will be set right.  I welcome, Commissioner, your suggestion on broad consultation on how to embed sustainable development in a legally binding way in the Treaties. I also believe that Parliament has to support you when you call for the Council to publish negotiation mandates at an early stage in the future, because that would be the right way to proceed from now on.  At this moment we are dealing with the CETA Agreement and let me say that, even if Canada is a very nice country and Trudeau is a very nice guy, some Canadian mining companies are not best known for their responsibility and accountability, and this may be felt even in my country, Finland.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, carnivals go by but certain masks remain. The masks of hypocrisy of those who pass off CETA as a simple and banal agreement with laughing Canada, based on common principles and values, a cornerstone of sustainable trade. Take off the mask and tell the truth. The truth about the fake abolition of the ISDS, about the conflicts of interest of the arbitration courts, about our constitutional rights trampled in favor of multinationals. The truth about wild privatizations and liberalizations of water, health and public services. The truth about 230,000 European workers whose jobs and dignity you sold off for thirty pieces of money. We spokespersons of the 5 Star Movement have chosen which side to be on: on the side of those who do not want to be consumed by consumerism, on the side of those who defend the rights of all against the profit of a few, on the side of three and a half million citizens' signatures Europeans. No to the Trojan horse and TTIP, no to CETA!

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of this House, it has indeed been a very long and interesting debate. We are here discussing a trade agreement. Trade has made the European Union the biggest economy of the world. It has benefited the prosperity and welfare of Europeans. Trade with other countries outside the European Union has created millions of jobs, 31 million in the export sectors and many, many millions in the import sectors. Countries are queuing up to make trade agreements with us but they are, of course, looking very carefully at what is going to happen today, whether we are a reliable partner or not. Trade globally has lifted millions and millions of people out of poverty, so trade is a good thing, but of course trade needs to be regulated in trade agreements and that is what we are discussing here today.  This is not business as usual; this is a new type of trade agreement. It has economic advantages: we are taking away tariffs, we are increasing market access, we have achieved the recognition of many important geographical indications, we are taking away red tape and this is beneficial. After all, most small and medium-sized companies – 80% of the 70 000 companies who today export to Canada are SMEs – have smaller margins than the big companies because the latter can always manage. SMEs benefit from lower tariffs, from increased market access, from less red tape. We are taking away tariffs, for instance on textiles of 18%, on shoes of up to 18%, on machinery of 9%. These are not small sums for small companies, and many of them are also involved in exporting geographical indications. We know that trade works. The trade agreement with South Korea has increased exports by impressive figures and created many jobs.  This is also an agreement about values, about the right of governments to regulate, about maintaining our high standards, about labour rights, about environmental rights, about sustainable development, about reforming the old ISDS system – because it was not invented in CETA, it has existed since 1959, it was invented in Germany. All countries, except Ireland, have ISDS clauses. We have made them more democratic, more transparent and introduced a more ethical system. You, here in the European Parliament, have been very active in that transformation. (The President interrupted the speaker to call for less noise in the House)  J’allais juste répondre aux collègues français qui ont exprimé leurs inquiétudes par rapport au secteur bovin. J’ai discuté avec le commissaire Hogan et M. le Président Juncker, et nous allons vous adresser une lettre pour répondre plus en détail à vos questions. Je peux vous affirmer qu’en ce qui concerne l’accord avec le Canada, celui-ci a été bien conçu, en tenant compte de la sensibilité de ce secteur. Je reste convaincue que les importations n’auront pas un effet dramatique sur le secteur. Les services de la Commission assureront le suivi régulier des importations en question, y compris le taux de remplissage des contingents, en utilisant tous les instruments dont nous disposons afin d’être en mesure de réagir avec efficacité et rapidité en cas de distorsion. Vous aurez plus de détails dans une lettre à la fin de cette semaine. Actually, honourable Members of this House, for years many of you have been calling for trade agreements which include sustainable development, human rights, labour rights, environment, climate, animal rights. All this is in this unique agreement, but it does not include anything which forces any municipality, country or region to implement privatisation. It will not lower standards, and it will not deprive the governments of their right to regulate in the interests of their citizens. Things that are forbidden on the European market today will remain forbidden, and the Joint Committee will not change anything in our legislation. That is for the EU institutions, including you, to do.  We are making this agreement with Canada, and I would like to salute the presence of the Minister of International Trade, Mr Champagne, who is in the Tribune here today. Canada is a democratic country which shares so many of our values, which is committed to the rule of law, to human rights, and which plays an important international role in defending the multilateral system. They have a strong public sector and they are committed to working with us to shape globalisation.  (Interruption by the President)

name: President. –
text: Sorry, Commissioner, please take a breath for one moment. I am not going to resume this debate until we have some semblance of order and silence because the Commissioner is responding in detail to questions raised during the debate. Please bear with us. We have two more speakers and then we vote. Commissioner, again, apologies for the interruption.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Canada is committed, in the framework of CETA and of our partnership agreement, to working with us on all the issues that you have mentioned, shaping globalisation to set strong international rules, faithfully respecting the mandate given to us in the Commission by the Member States and expressed in the resolution of this Parliament. Twenty-eight governments have signed this agreement, and it has been done in transparency. The CETA texts have been public since September 2014. The old Investment Court System (ICS) reform has been public for a year. The original version has been online for two and a half years. There have been 12 meetings on this with the European Parliament, nine meetings with the Committee on International Trade, three workshops, two EP delegations, and I could go on. It has not been negotiated in secret. Honourable Members will be involved in the implementation of all this, and we will work with you in order to make sure that we reform and look at how we can become better in the implementation of the sustainable development chapter.  I do respect – and that is perfectly normal – that there are different views on this. You can be in favour and you can be against.  (The President interrupted the speaker to call for less noise in the House) I respect that there will be people voting in favour and against, but calling a trade agreement with Canada a coup d’état is, frankly, going too far. (Applause) So, voting in a few minutes on the two agreements we have in front of us will enable us to take a great economic and geopolitical opportunity, deepening economic relations, affirming our social and environmental protection, showing that trade and values can go hand—in—hand, and strengthening a shared partnership. I hope that you will vote in favour of these two agreements that will send a strong signal to our friends in Canada, and also to the rest of the world. (Applause)

name: Artis Pabriks
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I will not repeat all those arguments in favour of trade agreements between the European Union and Canada because it was very well argued by all the Commission recently.  (The President called for quiet in the House) I would like very much to thank all those shadow rapporteurs like Mr Moisă, Ms Schaake, David Martin and others, who contributed so that this trade agreement here in Parliament is of such a high quality. Thank you to all of you. I would also like to agree with speakers such as Alexander Graf Lambsdorff and others who noted that, once more, the far right and the far left of this House are united against everything that is good for the European Union.  (Applause from certain quarters) If anybody is taking away jobs, if anybody is taking away the wealth of the people of Europe, if anybody is loosening the foundations of European nation states, then turn to these radicals on both sides. I believe that we will vote today correctly to the benefit of the European Union. I would also like to say that already next week, we will have the first national parliament – that of my country, Latvia – that will ratify this agreement, and the other countries will be able to follow. Those who want to listen to facts and not to be ‘trumped’ by alternative arguments to the right and left, should rather listen to what kind of benefits this will bring after it comes into force provisionally. I believe that this vote is the right vote for our Member States and for the European Union as a whole. Let’s go forward. (Applause)

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, what has been very clear to me today in the debate is that – across the House, other than for a minority of alarmist, protectionist and isolationist voices on the far left and right of the Chamber – there is near-universal appreciation for the strong ties that exist between Canada and the European Union. Our shared culture, democratic norms and history bind us together in a way that is unique. It is vital that the EU champions those shared values to maintain the levels of prosperity and success that we enjoy today and to stand together as strong advocates for free trade and liberal multilateralism across the globe. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA) will act as a model for future trade and political relationships between the European Union and third countries. This is also a potential model around which the United Kingdom could base its future trade relationships with the EU post—Brexit. Fighting international crime and terrorism, tackling climate change and ensuring continued space for economic growth and job creation in an era of globalisation and technological change are all issues that cross borders, and they can only be tackled by democracies like Canada and the EU Member States working together. As these changes take effect, it is vital that we all pull together to ensure that they work for all our citizens, and that we do not allow our economies to drift towards the simple allure of nationalism, isolationism and protectionism that can only lead to less prosperity and security for our citizens. It has taken many years to reach today and to conclude these deals, but as we are now finally moving in this House to ratify the SPA and CETA, it is clear that this time and effort has been very well worthwhile. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: I would like to thank the Commissioner and you too, honourable Members, for your cooperation in this lengthy and important debate. I have received six motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - The EU-Canada Free Trade Treaty, says CETA, will complete the transformation of our deindustrialised regions into commercial cemeteries. When Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau came to address MEPs, he was pleased that European consumers will now be able to buy “beautiful Canadian Mukluks winter boots” at low prices, due to the disappearance customs tariffs between the EU and Canada. With all due respect to Mr. Trudeau, Europeans are not just consumers willing to run the Canadian trade machine. They are artisans, traders and workers who, like the Bata and André companies, have supported thousands of families for nearly a century and exported French know-how all over the world. Like the Bata factory in Hellocourt, nicknamed "Bataville", brought to its knees by unfair Asian competition, it is now up to the "Andre" brand of the Vivarte group to suffer the killing of free - wild exchange. With the new CETA treaty, our French VSEs will now be condemned to fight against Canadian multinationals without benefiting from customs protection. Mr. Trudeau, you forget that when jobs disappear, so do consumers.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Due to an insurmountable personal obstacle I could not be in Strasbourg on 15 February to take part in the vote on the "CETA" agreement between Canada and the EU. If I were present, I would be voting against this agreement, as I share the view that CETA, despite some improvements, especially following proposals from Member States during the negotiation period, still has a negative balance for European economies in the end. and societies. On this basis, I would vote against the agreement, as did the parliamentary group of the European Left, GUE / NGL, to which I belong.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Economic and Trade Agreement between the EU and Canada (CETA) proposes the elimination of almost all tariffs and non-tariff barriers and the liberalization of trade in services between its partners. It also aims to open up the Canadian public procurement market to European companies. In 2015, the value of imported goods from Canada was EUR 28.3 billion, and exported - EUR 35.2 billion. It is estimated that these amounts may increase by 20% after the implementation of the above agreement. On the most contentious and controversial issues, the EU and Canada reaffirmed that countries had the right to apply their own laws. Another such issue was the investor-state dispute resolution mechanism. It was eventually replaced by the Investment Court, which will ensure government control over the selection of arbitrators and enhance the transparency of the process. Today, we will also vote on a Strategic Partnership Agreement between the EU and Canada, which complements the CETA, by enhancing bilateral cooperation in areas such as foreign and security policy, counter-terrorism, combating organized crime, sustainable development, research and culture. Despite CETA's many advantages, there is still a lot of ambiguity, such as the agreement's compatibility with the Treaties, so I will not support this agreement.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – MEPs received very large numbers of messages from constituents, expressing opposition to this CETA deal. I am not against trade deals. Scotland is a trading nation, with a long history of building valuable commercial links around the world. I want that to continue. Although I acknowledge that changes in the CETA deal have been achieved, these improvements had been strongly resisted, and only very grudgingly given when serious democratic challenges have been mounted, such as the Wallonian opposition to the original text and the threat of resistance to ISDS in this Parliament.  I find myself unconvinced that the current CETA text is the best deal available, and am very suspicious of the moves to limit debate and steamroller the deal to a conclusion, both at Westminster recently and in this Parliament where the normal committee processes have been curtailed. Labour law standards have not been adequately safeguarded and an envisaged consultation process remains opaque in its eventual effect. The Investor Court System, while admittedly improved, will still undermine the general corporate law by developing a specific, and unnecessary, supranational court for investors. These are just some of the reasons why I will vote against giving consent at this time.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted against the controversial, next-generation CETA globalization deal for many reasons. Both due to the fact that the document was prepared in a secret manner, with the possible influence of third parties on the negotiation process, but without the participation of the governments and parliaments of individual EU Member States, and without the participation of the public, which violates the basic principles of democracy. It is also a danger of losing the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of lawmaking and protection of the public interest. According to expert opinions, there is a risk of losing 200,000 to 600,000 jobs in the entire EU, and in Poland it is estimated at around 200,000. According to many expert opinions, CETA gives corporations the opportunity to appeal against virtually any regulation, both domestic and intra-community, through the ICS mechanism (supra-state arbitration court). . This could jeopardize the expected profits of concerns, which puts corporations above state law and is contrary to the interests of particularly less affluent societies. CETA is a threat to small-scale family farming in Poland, as the lifting of all barriers threatens to collapse Polish agriculture. CETA will lower food standards, especially due to the danger of importing genetically modified and industrially produced food, which is cheaper and of poor quality. CETA may restrict states' rights to renationalise or regulate public services, and may endanger the environment by facilitating the import of Canadian tar sands fuels.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: In written form. - I strongly believe that the SETA agreement will give a new impetus to our economies in the fast-growing global trade. EU-Canada relations are based on shared values, as evidenced by the long history of broad political and economic cooperation, and we must deepen them, not encapsulate them. In 2015, the EU imported goods from Canada worth 28.3 billion euros, while exports of goods from the EU to Canada amounted to 35.2 billion euros, and this figure is expected to increase by more than 20% when the agreement is fully implemented. This is a real example of the benefits that SETA will bring to the EU and Canada. We must not overlook the fact that the agreement introduces a new investment judicial system and improves investment protection rules. It will make the settlement of investment disputes fairer and more transparent. SETA is the first free trade agreement concluded by the EU with another established and important OECD member state. It is also the most ambitious agreement between both the EU and Canada, and we must support it.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU has trade agreements with dozens of countries. Canada is the most advanced of them. It is one of the countries with the highest quality of life in the world. Slovakia has signed an old business agreement with it, which favors Canadian investors over our companies. The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between Canada and the European Union is the largest trade, services and investment agreement the EU has ever concluded. Its implementation will bring economic growth and job creation, and mutual trade should increase by up to EUR 12 billion a year. The abolition of customs duties of EUR 400 million on goods originating in the EU and the mutual recognition of certificates of conformity of products and goods will reduce costs for European businesses and increase their competitiveness and market access. Canada will allow European bidders to participate in its governmental as well as regional public procurement, providing 140 geographical indications for food and drink at the same level as in the EU. Strengthened investment protection rules and fairer and more transparent settlement of investment disputes will increase legal certainty for European entrepreneurs and contribute to the growth of mutual trade. The agreement is subject to ratification by the member states.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted against the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement (CETA) in the vote that took place in the Plenary Session of the European Parliament on 15/2/2017, as I had said publicly for years, from the first moment the EU-Canada negotiations began. I had from the beginning taken a stand against CETA, as this is a trade liberalization agreement that has a number of very serious negative consequences for Greece. It paves the way for the introduction of mutated foods, breaks down labor relations, commodifies public goods such as health and education, and overturns the principle of prevention, which is important for the protection of public health. It favors multinationals, destroying local small producers, opening up the service sector to Canadians and at the same time creating a paradoxical system bypassing the courts of EU Member States. had the Greek feta as a product of Protected Designation of Origin (PDO), irreparably damaging the production and quality of the Greek feta, a traditional product, which, only from exports, brings to Greece over 185 million EUR. At the same time, CETA favors the main Canadian producer of so-called "feta", who, remarkably, is from Skopje !!! The fight against CETA continues.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. - The economic agreement with Canada commits us societally. It brings into play our agricultural models, our public markets, our legal systems and European health and environmental standards. However, as it stands, too many uncertainties remain on the legal, economic or environmental level. That is why I am calling for a vote against this agreement. It is not about voting against Canada. It is not because Canada is a democracy that this agreement is necessarily good and that we must stop thinking and taking a step back on a text that will have a lasting impact on EU trade policy. Economically, the results will be virtually non-existent, by the Commission itself. From a legal point of view, it is not yet clear what form the arbitration mechanism will take. From an environmental point of view, the precautionary principle risks being undermined by the process of "recognition of equivalence". I also believe that the negotiation process has not created the conditions for a truly transparent debate. The public debate will now be able to continue in each Member State with a view to voting by national parliaments.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - CETA as it stands is not acceptable, because it is a new generation agreement which aims to harmonize standards. However, it does not offer the guarantee of pulling them up. These norms are essential and deeply cultural. While it is possible to make compromises in terms of customs duties, we cannot, on the other hand, make any concessions with regard to European standards. Imagine what the impact might be on diet or social demands if the safeguards were not clearly established. Today, the European Union is negotiating major trade treaties considering trade as the alpha and omega of development, without first defining its position from an economic point of view, as well as from a social and environmental point of view. The underlying objective of this type of agreement is cooperation and regulatory convergence with a view to removing non-tariff barriers to trade, but without first settling the issue of differences in regulations and public aid, l He European Union runs the risk of unfair competition between Canadians and Europeans. These are, among other things, the reasons why I am voting against CETA today.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Recently, we have been MEPs under more pressure from EU citizens for an EU-Canada trade agreement. This pressure also forced me personally to listen to the arguments of citizens, but also of experts. Even today, when we are negotiating the CETA agreement in plenary, we have the opportunity to hear arguments from our fellow Members for and against. I want to join those who support the agreement. The application of the agreement should increase mutual trade by up to 12 billion a year, as well as support economic growth and job creation. For me, the fact that goods imported from Canada must comply with all the rules set by the EU is also a convincing argument. Another important argument is that Canada will only recognize more than 140 traditional and protected products produced in the EU in a certain area. I was also convinced by the arguments of EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmström, who clarified that the agreement with Canada did not mean the privatization of public services, would not lead to lower consumer standards, and also explained the role of arbitration courts. From the agreement between the EU and Canada, I expect a benefit for Slovakia as well, not only in business, for example in the automotive sector, but also in mutual exchanges of experience between our and Canadian educational and scientific institutions.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Today, the European Parliament has left Europeans in the lurch and put corporate interests and uncompromising capitalist logic at the forefront, trampling on our social and workers' rights, public health, food standards, natural resources, fundamental principles of democracy and the rule of law. The European Temple of Democracy has thus completely ignored one of the largest mass civil uprisings to date, bringing together millions of citizens, NGOs, trade union representatives, local communities, experts and others, but all this was clearly not enough. Such a move is all the more worrying at a time when people are increasingly feeling that they are not deciding on anything anymore and that key decisions are being made far away, especially in the almighty centers of capital. Isn't it high time that the issues that are so crucial to our future take into account the voice of the people, which is clear here? I myself voted against an agreement that pursues a narrow-minded and greedy trade policy and threatens the fundamental postulates of our society, instead of pursuing a fair and transparent trade policy that does not play with the fates and rights of the people. I now call on the parliaments of the Member States to show respect for the citizens in the ratification process and to give up their support for the Ceti. Clearly, national parliaments remain the last bulwark of European standards and European democracy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the CETA agreement, as I believe that it is a modern agreement that offers a very good basis for cooperation, without the risk of lowering European standards. I am assessing this not only on the basis of general assessments, but also on the basis of a detailed review of the agreement. I understand people's concerns about maintaining European standards, acquired rights and the influence of corporations, but the concerns are unnecessary. Over the past year, it has become clear that opposition to CETI is not so much about content that many are unfamiliar with, but more about the issue of opposition to globalization and the spread of populism. It would be dangerous for the EU to be economically closed in on itself. With the abolition of customs duties, for example, it will be possible to buy products on e-bay at no additional cost. Diplomas obtained in Slovenia will be valid without further verification, and companies seeking their opportunity by exporting to the Canadian market will operate with less bureaucratic obstacles. Protectionism, monopolies and the policy of isolation in the global world do not bring positive results, on the contrary, they cause irreparable damage to the economy and the well-being of European citizens.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ahead of such a controversial vote I thought it might be quite nice to break the tense atmosphere here with some good news and point out that on 6 February 2017 Her Majesty the Queen celebrated her sapphire jubilee: 65 years on the throne in the United Kingdom. I think colleagues would like to join me in paying their respects to Her Majesty the Queen, especially colleagues from the Commonwealth, from Malta and from Cyprus.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - It is only a question, Mr. President, because I have not understood.It is a question: are you not going to vote today or are you never going to vote?

name: Presidente. –
text: I have never voted as Vice-President and I will never vote when I chair the sitting.It is my personal choice, I could do it, but the position of the President must be the position of Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Helmut Scholz
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, dear colleagues, I want to draw your attention to the forthcoming file, the partnership agreement with Mongolia, which has been negotiated and concluded, and finally today we can give consent to this agreement. Unfortunately, we did not have the chance to discuss the content, and I want to draw your attention in particular to the fact that we need the opening of a representation of the European Union in Mongolia to accompany the future cooperation and political, economic and cultural relationship with this important country in Asia.

name: Ian Duncan
