text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all my colleagues who helped us get to this point. There is an expression in the English language, which is called ‘squeaky bum time’. I think we have lived through that today and yesterday and for several months. I would now like to request a mandate to refer this back to committee in order to begin interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am very sorry to take up 60 seconds of your time, but I think it is essential people in this Chamber know what they are about to vote on. Charities, religious groups and many businesses support rejection of this technical standard because they are concerned about the impact of speculation on food commodity prices. Many of you will know that those spikes in food commodity prices have been linked to famine in some countries, pushing millions of people into poverty. We are asking for a very small change to tighten up rules. National regulators will still have the power to loosen those rules if they have to, and farmers who use derivative markets to hedge their bets are accepted. Please, whatever group you are in, reject these technical standards.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen.I just want to draw your attention to the fact that a qualified majority is required to reject it.That is why a tied vote is still a long way from being a qualified majority, and that is why it makes no sense to discuss it now.

name: Presidente. –
text: This concludes the voting round.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE).
text: - Sir. Chairman! When I was going to enter Parliament this morning, there were a lot of young people on the ground out here in front of the entrance, demonstrating. And I want to say that I think that was pretty uplifting. All the while that when young people sit on the street in queues, it is most often because they are sitting and waiting for an iPhone or something, but here there is someone who chose to get up - or rather to lie down down - for a political idea that they believe in. I think it is worth all the honor and respect. But having said that, the agreement stops then too. Because I have chosen to vote in favor of the CETA agreement, and I do so simply because I basically think that free trade is good. It is even better when it is such that it is regulated. It is my view that both in terms of the legal system, in terms of consumer protection and the environment and in the whole politically open process that has taken place on this agreement, we stand today with the world's best free trade agreement. And at a time when we have a President Trump who is trying to isolate and with protectionism, then I think the step we have taken today from the European team and from the Canadian team is the right signal to send. to the outside world.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - So, CETA is not in the interest of the people, but in the interest of the capital that rules politics, and this was also shown today in today's vote.Today, the European Parliament has left Europeans in the lurch, protesting loudly, even here in front of the European Parliament, against agreements that also threaten the environment, which in fact affect the future of generations to come.And of course with arguments that don’t hold up.Such an agreement will not bring economic growth, even more so, from the experience that Canada has with a similar agreement with America means job loss and risk in many areas, including the environment, labor and social rights.Now it is the turn of the national parliaments and I hope that Slovenia will also be among them, which will put itself on the map of the defender of the future of our generations.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, removing barriers to trade boosts growth, encourages innovation, raises wages and gives consumers greater choices, and in the case of the EU-Canada deal it even gives us cheaper chocolate. This is a good deal. But the Canada deal is not the best template for the future relationship between the UK and Europe, as our own trade is much more sophisticated and intertwined, especially in key 21st—century economic sectors. High product standards underpinned by the mutual recognition principle is what this relationship is based on, and I hope that the UK-EU deal will be a much more advanced and future-looking partnership.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, I voted against SETA because I do not think that it is in the interest of Bulgaria. For years, agriculture in the country has been shrinking. With the fall of import quotas and import duties for Canada, Bulgarian production will most likely only receive additional competition. In the domestic and European markets a significant part of the products have transitional quotas, for example for beef and pork are a direct threat to these sectors in Bulgaria. Also, no Bulgarian product protected with geographical significance is included in SETA. Their manufacturers are not protected from imitation and abuse in the Canadian market. Moreover, apart from that, Canada is the fifth largest producer of GMO foods in the world. In this regard, the European Commission argues that Canadian food will have to comply with European legislation. But that means labeling foods. This does not mean that these foods will not be distributed. They will be distributed indefinitely and these foods will be bought by the poorest strata in Europe, including Bulgarians and Bulgarian retirees.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I have said 'no' to CETA because more than two hundred thousand jobs will be lost in the European Union.I have said 'no' to CETA because inequalities will increase, wages will fall and long-term unemployment will rise.I have said "no" to CETA because labor relations are being unbalanced in favor of multinationals, which will have arbitration tribunals to attack workers' rights.I have said 'no' to CETA because Canada is a country that has not even signed the ILO Convention on the right to collective bargaining.And it is not me who says it: it was this Parliament when it voted its resolution on employment and CETA.I regret that today you ignore your own words and prefer to defend the large multinationals rather than the workers themselves.The fight continues and we will not give up.No to CETA, no to TISA and no to TTIP!

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, today is not a good day: today CETA, the Agreement with Canada, has just been approved here in the European Parliament.We, from the European left, have voted "no" but, of course, even so, it has been approved with 408 votes in favor of the European People's Party, the liberals and the vast majority of Social Democrats, including the PSOE.The grand coalition works perfectly here.But we have not lost this battle, because this has just begun.Now CETA must be ratified, it must be voted on in all Member States, and that is where we have to redouble our efforts.We are only going to stop this if we are thousands, millions in the streets, organized, the political and social forces of all Europe and Canada together.Therefore, this is one more call to participate in the campaigns that are organized against CETA, against TTIP and against TiSA.We will continue in this fight, and as always, from Izquierda Unida, we will also be there.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, today, in the face of absolute commercial trade logic, the EU Parliament actually capitulated and gave away a huge amount in terms of what is common sense in trade policy. Everything about trade policy is about generating jobs and protecting people; it is not about succumbing to lobbyists and to bigger principles from the big corporates. But that is what we gave away today and, in doing so, the United Kingdom may well have given away the protection that the National Health Service has enjoyed.  Indisputably, what was also sanctioned today was the investment and court system being brought into play. That is going to allow big corporates to sue governments if they want to. Is that really the future for trade policy across Europe? I do not think it is. So today a very, very disappointing decision by this Chamber.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the EU is currently struggling with multiple crises, one of them being the new trends of protectionism that we see around the world, particularly from the Trump administration. Today has been different. Today, the European Parliament has been able to send a united strong signal to the world, a signal that we want to uphold the post-war consensus of openness and free trade. I am therefore very proud to have supported CETA today. It is an act of resistance against Mr Trump’s new administration. It is an ambitious, modern, progressive deal that will, when it enters into force, abolish over 98% of the tariffs still in place today. It will open bidders for a public procurement on EU businesses, and it will also protect our environmental and social standards. Today, we have taken a good step. We should continue in that way.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, voting ‘no’ to CETA was a most difficult vote for me. I come from a small open economy, and I am in favour of free trade. Certainly in Ireland we need to trade in order to survive and thrive economically. I listened to the debate this morning and I heard people say, what about the geopolitical situation? The EU, of which I am a full supporter, is under attack from both inside and outside, and if we cannot do a deal with those decent Canadians, who can we do a deal with? Well, all of those arguments are valid, but you cannot vote on a very detailed trade deal on your gut feelings only. You must vote on the essential elements that are in the deal.  There are many elements I could comment on, but in my limited time I will mention just one, and that is the inclusion of investor courts in this deal. In one of his first addresses to this Parliament, President Juncker said: ‘My Commission will not accept that the jurisdiction of courts in the EU Member States be limited by special regimes for investor-to-state disputes’. Yet that is precisely what we have in this agreement. And just as President Junker would not accept it, neither can I.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, I voted against the EU-Canada agreement that everyone knows as "CETA". Indeed, contrary to what the Commission repeats as a mantra, this is not a good deal. It is dangerous for our agriculture and the preservation of the general interest. Multinationals will be able to challenge social or environmental laws that they deem potentially harmful to their benefit - regardless, in that regard, the name of the tribunal. It is also dangerous for public services. It only rebalances an aberrant situation of reciprocity or rather lack of reciprocity, so far, in access to public markets. It is undemocratic because of the opacity of its negotiation and the illegitimate quasi-legislative role given to the joint committee, but also because most of this agreement, however mixed, will enter into force in a few weeks without waiting for the opinion of parliaments. necessary for its ratification. On this subject, like so many others, the gulf between the self-proclaimed elites and the peoples continues to widen.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, what we have experienced in this House today is a grotesque. The deputies of this Parliament themselves voting against this Parliament, voting against democracy. They have voted that this House and the rest of national and local Parliaments lose their power, lose their sovereignty to give it to the business, to give it to the lobbies. How? With CETA, a free trade agreement that puts private benefit before people and the planet, that will create its own justice and that will kill SMEs and small farmers and ranchers. Popular, liberal, sticker socialists who voted in favor: next week your mouth will fill saying that we need more Europe, but your model of Europe is a precipice and people will not follow you to its precipice. More than three and a half million signatures, more than two thousand municipalities declared free of CETA. This treaty will not see the light. People will bury him forever as he passes through national parliaments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the dilemma is relatively simple - Trudeau or Trump, free trade or protectionism?When I recently heard Mr. Trump talk about how there will be fewer cars produced in Europe on American roads and how he no longer wants to see them, it was clear to me that then our employees, our car workers in Croatia and their subcontractors, whoare small businesses, get into trouble.Because there will be fewer exports from Europe to the United States, and that’s why I’m for free trade.That is why I am in favor of this agreement, because I am sure that such agreements enable and give a greater chance, not only to large companies, but also to small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President!I voted against CETA because it is an agreement that really attacks our democratic roots.CETA is the first agreement in a whole series of agreements - such as TiSA - that are actually there to introduce the neoliberal economic system in our EU.Very soon we will be voting on TiSA here in this House.It is always about the same principles, the principles of liberal economic philosophy.It is about deregulation, that is, reducing state influence, curbing the economy, it is about social cuts and it is about the privatization of public tasks.This will shake our democratic principles.That is why I voted against CETA.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: - In fact, it is still too early for a final judgment on CETA. By saying yes or no, the opportunity to fight for a trade agreement that can serve as a model for fair world trade is lost. The negotiations still have many open ends. Under pressure from our group and from society, ISDS has been discontinued. ICS is now chosen for the settlement of disputes. We do not think this is a perfect solution, but at the same time, the Commission has pledged to negotiate to transform ICS into an international public court, which means that the more than 1,300 European ISDS clauses will also lapse. We are therefore happy to await that development. The PvdA also wants environmental organizations and trade unions to have the right to take legal action to protect labor and environmental standards. Again, the Commission has pledged to work with Canada to come up with a sanction system before this summer that can be transposed in the event of violations of these rights. The European Parliament's verdict is not the final verdict on CETA. National parliaments are also discussed. And then we know enough for a final judgment.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I voted against the agreement with Canada because, although they say that these exports will save us, they relocate our production and our industries.When they tell us that there will be cheap products in the markets, they are telling us that we will have less wages and that we will have less income in agriculture.I voted against CETA because it puts the sovereignty of peoples in the hands of large transnational corporations, because it endangers our life, our health, our food, our public services, education, health, our agriculture, our fisheries andour small and medium-sized businesses.I voted against CETA because I want a future for us, for the popular classes and for our people.I voted no, because I defend the right to decide freely about our future, and I ask that this treaty not be applied until the Parliaments of the States say the last word.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, free trade is something I believe it when it is fair and when it enables all the parties in each country to trade freely. But this EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) is not one of free trade. It is not one that is fair. It is not one that can be fair when the corporates were the only ones invited to make agreements in secret with the Commissioners, when investors will be able to sue freely through the new Investor Court system, and when corporations will actually be invited to make the rules. There were no protections for the National Health Service, which is vital to the United Kingdom. Wallonia opposed it and was bought off. Our parliaments do not have the opportunity to vote on it before it is in place. People emailed me in their thousands: they have been ignored. Demonstrators were dragged away in this Chamber: they have been ignored. Huge corporates and wealthy bureaucrats won today. The people, democracy and trade lost.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this free trade agreement. I am very pleased to have been present at this historic vote, and I am convinced that this agreement will strengthen trade relations between the European Union and Canada. After all, I am in favor of the principles of free trade in general, I am opposed to tariffs and other trade barriers, which we, as the European Union, should oppose and fight against. After all, the European Union, one of the ideas of our integration, is precisely the free movement of goods, services, capital and people, and this agreement fits into our philosophy, our cooperation between free states. I am therefore very pleased that this agreement has been adopted and I hope that the estimates will be fulfilled, that it will increase trade between the European Union and Canada by up to 20%, and that the benefits will be in the billions of euros for both parties and that it will lead to to more vacancies, not to what frightens the left, that, on the contrary, jobs will be lost.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!CETA supporters say, as the rapporteur recommending the recommendation said, Canada is closer to us than some European countries.Of course, I very much admire the people of Canada and their participation in two world wars on our side.It is a country that is allied with us.But when I was listening to this colleague, I thought that international concerns located in Canada are closer to him than Polish or Greek farmers.In fact, this decision was made without regard to the principles that we often refer to.We are talking about minorities, but has anybody thought about farmers?We are talking about the equality of entities, and who thought about the privileges of international concerns over our own entrepreneurs?We are talking about fighting populism, and this treaty is one great work of populist consumerism - which is why I voted against.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh, mar a dúirt mé ar maidin, bhí mé i bhfabhar an tionscadail seo agus vótáil mé ar son na tuarascála agus ba mhaith liom na daoine a d’oibrigh ar an tionscadal seo ar feadh 7 mbliana a mholadh. Tá an-jab déanta acu; agus duine amháin ba mhaith liom a lua ná an Cathaoirleach ar Thoscaireacht Pharlaimint na hEorpa don Chaidreamh le Ceanada ar feadh 5 bliana, sin é an tUasal Bradbourn nach bhfuil beo a thuilleadh. Tá sé imithe ar shlí na fírinne. Ach gach cruinniú a bhí againn, bhí an t-ábhar seo ar an gclár agus bhí suim ar leith aige san ábhar seo. Ach inniu, tá dea-thoradh tagtha ar an obair a rinne sé. Bhí daoine ag déanamh agóide, agus mar sin de, agus tá sé sin go maith; ach caithfidh mé a rá gur fhreagair an Coimisinéir Malmström gach duine inniu mar d’inis sí cad atá i gceist sa chomhréiteach iontach seo.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have also supported this free trade agreement with Canada, because in my opinion, free trade simply helps, unless it is subject to administrative or other obstacles. On the contrary, I am convinced that well-managed trade rules and trade policy can move the European economy even more. According to conservative estimates, this agreement is expected to increase the volume of the economy between the two units by 20% when it enters into force. Those conservative estimates speak of $ 12 billion. Most tariffs and fees are eliminated. I am convinced that this agreement will not lead to the loss of employment, as the left claims, on the contrary, that it will support employment. And I am also glad that various geographical indications have been protected, such as Czech beer or Satu Mare hops. So, in this regard too, I welcome the agreement and I firmly believe that it will bring the benefits we are talking about here.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - President!CETA threatens EU standards in the areas of environmental protection, food safety and labor law.It threatens sustainable European agriculture.The institution of investment protection courts undermines the sovereignty of the Member States.87% of EU SMEs produce for the internal market, so they will not be able to enter the Canadian market, but capital-intensive businesses will come here.And US-based companies can enter EU markets through their subsidiaries, taking advantage of CETA.The EP's website is proud to announce that 751 MEPs represent you, the citizens.It is therefore a shame that this agreement, which represents the interests of global companies, has been approved by this Parliament.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of concluding a global economic and trade agreement between Canada and the European Union in recognition that Canada is an important trade and investment partner and ally for the European Union and that the agreement is an important instrument in European Union's efforts to define a strict framework for world trade standards. In my decision, the fact that today we live in a time of uncertainty and ambiguity and a resurgence of dangerous protectionist policies, which are a setback to the multilateral and bilateral trade system and open an unknown about the future of trade relations, weighed in. I therefore believe that the European Union must, therefore, strengthen partnerships and more intense models of cooperation with States with which it shares a shared values ​​and strategic interests. However, I want to emphasize that, in environmental matters, CETA should have been more ambitious and in line with the commitments made in Paris and even with the European project itself in terms of climate energy objectives, which aim at a green, sustainable economy, giving priority renewable energy and the fight against climate change. CETA should also promote, in a more rigorous way, sustainable agricultural practices, since the link between energy, food and water is an essential condition for the well-being of citizens, for poverty reduction and for sustainable development.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I supported the agreement with Canada, as did the other 407 Members.I am glad that, in the end, the agreement had so much support.I think that in this precarious situation, the European Union needs a strong, stable partner.I am also glad that this trade agreement is not just about trade relations, but also about cooperation in foreign and defense policy, in research, in education.The CETA agreement goes beyond a mere commitment to eliminate trade tariffs.It also contains commitments to protect high standards in the field of the environment or working conditions, consumer protection and geographical indications, as colleagues have already said here.I consider import quotas and the public policy exception to be absolutely sufficient safeguards and guarantees to ensure competition.Ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased that the European Parliament has taken this important step.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, CETA is a landmark free trade agreement that would make both parties richer. By abolishing 98% of tariffs and other trade barriers, it would provide excellent opportunities for SMEs. It would also liberalise cross-border investment and trade in services. It would open competition for large government contracts, it would support enforcement of intellectual property rights and would facilitate mutual recognition in the extremely important services market.  Beyond the merits of the agreement itself, its adoption would also signify two essential things. It would reinforce that the EU still believes in the benefits of free trade and open markets that ensured its post-war prosperity, and that it is able to regain some of the trade negotiation credibility that it lost when it decided to give up its exclusive competence over the deal.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: –  A spoonful of tar, as the Polish proverb says, spoils a barrel of honey. There are several spoonfuls of tar in this barrel of honey. I voted for, because I like honey, but with a heavy heart. In fact, I support the position of Mr Petr Mach of the Bohemian Party of Free Citizens who proposes: dissolve the European Union, dissolve  the Dominion of Canada, and let the Canadian provinces and European countries live happily under CETA .

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, this agreement between the parties was a very, very partial agreement. On the one hand, we have three and a half million people who have signed, who sent us their signatures, in fact, rejecting this agreement. We also have two thousand more regions that declare themselves free from CETA and TTIP and, on the other hand, we have multinationals and profit. The majority of this Parliament decided to choose multinationals and profit rather than those that are in the interests of the citizens. Besides, he had a strange behavior, I would say. It is a Parliament that votes in favor of a majority agreement, but that has no political position on it. It is unable to make a political resolution that can expose what is Parliament's position. So it is a Parliament that does not think. For this very reason, I want to say that citizens will continue to resist and, surely, national parliaments will have to listen to these citizens. The game is not over yet and I am certainly on the side of people, I am not on the side of profit.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament, kept on a leash by multinationals, has just approved CETA. Compliments! You have carried out the first silent coup in history. You have condemned the citizens of Europe, eroded sovereignty and stabbed democracy in the heart. To enter Parliament this morning we all went through a demonstration of hundreds of people lying in front of the entrance doors. This was the voice of the citizens and they are not the first to oppose CETA. 150 000 have written to the Commission against the evil ISDS clauses, 2 137 regions and municipalities have declared themselves free from CETA and over three and a half million Europeans have signed the petition against this treaty, the petition to the European Union with the most signatories ever realized. Colleagues, you have ignored them and, rather than having voted on a treaty, you have betrayed a trust. Your owners will be proud of you and your work. But I, frankly, am ashamed for all of you.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, continuing my comments on the investor—state dispute courts, I want to say that we don’t have special courts to enforce workers’ rights, and we don’t have special courts to enforce citizens’ rights, yet this deal gives us special courts to enforce the rights of investors when they take on national governments. It’s also worth saying that these courts are not answerable to any national court – not even to the European Court of Justice. And I don’t believe European citizens support the inclusion of these outdated, unnecessary and – in my view – undemocratic regimes in any trade deal.  I have other significant issues with CETA. What about negative listing, where we in Ireland have one of the shortest lists when it comes to extra sectors to be excluded from liberalisation. I wonder how many of our politicians were involved in drawing up our short, miserable list of just three extra exceptions. And from an Irish perspective, the amount of beef with tariff—free access to the EU market will be very significant, and would pose significant challenges to our suckler herd. Add to that the impact of a hard Brexit with 63 million fewer consumers for tariff—free beef, and this has the potential to undermine the entire sector.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, from the outset I was opposed to the CETA agreement, which is why I voted against the European Union-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement, as well as the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement. I believe that CETA is an agreement that destroys European agriculture, destroys Greek agriculture, does not protect products of Designation of Origin, such as Greek feta and Kalamon olives, paves the way for Genetically Modified, dissolves labor relations, commodifies Public goods, such as health and education, overturn the precautionary principle, which is important for the protection of public health, is at the service of multinationals and, at the same time, creates a paradoxical system, bypassing the courts of the Member States. In addition, it bypasses the Parliaments of the Member States that also have the power and there we will fight to prevent CETA from passing.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Dear President, after all, when are we afraid of that?We are afraid of Canada, the most European country outside the European continent.More than 75% of Canada’s population has European roots.35,000,000 inhabitants, which Canada has, against one market of 500,000,000 inhabitants, which the European Union has.I think we need to really ask ourselves who we are afraid of.I am definitely sure that free trade within the European Union, the removal of barriers within the European Union, has brought a better economic situation within the European Union.Croatia has also had excellent GDP growth in the last few months, a year, two, precisely because we have become a member of the European Union.Precisely because we took advantage of free trade.That is why I think that free trade is the trade that enables economic growth.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I voted against CETA because it goes against social rights and only benefits multinationals on both sides of the Atlantic. More than three and a half million signatures of European citizens asking to vote "no" to CETA that have been literally thrown away by the great coalition of the PP, the Socialist Party and Citizens, these signatures that we have in our seats. CETA puts up for sale our public services, our health, our hospitals, our schools and, as the tides said, "our health and our school are not for sale, they are defended." And that is what we have done right here. CETA puts our democracy up for sale. Private arbitration tribunals are a blow to the rule of law that put the profits of corporations before the law of the states. CETA and neoliberal austerity policies and cuts are the perfect breeding ground to pave the way for the ghosts of fascism like Trump or Le Pen. Because our lives are worth more than their benefits, which is precisely why I voted against CETA.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Honestly, I wanted to say a few other words, but the previous speaker provoked me to refer to his speech. It is a fantastic statement. Fantastic. You mentioned, as a huge threat to the European Union and the society of our Member States, all the elements that are not in CETA and are excluded. Healthcare, communal services, education, culture etc. are turned off. That is why I said here in an earlier speech that we are hearing lies and nonsense here, because things are mentioned here and people - the people of Europe - are scared by things that are not in CETA, or that are, but have been limited, there are guarantees and security. Therefore, I am very happy that, of course, apart from the issue we are talking about, the matters relating to the CETA agreement have also been dealt with positively. One could conclude and say that reason has not died today, and nationalism and stupidity have lost.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE).
text: - Sir.Chairman!I have all the honor and respect for those who want to make themselves advocates for the 3.5 million who have provided signatures, but do not make you the "voice of the people", because then I want to make myself the voicefor the 496.5 million who have not signed a protest against the CETA agreement and who know full well that this is an agreement that may in fact be the best free trade agreement we have ever seen in the world.And I would just like to briefly address it with the investment court system, which has been mentioned by many as the big problem in this agreement.In addition, it is safe to say that the possibility of suing states lies in virtually all free trade agreements in advance through the system we have today, which is an ad hoc system.Now we finally get a transparent system but a very stringent code of conduct, and that should be in everyone's interest.Hence a clear YES to this agreement today.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, precisely because free trade has enabled such growth of our economy, the European economy, we practically have a situation in which, with the appropriate regulations and this agreement, the Canadian economy will join, in a way, the common European economy. Multinational companies also operate in the European Union, they are ubiquitous. Let us not forget that our SME sector is the most vital and best sector of the European Union. These are precisely the chances of our economies permeating together, and I see this as a great opportunity for small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the European Union and in Canada. It is evident that the far left and the far right are against this agreement. Maybe it’s not even that weird because they don’t have any serious responsibility anywhere, not even here in the European Union, because they don’t govern anywhere, nor are they in power. Therefore, that extreme neo-fascist right and the extreme neo-communist left, really do not deserve to be followed at this moment.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: - Mr Chairman! Well, we experienced here a spectacle of demagogy shows and shows of propaganda lies. It was not a political debate rather, which is a pity. All the more it is a pity that the political and parliamentary mainstream somehow believes in the lies of its own propaganda. They are great propagandists, but believing their propaganda lies harms the political debate and its consequences. Europe will lose a lot from this. If it were a free trade agreement, it would have one sentence: "It is forbidden to interfere with economic contracts between citizens and businesses," end. And when you create several thousand pages of legal acts, there are all the misfortunes sewn in and Europe will pay for these misfortunes, and it will pay dearly - this is the feeling of irresponsibility for the fate of European states and nations. The source of the misfortune is the lack of responsibility in this House that emanates from this House. I hope that the European parliaments of individual countries will come to their senses and that such a disaster will not happen.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I voted against CETA today. CETA negotiations were done behind closed doors, between the unelected Commission and the Canadian Government. On 14 October last year, the regional parliament of Wallonia in Belgium voted to block CETA. However, two weeks later, the Canadian Prime Minister was in Belgium signing the deal with the Commission. We do not fully know what was discussed behind closed doors, as is always the case with the Commission, but we do know that the documents were signed, despite elected representatives saying ‘no’ and the people saying ‘no’. Welcome to democracy, EU style. CETA has not been designed to benefit my constituents. Instead it benefits big business and global cooperation.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! As a member of the Ruhr Area, I am responsible for a region that is still the industrial heart of Germany. We are proud in this region that there is still a high occupation with industry. This high level of industry has proven its worth in the past because it has made the German economy more resilient to crises. In the past, when the decision we had to make - regarding reform of the emissions trading system - I was confronted with great concerns from works councils and unions. I took these concerns very seriously today in my voting behavior, because our aim is to ensure that investments in the future can be planned and thus the security of jobs in our region. It is clear to me that climate protection and the protection of industrial workplaces have to go hand in hand - they don't go against each other - and that's how I acted in the votes today.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, policies on energy and emissions are areas where countries need to work together. Carbon emissions are a real danger and the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) has not worked. This is a good review: it focuses on those industries which produce the most emissions and it has simplified the rules for smaller companies. It will give industry the incentive to modernise and innovate and will help European countries to live up to their international commitments. However, it is important that Europe remains a place in which it is attractive for industry to be located, and we must not simply export our energy-intensive sectors to other parts of the world. The tax on our borders was not the right solution and it is good to see that part of the package rejected. I am pleased that this work has been led by a British negotiator. I wish him and the rest of the team the best of the luck at the next negotiating stage, and I hope that in a post-Brexit world, the UK and EU will continue to work together on areas of mutual interest, like this.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the House today for adopting amendment 149, which gives my country, Greece, the opportunity to benefit from the financing of the Modernization Fund, in the context of the revision of the Air Pollution Scheme Directive. I would especially like to thank the 27 colleagues of the European People's Party, without whom we would not have been able to gather the 38 signatures for the amendment to be decided by the European Parliament today. Thanks to amendment 149, Greece can participate in the Modernization Fund and thus the distortion is corrected, the gradual detoxification from lignite is encouraged in practice and we can, with more comfort, participate in the effort to achieve the goals of tackling climate change. Above all, however, we have the practical solidarity of our colleagues, in response to Euroscepticism and populism and to all those who do not recognize that we are in the European Union to ensure progress, our quality of life, the safety of our citizens, but also our positions. work.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil mé an-sásta leis an tuarascáil seo agus leis na leasuithe ar glacadh leo agus nár glacadh leo inniu. Bhí seans agam labhairt ar an ábhar seo sa Pharlaimint oíche Dé Luain agus na pointí a luaigh mé, glacadh leo inniu. Go háirithe, ní bheimid ag easpórtáil ár n-astaíochtaí de CO2 go tíortha eile, ach ag an am céanna is féidir linn ár spriocanna maidir le COP21 agus COP22 a bhaint amach. Tá sé sin thar a bheith tábhachtach. Freisin, bhí mé sásta gur glacadh le PRODCOM in ionad NACE 4. Beidh sé sin an-tábhachtach don tionscadal déiríochta. Freisin, an meastachán cáilíochta: tá sé íslithe go dtí 0.12 in ionad 0.16, mar a mhol an Coimisiún agus tionscadal SHRINE; an t-ualach a bhí á chur orthu siúd, tá sé sin ardaithe anois. Dá bhrí sin, tá jab an-mhaith déanta ag Duncan, Belet agus De Lange agus na daoine eile a d’oibrigh ar an ábhar seo.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! There is no doubt that the European Union is at a bend. This is evidenced by our yesterday's debate, during which we spent many hours thinking about how the Union should look in the future, how to change it so that it would be better for its citizens. We are talking about the consequences of the financial crisis of the past, about the economic crisis of the countries in the euro area, above all, of course, about the sudden and enormous influx of migrants and refugees to the European Union. We try to answer the question of how to deal with all these threats. It seems to me that we spend the least time in the economy. It seems to me that we devote the least time to entrepreneurs, and yet it is the economy that gives income to the Member States and the European Union itself. It is entrepreneurs who create jobs thanks to which people have a lot to live on and can plan their future. The debate on the ETS confirms that we do not feel the economy and we are not doing everything to make the European economy strong and competitive in the world.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! I would like to take this opportunity to make it clear why I felt it appropriate to vote against Amendments 12 and 84 in the report adopted by the Environment Committee on the reform of the ETS. These amendments contained very dangerous provisions with regard to the functioning of the cement sector and the lime sector. They contained an unacceptable proposal to exclude these sectors from the mechanism of free allocation of emission allowances and to cover both sectors with an unspecified border protection mechanism. I do not have my consent for such actions and experiments. The cement sector and the lime sector are an important source of economic income throughout the European Union. Only in my country, in Poland, about 30,000 people are employed in the sector and providing services to the sector. employees. The proposals of the Environmental Protection Committee would lead to a drastic increase in production costs, a decrease in investments, legal and operational inaccuracy, a decrease in the sector's competitiveness and, consequently, a decrease in employment. That is why I voted against the exclusion of the cement and lime sectors from the free allocation of emission allowances.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, today we voted in favor of an important change for the allowance market. The surplus of allowances on the market logically leads to a significant reduction in their price, recently the price of emission allowances fell below EUR 4. We should not be surprised, then, that the effectiveness of this system is in question. If we want the system to work more efficiently, and I assume we all want that, we must logically try to gradually reduce the number of allowances in circulation in some way, but in proportion to what the industry can bear. That is why I did not support a reduction in the number of allowances by 800 million, as proposed by the ENVI Committee. At the same time, however, I supported maintaining the linear reduction factor at 2.2%, and not increasing it. I am well aware that there is an interest in protecting the environment and streamlining the system of operating allowances against the sustainability of business in some sectors of heavy industry. I think we have found a balanced solution today. That is why I voted in favor.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen! I voted against the ECJ in the shape you proposed today. Why? Because it is inconsistent with the provisions of the treaties, which give the Member States the right to shape their energy mix. By passing the limits of 450 grams per kilowatt hour, the state wants to exclude the possibility of financing the modernization of all coal-fired power plants, so it is not necessary to change the Treaty to take something out of this Treaty. It is possible to deprive a Member State of what is provided and guaranteed by the Treaty in situations such as today. The state frequently invokes the Paris arrangements. So, have you forgotten that the final determination was made in Paris only because decarbonisation was not included in it? Today we are witnessing decarbonization. You have caused that no coal installation will be able to use the funds allocated for modernization, and even most gas installations and, interestingly, only a few gas installations produced in Germany. This is how lobbying is done. Do we want this? Do we want to force some installations at the expense of others, depriving the Member State of providing its citizens with decent living conditions? Because through these regulations, the state will lead to an increase in energy poverty, to the leakage of emissions, and thus to an increase in unemployment in the European Union, and especially in my country, in my homeland, in Poland.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, a key demand of Greece for years has been to be excluded from the gaseous emissions trading system because all countries with a GDP of less than 60% by 2013 received this exemption, such as Bulgaria and Poland. Greece requested this exception. I therefore tabled amendment 162 which set 2014 as the base year, when Greece also had a GDP of less than 60%. This would be an arrangement that would alleviate PPC, which pays EUR 400 million a year in emissions rights and at the same time enable it to proceed until 2030 by continuing to use lignite, which is a key factor in PPC's operation. . But there is a problem: my amendment 162 was not put to the vote because it was considered to be covered by amendment 89, but it has nothing to do with the amendment I tabled, since my own amendment refers to 2014 and the amendment that was voted on refers to 2013. That is why the legislation is responsible here in the Plenary and I consider it unacceptable that the amendment we tabled, amendment 162, was not put to the vote.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, there is the law of unintended consequences, and then there is the law of unintended consequences as it applies to the European Union in its rule-making capacity. Here today we have a policy that says we want to try and reduce emissions and bring low-carbon investments to Europe, but the law of unintended consequences is very clear, in a very small rule that you heard about in this Chamber today from Members from Poland to Ireland to Greece and now the United Kingdom: the border adjustment mechanism will simply drive jobs out of the United Kingdom and across Europe. We have in the British ceramic sector an industry of some 5 000 people. In concrete we are talking about 15 000 jobs and in industries such as our building industry 2.93 million jobs. All of them are under threat from the fact that this regulation will increase their costs and, as the Commission says, potentially close down 20 factories across Europe. It is a bad law and, once again, it has been made here.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted against because I consider these restrictions a scandal. The point is to produce energy in the cheapest possible way, because thanks to this, the consumer benefits, thanks to which jobs are created - because when people spend less on energy, the more money is left to buy something else, and then jobs are created. This is also reflected in Silesia, which I represent here, and in the Ruhr, which is under-represented by Mrs Merkel. Ladies and gentlemen, moreover, I would like to note one fundamental thing. Plants need emissions, they need carbon dioxide, they need heat. Plants grow from carbon dioxide, they grow from heat. Plants need heat and carbon dioxide. Those who do not want carbon dioxide kill plants. I would like to remind you that at the moment, after the victory of Donald Trump, an investigation is already underway and people from the US Ocean and Air Commission will soon go to jail for falsifying the results of the research that led to the decisions made at the Paris Conference. And here, all those in Europe will also go to jail.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we, the Five Star Movement, have always been very critical of ETS as we believe that the system simply does not work. Considering that we had to play this game again, we played it hard, supporting all the amendments to increase the ambition of the system as much as possible, such as ‘rebasing’, meaning adjusting the starting level to actual emissions in order to get rid of the huge surplus pollution permits and adopting the mechanism to include importers of cement and clinker. We do not believe that the inclusion of the maritime sector in the ETS would be a good deal for the environment. Shipping is a sector that has a big margin of improvement in terms of reducing its emissions by pushing the transition to less carbon fossil fuels in a stronger manner, rather than starting a market-based approach again. Nevertheless, the amendments have been rejected, and therefore we voted against the report.  I hope the EU will realise soon that trying to fix the ETS again will not bring any real reduction in emissions and any real investment in clean production. A new and alternative solution could finally be debated and hopefully adopted and implemented. The sooner this happens, the better for the climate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, I voted against the 2016 report on Albania because, firstly, I strongly disagree with any prospect of Albania joining the European Union and, secondly, because the report is unbalanced. The report is biased in favor of Tirana because it does not address key issues, such as the continuing violation of the rights of the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus, the violations committed by the Albanian government, the confiscation of property, the demolition of churches, the persecution. the threats and mainly the movements of populations in the region of Northern Epirus in order to alter the population composition. In addition, Tirana and Albania are promoting a policy of redemption and cultivating the so-called concept of Greater Albania, by claiming territories that belong to Greece. They use the Tsamides to create problems, the Tsamides who are war criminals and have been convicted by Greek courts, the Special Courts of Dosilogos, because they were collaborators of the SS during the German occupation in Greece.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! I welcome the progress made by Bosnia and Herzegovina in the previous year and hope that the country will continue on its path to future EU membership. That is why I also think that the Commission's approval of the application sends the right signal. I would therefore also like to point out again that in a country with 14 parliaments, 3 presidents and 130 ministers, all talk of further federalisation is nonsense that the EU should not be committed to supporting. Bosnia's real problem is that nationalist politicians have been able to continue with impunity for 20 years. They have been allowed to continue, even though there are both means and ways to stop it. So now, after 20 years, more and more people are also starting to think "But maybe we should also pursue that policy, it pays off". If the EU is to help Bosnia with their rapprochement with the Union, we should reduce support for nationalist and separatist forces and instead promote the creation of a functioning rule of law, investing in helping the country become a functioning rule of law. Then many of today's problems will disappear.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Despite the fact that the past year turned out to be relatively good for the European economy and the situation on the labor market, we should not forget about the still unsolved problems. It seems that from the point of view of long-term consequences, the greatest challenge is still high unemployment among young people. Across the European Union, more than 4 million people aged 15-24 are unemployed, and those who do have jobs very often have to work below their qualifications part-time or in the so-called flexible forms of employment. Six and a half million people in this age group, in turn, belong to the NEET category, which often means that it will not be easy to bring them back to the labor market or make them improve their qualifications. Almost 30% of young people are unemployed for more than a year and it will be necessary to undertake particularly intensive activities to activate them professionally. All these data show that there will be huge problems for social security systems in the future, but the need for more action by public and private employment services is absolutely necessary. There is a whole generation growing in Europe, many of which have never worked or will not have a stable job, therefore it is necessary to take appropriate action at all levels, including the European Union. In addition, we, as the European Parliament, must ensure that during the review of the multiannual financial framework, adequate and stable funding is guaranteed for all initiatives aimed at improving the situation of young people on the labor market. This is why I supported the Social and Employment Report in the Annual Growth Survey 2017.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Yana Toom, for the very good report and acceptable proposals. We can see the disproportion in development between the economic and social dimension of the European Union. A big part of the social agenda was left to national states and very often these national states failed to provide adequate social protection for their citizens. From the other side, the European Union developed free movement of people inside the EU and the result of this imbalance is that many citizens move to other EU states with higher salaries and higher social protection. In the last 25 years, my country, Latvia, has lost more than 35% of its population, partly because of low birth rates, but mainly because of migration to other EU countries. Thus places have been created in the EU where population density is very low. The economy cannot develop because of the declining number of workers, taxpayers and customers, the remaining population becomes older, and in these circumstances it is very hard to maintain and develop infrastructure and attract investment. This means the lack of prospects will push more young people to leave the country. Colleagues, we cannot move ahead without a common social policy. We have to break this taboo.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! It is an extremely important document, but on one condition - that the conclusions drawn are then put into practice and put into practice. However, not always and not everything is like that. Due to the short time at my disposal, I will focus only on one issue - particularisms. We are creating a single common market, but unfortunately almost every day we can hear reports confirming that various types of national, regional, industry and sectoral particularisms function in the European Union on the common market. The worst thing about it is that it is so reliable, it could be perceived as such, by the bodies that should take care of fair competition in the common market, including, unfortunately, the European Commission. It is enough to look at the strange and unacceptable lengthiness of international transport matters. Such cases have been going on for years. How can entrepreneurs work steadily, hire their employees, provide them with what they are entitled to, if they do not know every day what will happen to them on the way? We must end this to build the strength of the European economy.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted for the introduction of low-risk biopesticides, that is, the reduction of chemical pesticides, which are part of xenoestrogens, which are not only responsible for numerous diseases, especially cancer, but also seriously pollute the environment, air, water and soil. In addition to the arguments presented during the debate, I would like to pay special attention to the very interesting French-Danish research on the significant reduction of the population of earthworms that function as soil fertilization and oxidation, the number and dimensions of which decrease drastically in soil treated with chemical pesticides, especially fungicides. Although the population of earthworms somewhat reduces the toxicity of these chemical pesticides, earthworms are only one studied example of the degradation of the soil environment by the use of chemicals, therefore it is important to speed up the procedures and research on natural pesticides.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Monika Hohlmeier, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on combating terrorism and replacing Framework Decision 2002/475/ JHA of the Council on Combating Terrorism (COM (2015) 0625 - C8-0386 / 2015 - 2015/0281 (COD) (A8-0228 / 2016).

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I am delighted that we are able to lead the discussion here in the European Parliament today which concerns the fight against terrorism and which focuses on the criminal law directive, the anti-terrorism directive. The attacks of the past few months, the past two years, have alarmed us immensely within the European Union. Many people have been killed, they have been injured, there are many people affected. And for us within the European Union it was not easy to understand that we are now the target in the focus of international terrorism. That is why I am particularly pleased that we have succeeded in meaningfully incorporating the essential questions of the modern and new international standards set by the UN and the FATF in questions of the financing of terrorist networks in this directive. On the one hand, it is about transferring what framework decisions we had on the part of the interior ministers, namely before we, as co-decision-makers, as the European Parliament, could have a say. This had to be translated into a directive. On the other hand, it is also about tackling the new challenges. These new challenges include, for example, the subject of training terrorists, either if you are the organizer, the facilitator, or the financier, or someone who can actually be trained for terrorist attacks. This includes questions of propaganda and also the recruitment of young people, the recruiting of young people for terrorist purposes. There was also a discussion here: What does glorification mean? Glorification - just take a look at the consequences of Bataclan, how it was presented on the Internet by the IS propaganda machine. The glorification the perpetrator and the specific call to follow these perpetrators to commit similar glorious deeds. That means trying to radicalize young people and win them over to criminal and terrorist targets. Another focus is terrorist financing. Another focus is the topic of aiding and abetting terrorist offenses. We have achieved something special in this direction, and I would like to thank my co-rapporteurs, you, dear Caterina Chinnici, as well as my colleague Petr Ježek. I would like to thank my colleague Monica Macovei very much and also, in the critical discussion, Cornelia Ernst and colleague Joly, because we really tried to define the subject of the obligation to exchange information in particular. For the first time, the Member States have committed themselves to exchanging information. At the same time, however, we have strengthened victims' rights. I would particularly like to thank my colleague Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and the Maite, who are particularly committed to ensuring that the rights of the victims are seen. They become victims because terrorists are taking action against our value system, against the state. And that means in consequence: We have to give the victims better rights. This has been achieved in this guideline. We have also succeeded in finding a good balance between security on the one hand, but also the strict observance of fundamental rights, because security without fundamental rights is not possible. Security serves basic rights and must be based on them. For this reason also the explicit listing of the Charter of Fundamental Rights in Article 23, the express listing of the freedom of expression, the freedom of the press. Also the clarification that one may express oneself in a polemical or radical way; that has nothing to do with propaganda, that has nothing to do with glorification, that is simply freedom of expression and nothing else.I think we managed to achieve this balance very well here.I would like to express my thanks to all colleagues who were willing to work so intensively here, to work constructively.I would like to thank the Commission for the excellent cooperation and for the willingness to always contribute with new ideas and support, and I thank the Council, the Slovak Presidency, for their very constructive attitude.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members. Terrorism creates havoc. It takes away lives and leaves those of us who live on scarred forever. In the last 18 months, in particular, we have seen too many attacks and far too many victims. At the same time, the terrorist threat has continued to change and evolve. It is more than ever present and more indiscriminate. That is why I think we should be proud that, together, we have been able to reach this point on this very important piece of legislation. I would like to thank the Council for the work they have done, and, in particular, the Parliament and the rapporteur, Ms Hohlmeier, for their commitment and the effort made to review this counter-terrorism directive. It will contribute greatly to the effective work done by law enforcement authorities and prosecutors in countering the terrorist threat, and this will contribute to making our lives safer, without compromising our values, which are the very same values that the terrorists seek to harm. Fundamental rights are and must remain at the heart of our action. As Ms Hohlmeier said, with this piece of legislation we are also aligning the EU definitions of terrorist offences with the standards agreed under the Council of Europe Convention on Terrorism. Let me highlight very briefly the main elements of the text. First, it will criminalise travel for the purposes of terrorism. Not only will it be a crime to travel from the EU to conflict zones to participate in terrorist activities but also, thanks to the support of people in this House, it will cover those coming to the EU with terrorist intent, including terrorist fighters. Second, an efficient exchange of information is key to combating the terrorist threat. The new rules will strengthen the obligation to exchange information and will make the Member State receiving information responsible for taking appropriate action. Last, but by no means least, the new law will make a real difference for victims. It builds on existing rules, reinforcing in particular the immediate and coordinated nature of the response to victims of a terrorist attack, including legal aid and medical treatment. It also strengthens the rights of cross-border victims, who will get help with information and referrals to relevant services. I am happy to say that this piece of legislation shows that the EU is able to act in a swift and united manner. The political agreement on the directive was reached in less than a year. Now, we need to make sure that implementation follows with the same speed The Commission is ready to support the Member States in this task and will organise transposition workshops in the coming months. Let me conclude, Mr President, by saying it is clear that an effective response to terrorism is a complex and challenging process, which includes the fight against radicalisation as well as the efficient exchange of information between all relevant parties. That is why I would like to reiterate the Commission’s support for the joint statement by the three EU institutions which accompanies the agreement on this directive, expressing commitment to take forward action in all of those fields. I am also glad that, later this afternoon, we are going to have the opportunity to discuss in more depth the crucial issues of information exchange and interoperability.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the terrorist attacks in Europe that we have witnessed in the last years shocked us all, but our grief and our anger gave way to a grim resolve to counter the terrorist threat and to address both the immediate danger of more attacks and the causes of radicalisation that plague our societies. The attacks on our soil were no random attacks. Paris, Nice, Brussels, Berlin, were all targeted because these cities are the very embodiment of what Europe stands for. They were planned to strike the maximum amount of panic into all of us and designed to make us feel unsafe doing the things we always do, and living the lives that we want to live. They failed because fear did not define us, but determination did. And with this report we are going some way in ensuring that our systems adapt to the reality under which we find ourselves and ensure that we remain one step ahead of criminals and terrorists while respecting the values we cherish in Europe. We are coming down harder on those so-called foreign fighters, EU nationals who travel to conflict zones only to return radicalised and recruit more people for their murderous cause. We are pushing forward concrete plans for better cooperation between Member States, and we come down on hate preachers or anyone who incites terrorism. Crucially, the report also lays down provisions that will allow victims of terrorism to receive all and whatever assistance they may require. Finally, allow me to thank the rapporteur for her very excellent work in pushing this file through, and urge you all to vote in favour of the report tomorrow so that we can send the strongest possible signal to our citizens.

name: Caterina Chinnici
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like first of all to thank the rapporteur, my colleague Monika Hohlmeier, and all my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the commitment and constructive spirit shown in the various stages of the interinstitutional negotiation that led to the text we are preparing. to vote. The directive on the fight against terrorism is an important legislative document with which Europe lays the common basis for harmonizing the national laws of the Member States, some of which, unfortunately even recently, have experienced dramatic terrorist attacks. I believe that as Parliament we have managed to make a good contribution to the text, introducing particularly significant measures to combat terrorism in the balance between security and respect for rights, including the mandatory exchange of information, with a view to increasing cooperation. and coordination between judicial police and intelligence forces. Too many times, in fact, in this House we have found ourselves discussing the fact that a timely exchange of information could perhaps have prevented dramatic attacks. The directive then gives the Member States some regulatory instruments aimed at combating the financing of terrorism, but also at breaking the growing relationship of collaboration between criminal groups and terrorist formations. I am thinking of the confiscation or punishment of certain crimes connected with terrorist activity such as the production of false documents or the trafficking of cultural goods. However, we still have to work towards a swift approval of further measures to counter terrorist financing, such as the revision of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Last but not least, I want to mention the provisions dedicated to the protection and support of the victims of terrorism and I am satisfied with the agreement reached, which places members medical and psychological assistance and legal support for those who have suffered an attack aimed at destabilizing a state or a government.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, after the shock and tears after the terrorist attacks, after the death, we did what we had to do: we gathered and worked on a package against terrorism, a package of several laws that will be largely voted on in this session. We want to defend our values, we want to defend our lifestyle, we do not want to change it, but we must defend ourselves against those who want to destroy our values ​​and lifestyle and the whole history of civilization and the civilization we have reached today. . This new directive, the Counter-Terrorism Directive, punishes those who finance, organize or facilitate travel to areas where the Islamic State operates. It also punishes those who organize training for fighters or finance terrorist acts. Incitement to terrorism and public distribution of messages, including messages glorifying terrorist acts, will now be defined as terrorist activities. So we will have new crimes in terms of terrorist activities, which will have to be transposed into the law of the Member States. The threat of terrorism is not a momentary issue, but a long-term one. It is undeniable that we need a united response to protect ourselves and resist the danger of terrorism together. First of all, we need to talk about the right to life. The right to life is the first right to be protected in this world because without the right to life there is no other right and, therefore, the real threat comes from those who seek to destroy the right to life. I thank Monika Holhmeier for leading the work on this report and I congratulate her once again and I urge everyone to vote on this report.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, while the terrorist threat in Europe remains at a critical level and as ISIS loses ground in the Middle East, this threat and the one posed by their returning foreign fighters is likely to persist. Whereas responsibility for security lies primarily with Member States, recent terrorist attacks in Europe have shown that no country can manage on its own.  We need to adapt our counterterrorism measures to this reality and add a truly European approach. 82% of Europeans want Europe to do more to combat terrorism and 69% consider its current measures to be insufficient. I believe that this new directive is part of our response to their demands. It will strengthen the EU’s arsenal against terrorism by criminalising acts such as receiving training for terrorism or travelling for terrorist purposes, while, of course, preserving fundamental rights and freedoms. Giving Member States harmonised judicial tools should also facilitate their cooperation. This is key for me and my group, and we will not give up on this.  I would like to thank the rapporteur, Monika Hohlmeier, the shadows, the Commissioner, his team and and the Slovak Presidency. Well done, well done.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! In Hungary, Ahmed, a Syrian, was recently sentenced to ten years in prison for participating in protests against the closing of the border. He was condemned as a terrorist because the Hungarian anti-terrorist laws allow it. Only he's not a terrorist - he demonstrated. These laws have already been criticized several times before the European Court of Human Rights because of their unclear, far too broad definitions. I ask you: are we changing anything substantial about it with the directive? No i don't believe The definition of terrorism in the directive remains blurred. On the contrary, one has to ask how safely demonstrators - those who think differently - can still exercise their rights. The prosecution of the glorification of terrorism is also a noble goal and I can understand that. But the connection to a real terrorist act is far too weak. Regarding the paragraph on travel for criminal purposes: I can understand you, I know what is meant. But we are really on thin ice because the difference between a criminal and a lawful act lies solely in the intent to terrorize, and that is difficult to determine. Of course, terror must be fought. We see it that way too. We need to deal with it in a complex manner. It starts with proper police and judicial training. Better coordination of the authorities, serious dropout and victim protection programs, prevention and education from school. Because neither the problems nor the solutions lie in criminal law alone. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Do you know how many passports this Ahmed had? Seven.

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- That's not the question.You have to judge someone who throws stones, for example, for what he does.That's not even the question, you're welcome to talk about it.My question was another one that needs to be answered.Is this man a terrorist?And then I say: no.But Hungarian law allows it because the definition of terrorism is incredibly broad.As I said, the Tribunal has criticized this several times.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ahmed, whose case has just been mentioned by my colleague, has therefore been prosecuted for allegedly terrorist reasons. Why? Because he was simply trying to ease tensions between police and migrants at the border by telling everyone to back off using a megaphone. Did he seek to unduly coerce the Hungarian government? Is this terrorism? In France, an Internet user who had the bad taste to baptize his wifi access "Daech 21" was sentenced to three months in prison for apologizing for terrorism. Is this really the apology for terrorism? Let’s not be fooled. Anti-terrorism laws are routinely abused or used for other purposes in violation of our rights and freedoms. There are already too many examples. We don't want the list to grow any further. The criminal harmonization of anti-terrorism laws at European level is obviously a laudable and necessary objective, but the harmonization must be precise in order to limit the interpretations which could infringe our rights and freedoms. Unfortunately, this directive contains too many vague concepts. In the current climate, Europe cannot afford to leave loopholes that governments can so easily abuse. This directive criminalizes indirect provocation to terrorism when no one knows what this vague notion covers and the risks to freedom of expression and information are real. The definition of "terrorist offense" is also problematic because it includes, for example, acts that may cause major economic loss. Governments will, as we well know, have no qualms about using this broad definition to muzzle acts of civil and environmental disobedience that go against their interests. Finally, the added value of the criminalization of travel has not been demonstrated.An individual suspected of terrorism may already be arrested because of this suspicion.There is no need to criminalize travel as such.The risk that this provision will be misused and misused in a discriminatory manner is itself real.Rather than increasing the number of blurred and dangerous grounds for criminalization, we should focus on the essential: the automatic and compulsory exchange of information and greater cooperation between Member States.All the recent attacks have revealed gaping flaws in this area.What are we waiting for to take measures that have real added value in the fight against terrorism?The hypocrisy of Member States in the fight against terrorism is blatant.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the terrorism we are fighting today acts with unprecedented operational, communication and financing methods. It represents an internal threat that manifests itself through individual actors or even through groups that easily move between the borders of the Member States. Thinking that it can be defeated with national policies alone is illusory. In order to give a European response to a transnational phenomenon and an imminent danger, we have tried to reconcile the need to strengthen measures to combat terrorism with the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms. On the one hand, we have therefore asked for greater cooperation between the Member States, certain that a better exchange of information and compulsory cooperation between the judicial authorities represent an effective measure to combat the activity of terrorist groups. On the other hand, as Movimento 5 Stelle, we have presented amendments aimed at better defining the types of offense, for example keeping the basic principle of materiality firm and respecting the Latin phrase cogitationis poenam nemo patitur. We have defended freedom of expression on the Internet and on social media, demanding that any repressive intervention on the network should be subject to the control of the judicial authority. The balance between freedom and security of eternal discussion is therefore fundamental to the rule of law. The fight against terrorism and in general the protection of security must not represent the picklock to limit or worse still repress fundamental rights, but must always be functional to the protection of individual rights and freedoms. As highlighted in the report on the fight against organized crime, of which I was rapporteur, it is finally necessary to complete the European legal framework with a global approach, thus also addressing the narrow and worrying interconnection between terrorism and organized crime, which often collaborate and merge to gain mutual benefits, often of an economic nature.

name: Janice Atkinson
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, I am not going to pretend to Sir Julian that it is easy, but the EU does not actually help itself. There are some simple steps that we can take. First, we close our borders and we have to abandon Schengen. Unpalatable as it is in here, that is the only way to stop the spread of terrorism. The nation states have to pay their fair share into NATO, as you have been told by Mr Trump. Nation states have to take responsibility for their own borders, not Guy Verhofstadt’s idiotic idea of a barmy EU army. Let us join Trump in banning travel from those states which are exporting hate and terrorism. We have got to build our own walls. Let us tear up the passports of those who are travelling to train as terrorists. They will not be stateless. It is not against international law. They will be citizens of ISIS. That is what they want. At home what we can do – and I suggest you do it in your own states as well – is to increase the recruitment of the police force, the armed services, prison officers; border control is essential, as are our intelligence services.
