Let us protect our citizens, because the EU’s policies put us in danger.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question.- I would like to point out something to the colleague.You say here: "We cannot deal with Guy Verhofstadt's insane idea for a European army."I would like to tell you that the Eurobarometer is a survey of Members of the European Parliament, of all citizens of Europe, and that it shows very clearly that 80% of our citizens want Europe to work on European defense.So the idea isn't that crazy.I would also like to point out to you that if you look at the defense spending of the 28 Member States, you will find that we spend half of America with a return of only 15 percent.May I ask you: are you not in favor of saving, so that we pool all those resources and the output is better and thus better protect our European citizens?

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF)
text: blue-card answer. – Well actually, as a Thatcherite and Reaganite conservative, yes, I do want to conserve money – but money is being spent, wrongly, especially the waste that goes on in this place. We should be reinforcing our borders. That is the only way we can do it, and actually investing in our own border-force people and across that. And there was a survey by the Chatham House institute back in the UK that said that 80% of your citizens do not want Muslim migration. So you’re not listening, are you? And who is it who is causing all the terrorism? It is the basis of ISIS, it is Muslim terrorism. It is Islam.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, my constituency has long been plagued by the scourge of terrorism. Successful attacks are now thankfully irregular and generally isolated. Nevertheless, we must maintain vigilance and remember the victims. The murderous campaign of the IRA left much hurt and devastation, many empty chairs. The people of Northern Ireland know and understand the need to stand firmly with our European neighbours against the scourge of terrorism. We must never allow terrorists to control the narrative, indulge their revisionism or glorify their deeds to radicalise a new generation. We have some in Northern Ireland who propagate such revisionism. They seek to revise history to justify their evil deeds. Instead, we must give victims a voice. They require protection, specialist support to respond to their specific needs. And as we assist victims, so too experience has taught us to guard against complacency.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the new European legislation is more necessary than ever, not because terrorism came to Europe to stay but because terrorism is evolving to the detriment of the European idea and of European citizens and especially of future generations. Congratulations to Monika Hohlmeier and her colleagues for drafting an up-to-date and balanced piece of legislation criminalizing participatory action, organization, training, travel for terrorist purposes and terrorist financing. Above all, we must realize that this is the first text in which the actions of terrorists are updated in terms of criminal depravity, on the one hand, and on the other, the victims and their families are protected, who have not yet received the European umbrella of protection. In addition, jurisdiction, especially for the offense of education, is of great importance. It is important that this European legislation is promoted and advertised because terrorism does not discriminate between Member States and concerns us all.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: -  Mister President! International terrorism is one of the greatest threats of our time, it brings endless suffering to those affected. A few weeks ago we were able to see for ourselves here in this house when we heard the testimonials of the Yezidi Sakharov Prize winner. International terrorism seeks above all to destroy the very foundations of our free society. I fear that this threatening scenario will be with us for a long time. International terrorism cannot be tackled with national methods alone. Something that is not national in character - ISIS - sees itself as a stateless actor - something it is not. It must therefore first and foremost be combated by the international community. Security Council resolution 2178 provides a very good definition framework and obliges states to criminalize actual or intended travel to other countries in the context of terrorist activities, as well as propaganda and training. It is therefore very important that we, the Union, finally have an appropriate legal framework with this directive on combating terrorism. The previous framework decision was not sufficient for this and the legal situation in the individual member states varied widely. The directive is a very important step. It allows the police and judicial authorities to act in a coordinated and systematic manner. But we shouldn't feel safe and believe that this will solve the problem. Rapid implementation is required, accompanying measures, deradicalization work and work in prisons need to be improved, and above all law enforcement needs to be intensified, not just among those returning. Above all, there is also a need for more independent cooperation in the regions of origin where the crimes are committed Jurisprudence.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: - Tomorrow the European Parliament will normally approve a new anti-terrorism directive. The aim is to arrive at common definitions for terrorist offenses, which are also immediately linked to minimum sentences. The terrorist motive is now considered an aggravating circumstance. Online hate messages from IS sympathizers, for example, will now have to be prosecuted and taken offline all over the EU. Hacking of critical infrastructure, travel and recruitment for terrorist reasons is also prohibited. At the same time, attention is paid to the victims. The directive stipulates that Member States must take concrete measures to provide better medical, psychological and legal assistance to victims of terrorism and / or their families. Efficient help, a fast legal settlement of claims and putting an end to the administrative agony in order to be recognized as a terrorist victim, that is the goal. After the attacks in Brussels on 22 March last year, it turned out that there was still a lot of room for improvement in that area in my country. That is why N-VA is satisfied with the proposal.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! We are currently witnessing how civil rights are being attacked and, in some cases, dismantled at the national level, in the panic attempt to get the terrorist threat under control. It almost seems to me that the same thing is now happening at EU level. We are in the process of passing a law without considering its long-term impact on fundamental rights. A law that criminalizes actions that usually have no direct connection with terrorism in advance. In this way we create the basis for preventive legislation in criminal law and the endangerment of the presumption of innocence. The example of Ahmed H. from November 2016, a resident of Cyprus who was sentenced to ten years in prison in Hungary for an alleged act of terrorism, has already been mentioned. It proves that the term terror is definitely being interpreted incorrectly and far too broadly here. Our goal must be to strike a balance between the legitimate desire for security and the desire to protect fundamental rights and freedom. If there is any doubt about security, it certainly cannot be the solution. As legislators, we have a moral obligation not to pass laws on the basis of scaremongering, because that certainly does not create trust.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, as someone who has spent decades involved in conflict resolution, I am disappointed at the security-driven approach that is contained in this directive. In order to deal with conflict we have to address the causes of conflict. What is the political context? What is the social and economic context? What avenues exist to address grievances and pursue legitimate political objectives? Not all situations are the same and the right to assist is valid in certain circumstances. But let us be clear. IS murder indiscriminately. They oppress and abuse people of all faiths and none. So processes of conflict resolution will not apply in all situations. However, increased repression is more likely to fuel further acts of violence than to reduce them. And limiting civil rights and freedom of expression will not make society safer. According to the European Parliament’s research services, all of the stakeholders that followed this legislative file have expressed serious concerns about this directive, and they should be listened to. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. You talk about IS murdering indiscriminately. Would you agree with me that the IRA also murdered indiscriminately? To the families of those who died at Kingsmill and the family of Edgar Graham, who is today in the news in a controversy because the law lecturer in Queens University refused to condemn that murder, would you also agree that those were indiscriminate acts?

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Diane, for that question. I think what is important for all of us who have come from a situation where we are emerging from conflict is to show and demonstrate in a parliament like this that building peace is more important than fighting a war. We, you and I, could trade statistics of incidents and tragedies, and that, of course, would keep us all looking backwards. There are lots of families, and you have mentioned some here today, who, without doubt, deserve the kind of justice that they are seeking. This week I had three families over here in this Parliament – the brother of Pat Finucane and the daughter of a woman who was murdered by the British state, by British soldiers, and a son whose father had been killed, respectively 42 and 46 years ago. These people are just looking for a basic inquest. They are looking for the Stormont House agreement to be taken forward. I know the Commissioner is very aware of the work that we have done thus far, and we would hope that he and others would support the kind of conflict resolution that we are involved in.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What is good about this directive is obvious. We are harmonizing the criminal offenses in the area of ​​combating terrorism, we are creating better protection for the victims of attacks and we are ensuring that the exchange of information - and above all the fight against the financing of terrorism - are improved. But this guideline goes too far in the end. It becomes problematic where we create new criminal offenses that have not yet existed in many EU countries. Which are unclear, for example when it comes to travel within the European Union or when it comes to the fact that the possibility of significant economic damage already opens up the definition of terrorism. The real problem is that we are not really pursuing the terrorist offenses that are already in existence. So instead of creating new facts, we should concentrate on improving cooperation in Europe, for example through investigation teams at Europol and better equipping police officers to prosecute these crimes. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I just wanted to ask my colleague: What do new criminal offenses mean here?Do you really want someone in Syria to be trained in a terror camp, to be able to commit crimes there, to be able to return here and prepare an attack without us arresting the person before the attack, bringing them to justice and then the judgesjudge how this person is to be judged?

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you for the question, Monika!The problem is not that we are not already prosecuting crimes in the area of preparing for terrorist attacks, for example when someone travels to a terror camp and returns with the intention of carrying out an attack.That is already a criminal offense today.The problem here is that even travel within the European Union is criminalized and, to my knowledge, there are no such terror camps within the European Union.In my opinion, one simply has to say, in keeping with proportionality: Freedom of travel within the European Union should not be questioned in such a way.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: - Mr President! The terrorist attacks have become so numerous that we hardly reflect on them anymore and the media has bought the image that each act is completely independent and has nothing to do with the other. It is believed that it is lonely lunatics who perform these deeds. The proposal we are debating today is good in the sense that it puts pressure on countries to tackle problems with jihadist travel and parts of society that become radicalized and more. This is good at a time when we will see more attacks on European soil, especially now that the Islamic State is losing ground in Syria and Iraq. Another proposal which claims to fight terrorism but which in fact only affects law-abiding citizens is the proposed amendments to the EU Weapons Directive. In a desperate way, the EU attacks honest hunters, snipers and weapons collectors. The entire civil defense is set in motion because the possibility of owning and transporting certain weapons becomes indirectly illegal. In addition, the proposal is so idiotically written that even the leading experts in the field cannot explain how the European Commission has thought in this case. The Commission introduces new terms and shows that they do not even have a basic understanding of how these weapons work and what a magazine is and so on. The Commission is clearly showing here that it intends to combat legal weapons, which are almost never used in mass shootings, instead of tackling a problem of smuggling illegal weapons, especially from Slovakia, which has been the source of several of them. Should Swedish law-abiding citizens suffer just because the EU wants open borders at all costs? What has Anders Ygeman actually said in the Council when this proposal has been discussed? The questions are many and I start looking for the answers. From next week, I will visit the hunters and weapons collectors concerned to find out how it is.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr. President, Islamist terrorism is a barbarism that must be fought without weakness. That’s why I endorse the Hohlmeier report, which tries to tackle it, despite all its shortcomings recalled just now by Mrs Winberg. However, I express two regrets. The first is that Islamist terrorism took advantage of the porosity of the European Union's external borders, that is, of the terrible failure of the Schengen system. The French are in a good position to know this, as the Bataclan terrorists have almost all come from abroad. However, the report refuses to recognize this evidence. The second regret is that the report never uses the word "Islamist". He is talking about terrorism in general, when it is indeed Islamist terrorism in question. I condemn this cowardice because, as Albert Camus said, "to name things wrongly is to add to the unhappiness of the world".

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the various forms of terrorism, in general and Islamic terrorism in particular, are currently the greatest real threat to the security of the peoples of the countries of the European Union. Although the responsibility for tackling terrorism lies with the states, its effective fight is nevertheless achieved through a comprehensive cooperation of all the countries of the world and Europe in all areas but especially in the legal, social and prosecution fields. But whatever cooperation is achieved between the police and intelligence services of the countries, whatever information is exchanged between them, whatever legal coverage is provided in their repressive activities, these are later steps. The proper education of young people must be preceded so that they are not vulnerable to the propaganda of terrorism, and in particular of Islam. proper control of external borders. This mission must be entrusted to the security forces and the armed forces of each country ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I wanted to start by expressing my doubt that Albert Camus would be delighted by the appropriation that is wrongly made of him by the National Front in this forum. I would still like to tell the representative of the National Front and the colleague of I do not know which British party, probably a little off the mark, to the right, who spoke before, that it is not borders the problem because those who carry out attacks in the middle of Europe were born here, were radicalized here, may have traveled outside of Europe and returned. Ultimately, it was our citizens who made a mistake in their course. I make no apologies to them and I would like them to be condemned for it, once apprehended. But I refuse and I denounce this stupid, fundamentally stupid attitude of telling Europeans that misery comes from outside. Poverty is produced in our poorly governed suburbs, whether in France, Belgium, the Netherlands or the United Kingdom. Misery, radicalization in Europe is a reality. Radicalization in our prisons is a reality. Radicalization in our failing social structures is a reality. Our problem is that we often preach the right things but struggle to apply them. Therefore, I welcome all the new elements contained in the legislation presented by Mrs Hohlmeier, but I would also like us to place much more emphasis on the rigorous strengthening of what already exists. (The speaker declined a "blue card" question from Georgios Epitideios)

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: - President! In the wake of the terrorist attacks of recent years, citizens in Europe - I think everywhere - rightly fear their security and rightly expect their governments to protect them from terrorists. However, we can only do this if we are willing to face the facts. That is why we need to clearly distance ourselves from the vile political campaign of the European far right, which assumes direct links between refugees, migration and terrorism. They arouse fear and arouse hatred. We know that the horrific assassinations of recent years, as Mr Engel has just pointed out before me, were committed by young people born here in Europe, socialized here, who were pushed to the margins of society, who could not find prosperity in European society. Our task is to find the antidote to radicalization. And in this, the increasingly severe punishments, the senseless rigor, the observation and eavesdropping of everyone, the confinement and seclusion will not help! Rather, we need to take decisive action on the cooperation of intelligence services. That we are trying to disrupt and eliminate the organizations of radical Islamic circles with clear and targeted observations. But most importantly, we need to take decisive and clear steps towards social integration and an inclusive society so that second- and third-generation immigrants find their future here, in these liberal democracies, and not in radical Islam.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, when we are talking about combating terrorism,  we must pay tribute to the men and women of the armed forces and the police, who have given service and made sacrifices in tackling the terrorist threats. During the decades of terrorism in Northern Ireland, the police and the army sought to prevent terrorists from plunging my region into anarchy and civil war, and now we have a witch—hunt against elderly former soldiers who are being questioned and brought before the courts in connection with events that happened more than 40 years ago. Meanwhile, the 200 IRA terrorist suspects have been getting letters of comfort and others have received royal pardons. There are some people, including in this Parliament, who are trying to rewrite the history of Northern Ireland’s past. I sincerely hope we do not let them do it. We have had many atrocities and I could go on and deliver them at great length from Warrenpoint to Tullyvallen to Harrods to Warrington and all over the United Kingdom.  Let me make it very clear: all terrorism is wrong and cannot be condoned, nor can it ever be justified by anyone. We must keep a sense of proportion and ensure that, in investigating the past, we do not focus disproportionately on the actions of those who sought to keep our community safe and who suffered grievously in the process. I would urge all Members not to be taken in by the cynical self-serving attempts to whitewash the crimes of history. And yes, Mrs Hohlmeier, you are so right. The victims are the most important, not the victim—makers.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, in effect, the victims are the most important thing, and Albert Camus said: "In the face of evil, in the face of death, man demands justice from the depths of himself." This is also what this Directive is about. The updating of the Directive was necessary because globalized terrorism requires a harmonization, at least European, of criminal offenses, with justice, without excesses. There is no other way to avoid impunity, and not all countries were prepared. There are two "buts", however, to the result after the tripartite dialogue - although I must thank the rapporteur and the collaborators for the effort they have made -: one, the exchange of information, which has been limited to judicial exchange, and not police ; and two, the innocent, the victims of terrorism, who will continue to have very different rights and treatments —in many cases, very deficient— according to their nationality, even in the face of the same attack. Some believe that victims do not need their own specific directive; I think so. Not because crimes are more serious, but because terrorists use our lives to condition the entire society, and each new attack opens the wounds of previous victims. Both will have to change at some point.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I believe it is important that we stress the importance of education, and engagement with those vulnerable to radicalisation, in combating terrorism. Nothing can justify extremism, but we must acknowledge that it does not arise in a vacuum. Narratives of grievances, actual or perceived injustice, promised empowerment and sweeping change become attractive where human rights are being violated, good governance is being ignored and aspirations are being crushed.  Violent extremists have been able to recruit over 30 000 foreign fighters from over 100 nations to travel to Syria, Iraq, Libya, Yemen and Afghanistan, according to the UN Secretary-General. Some of them will no doubt be horrified by what they see and will be anxious to put those experiences behind them, but others have already returned to their home countries to spread hatred, intolerance and violence in their own communities.  We will not be successful in combating terrorism unless we can harness the idealism, creativity and energy of young people and others who feel disenfranchised. Young people must be viewed as an asset and must be empowered to make a constructive contribution to the political and economic development of their societies and nations. We must offer them a positive vision in their future, together with a genuine chance to realise their aspirations and their potential.  The same applies to those states we have neglected, whether economically or politically. Our security services can only do so much to protect us, and as we are constantly told, the terrorists only have to get lucky once. We need to change hearts and minds, and while strengthening legal definitions and formalising cooperation might help, ultimately we need to successfully challenge the whole ideology behind the extremist narrative.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this directive discovers hot water, speaks to us of terrorism and does not dare to call it by its name: Islamist terrorism! What courage does it take? I miss what you have! Someone says that we shouldn't talk about borders and attacks my colleague, who spoke very well of them, rightly so. It is true, they come from the suburbs, but then they flee to Italy from Germany or after the Bataclan, calm as peaceful tourists that no one controls since there are no more borders. Lebreton is right then! Free movement for everyone, even for those who make propaganda, like the Muslim Brothers who even infiltrate governments and act as consultants to our governments. You want free movement for everyone, but not for hunters. The weapons of the hunters are very dangerous, not those of the lone wolves, not those of the jihadists. There are no concrete measures against the jihadists. How do you look for them? There is no proposal for specialized sections of the judiciary that are in direct relationship with the police and services to make effective sentences. Let me conclude, dear President, we must have the courage to take serious measures. Let us remember the victims, of whom you do not think, who today suffer in hospitals and re-education centers. Nobody helps them. Even the Italian victims of Nice, abandoned by Europe and Italy, a shame!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, your methods of fighting terrorism are like putting oil on fire. Listen: first, we must introduce the death penalty. We cannot win when they can kill us and we cannot kill them. Some terrorists are not ready to die, for example those who killed at Charlie Hebdo. Second, every man should have a gun. It will not help in most cases, but in some it will. Three, no social benefits to immigrants. They must work, and work hard, like the American immigrants in the nineteenth century, for small money. They must not have strange thoughts in their minds: they must work and not think about something. Four, no wall will stop terrorists: we must agree that there will be terrorism and live with it. Far more people die in car accidents than through terrorism and we do not care, or we do not get hysterical about it. And the last thing: stop the journalists. What the terrorists want is to be famous and to spread hysteria in society. The journalists should cut off the terrorists: no photographs; no interviews with terrorists. The terrorists should be hanged the next day, there should be no names and they should be buried under the pigsty. This will minimise terrorism. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question.- I don't know whether to give Mr. Korwin-Mikke more time, but I do want to remind him of one thing.To combat terrorism, as to combat any type of crime, you have to base yourself on four actions, on four "Ps": you have to prevent, you have to persecute, you have to protect and you have to penalize —not journalists, by the waynot to journalists.We must prevent through intelligence, cooperation, and we have a European Center for the Fight against Terrorism which is key, it is an essential platform to develop European intelligence.Don't you think that prosecuting requires a joint police and judicial force?Don't you think that to protect the victims, the vulnerable people, the cooperation of the institutions is necessary?And that, to penalize, do you need directives that truly punish those who commit crimes?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – One justice and one hangman is enough.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, excuse me, but here we are discussing human rights and an excellent directive that protects them.Is it possible that you are not blocking a speaker who is speaking in continual violation of human rights?At least say a word!

name: President. –
text: As I understand it, this was a blue card to me, not to Mr Korwin—Mikke. Mr Korwin-Mikke, do you consider that you answered Ms Becerra Basterrechea?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – I have one right: to be protected by the state and not by the inefficient bureaucracy that cannot help.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, first of all let me thank Mrs Hohlmeier and her team for their excellent work. That directive does not really cover everything, but I think that it is becoming more and more topical and that many of the topics we wanted to have in the directive are mentioned in it. Although the directive responds in a way to the attacks in Paris, I think it has become increasingly relevant after the attacks in Berlin. That is why I am glad that many of you, dear colleagues, also mention the rights of victims of crime here. Because victims of crime and victims of terrorism have often been forgotten. Last year, Europol's fears were confirmed, concluding that it was very reasonable to expect a religious-inspired terrorist group to launch a terrorist attack again somewhere in Europe. And this fear persists. It is therefore necessary that we fight terrorism intensively and prevent similar attacks. There are now several thousand European Union citizens in Europe, not to mention outside the European Union, who are suspected of being involved in the fighting in Iraq and Syria. However, no one is able to determine the exact number. Whether they are returning foreign fighters or lone wolves, the European Union must be able to deal with these people adequately. And it will only deal with them if we have a unified criminal law in these matters.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, the attacks that we have known in recent years have brought horror, but they also reaffirmed the firmness of our condemnations. With this new directive, we are once again showing our determination to fight terrorism. This text defines the acts which must be criminalized, improves the protection of victims and strengthens the exchange of information on criminal investigations. These three axes are fundamental and - I hope - shared. Within the European Parliament, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) takes an active part in the fight against terrorism. In its action, we will note the strengthening of the protection of our external borders, the harmonization of criminalization between the Member States, the fight against the financing of terrorism and organized crime, or the cooperation between States and with the agencies. European. The European Parliament carries out this work with the aim of ensuring a balance between security and the protection of fundamental freedoms. If I want to stress the reality of this work today, it is because I was surprised to learn that we would need a new commission specific to the fight against terrorism. Its objectives are, of course, still unclear: it would be to highlight the shortcomings of the national authorities whose countries were affected by the attacks. Is! But what are we trying to do? What do we want to prove? Point out those responsible? Assess whether it is Europe's fault, Schengen's or our neighbor's fault? Is it about doing the same investigative work as national deputies in France, Belgium, or even Germany? Is it a question of taking positions other than those expressed by LIBE, which is a competent and experienced parliamentary committee, or of allowing the exploitation of attacks for political ends to flourish? this election year in several European states?You will understand, this hypothesis of a special commission or commission of inquiry strikes me as a controversy in a field that especially deserves to be avoided.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!I propose a serious debate - the seriousness of the situation is really important.Our constituents expect serious debates from us, serious solutions, and not discussions that I think even insult the seriousness of our Parliament.These proposed solutions are a step forward.But it is also not that they are not subject to criticism.I think that at the moment from the point of view of the average Pole, German, French, British, Czech or Danish, the issue of security in the context of terrorism is an absolutely fundamental issue and the voter I represent here is ready to increase the powers of various institutions that deal with security,at the expense of his safety.We must remember this.Let us try to meet these expectations.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I am delighted that tomorrow, after the vote, we can have a consolidated arsenal to fight together and in as harmonized a way as possible against terrorism. Through this text, the Member States will finally adapt their national legislation on terrorist offenses since in this area, as everyone has said more or less positively, there are no borders while there are brakes. between the different criminal law codes of the Member States. This text is a real progress which takes into account new forms of terrorism, new modus operandi, the phenomenon of foreign fighters, travel for terrorist purposes, propaganda, provocation, recruitment on the internet, as well as the families of the victims. . This is progress that will enable all judicial authorities to apprehend this scourge more effectively and bring the perpetrators to justice. I also welcome the strengthening of the mechanism for the exchange of information between the judicial authorities, although I regret, in conclusion, that the Member States have not sufficiently supported our proposal for a mandatory exchange between the authorities. When will States understand that it is not by carefully guarding this type of data that we will succeed tomorrow in responding, together, to the global and colossal challenges we face?

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, you are breaking down the dikes and you are surprised that there is flooding. How can you be surprised by the increase in terrorist acts when you constantly encourage the free movement of goods and people, and therefore of weapons and terrorists? You actually keep illustrating the famous Chinese proverb: "When the sage points to the moon, the fool looks at the finger". Not only do you remain focused on the consequences but, moreover, you go after those who, like us, point out the real causes of terrorism in Europe. You don’t see them because you don’t want to see them, otherwise you would have to admit the terrible mistakes that you and your friends, predecessors, and yourself made in opening the floodgates on immigration. In fact, well-meaning people insist on denying the obvious link between immigration and terrorism. However, I said it a few days ago, and I repeat it today, in this Chamber: all the terrorists who have struck France in the last twenty years are immigrants or of immigrant origin. There are of course other factors, but if you continue to refuse to consider this fundamental first cause of massive and uncontrolled immigration, then you condemn our people to suffer more and more Islamist attacks on our soil.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - President! Their personal safety is paramount. If there are doubts about the inability of the holder of legitimate violence - the state - to maintain order and security, it creates insecurity and chaos in other areas of life as well. The growing intertwining of terrorism and organized crime means that we face systemic threats: it is an old truth that law enforcement needs to keep pace with crime. Therefore, we must act against terrorism by all possible means, with the same organization, by which terrorists and the networks that support them break into the lives of our citizens. We cannot tolerate the training of these people in our area, their radicalization and their subsequent travel to a conflict area from which they can easily return. We need to rethink our notions of aiding and abetting and pay close attention to acts committed in cyberspace. Widespread sharing of intelligence presupposes a high level of trust between Member States, but it is a necessary step. We face the same threats, so our action can only be coordinated. One of the best things about today's Europe is that we can actually travel between Member States without obstacles. This is exploited by terrorists, of course, but the right response is effective prevention and tough action, not restoring borders and closing in. If we choose this, they have already won.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - This directive, prompted by the November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris, aims to harmonize criminal law, improve the exchange of information and prevent further terrorist attacks. Parliament has managed to improve several provisions, alerting to the danger of hot responses, which fall outside a global strategy to combat radicalization. The directive has three main problems. First, criminal offenses not properly defined, leaving the door open to interpretations that may disproportionately restrict fundamental rights. Combating terrorism on platforms such as the Internet must be done in an intelligent and technically effective way, which is very different from criminalizing the use of the Internet itself. Serious is also the Commission, which promises better legislation, once again waived the impact assessment. Third, the foreign fighters terminology is wrong. The overwhelming majority of terrorists who attacked in Europe are Europeans, disintegrated but born and raised here; they did not need to travel abroad. Fundamental to combating terrorism is not in this nor in any directive. It demands that governments, our governments, abandon neoliberal authoritarian policies, that evade sources to equip and train police and law enforcement, that create ghettos and segregation in our cities, that turn prisons into centers of radicalization instead of rehabilitation. And these same governments must stop importing Wahhabite fundamentalist propagandists into European mosques. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the “blue card” procedure, pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Nobody doubts the necessity to fight terrorism. Terrorism is like a disease, it spreads around, but it overcomes and oversteps the boundaries of the European Union. The European Union is bound to cooperate with neighbouring countries, but the diverse descriptions of terrorism sometimes from third countries is used as a pretext for political prosecution. Colleague, would you agree that the European Union as such and Member States have to be very vigorous, even selective, in cooperating with some neighbouring countries when it comes to the fight against terrorism in order to protect the political freedoms of citizens and respect freedoms as such?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I know that several anti-democratic, autocratic governments are using the excuse of terrorism, and the obsession with the fight against terrorism, to actually suppress basic freedoms and suppress legitimate criticism and dissent. We cannot align ourselves with that and that is also why we need to be very critical about what is happening inside the EU and that is why I am also critical about some of the solutions that are in this Directive that, in my view, put in question disproportionately, or may put in question disproportionately, the fundamental rights of the European citizens themselves.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! The text on combating terrorism proposed by the Commission states that the terrorist threat has grown and changed rapidly in recent years, and one amendment adds that the fight against terrorism is primarily the responsibility of the Member States. It is also proposed to coordinate actions against terrorists at the EU level in the face of the terrorist attacks reported in Europe in 2015 and 2016. Let me remind you that so far the European Union has remained passive and condemned the cooperation of the Member States with the United States in the area of ​​combating terrorism. An example is the curious CIA committee on prisons, which operated during the sixth term of the European Parliament. As you can see, only the immediate threat to the lives of our citizens by terrorist attacks prompts us to change. Better late than never. I agree with the European Union's Counter-Terrorism Coordinator that an effective response requires a holistic approach and long-term efforts.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I will speak here with pride about what we now have about the decision. I recognize that the anti-terrorism directive is at the heart of what can shape Europe's security in the future. I am glad that the Commission and Parliament are clearly pulling together here. I congratulate all members of the LIBE Committee, above all the rapporteur Monika Hohlmeier and the shadow rapporteurs, on this achievement. We can unplug terrorist preparations and propaganda over the Internet. We can turn off the financing of terrorism. We can take effective action against foreign fighters - yes, they are European citizens - and Islamist radicalists, even if the terrorist acts did not take place. We have new criminal law frameworks for effective prosecution and, for the first time, Member States are obliged to exchange data - a long overdue measure, because no Member State in the EU can tackle just one of the challenges on its own. Cyber ​​attacks, attacks against water and electricity supplies are included in terrorist offenses. We go very far. And I realize that we must oblige the internet platform providers to delete content even more. With billions of dollars in profit, no expense is too high.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Mr President, faced with the terrorist threat, the Member States cannot act alone. We need a united, strong and cohesive Europe to respond to this global threat. This report affirms the need for cooperation to enable the European Union to strengthen its arsenal in the fight against terrorism. It is through better cooperation and pooling of our capabilities that we will be able to better protect ourselves against attacks. I welcome the provisions on the obligation to exchange relevant information on criminal investigations between Member States, as well as on the confiscation of assets and funds used in terrorist activities. The Social Democrats have always demanded better information sharing and an aggressive policy against the financing of terrorism. I also welcome the proposals for improving the rights of victims of terrorism, but the battle is far from over, as experience has taught us that the text will only have real significance if all Member States comply. to the transposition commitments. We MEPs still have a role to play. I will be very attentive to the Commission’s assessment of the implementation of the text in order to verify its added value. It will also allow me to ensure full respect for fundamental rights, freedoms and the rule of law. The security policies implemented by the States can in no case derogate from these fundamental values.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you Monica for your commitment to the victims. I dedicate this report to them. Ladies and gentlemen, when I speak of terrorism, of how to combat and prevent it, I can say that my life is going on, because life is what some ETA terrorists took from my brother and his wife. No matter where the terrorism comes from - if it is a nationalist, if it is an Islamist - the goal is the same: the extermination of those who do not think like them. I have heard in this House that you should not be in a hurry, that you should not exaggerate. With all due respect: against terrorism, goodwill is not enough. What helps us against terrorism is intelligence, firmness and unity, and this report responds to what citizens ask of us: to be able to live in peace without a bomb or a shot in the neck violating the most sacred of their rights. , The right to life. I am glad that a giant step has been taken in assisting European victims, but we need a specific directive for victims of terrorism, because terrorist crimes are crimes against humanity and it is society as a whole, ladies and gentlemen, the real and last victim of terrorism.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - In recent months and years, the world has witnessed the barbarity of terrorism and the horrific acts of terrorists. It is therefore right that security and the fight against terror are the top priority of the European Union. Much has already happened. We have adopted the PNR Directive. We have a new mandate from Europol with more room to combat online radicalization. We will also vote tomorrow on better controls at the external borders. We have focused on better protection of the external borders. This report is another important step and I congratulate Mr Hohlmeier and the shadow rapporteurs on the good result, because it is important. The people who intended evil have recently been able to find the weak spots in Europe only too well. 28 different countries with 28 different approaches, that was too fragmented to be effective. This directive takes a very good step in the right direction by aligning itself with criminalizing travel for terrorism, participating in a terrorist organization, recruiting terrorists, financing terrorists and also glorifying terrorists - because much has been said about this today. And yes, we cherish freedom of expression. We cherish this as one of the most important foundations of our society. But there is also such a thing as collective responsibility, a level of minimal civilization that we can expect from everyone in the European Union. And glorifying terror is not one of them and must be tackled very hard.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to start differently, but I have to make a clarification, because some colleagues guilty wanted to transform this directive which, as my colleague Hohlmeier well said, is a directive against terrorism, into a directive against the Muslim community. It is exactly the opposite. We must instead collaborate with the Muslim community and take advantage of integration, we must not isolate the Muslim community. So, hearing the claims that speak of Islamist terrorism, I wonder what it means. Does it mean that there is an Islamist terrorism and then there are other forms of Series B and Series A terrorist acts? This is a very serious thing, a very serious principle. So the directive is excellent, the exchange of information is excellent, because it not only harmonises and serves precisely to coordinate within the Member States, but because the exchange of preliminary information is fundamental because unfortunately the methods of acts of terror change. Once the bus that crashes in Berlin, another time what happened in the airports. So, very well the new types of crime, which are not invented by Parliament, but which adapt to the new forms of criminal acts on the Internet. I'm done, Mr. President. Excellent directive, it must be voted on.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, terrorism, as we well know, is an asymmetrical war which seeks not only to destroy lives, to cause victims, but even more, to fracture our societies, to play on emotional springs , sometimes the most sinister, and to make its own ideological publicity. So, faced with this extremely complex challenge, which is mutant, plastic, as much security as sociological, educational or political, we must have an appropriate response. This cannot be achieved only through emotion, which is legitimate, but which often leads us to take spectacular measures but not necessarily effective. From this point of view, I am delighted that the directive which is being discussed today, enriched by the work of Monika Hohlmeier, provides concrete, professional answers and really contributes to improving what is fundamental, that is - that is to say our legislative arsenal, harmonized throughout Europe. It is absolutely essential to have this common ground. It is also necessary to articulate the dimensions of intelligence, police and justice much better, and not to confuse them. I hear too many colleagues here confusing the exchange of information and intelligence of different kinds. I know only too well that, before coordinating and sharing information, it must be collected, and when we look at what has happened in our different countries, we see that very often, dysfunctions affect people. first the collection of information even before the exchange of information. Yes, therefore, to improved European platforms, reinforced at the judicial and police levels, but be careful not to create confusion or unnecessary superstructure which complicates the operational work more than it improves it.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! The security situation has deteriorated extremely in recent years and that is why we cannot stop at criminal offenses. The permanent threat actually forces us to think about how we can do it better, also to better focus on the police and the security services. Otherwise internal security will be pushed out of the internal balance of the European Union. That is why the fight against terrorism must be a priority. That is why the report that Monika Hohlmeier negotiated here is an important instrument for this. Our aim should be to prevent the attacks in Paris, Brussels, Nice and Berlin accordingly. That is why we should be better able to filter out the terrorist networks - foreigndFighters, individual perpetrators. The data analyzes also offer better and better solutions here, without invoking the dismantling of basic rights by the evil state. But data protection must also go above the protection of life. In my opinion, what we need is - we have already got this going - to strengthen and equip Frontex in terms of personnel and material. We need the intelligent borders to regulate entry and exit, we need to implement PNR, we need the networking of the intelligence police databases of all EU countries, access to Eurodac, the implementation of Prüm with regard to the databases on DNA, fingerprints etc., motor vehicle, register comparison, ECRIS and the strengthening of the anti-terror system, as well as high standards for weapon protection.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, I congratulate Monika Hohlmeier on this balanced report. Terrorism is one of the most important threats to European unity, one of the arguments in the discussion about the shape of Europe, but in fact an argument against an open and common Europe, and therefore it is very important that we fight it effectively. There is no doubt that security is our priority now, that we need closer cooperation, exchange of information, and strengthen controls, especially within the external borders. We need more effective intelligence services and decisive action against people and groups who pose a threat, but we also need effective mechanisms of social and economic integration in Europe, because social stratification, cultural isolation, social ghettos are breeding grounds for radicalism. This is what we should avoid, and that is why I strongly support the proposed solutions that present comprehensive and balanced proposals.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the Spanish Socialists in the European Parliament have the best reasons to bet on an update of the Directive on the fight against terrorism, and to contribute all the painful experience of many years of fighting against terrorism. To begin with, against ETA terrorism, certainly not Islamist, but it did teach us the importance of European cooperation and the fight of European scope. In the first place, the classification of glorification, what we call in Spain the apology and the glorification of the crime. Second, the reinforcement of the aggravation of the recruitment of minors, especially vulnerable people. Third, the reinforcement of the blocking of websites, the prevention of computer attacks on the antiterrorist intelligence systems and the confiscation of assets derived from terrorist activity, but, very importantly, surely the most important, the reinforcement of the protection of the victims with specialized psychological, emotional, legal and economic and financial support, because this is a clear lesson in the Spanish fight against terrorism. It remains to refine the round trip of recruiting terrorists and also the protection of victims.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the European Union is facing a growing terrorist threat on a daily basis, and this has been driven primarily by an extremely liberal approach to migration and asylum policy.When you open the borders to millions of people from another cultural-civilizational circle who do not show a desire to integrate, and you yourself do not do too much to integrate them but try to adapt your culture to them, then it is not surprising that in that friction between the two sides of the bodyand a fire broke out.Now we have to put out that fire, and the first step is to define the quality of terrorism and terrorism-related acts at European level.I also expect the exchange of information between the competent authorities of member states to be even faster and more efficient, and NATO reform, which we can read between the lines since Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election, also opens the possibility for NATO to tackle terrorism more specifically.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, in the fight against terrorism it is urgent to move from words to deeds, and the key is a loyal, immediate exchange with all the legal guarantees of the relevant data in order to detect and prevent possible terrorist acts and take advantage of this endeavorall available resources.Classifying new crimes to punish the training and recruitment of terrorists is interesting, but without shared data it is useless.In several states, some bodies compete;in others, for exclusively political reasons, experience, knowledge and presence in the territory are dispensed with, such as those of, for example, the police of Euskadi or Catalonia, who continue to discuss whether or not they should be integrated into this European dynamic ofexchange, while the ten million Europeans they protect attend the ninguneo in astonishment.Improving is as easy in this matter as wanting to do it.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, first of all I want to condemn in the strongest possible terms all the terrorist attacks that have taken place in Europe and in Turkey. There can be no excuse for them. At the same time, however, I believe that we must see, here in Parliament, the causes of these terrorist attacks, causes other than war and poverty. Within this Parliament there are MEPs representing states that contributed to the wars, that gave birth to this spirit of evil. I am referring, if you will, to Mr. Tony Blair, who rushed to Iraq in search of a bottle of chemicals, from which a bottle of chemicals brought out this great spirit of evil. Interventions in other countries must be related to education and not be perceived by the citizens of those countries as interventions in their policy. I conclude with this: we can contribute to the development of the states around us but not in a way that is perceived as an intervention in the policy of these states, because the Arab Spring has finally become the Arab Winter.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - We can all be victims of terrorism and, above all, victims of the fear of terrorism.And it is our duty, as responsible people and individuals, not to spread fear of terrorism in a way that, of course, can provoke counter-reactions.I welcome, of course, the directive, which will increase the exchange of information and cooperation, including between security services.Of course, I have certain concerns about the definition of new crimes, because it is a sensitive topic that actually infringes on human rights, and many times in history different and unclear interpretations of crimes have led to abuses.That is why we need to be explicitly clear here and, of course, extremely precise.The powers of the various repressive bodies are also being strengthened, and I would just like to point out that security and human rights do not stand in opposition to each other, but are allies, so we need to provide a legal framework.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, it is absurd that we have more debates and demonstrations in Parliament on Islamophobia, xenophobia and the human rights of illegal immigrants than on the growing risk and victims of Islamic terrorism. Nationalists, exercising the fundamental right to express their views, are the only voices of logic and resistance but are systematically accused of being populists. Let the hate speech and the pogrom of political and non-political persecution against the nationalists finally stop. We believe in the traditions of our fathers and demand the consolidation of order, security and social peace. Some have imposed anti-Christian and pro-Islamist rhetoric in the name of multiculturalism, tolerance and respect for human rights. Islamic terrorism is not tackled by parliamentary reports and wish lists. It fights by all available means at its root, namely in the Islamic countries that produce it, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Otherwise, Europe will face the consequences of its decisions in the future.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: - Illum id-dinja qed tiffaċċja organizzazzjonijiet terroristiċi aggressivi ħafna li l-mira tagħhom hija li joqtlu, idgħajfu s-soċjetajiet moderni u demokratiċi, jheddu l-ħajja, il-libertà, l-ugwaljanza u l-j fraqerità il-biża '. L-organizzazzjonijiet terroristiċi qed isiru transnazzjonali, organizzati tajjeb loġistikament, bl-iskop li jfixklu l-funzjoni normali tas-soċjetà tagħna. Ikolli ngħid li, sa ċertu punt, irnexxielhom! Wara l-attakki terroristiċi tas-sena li għaddiet, f’għadd ta ’pajjiżi Ewropej, in-nies huma mwerwrin u m’għadhomx iħossuhom żguri f’pajjiżhom. Għaldaqstant, ma thadthiex b'sorpriża li aktar minn 80% taċ-ċittadini Evropej iħossu li l-ġlieda kontra t-terroriżmu u r-radikalizzazzjoni għandhom ikunu l-ewwel prijorità għmm-Unwonjo a Europe fil-ġlieda against t-terrorism. Wasal iż-żmien li nintebħu li għandna wisq x’nitilfu - u n-nuqqas ta ’azzjoni mhix għażla! In general, we will not be able to accept the terrorism, but we will be able to protect ourselves from the protection of the average person.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the fight against terrorism requires a comprehensive approach, one that covers a wide range of sectors, from politics, to the economy, to society and to education. First of all, there must be the prevention and fight against radicalization, which is achieved precisely because various Muslim countries have a significant influence on both their own populations and the populations of Europe itself. Second, there is a political field that is fueling the radicalization of the Muslim population, and that is the West's interventions in the Arab world. Another issue we need to look at is the enormous failure of the policies pursued by various European Union countries to integrate the various Muslim populations. If they failed, it was precisely because they were marginalized in society and the economy. The bottom line is that comprehensive approaches are needed to tackle terrorism.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: - Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, terrorism is undoubtedly the greatest global threat of the 21st century. Innocent victims around the world fall under barbaric terrorist attacks, regardless of their ethnic or religious affiliation. The European Union is no exception, and the problem with the so-called "Foreign fighters" and their eventual return to the European Union is quite real. That is why we need a comprehensive approach and a long-term commitment to ensure the security and peace of our democratic and free societies. In this regard, I fully support the proposal for a directive on combating terrorism. It has added value for the European Union, as it creates a harmonized basis for criminal law. Member States should continue their efforts to prevent terrorism by coordinating their strategies and exchanging information. They need to apply good practices at both Union and national level. But also to update their national prevention policies in line with the Union's strategy to combat radicalization and terrorist recruitment.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this debate. I would like to say first that I agree with all of those who have underlined the importance of working on the causes of terrorism and, in particular, the need to tackle radicalisation in our communities. Second, I agree that we need a range of measures to tackle terrorism, some of which fall outside the scope of this Directive. But I do hope, and I urge you, to support this directive because it transposes the provisions that were set out in the recently-passed UNSCR, provisions of the Council of Europe and the provisions of the Financial Action Task Force based at the OECD. It reinforces information exchange and it strengthens victim support. Third, I think we have all agreed that terrorists do not just target one Member State or another, they target our way of life and our values, and the Commission stands second to no-one in its support for fundamental rights, including the freedom of expression, which is an essential foundation of our society. Those rights are enshrined in the Charter and the Charter will steer the implementation of this directive. We, the Commission, will report on the implementation of the directive and that report will in particular assess the directive’s impact on fundamental rights. Lastly, our response, as many speakers have underlined, needs to be comprehensive and sustainable. It needs to build on trust and effective cooperation between these institutions and our Member States. From the Commission’s side we will continue to focus on strengthening the fight against terrorism by depriving terrorists of the means they use to commit their attacks and by enhancing our defences and building our resilience, and we shall continue to maintain the closest possible engagement with you, with this House, as we take that work forward.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank you very, very sincerely for the many very constructive and excellent contributions made by colleagues who support the directive. I have a request for the address of the critics: I really ask you to read the text carefully. Because some of the assertions that have been made here cannot be substantiated by this directive. The directive expressly provides a precise definition of terrorist acts, such as the hijacking of an airplane, such as the poisoning of water facilities, such as the possession of nuclear or radiological material with the aim of committing a terrorist attack. So, the definitions are very, very clear and not vague. They must be implemented accordingly in national law. Second: When traveling within the EU, the investigative authorities must provide evidence that someone is specifically planning a terrorist act. Only then can a corresponding investigation be carried out against the person. And then it does not matter whether he comes from Syria or whether he is traveling from Brussels to Paris or from Düsseldorf to Paris. We need to stop the perpetrators before they commit an attack, not complain about the dead and injured afterwards. We have to prevent it from occurring in the first place. Furthermore: the presumption of innocence and the guarantees of fundamental rights are set out very precisely in Article 23. The presumption of innocence must not be restricted, procedural rights must be guaranteed, fundamental rights must be observed, freedom of opinion and freedom of the press is a fundamental right and is expressly mentioned. For this reason: We do not give up any fundamental rights, but we also protect these fundamental rights from terrorists who do not even want you to have such fundamental rights. They fight against our western values, they fight against our European values.We fight to ensure that we can uphold these European values and that they are not destroyed by terrorists.This directive serves as a legal instrument for this.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday February 16, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: written.- Strengthening European cooperation in the fight against terror is a top priority.This new EU directive will step up the joint approach to terrorism and the Syria fighters in the member states.With these measures, we are taking a crucial step towards much closer and more efficient cooperation between national intelligence services.They will automatically exchange information among themselves when detecting terrorist activities and share information on suspected and convicted terrorists with Europol.That is the only good way to prevent acts of terrorism and tackle the terror threat.From now on, all Member States must also systematically carry out checks at the external borders of the Union.That is, of course, in the interest of all Europeans.It is a crucial step to protect our internal borders, to protect Schengen.It is a main task for the EU, which we must and will now fulfill in practice.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - Paris, Brussels, Nice, Berlin - hundreds of innocent civilian victims have died in recent acts of terrorism in these cities. Ensuring the security of European citizens must be a top priority for national governments and the European Union. The danger of further terrorist acts is real. More than five thousand EU citizens have left Europe to take part in the fighting in Syria and Iraq, and the number of returnees is constantly growing. Fighting, highly radicalized returning citizens are a huge threat. This is why the directive we are discussing today is extremely important, as it criminalises attempts to recruit and train, to take part in terrorist training, to travel abroad for the purpose of terrorism, and to organize and facilitate it, and to finance terrorist offenses. In 2016, Europol warned that another terrorist attack was likely in Europe. The Hungarian government is committed to increasing the security of Europe, while protecting its citizens, and Hungary supports all measures that promote the security of European citizens.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - Fighting terrorism does not mean hiding and praying that it will pass us by, closing its eyes. Europe's multicultural policy has brought these terrorists into our lands. It has turned neighborhoods of otherwise ancient European cities into Islamic enclaves and territories that police cannot even think of entering. This extremely disgusting phenomenon, which has spread within our Union, can only be combated with the joint efforts of all the Member States and, in general, of all the countries on our continent. Moreover, in addition to the young jihadists from the ranks of the Islamic State, who return to Europe and turn into lone wolves, we are already seeing the merger of organized crime with terrorist organizations. I therefore call on all Member States, including Bulgaria, to modernize their legal frameworks for combating terrorism and organized crime so that we can more easily combat the phenomenon of 'terrorism', which has become the scourge of today's Europe. !!

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The terrorist attacks in Paris have shown that the current European counter-terrorism legislation has a number of shortcomings. The aim of the directive is to eliminate them and update the criminal response to terrorist offenses in the European Union, to integrate the relevant provisions of new sources of international law, and to ensure a uniform interpretation of terrorist acts throughout the Union. The so-called In response to the relatively recent phenomenon of "foreign fighters", the Directive also financing of terrorist offenses. By making these acts punishable, it will be possible to screen out potential perpetrators and thus prevent further acts of terrorism. It is to be welcomed that, in addition to the new facts, the directive also addresses the issue of protection and assistance to victims of terrorism. From the outset, the Hungarian government has supported all measures that will significantly increase Europe's security, including the modernization of the EU's counter-terrorism framework. Guaranteeing the security of European citizens must be a top priority for all of us, as there is no freedom without security.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The argument is not new. It is necessary to "respond" to the attacks on European soil and "to fight" the so-called "foreign fighters". Of terrorism and these so-called combatants, of their origins and causes, not a word of framework and of the EU's accountability in the phenomenon. The legislative proposal aims to criminalize "activities related to terrorist practices". The absence of a definition of "terrorism", and the broad and poorly framed scope with which the measures and legal entities liable to be accused are proposed, will lead to the generalization of criminalization for "practices linked to terrorism", with questionable causality. The simple practice of visiting a website, or traveling to certain regions, may constitute a legal basis for detention and criminalization. MS will have free will to close websites, without the need for judicial authorization. At a time when the EU institutions speak so much about the so-called "radicalization", they contribute to stretching the rope of marginalization and exclusion, increasing stigmas and feelings of disgust on both sides. It is a dangerous legislative initiative that continues the EU's security drift, consolidating a strong Europe that makes the most basic rights and freedoms clear, imposing control, registration, profiling, censorship.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. - It is good that the European Parliament is once again dealing with progress in the fight against terrorism. Unfortunately, terrorist threats in Europe have increased in recent years, as evidenced by the recent attacks in Nice and Berlin. Terrorists operate without scruples, and their aim is to sow fear and fight Western civilization. In my opinion, the proposed directive rightly extends the definition of terrorist offenses. Under the new proposal, terrorist offenses will include not only attacks on people and objects, but also attacks on information systems and databases, critical infrastructure, such as power plants or banking systems. I believe that it is right for EU countries to punish public praise for terrorism, participate in terrorist training and travel for terrorist purposes. If we consistently introduce the proposed changes to European law, it will undoubtedly hinder the activities of terrorists.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for a debate on the report by Monica Macovei, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on strengthening checks on relevant databases at external borders (COM (2015) 0670 - C8-0407 / 2015 - 2015/0307 (COD)) (A8-0218 / 2016).

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, if we want security within the European Union, then we must secure the external borders of the European Union, and that is what we have done with this regulation, a joint regulation of the European Parliament and the Council, which strengthens external borders, strengthens checks at the Union's external borders. European. In short, what does this proposed regulation bring: the verification of people entering and leaving the European Union, through any external border of the European Union, in databases - and I will refer to this immediately: in databases. This means a change in the situation today, in which citizens of the European Union are not checked in and out of the Schengen area, and citizens who do not belong to the European Union, but are from third countries, are checked only at the entrance, not at exit. So what we are changing is that everyone, both EU citizens and non-EU citizens, will be checked both at entry and exit, and we are not just talking about the Schengen area, but the whole of the European Union, so the external border of European Union. How will they be checked? They will be checked in the databases. According to this proposal for a regulation, the mandatory databases to be used by the Member States are the Schengen Information System and the Interpol Lost or Stolen Documents Database. The regulation also provides for verification in any other relevant European database. It could be: the Visa database or, in the future, because it has not yet been adopted, the Exit database of people entering or leaving the European Union. Of course, these databases must be full of complete, accurate information and transmitted immediately by the Member States. Here again I appeal to the Member States, that all this cooperation and all this construction that we do depends on the speed and accuracy of the data that they send to the databases, because the Member States Member States are the ones who feed the databases, so they have a great responsibility to send the information quickly, completely and correctly. Checking each person has a few exceptions, just so as not to hinder traffic at the border. For land and sea borders there is the possibility that, at any time, when there is a very heavy traffic of passengers, by those crossing the border, to ask for targeted checks, based on information, so that only certain persons are checked, verified in databases only certain persons for whom there is information. Obviously, this can be done with the agreement of the Commission and after a risk assessment. There is a six-month transition period for air borders, during which Member States are required to purchase all the necessary equipment for these checks, equipment and for the training of airport workers. This six-month period may be extended by up to 18 months by the Commission, when requested by a Member State for certain airports. It is not necessary, for example, to apply for all airports in a country. Here you have to prove that you still have structural and technical problems. I would like to give an example of how this control will be done, so that everyone can understand. It is basically a scan of the travel document, the passport and, if information about that person appears in one of these databases, then the information appears on the screen of the person controlling and the person goes through other checks. So this is not a row check in the databases. It is a single interface where a red flag appears if you find that name in one of the mentioned databases, which means that this check in the databases should not take long. I also want to mention that for all this equipment and for all this training there is a European fund for internal security, which is at the Commission, the Directorate-General for Migration and Home Affairs, DG HOME, and from which Member States will receive money to purchase this equipment and for training. I would also like to point out that this regulation, this proposal for a regulation - I hope that it will be voted on tomorrow and be a regulation - is complemented by other provisions, in addition to those in the Counter-Terrorism Directive that we discussed earlier. which we vote on tomorrow. We also have other provisions which, for example, provide for mobile teams, which can come to the aid, if necessary, at an external border, immediately providing that, from Member States which are within the Union and do not have an external border of appropriate personnel to be sent to assist Member States at the Union's border. That is, to be a joint effort to defend our borders. Finally, I would like to thank all my colleagues for their collaboration, for how I worked. It was not a short road, it was not an easy road, but we came to understand each other wisely and to make a regulation, I say, good, for the citizens of the European Union. Again, it is very important how it will be applied by the Member States and how it will be put into practice by the border people.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the Commission proposed the amendment to the Schengen Borders Code introducing systematic checks for all citizens at our external borders. As we have just heard, these checks are vital to stopping, amongst others, potential terrorists, not just from coming into the EU, but also to prevent them from travelling to conflict zones. On behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Avramopoulos, as well as myself, I would like to say how grateful we are to the Parliament, and in particular to the rapporteur, Mrs Macovei, for the work that they have done on this important dossier. The amendment will oblige Member States to carry out systematic checks on all persons crossing an external border. They will be checked – as Mrs Macovei has just set out – against law enforcement databases, notably the Schengen Information System, to verify that they do not pose a threat to public order or internal security. This obligation will apply at all external borders – air, sea and land – both at entry and exit.  However, if a systematic consultation of databases leads to a disproportionate impact on the flow of border traffic, then Member States will have the option of carrying out targeted checks against the databases, provided that they first carry out an appropriate risk assessment. In the case of airports – again, as we have just heard – this option is generally only available for a transition arrangement of six months unless an airport has specific infrastructure problems, in which case an exception can be made to extend that transition period up to 18 months.  The EU will provide financial assistance to Member States to help them implement the new rules and in turn – like others here – I trust that the Member States will do their utmost to be ready on time and that the new measures will translate into immediate and tangible results.  The amended Schengen Borders Code, together with the European border and coast guards, are crucial in our bid to preserve freedom of movement within the Schengen Area and to ensure the security of our citizens. We now need to press ahead with work on reinforcing the management and security of the EU’s external borders, including the work on the entry—exit and ETIAS proposals.
