This is all part of returning to a fully functioning Schengen Area from which all our citizens benefit.

name: Marielle de Sarnez
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. - Madam President, from now on, checks at all external borders of the European Union - land, sea and air - will be compulsory for all citizens of the Union and for all nationals of third countries. This revision of the Schengen Borders Code is a direct response to the terrorist attacks committed on European soil and, in particular, I cannot forget, in Paris. This change will allow systematic checks on people entering and leaving European territory, as well as systematic checks against databases. This decision is likely to restore credibility to Schengen, provided that it is applied quickly and effectively at all our borders and that it is accompanied by the effective establishment of coast guards and border guards. Europeans. All the major communities in the world have effective controls at their external borders, it is time for the European Union to equip itself with the same means in the service of the security and protection of our fellow citizens.

name: Barbara Kudrycka
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - How to ensure greater security for Europeans? Among other things, by strengthening the protection of the external borders of the European Union. Therefore, it is extremely important that, after a year of difficult negotiations, we have reached an agreement with the Council and the Commission. We agreed together how to improve our security. We thank Mrs Macovei, our rapporteur, and all colleagues who have worked to achieve a common consensus. We agreed that the external borders of the Union must be more difficult to cross for those who want to enter it illegally and with malicious intent. They need to be more impenetrable to terrorist networks and they need to be better managed. Increased control at the external borders will allow the successful integration of the Schengen area to be made possible by the unhindered travels of Europeans within the Community. It is one of our important symbols of Europe. Let us not renounce it. The new challenge is how to deal with terrorists who have the citizenship of the European Union and return to Europe properly trained. Only increased controls at external borders, including airports, can help. And it will be up to the Member States to organize it so as not to increase the queues for passport control using the grace period provided for in the regulation. Now it is most important that Member States exchange data in a consistent manner, update their databases regularly and exchange best practices. If existing information systems are fully exploited then their interoperability can be ensured. This will certainly facilitate quick and simultaneous search and verification of databases and on the "hit or no hit" basis and should not cause any special difficulties. The EU's right to free movement may not be used by criminals, especially after returning from areas affected by armed conflicts. Effective and systematic external border controls Union can help with this.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - We have before us a report on changes to the border rules, which introduce much tighter controls on all passengers crossing the Union's external borders. In addition to systematic identity verification, we are also introducing mandatory verification for all passengers against possible threats in databases. We are not satisfied with the result in my political group. The new rules at the borders also have shortcomings and address security threats in an unbalanced manner. It will be possible to deviate from the rules of systematic review in very limited cases - we wanted more flexibility. At the same time, I wonder how effectively we will be able to carry out border control in practice, especially at airports. In Slovenia, we will probably already see long columns on the border with Croatia this summer, through which many pass for holidays. In just a few months, the number of crossings reaches millions. How quickly such a small country can find itself in a very difficult situation. On the one hand, we are taking new and new measures to tighten controls due to security threats. On the other hand, you are extending controls at internal borders, for example between Austria and Slovenia. And Slovenia has already protested to the European Commission because of this. So how do I explain to my citizens that the country can become a pocket, with the passage of the country requiring several hours of waiting due to new rule changes at both the northern and southern borders? I certainly support, Commissioner, measures for greater security. But I want these to be more balanced in the sequel, not only to make the borders just more resilient, but to stay or become even more friendly for all passengers.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - With this agreement that we have reached with the Council, an extensive screening of all EU citizens, including returning Syria fighters with a Belgian passport, is now possible. This is not a day too soon. Today there is only a minimal legal check of travelers with an EU passport who land at a European airport from outside Schengen. This will soon be a thing of the past because the rules are now being tightened, partly thanks to the N-VA. All travelers will soon be subject to a systematic check. An excellent thing for the safety of our citizens. In concrete terms, the Schengen border control will be adapted, which determines the practical implementation of controls at the European external borders. For example, it will be determined more quickly whether travelers who want to enter Europe are being searched by a police or intelligence service and whether their passport is false or stolen. Instead of traveling further, criminals are immediately arrested thanks to the new rules. For example, we are committed to further strengthening our external borders.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, ALDE will support this report but not with great enthusiasm. First of all, as so often, there was no impact assessment. It seems the Commission does not consider that necessary when it is about security and fundamental rights. I also think that the justification used, namely the Paris attacks, is a very strange one, because what turned out to be the case was that Member States were not sharing information and terrorists were able to cross internal borders without problems; so this does not seem to me to be a coherent vision on security and external border control but the usual Pavlov reflexes and salami tactics.  We are, however, pleased that we got at least one thing, namely that compulsory checks will be limited to well-defined databases, rather than the rather general reference that was included initially, namely checks against ‘all relevant databases’, which might be anything. Because what has also become clear is that the Member States actually fail to make full use of the Schengen Information System (SIS). We have a system in place and Member States are not using it, they are not feeding information into it, and they are not checking it. So again we are finding solutions to the wrong problem. I wish that the Member States would finally do their duty and accept that there is an obligation to use the existing systems rather than, every time it turns out they failed to share information, coming up with something new.  We also wanted a risk-based system, proportional and necessary, rather than the default setting of systematic checks. We wanted risk assessment at the European level, based on common European criteria, but that was impossible.  Finally, and this was also one of the priorities of Parliament, we wanted equal treatment of land, air and sea borders, and we did not get it. I think this is crazy, because if everybody is submitted to systematic checks at airports, but there can be exceptions for land and sea borders, then you do not need to be a rocket scientist to figure out that, next time, you take the car. I am not really sure what this is going to add, but because we made some minimal progress here, ALDE will nevertheless support it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I am very surprised by these doubts, but I would like to be precise.Which fundamental right will be violated as a result of objective and intensive border control?Can you name a fundamental right that will be violated?

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. –  Well, the whole idea in a democracy is that the powers of public authorities are limited to what is necessary and proportionate, and that also applies to things like privacy, for example, or other fundamental rights. So why would you allow authorities to do more than is necessary if you know that it is excessive? Besides, this is not only about fundamental rights. This is also about effectiveness. If we are all talking about the need for more security, then why don’t we tackle the real problem, namely the insufficient sharing of information between Member States – in some cases, the actual refusal of Member States to share information – rather than creating new IT systems the whole time (paid for by public money, incidentally), if we know that it is not going to solve the problem?

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, my group is resolutely opposed to this modification of the Schengen regulation, supposedly aimed at establishing systematic and compulsory border controls. It is a new stage in the construction of a secure Europe-fortress, which has taken a new turn since 2015 in the name of the fight against terrorism and the so-called migratory crisis, without qualifying for the one and the other and by feeding, in fact, racism and xenophobia. Member States adhere to this construction which enables them to offload their responsibilities onto the back of the European Union. This regulation cannot be seen independently of the other texts, which are currently submitted to us, and in particular the badly named “intelligent borders”. This text will make it possible to control third-country nationals on their entry and, henceforth, on their exit and, for good measure, we add European citizens. But in practice, checks will be random, and the relevant databases will only be consulted if there is any doubt as to the validity of travel documents. Member States will be able to suspend compulsory checks to facilitate traffic flow. Surprising! And certain categories of people may also be exempt from it. In the end, therefore, this device is really variable geometry. In reality, I see a lot of hypocrisy, not to say cynicism, to the detriment of fundamental rights, without the right to security and, above all, the right to safety of our fellow citizens being thereby strengthened.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, people watching in the galleries, for me this revision of border checks is a very telling example of ad hoc legislation and of symbolic politics, because we haven’t had an impact assessment by the Commission. I know you weren’t there, Commissioner, when we started debating that, but this is something which the Commission hasn’t proven, it hasn’t given us any proof that this will really make us more secure. No impact assessment was carried out. Indeed, it might be [questioned] whether it’s really suitable for catching terrorists. It is already possible now to have non-systematic checks of EU citizens coming in and out, and what is done now is done without any [grounds for] suspicion. For me and for us as Greens this revision is not necessary and it is not proportionate, as others have already said.  Let me give you one example, because the problem is that Member States don’t feed all the information they have into the Schengen Information System. I can give you a very concrete example. One of the Brussels attackers, Salah Abdeslam, passed through my home country, Austria, from Budapest with some people he took up in Budapest at the train station there. He passed from there to Austria, and there was a police patrol controlling him; they had an alert, but they didn’t say it was because of terrorism. So the Austrian Police a couple of days later informed the Belgians. Well, that was too late and the problem is that the Belgian authorities didn’t [give any] inform[ation]. So we have to solve that first before we control each and every EU citizen coming in and out. This simply will not make Europe more secure.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the amendment of the Schengen Borders Code should be aimed at making it easier to identify those who pose a threat to public order and the internal security of the European Union. One of the most difficult to identify is represented by the flows of foreign fighters. To this end, everyone at the external borders of the European Union, including European citizens, will be subjected to systematic checks through checks on the documentary and biometric information contained in the relevant existing databases. Only in the event that systematic checks have a disproportionate impact on the flow of passenger traffic will the Member States concerned have the possibility to carry out them in a targeted manner, provided that a risk assessment demonstrates that such a derogation does not harm the internal security of the Union. We wondered if it was no longer effective to provide as a rule, and not as an exception, targeted checks, carried out on reports shared between states following intelligence activities, but unfortunately the opposite opinion prevailed in the commission. A focal point is represented by the need to improve the dialogue between the databases and the interconnectivity between them and the infrastructures responsible for managing the external borders, in full compliance with the rules on data protection and fundamental rights.

name: Laurențiu Rebega
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the political line of our group, in the face of the major threats posed by illegal migration and terrorism, I appreciate the idea of ​​strengthening border controls. But I have three observations to make. The first concerns the hypertrophy of documents and Community legislation in the field. As terrorism becomes faster, more direct and more effective, the European bureaucracy splits the hair in four. With regard to the speed of threats, the Union's reactions are dinosaur - and we all know what happened to the dinosaurs. The second observation concerns the emptying of the content of the notion of freedom of movement. Under the pretext of security, huge databases are being built that escape any democratic control. Slowly, the freedom of movement of citizens is transformed into the freedom of suspicion of citizens by supranational institutions. Finally, the third observation, more specific this time, concerns non-Schengen States. According to the report, they do not have the rights of the Schengen States, but have the same obligations as the Schengen States. In other words, outright discrimination. It is incorrect and humiliating.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, last year the leader of the German country, Mrs Merkel, entered a monumental madness by opening the borders to millions of people who fled into that country. Since then, we have seen the impact of that across her nation. We have even now seen her making apologies for the mistakes that she said she made. On this side of the house, you heard people say that you needed to have border controls – checks to ensure that the people coming into the country, were not terrorists, could not commit crimes. Well, we were ridiculed, name-called: xenophobes, racists, casually thrown out. And yet here, in this paper today, and I quote from its own line, says that border controls are in the interests of Member States. Those of us on this side of the House who have been saying that for years are now vindicated. Only the people of Europe are saying ‘why did it take you so long to come to the same conclusion?’

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are facing security challenges that are unprecedented. We must have modern legislation in place to respond to new and evolving threats. Controls at external borders are key to ensuring proper freedom of movement and security within the Schengen Area because, in our opinion, one simply cannot exist without the other. Having systematic checks for persons enjoying the right of free movement across external land, sea and air borders is necessary and it is being required. In recent years, Europe has learned some very difficult lessons. As we have seen, the phenomenon of foreign fighters continues to plague our communities. We cannot allow terrorists to hide behind the protection afforded to them by their European passports. The reinforcement of checks will make it easier for our law enforcement agencies to identify those people at the border. With Islamic State losing ground in its traditional strongholds, it is becoming more likely that more of the approximately 5 000 foreign fighters in conflict zones will attempt to return to Europe. The measures being proposed are a clear and important response in terms of keeping our citizens safe. We simply must know whether people coming or going pose a threat to our internal security. We must have more security on our external borders while ensuring that our controls are efficient and secure. I would like to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs who have worked so hard on this proposal and I hope that tomorrow’s vote will mean one more step, maybe a small step but an important step for our citizens’ security. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Colleague!I would like to ask that when you say it is a tiny, but still a step forward for the safety of citizens.I think a hysteria about a fortress is more of a problem in people’s souls than an effective and professionally grounded job.I think border protection is a matter for professionals and not how politicians here harass different peoples.So that would be my question.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. Well, I agree with your last point, that we should not be spreading fear, and I think that having necessary and proportionate responses to the very threats that are creating insecurity amongst our citizens would be one way of doing that.  And I really believe, yes, that politicians, who would like to send a very strong message in order for our citizens – who vote for us to be in these positions – to feel safer, that we should be the ones to respond. Not with hysteria, not with far and extreme populism, but in order to send a very necessary and proportionate response. I believe that, if done properly, without hysteria, then with this proposal and this assertion we can actually send the message that our citizens would like to receive.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the tragic consequences of the recent terrorist attacks in France, Belgium and Germany have highlighted many weaknesses in the existing control system at the European Union's borders. There is also no practice of exchanging data between members. But the proposed combination of systematic controls of documents and persons in the relevant databases will finally allow for synergies in the structure of the system. We need to support proposals that provide greater security for citizens, but we must emphasize that this proposal will have implications for the technical, technological, administrative and personnel aspects of border control. Especially at the busiest border crossings during the holidays. Care should be taken to strengthen the capacity for such checks, because the existing technology is undercapacitated and does not allow fast enough extraction of biometric data, their verification in existing and storage in new systems. Also, some members still have border controls within Schengen. When we add to that the threats of certain Schengen members to block borders in the tourist season to members that have not yet done so, and under the pretext of implementing this proposal, unnecessary problems in its implementation can be seen. It is a pity that the final version does not contain some quality proposals from Parliament adopted by the committees. The political reality, however, requires strengthening the security of the Union, and that is why I will support this proposal. But we need to be careful not to make it difficult for those who are entitled to cross borders. This security instrument must not be misused for political purposes.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as we all know, Europe is facing huge security concerns from the current terrorist threat, and the introduction of systematic checks at the EU’s external borders is a tool that can contribute to dealing with the increase in foreign terrorist fighters. So I support this targeted response in order to increase the security in Europe, and I welcome this report from my colleague Ms Macovei. However, this approach can only work if there is access to reliable data in EU databases, such as the Schengen Information System, and national and international databases. So, strengthening information systems and working towards interoperability is vital to the success of these checks. I also welcome the flexibility in the regulation that will allow targeted checks. Overall, this is not a silver bullet, but if implemented properly it can play a useful part in shoring up Europe’s security at the point of entry in order to detect threats from terrorism and serious organised crime. I support this approach, but I also look forward to the Commission ensuring that Member States live up to their obligations.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, as a Democrat of the ALDE group, I am entirely in favor of the adoption of this regulation, which will oblige the Member States to systematically check all persons, citizens or nationals of third countries, which cross the external border. Why? Because we know that many of the perpetrators of the attacks that bloodied our countries were trained abroad and returned across the external border. Because we know that there are still some 2,500 European fighters in Syria, Iraq and Libya and that as Daesh recedes, many of them will return, necessarily crossing the external border. Under these conditions, it is imperative to carry out systematic checks to reduce the risk of attacks. Having said that, I want to stress that the obligatory corollary of such systematic checks is that Member States communicate the information they hold on suspected terrorists so that this information is available to border guards. If not, the increased controls will be an unnecessary and costly scarecrow, and a real media fable.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the borders of the European Union are, today and according to different organizations, the most dangerous on the planet for migrants and asylum seekers. We are aware that many borders of the European Union, such as the fences of Ceuta and Melilla, are places without law, where the security forces act against the law. There, police violence and hot returns are routine and it is impossible for the people who arrive to ask for asylum. With this reform, which speaks of the management of human flows as if it were objects, what you intend is to turn freedom of movement into an alleged crime. To carry out their xenophobic plan, they do not care about ending the Geneva Convention, returning people to the bombs or treating as criminals those who intend to enter our continent. Border reinforcement is directly responsible for the more than 5,000 deaths in the Mediterranean and also for the deaths on the land border between Turkey and Bulgaria. The problem is that you treat refugees and migrants as criminals when the dangerous ones are you, who intend to pass legislation that goes against human rights.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the controls of our external borders are, together with other criminal intelligence tools, one of the main safeguards that we have to maintain the security of the Schengen area. The threat from returned combatants is real and we must confront it. Terrorism also comes from radicalized European citizens. The latest data indicates that around 5,000 European citizens may have traveled to conflict zones to join terrorist groups. Many of them may have returned already or could do so soon. The threat is obvious. Much has been argued about proportionality and the need for such controls. I respect and defend the need for this debate, which in turn we are reproducing in many other legislative projects. I, as rapporteur for the Smart Borders package, have addressed the issue and, therefore, I sincerely believe that ensuring our security is compatible with the defense of individual rights. This agreement achieves this, and for this I congratulate the rapporteur. We speak of security wrapped in rights and guarantees. The territorial scope of this report covers border controls on land, at sea and in the air, thousands of points with their own specificities that make this task an even greater challenge, and in my opinion the transitional period set for airport infrastructures is acceptable.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, a moment ago we discussed here in the European Parliament the amendment of the Directive on the fight against terrorism and the importance of pooling all the available information, with all the databases and all the technology available to the European Union, which is not little. It is important to prevent computer attacks on intelligence systems, it is important to transmit information under judicial control and with all guarantees; But if it is important to strengthen the databases at the external borders of the Union, it is even more important that this does not turn the external borders of the Union into a hell that is impenetrable, even for European citizens. That is why we draw attention to the need for controls and their reinforcement not to be systematic, but to be so exclusively when they are rationally subordinate to safety, and there is sufficient flexibility so that those controls can relax both in intensity and its temporal dimension, in its temporal scope, whenever possible taking into account security and, above all, for the sake of free transit and movement of European citizens within the internal borders of the Union, because that is Schengen, the most common acquis precious of European construction.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I want to strongly support this regulation. This is exactly what the European Union should do, and it will strengthen and make control at the external borders more effective, and it will also inspire states to control better. Together with other instruments such as the Passenger Data Protection Directive and the Anti-Terrorism Directive, it forms an effective security policy and, frankly speaking, I do not understand these voices, I do not understand why some of the left say it is an anti-democratic solution. ALDE is indifferent. Someone said that we are only doing this because there were attacks in Paris, but you blocked the PNR directive before the attacks in Paris. Essentially, freedom cannot be interpreted in completely unlimited terms, against security. Order is the basis of freedom. If Europe is not secure, it will be difficult to promote freedom, so it is worth supporting this regulation.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is delusional to think that collecting more data on ordinary citizens will make Europe a safer place. Everybody wants European citizens to be safe, but this regulation would not have prevented the attacks that took place across Europe. It will not work because the massive collection of data is not targeted. It is an infringement of the civil liberties of EU citizens and residents. It is invasive and unnecessary. The Commission has not even made an impact assessment to justify the regulation before pushing it through.  If Europe wants to prevent terrorism, it needs better use of existing data, better cooperation between Member States, police and public prosecutors, and it needs to promote conflict resolution instead of fanning foreign conflicts and wars. The European institutions should concern themselves more with the protection of citizens’ civil liberties and less with treating ordinary citizens as subjects.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, dear colleagues, our main priority is the security of European citizens. The phenomenon of "foreign terrorist fighters" requires answers and more concrete action. Today's report is a step in the right direction. That is why I also welcome the introduction of mandatory checks on third-country nationals entering and leaving the European Union, as well as systematic checks on persons enjoying the right of free movement in the European Union. Detecting as well as preventing travel in support of terrorist acts is a key priority for us. At the same time, I would like to draw special attention to the fact that ensuring security in the European Union cannot be effective if the measures envisaged exclude Member States outside the Schengen area but having external borders within the Union. In this regard, we must not lose sight of the need to join Schengen and provide full access to the database of the Schengen Information System to countries such as Bulgaria. The lack of exchange of information is an obstacle to strengthening the security of our external borders. In order for Bulgaria to continue to successfully deal with guarding the Union's external border, the country needs the full range of tools. Let us not forget: guaranteeing security in Europe depends on guaranteeing security in Bulgaria as well. The country expects this positive sign.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: - Madam President, given the current state of threats, I can only stress the need to better manage our common external borders and to ensure freedom of movement for all within the Schengen area. It is only then that it will function normally again, and that is our goal, because returning to national borders is not an option. However, two remarks are necessary here. First, the Social Democrats Group will remain vigilant about an accumulation of checks, checks and databases. Our efforts for the safety of our fellow citizens could become counterproductive. Secondly, I will be attentive to the practical implementation of these measures by the Member States, in particular the need for airports to adapt their infrastructures for the application of systematic checks. I do not want the PNR directive situation to happen again. The Council also lobbied Parliament for the swift adoption of the text, while today only four Member States are on the verge of having an operational PNR. Safety is everyone's business. It is through better cooperation of all actors, both European and national, that we will be able to act effectively against current threats.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the increased influx of people into the European Union is a direct consequence of wars and the poor economic situation in neighboring regions, and we will unfortunately face this reality in the coming years.We all believe in the imminent end of the war in Syria, but we will certainly feel its consequences long after the war itself is over.Knowing the pressure on the Union's external borders and the instability created in some Member States, irresponsible policies towards migrants and the return of some ISIL fighters to Europe, I am afraid we are a little late in tightening controls at the external borders.But better late than never!I hope that this is just the beginning of a smarter policy, which will guarantee a higher level of security for all our citizens.If we fail to do so, there will be an additional closure of each country within itself, and thus the many positive effects of European integration will be reversed overnight.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner King, Dear Colleague Monica Macovei, the introduction of stricter controls through the systematic consultation of existing databases - European and national - is a good example of how we can provide more security, in European citizens. To ensure that the Schengen Area remains an area of ​​freedom, security and justice, we must act at the external borders and ensure the best possible cooperation internally. It is therefore crucial that we are able to guarantee full due control of those crossing our external border, as these amendments intend - not only those who enter, but also those who leave, not only third-country nationals, but also Europeans. We want to optimize the use of information systems, such as the SIS, the Schengen Information System, in order to enhance the sharing of information and cooperation between Member States to give maximum effect to these changes to the Schengen Borders Code. That is why the proposal made by the Commission, last December, to change the SIS cannot be disconnected from these measures. And with this, I finish, Madam President. The safety of Europeans is not guaranteed by isolated layers; the security of Europeans is done in a planned way, ensuring a balanced performance, because it is our obligation to ensure security, but also freedom, including the freedom of movement for all Europeans.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, checks at the Union’s external borders remain one of the main safeguards for the area without internal border controls. These are checks that are carried out in the interest of all Member States, aimed at preventing any threat, even in the event that, as we saw in the recent attacks in Paris and Brussels, such a threat comes from Union citizens. Thanks to the new technologies available and the national and European databases at their disposal, the border guards located at the external borders of the Union will be able to carry out systematic checks aimed at all European citizens. However, respect for the law remains for us the overriding principle underlying this regulation. The verification of the identity and validity of the travel document must always be carried out in full compliance with Union law enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, in particular for the rights to respect for privacy, data protection and freedom of circulation and residence.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, controls at Europe's external borders have always been and will continue to be one of the most important guarantees for security within the Union and for the protection of the right of free movement of European citizens. I believe that the introduction of systematic checks at the external borders of the European Union, not only for third-country nationals, but also for all European citizens, will support the work of the security services in capturing people who pose a terrorist threat. This dossier is extremely important for my country, Bulgaria, which is defending one of the most difficult European external borders, the one with Turkey. Bulgaria has repeatedly proved that when it has the necessary information from European partners, it successfully copes with counter-terrorism. However, Bulgaria's experience shows that in order for the new policy of systematic checks to be successful, the relevant databases must be regularly populated with information from the various services and all Member States must have full access to these systems, especially the SIS. In other words, in order to successfully strengthen cooperation and the exchange of information between the European security services, all countries at the European Union's external borders must join Schengen.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, in the previous debate, I pointed out that so-called foreign fighters and other people who have undergone combat or training in conflict areas are coming to the European Union.After the introduction of the Schengen system, these people are free to move around our territory and we are not able to control their movement or monitor them.It is therefore undoubtedly essential that we ensure that anyone who crosses the external borders of the European Union does not pose a threat to either internal security or public order.We must therefore not only introduce systematic border controls, but also make effective use of the SIS and the Interpol database, which records stolen or lost documents.Such international cooperation is necessary because the European Union cannot fight terrorism alone, let alone win it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that Europe is in the eye of the storm because of the terrorist threat is an objective fact. The proposal of the rapporteur Macovei is to make exit checks at the external borders of the Union systematic with the help of databases and biometric devices. I believe that this hypothesis should be evaluated within the overall framework of the reorganization of European defense systems, coordinating it with other actions undertaken and planned. I believe it is necessary to clarify the mechanism for modulating controls on the intensity of outgoing traffic which, in addition to not hindering the fluidity of movements, must also guarantee equal treatment between citizens. It is essential that Europe respects the principle of proportionality and that any intervention aimed at raising the level of safety does not feed, as often happens, unjustified restrictions on personal freedoms. Ultimately, the desirability of exit checks must be assessed in the light of concrete data, intelligence information and specific research and not by leveraging the fears of citizens or the still painful memory of the attacks in Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in the last month I have visited two Aegean islands, Chios and Samos, and on Saturday I will visit Lesvos. There are at least 16,500 refugees and illegal immigrants trapped on all these islands. There is resentment among the islanders, which has become even greater because a successful visa system upon entering the port has stopped. This system is called "GATE VISA SCHENGEN" and consists of being able to get a visa at the port where the ship will approach, after landing at the port. This visa can be obtained by tourists such as Chinese, Russians and other third-country nationals and pass through, from Turkey, from Kusadasi, where Ephesus is, and visit Samos. So you stopped that. It was allowed for four years as a pilot project and has been stopped by a decision of the Commission. I asked you a written question and I want an answer, even today, to tell me what will happen. Will this exception continue? Because it is not possible to ban legal tourists and have thousands of illegals coming to the islands.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - We would all like our citizens to be safe, so that there is effective protection against terrorism.This regulation is probably necessary, but the question is whether it is a sufficient condition for this, which should, of course, defend against terrorism.And the screening of citizens at all the EU's external borders to prevent terrorism seems to me to be a rather complex measure, especially in terms of its implementation and in terms of technical preparations, the exchange of records, everything that is needed to do so.It is important to know, of course, that the terrorists who caused the attacks in Paris and elsewhere did not come from outside, they are here with us.And that is precisely why it seems to me necessary to have a sense of proportionality here.Above all, I would say that if this measure were effective, would you, then, the Commission, require the Member States to tear down the walls of the internal borders, pick up the wires and thus release the free movement of goods, services and people in accordance with the European Union Constitution?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Madam President, the regulation on systematic audits by the states of all those traveling to and from them is moving in the right direction. But before these checks can be carried out, refugees and migrants, both illegal and illegal, must have been checked and registered at Europe's external borders, so that intrusion is not allowed or at least efforts are made to reduce the intrusion of terrorists inside. in these states, as has unfortunately already happened. This mission must be entrusted to the security authorities of each state, who have both the experience and the will to carry out this mission. The authorities then transmit the information gathered to the respective authorities of the other countries and thus we will have a proper treatment of the phenomenon of terrorism and travelers traveling to European countries will not have any problems.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this debate which I will give a full account of to my colleague Commissioner Avramopoulos, who regrets that he cannot be with us this afternoon. Thank you also for the work that has been done on this proposal, which I agree has been strengthened by those discussions. As we heard in the previous discussion, security is one of the major concerns of our citizens and we believe that the reinforcement of checks against relevant databases will reinforce our external borders and strengthen our knowledge about who enters and leaves our shared space, and that can have an impact. I have seen myself at Charles de Gaulle Airport, where they already implement the systematic checks, the impact that that can have in terms of the increased knowledge about people who are arriving and, in a significant number of cases there, the controls that they were able to conduct as a result of that knowledge.  We are not, in these proposals, creating new databases. This is about checks against the relevant specified databases. But I do agree completely with those who have underlined how important it is that those databases are properly used and properly supplied by the Member States, in particular, the most important and significant of these databases, I believe, the Schengen Information System; which is precisely why, in the proposals that the Commission brought forward in December, which you are going to be discussing, we have made a number of suggestions for strengthening the Schengen Information System and, for the first time, we are proposing the introduction of an obligation on Member States to share information with that system regarding terrorism. I hope that you will support that.  I agree that we need borders that are not just resilient but also functioning and that is why, as a number of speakers have underlined, there are elements of flexibility that are included in these proposals and those depend on risk assessment. So I hope you will support those elements of the proposal as well.  We do need to be very careful about effective implementation; on this, as on all of the issues relating to this area of the security union. That is why I am glad that the Commission has undertaken to present an evaluation on the implementation of these proposals to Parliament within two years following the entry into force of the regulation.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - The issue we are debating today has been under discussion for a long time in the Committee on Civil Liberties, of which I am a member. Undoubtedly, the control and protection of external borders remains the most effective way to ensure the long-term security of the EU. After all, external border controls are carried out to ensure the security of the EU as a whole and its citizens. One of the objectives of such controls is to contribute to the fight against irregular migration and trafficking in human beings, and to prevent all threats to internal security. In such cases, it is advisable to strengthen the protection of the external borders in order to identify more effectively those persons who intend to conceal their true identity. But this system can not become an insurance system, you need to use common sense to solve this issue. Of course, border guards must be able to decide not to check certain databases in the case of a person enjoying EU law on the free movement of persons, provided that the assessment shows that this person does not jeopardize the internal security of any EU country. Such persons include all children under the age of 12 and minors traveling with their parents, schoolchildren traveling on organized excursions, as well as persons holding diplomatic passports. We must not forget that the effectiveness of border guard services depends on the level of their funding, so the EU must give significant support to those countries that have EU external borders.

name: La Présidente.
text: - The agenda calls for the debate on the Council and Commission statement on the exchange of law enforcement information in the Union and the replacement of instruments prior to the Treaty of Lisbon (2017/2504 (RSP)).

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, strengthening the exchange of information is one of the measures which were agreed by the Council as a response to the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels. Besides the enormous importance of collecting information, it is equally important to join up the dots and make the best use of the information.  Last June, the need to address the issue led the Council to endorse a roadmap on information exchange and information management in the Justice and Home Affairs area, including interoperability solutions. The roadmap contains no less than 50 practical short and medium—term actions and long—term orientations. The implementation of those actions is monitored by the Standing Committee on Operational Cooperation on Internal Security. The essence of the roadmap is to make sure that the practitioners have access to the information they need. It provides a coherent framework for a more integrated EU information architecture in the Justice and Home Affairs area. This must obviously happen in full respect of fundamental rights and data protection rules.  Improving information exchange and implementing the roadmap has been a priority of the previous Presidencies and it continues to be a priority for our Presidency. I believe that, based on available statistics, it is fair to say that there has been substantive progress in increasing the information exchange, both among the Member States and with Europol, over the past year. Let me give you some figures to demonstrate this point. For instance, in the third quarter of 2016, more than 200 000 messages were exchanged via the Secure Information Exchange Network Application amongst the Member States, and between the Member States and Europol. This is an increase of 16% compared to the same quarter of the year before, 2015. Regarding new cases, nearly 11 000 new cases were initiated via the same network application in the third quarter of 2016, which amounts to an increase of 6% compared to 2015. As regards the use of Europol’s databases, both the input of data and the number of searches in the Europol information system substantially increased in 2016. The number of searches conducted in this database even set a new record in the third quarter of last year, reaching more than one million searches for the first time. I am aware of the fact that using the existing tools is only one part of the process. The implementation of many of the actions of the roadmap and achieving interoperability of information systems will require certain legislative changes. Important work in this direction is ongoing in the high—level expert group which the Commission set up last April and in which the European Parliament participates. Once the group’s report is presented to Parliament and the Council in April, our common role as co-legislators will be crucial when addressing some of the challenges ahead.  Regarding the various legal instruments, I would like to make the following points. Regarding the exchange of information on terrorism offences, the Council, throughout the negotiations last year on the Counter—Terrorism Directive, was actively engaged in seeking a compromise with Parliament on strengthening the exchange of information. I am glad that Parliament has just had a debate on the directive and will vote on it tomorrow. I would like once again to thank Ms Hohlmeier and her colleagues for their work on the directive. The directive will strengthen the European Union’s legal framework to prevent terrorist attacks, notably by criminalising acts such as training or travelling for terrorist purposes, and it also reinforces the rights of the victims. This morning we had the opportunity to address the media, together with the rapporteur and Commissioner King, on the expectation that tomorrow’s vote on this directive would now pave the way to its adoption. The political agreement on the directive envisages that Member States will be obliged to exchange relevant information gathered in criminal proceedings wherever such information could be used in the prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of terrorist offences, and irrespective of whether there has been a request to that effect.  To ensure better compliance by Member States, an explicit obligation for the receiving competent authorities to take active follow-up measures on such information is also introduced. At the same time Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed that to ensure efficient and timely exchange of information on terrorism, measures in a broader policy context are necessary. In a joint statement the three institutions underlined the necessity of making full use of all the existing Union instruments, channels and agencies to exchange information. A swift implementation of all adopted Union legislation in this field is key.  Madam President, I will stop here – though I can see that in the time that I have been addressing the House, it is no longer Madam President but Mr President – and I now look forward to listening to your debate in the House and responding later.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss this question of EU law enforcement information exchange. Forgive me in advance if some of this gets a bit technical. I know that there are many experts here who can match, indeed far exceed, my technical expertise. EU Member States are in the front line for dealing with many of these issues to do with tackling terrorism, security, and law enforcement. But we can, and should, do all we can at the EU level to help and assist and support EU Member States and EU Member States’ agencies. Information sharing is a key part of that, as we all recognise, and indeed the Member States and their agencies recognise. Unfortunately, and we have already talked about this in earlier discussions this afternoon, some of the recent attacks have shown some weaknesses in the way that information is currently being shared across the European Union and, more generally, in the way that some of these systems are operating currently, including how they operate with each other. The Commission has consistently called on Member States to exploit fully the potential of the existing information systems at EU level. And we work to support the Member States in doing this with funding, expertise and by getting them to share best practice. As I have said on several occasions before this House, EU instruments can only bring added value on the ground, if and when they are fully implemented by the Member States and applied in practice. This is why a key aspect of our work towards an effective and sustainable security union is better application and implementation of existing EU instruments. It is one of the pillars of our work towards a stronger and smarter set of information systems and greater interoperability; it is a key part of the work of the high-level expert group to assess various options and make recommendations to that end. The Commission assists Member States in every possible way to ensure the proper implementation of our agreements, but where necessary we do not shy away from enforcing the law, including the use of infringement procedures. Let me turn to some of the key instruments and give you a brief update on where we stand in terms of their implementation and their use. The main instrument, we have already touched upon it earlier this afternoon, that I am going to address, is the Schengen Information System (SIS). It is the most widely used information-sharing system in Europe and I believe it is a real operational success, thanks in part to our collective – and I include very much the work of the Parliament here – support and work to raise awareness. There is a clear upward trend in the way Member States are using the SIS. To take just one example, there has been a significant increase in checks by, and involvement of Member State security services with this system. An 800% increase in the discreet and specific check alerts issued by those services over the last two years. So I believe we are moving in the right direction, but there is still a long way to go. We need to make technical and operational improvements to the SIS if it is to become more effective and efficient, as we all want. That is why, as I have just said in finishing the last debate, in December, the Commission presented a set of proposals to improve the technical functioning of SIS, to streamline national processes and to strengthen data protection by introducing additional safeguards. In doing so, we propose to turn the current Council decisions on the SIS – which are pre-Lisbon instruments and part of the so-called former third pillar – into regulations to be adopted under the ordinary legislative procedures. From the various improvements tabled I would highlight one in particular: for the first time, we propose to make it obligatory for Member States to issue alerts in SIS for persons related to terrorist offences. I hope you will support that and we stand ready to examine whether such mandatory obligations for information-sharing could/should be introduced for other EU databases. It is important that the co-legislators work together for the swift adoption of these proposed measures. In parallel we are continuing to work with the Member States to ensure the full implementation and effective use of all of our information exchange tools. One well-known tool is the Prüm framework for exchanging data regarding DNA, fingerprints and vehicle registration, and for enhancing cross-border cooperation against crime and terrorism. We are focused on getting to full implementation of this system, which, as you know, was agreed some years ago. Despite all the efforts we have made collectively there are five Member States that still do not comply with the requirements of the Prüm Decision. That is why, for the first time in relation to a former third-pillar instrument, infringement proceedings were launched in September last year. All five Member States have responded; we are looking at their replies and, in the light of those, we will need to take a decision on next steps. We have also got the high-level expert working group looking into the challenge of strengthening and improving the functioning of Prüm cooperation. Another instrument that I want to pause on is the Council framework decision referred to as ‘the Swedish initiative’, well known to you here. It provides a common legal framework for the effective and expeditious exchange of information and criminal intelligence between Member States’ law enforcement authorities. Now good progress has been made, and only one Member State has not notified transposition. But some Member States use the Swedish framework decision more extensively than others – to put it politely – and overall there remains room for improvement. That is why the Commission is currently looking at the Member States’ use of the Swedish initiative and why we plan to launch a compliance study to look into this in more detail. It will help us to determine what is needed to ensure a better use of this important instrument. The last instrument I want to pause on is Council decision 2005/671 on the exchange of information on terrorist offences. This legislation, again well-known to you, requires Member States to designate contact points with responsibility for sending information on terrorist offences to Europol and Eurojust. It defines a minimum base for what types of information should be shared with the two agencies. It requires Member States to transmit information on terrorist offences to Eurojust, Europol and other Member States concerned, unless this would jeopardise ongoing investigations. Information sharing with Europol and Eurojust has increased significantly over the last year. For instance, the number of foreign terrorist fighters communicated to Europol and entered into its Europol information system increased from 3 740 entries in December 2015 to 7 884 entries in December 2016. The volume of data concerning foreign terrorist fighters shared with Europol’s Focal Point Travellers – Europol’s specialist team of analysts and experts who work on analysing information around foreign terrorist fighters – increased almost threefold over the course of 2016. Now I take this progress to be encouraging, but the level of engagement still differs between different Member States. The obligations in the Council decision will be strengthened through the Directive on combating terrorism which you are voting on tomorrow. Thanks to the work of the Parliament, the Directive will make the exchange of information mandatory and include an obligation for the receiving Member State to take appropriate action when they get information. Finally, let me say a few words about our work on information systems and interoperability and the preparatory work at senior officials level that is currently being done by the high-level expert group. President Juncker’s State of the Union address in September and the European Council conclusions of December, refer to the importance of overcoming the current shortcomings in information management and improving the interoperability and interconnection between existing information systems. To accelerate the work of the high-level expert group, the chairman presented an interim report last December. We discussed the findings with some of you in the LIBE Committee in January and I look forward to continuing a discussion on this important subject. Today I would just like briefly to refer to the interim report’s recommendations. First, the Group suggests ways to improve data quality in EU Information Systems. The Commission welcomes this, as information systems are really only as effective as the quality of the data they hold and we intend to pursue the proposals put forward by the Group. Second, the Group proposes to look at a European portal capable of searching simultaneously all relevant EU databases to which the person conducting the search has access rights. Again this would seek to make better use of existing systems in full compliance with existing rules on access, the use of data and data protection rules. I think it is a good suggestion which I commend to you. More generally the process we initiated last year with a strategy presented in April, the setting-up of the high-level expert group, allows us to address shortcomings in the EU information systems in an inclusive and transparent way. The high-level expert group will present its final report later this spring, and, on this basis, the Commission will consider if, and if so what, further measures might increase the effectiveness and help address the current security threats. Any proposals – I think it goes without saying – for amending the existing legal framework will of course need to be taken forward with you in the normal way. On that and indeed all of these issues to do with information exchange, I look forward to continuing the close dialogue that we have between the Commission and the Parliament because these subjects merit it.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear Presidency! First of all, thank you for the very detailed answers. Nevertheless, I want to ask a few critical questions. First of all, I think it is very good that we are talking about replacing the pre-Lisbon instruments, because we have had a say in these issues in the European Parliament since the Lisbon Treaty. It is necessary to implement the terrorism directive, which we will adopt tomorrow, with further legal instruments. We are currently having a lot of talk and are justified in talking about terrorism. However, we also have other forms of serious international crime - in particular organized crime - which in part facilitate each other with terrorist networks, support each other and thus in part develop forms that are dangerous to the state. I think it is particularly important that, firstly, when it comes to the exchange of information, we ensure that all Member States are actually feeding in information, that the information is analyzed - first at national level, then merged at European level - and that we have significantly more manpower when it comes to analyzing information and also to provide technical equipment, because it is thanks to the precise analysis of information that we can prevent serious criminal offenses, and not only to the mere collection of information. Secondly, I think it is very important that we also ensure that data is fed into the SIS. It's been years since we've been debating this, and there are still some who don't feed in - I don't want to believe it! But slowly the last one should have understood. A common list of threats would also be needed, and it would be essential to give the Joint Investigation Teams less bureaucracy and more money to help us have more cross-border cooperation and less ineffective bureaucratic structures.

name: Claude Moraes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his comprehensive assessment. Commissioner, you mention that colleagues here can match you for technical detail. Sadly, we cannot match you for speaking time, so I am only going to identify one or two of the issues that you spread over 12 to 14 minutes.  Ms Hohlmeier mentioned the pre-Lisbon instruments.  Let me say first of all that we must be there; this is why Ms Hohlmeier mentioned the pre-Lisbon instruments. I want to say to Mr Borg: thank you to your JHA Council for keeping up the pressure, and we as a Parliament will want to see the Council face to face, because this is very much about the Member States.  The Commissioner mentioned the Prüm Convention. I only have two minutes, so let me mention the Prüm Convention. In terms of intelligence cooperation this, as the Commissioner mentioned, is the building blocks, the vehicle licensing, the DNA databases. All of the things he said were correct: evaluation, implementation, ensuring that there is cooperation, and ensuring at the bottom of this that there are fundamental rights, the Police Directive. But in the end, if the Member States are not willing to share the basic information, as we saw with the Prüm Convention and as we now see with continuing infringement procedures by the Commission, then we don’t have the genuine sharing of intelligence and police information, and that is the problem.  So, before we have any new legislation or any new avenues, we must have a proper structure in sharing of information which has all of these elements together, which takes the valuable private information of individuals to fight the crime or terrorism that invades our fundamental freedoms. This is the really important area when we see record numbers of searches on the SIS database, when we see records being made on the Europol searches, all of the things that the Commissioner mentioned. The High Level Working Group on Interoperability is now one of the key challenges for us.  I think Parliament is doing its work. There are experts here. In fact, the small number of Members here in the Chamber now are experts, as you as you rightly identified. We are doing our work to ensure that this balance is created, but the key, as the Commissioner said, is implementation and evaluation, and of course we will do our work in relation to fundamental rights. This is such an important area because as soon as there is a terrorist attack, everyone says: have we had the intelligence-sharing? We need to answer, intelligently and with practicality in this House, that we have also done our job.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Currently, information should only be shared in exceptional cases. However, given the changed security situation, the question is whether the exchange of information between Member States on terror and serious crime should remain non-committal. My party is in favor of a thorough exchange of information because it promotes security. Earlier we discussed the border surveillance regulation, which introduces systematic checks for everyone entering or leaving the European Union, including through international airports. The intention is to screen both EU and non-EU citizens by consulting the EU databases, such as the SIS system, and international databases, such as the SLTD system. It goes without saying that those databases must contain relevant data. In addition, the anti-terror directive to be voted on tomorrow requires member states to share relevant intelligence on criminal investigations with other EU countries. The uniform definitions for terror offenses should also facilitate this. At the same time, we understand that intelligence services may share less information if they are obliged to actually share everything with the countries they do not fully trust. The fact that the Council is now considering a directive for a stricter legal framework for the exchange of information and intelligence between law enforcement authorities at Union level is an interesting option. It is really important to arrive at a balanced and widely supported solution.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, we all agree that the exchange of information is essential. Commissioner, I am not going to talk technical today. You've taught us a lesson, so I'm not going to venture that far. I do not dispute the progress that has been made in recent years in the exchange of information, but, Presidency of the Council, this is the least of things after the events we have known. The increase that is observed shows how insufficient it was previously. Therefore, the need remains the same and the little progress made is not enough. I also take careful note of what the Commissioner said - and I welcome it - about the creation of the high level group on interoperability. It is all the same extraordinary, Commissioner, that it was not until the creation of ten to twelve systems for collecting information at European level, in very different matters, before we really began to worry, in a systemic way. , their interoperability. This is not a review, you are not responsible for it. Furthermore, I want to warmly welcome the Commission proposal, which aims to make the reporting of suspected terrorists in the Schengen information system compulsory. But it's not enough, everyone agrees. This obligation concerns only one database, the SIS, and one category of suspected persons, terrorists. Am I wrong, Commissioner? On the other hand, the base from which law enforcement agencies still operate predates Lisbon. We are still in pre-Lisbon. However, the transitional period for actions in the field of information exchange, as set out in the Protocol 36 of the Treaties of the European Union, expired on December 1, 2014, Commissioner, and it is provided in Declaration 50 attached thereto that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission will seek to adoptlegal acts amending or replacing acts of the Union which were adopted before the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.So, Commissioner, when will this proposal be made?

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! When we talk about the fight against terrorism, we must of course also talk about the exchange of data and how the two Council decisions from 2005 and 2006 are actually implemented. Lo and behold, most recent terrorist attacks have shown that this is precisely what is lacking. Any suspects have been suspicious for a long time, are then arrested, let out again for lack of evidence, only to turn up at crime scenes at some point. The necessary data exchange - we know that - doesn't work at the front and back. I wonder why someone is known as a terrorist suspect in one EU country and the other neighboring country does not know that. There are three options: Either - and you said that, Mister King - the member states are not implementing EU law properly, or the information that is exchanged is the wrong one, or both. That is precisely why we need a comprehensive qualitative evaluation of the existing instruments in the Member States too. And the point is not to create even more databases en masse, to accumulate even more data, but to achieve a targeted exchange. This is the only way to make progress - and that is what we are asking for.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner King, it is exactly what you have outlined here: the better use of the existing infrastructure that we have in place, especially when it comes to the Europol Information System, the Schengen Information System, and those databases which we already have in place for the exchange of information on risks and on suspects. That is what we have to improve and I really appreciate that you are taking this on your agenda and I would really see that Member States are supporting you in making better use of these systems. Because what we have been talking about for years is very often the wrong way, to say that the systems are too few, that there should be more systems in place, that there should be more pots of data in place, because we have just been saying that more data would do the trick. But the point is that very often we have the data, as has been said often in this debate, and it is not being used. One case we saw recently was the Berlin attacker who was very well known to the intelligence services in Germany at least, and who, even after this attack in Berlin, was fleeing through some Member States, even France which is in a state of emergency, with a weapon in his hand, and I think that shows very much that we have to divert away from spending big money into new systems, rather than investing, and that should be our focus in the cooperation between the police authorities, for example in the field of joint investigation teams with Europol.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, are there better topics than this to prove that no member state can do it alone, how we must cooperate, how the problem of migration and terrorism has called us to cooperation. Not only did the member states not exchange data, not that the provinces did not exchange data, but even some city districts did not cooperate with each other, if we remember the recent terrorist attacks. That is the question we must all ask ourselves. Today we have heard here that we want less bureaucracy, but still more technology, and that we must not all get entangled in a new bureaucracy, new systems. We have a lot of different systems, but we are not working on their interoperability. That is what we want to say to both the Commission and the Council today - interoperability is essential. We, as the European Parliament, have been given the right to co-decide after the Lisbon Treaty and we have that responsibility, but the responsibility is also on the Member States and today the question is what is the Schengen system, what is the SIS, how do we think about those countries which are Member States and which are not part of the Schengen system. Specifically, I come from Croatia, we do everything to meet all the criteria, we are waiting for the evaluation and we want to be part of that system in order to cooperate equally and change the data equally. This is a topic that may need to be addressed today, as five countries still do not exchange data, but so five countries are still not members of that system, I call on both the Commission and the Council, and members of certain committees in this House, to help us of that system so that we can work together and exchange information that is an obligation. I welcome the new Directive that we will adopt tomorrow.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, after the terrorist attacks in the United States of America, the European Council stated at its extraordinary meeting in September 2001 that terrorism is a real challenge to the world and to Europe, and that the fight against terrorism would be a priority objective of the European Union. The Council decided to increase cooperation between Europol, Eurojust, the EU intelligence services and police forces, and adopted some decisions. Although the situation in the EU has changed since that time, the current legal framework at European Union level for the exchange of information and intelligence is still mostly subject to pre—Lisbon instruments. The EU Treaties enable the adoption of legal acts amending or replacing the acts of the Union in the fields of police cooperation and cooperation in criminal matters which were adopted before the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.  After numerous terrorist attacks in Europe, the European Council promised to make some changes and to improve the exchange of information to address the current security challenges facing the EU. So we need change to strengthen the legal framework for the exchange of law enforcement and intelligence information at European Union level and we need Parliament’s participation in this process.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - After every terrorist attack in Europe we hear afterwards that the cooperation and sharing of information between member states, between security services of member states, was not optimal. We have therefore regularly called on the Member States from the European Parliament to take action in this area. That is quite right. The lack of cooperation between Member States worsens the sense of security for our citizens and a lot has already happened. The Commissioner rightly also refers to the Prüm system and Claude Moraes, our colleague, also mentioned it as a cornerstone of that exchange. At the same time, I hear from many practitioners that the Prüm system is outdated and slow and I would like to ask the Commissioner if he can comment on that. But more has happened. We have the data sharing articles in the terrorism directive that we will vote on tomorrow. We have the same articles in the PNR Directive. We are seeing - as the Commissioner rightly pointed out - an increase in data sharing via Europol. We are working on interoperability. That is all very good, but it is not enough and the fact that we are still working with Council decisions from 2005, 11-12 years ago, says it all. We cannot fight tomorrow's terror with yesterday's tools. We have to take action and we will have to learn from our mistakes. And to learn from our mistakes we will have to examine those mistakes. Given the transnational nature of many of the attacks that have taken place in recent years, such an investigation should take place at European level. I am therefore a strong supporter of Manfred Weber's proposal to set up such an investigation committee from within the European Parliament and I ask all colleagues to support it wholeheartedly.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon has been the most important step in reforming and consolidating the European Union since its establishment. At the same time, today's realities show us that there are arrears on the part of the Member States, which create major difficulties in meeting the commitments and obligations assumed to ensure security and stability at EU level. Recent armed attacks in various cities and capitals within the Union show that terrorism has become a real threat to the lives and security of the citizens of the European Union. The answer to this problem must be cross-border, and in this respect the authorities of the Member States must have access to relevant data included in files, documents, information, objects or other information as soon as possible. means of proof retained in connection with terrorist offenses committed in another Member State. The European Union institutions must make every effort to create up-to-date instruments and adopt an efficient, rigorous and harmonized legal framework. They must make the Member States accountable for the fulfillment of their obligations, namely to provide each other with information on terrorist offenses and not only and, I emphasize, not only, to enable decisions to be taken in real time. Only by strengthening the legal framework of the Union and cooperation between Member States will it be possible to combat terrorism in all its forms, while ensuring respect for a fundamental right of a citizen, namely the right to life.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to your speech, which has been really extensive and of good quality, and thank you for it, but the whole debate that has taken place here has clearly shown that the key issue is the reluctance of individual Member States to share information. I think this is probably the biggest problem, and even if we adopt a directive tomorrow that sets out new obligations for the Member States, I believe that the Commission and the Council need to put constant pressure on the Member States and point out that without the willingness of individual States, no best system will work. In short, this is a reality, and any adoption of new rules will not solve the situation without the willingness of the Member States. Personally, I wanted to highlight the issues of Europol and its new counter-terrorism center, as I see the first results, and you also mentioned it, this center is starting to work well and the amount of information that is being exchanged is growing. Therefore, I ask for more financial support from this institute.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
