text: – Mr President, Mr Borg, Commissioner King, the European Union’s area of freedom, security and justice was created to ensure free movement of persons and to provide its citizens with a high level of security. In recent years terrorism has become a real challenge to the world and to Europe. Therefore, to make the fight against terrorism a priority objective of the European Union, as the Council stated many times, requires better collaboration between Europol, Eurojust and Member States’ intelligence services. I agree with Commissioner King that some of the recent terrorist attacks showed the weaknesses in the sharing of information between Member States. Information exchange needs to be improved at their level in order to facilitate the performance of EU bodies. In this matter, the role of the European Parliament as a co-legislator is more than necessary in improving the legal framework to ensure that certain information vital for law enforcement authorities is exchanged in good time within the Union, but of course, not forgetting data protection.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Council has repeatedly reiterated its commitment to improving the exchange of information in order to address the current security challenges facing the European Union. However, the legal framework currently in place for such exchange between the authorities in charge, including the exchange of information on terrorist offenses, is still largely subject to instruments prior to the Lisbon Treaty. The slowness with which the Union is working on prevention is not admissible, especially in a historical moment in which European citizens feel the need for security more. I believe it is essential that the Commission act decisively, launching an infringement procedure against Member States which are reluctant to share information to which they are obliged by the current legal framework, and in the meantime make an ambitious proposal for a directive aimed at guaranteeing a legal framework compliant and stricter for the exchange of law enforcement and intelligence information at Union level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, matters of internal security and public policy, such as the fight against terrorism, are the sole responsibility of the Member States of the Union. At the same time, it is a given that when gathering data, the constitutional conditions that exist in each state must be respected and, of course, the protection of private rights must be ensured. Of course, the exchange of information between Member States is particularly useful. We must not forget that the European Council has repeatedly emphasized the need to improve the exchange of information, especially in the field of law enforcement, and also to strengthen the budget of the European Police Office. It is a given that the current EU law on the exchange of information needs to be modernized, and in this context this debate is taking place, because it is still one of the pre-existing instruments of the Lisbon Treaty. The exchange of information is therefore important, as is the intervention of the European Commission and the European Union, but only if the conditions relating to the protection of private interests are met.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner King, on strengthening the exchange of information available between police and judicial agencies in order to better combat the terrorist threat, we have spoken a lot this afternoon in the European Parliament, and I want to say two things with complete conciseness. The first: interoperability must be strengthened, because we have the SIE, the SIS (first and second generation), we have PNR and no investment will be enough if we do not guarantee the availability of all the information and the political will of the police and judicial authorities to share it. And the second, legal: the five-year period established by the Lisbon Treaty itself to adapt to Lisbon all the instruments of cooperation in the field of information foreseen in the Decisions of 2005 and the Framework Decision of 2006 has expired long ago. It is imperative, first, that the Commission offers an assessment of non-compliance and requires compliance with those pre-Lisbon instruments. But, secondly, that it guarantees the definitive adaptation of that 2005 Decision and that of 2006 - the Framework Decision - to the Lisbon Treaty with full guarantee of the fundamental rights of Europeans.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Borg, Commissioner, efforts to prevent and combat terrorism must be stepped up, we all agree, given the attacks of the last year. This report is welcome, but implementation of measures and collaboration between Member States is essential. As the report shows, the fight against terrorism is a global fight and the European Union cannot tackle and win on its own. Communication and transmission of information is important, but not sufficient. The 2014 UN Security Council resolution imposes an obligation on Member States to criminalize certain terrorist offenses, and you must, Commissioner, follow this if it applies. You talked about the Schengen information system, it's very good. The problem is that we have the borders of the European Union and outside the Schengen area and you have to do everything possible for non-Schengen states to enter the exchange of information, because, in the end, the passage of terrorists is cross-border and we must to be concerned with the border of the European Union. I hope, however, that we will take steps to combat terrorism and ensure peace in the world, because peace saves lives.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Council decisions on data exchange between Member States should take into account the provisions as agreed in the Lisbon Treaty. This should have been done years ago, but unfortunately nothing has been done yet. This matter is of utmost importance for the security of European citizens. There is an urgent need to improve information sharing among and between the Member States, and for instruments such as the new so-called Police Directive on data protection, providing a high level structure for information exchange. I believe it is important to ensure fundamental rights protection as well, the necessity and proportionality of what is exchanged, and the data protection and privacy issues on how the data is exchanged and between whom – speaking now about the respective institutions.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I shall follow the discipline of previous speakers. We are all agreed that it is absolutely crucial that we fully exploit the potential of existing information systems at EU level, and that means making sure that all Member States implement what they have agreed to do and that we also find ways of encouraging the effective use of these tools by frontline practitioners on the ground, with effective cooperation between police, border guards and immigration officers. For me, implementation is absolutely the priority, and that applies whether the instrument in question is a pre-Lisbon instrument or one that has been adopted since by Parliament and the Council. To support that implementation, we have funding: we have the Internal Security Fund (ISF), which continues to fund national programmes in this area, and we have extra funding that has been dedicated to supporting the agencies, notably Europol to reinforce staffing for the new European Counter Terrorism Centre (ECTC). We have expertise and we have the sharing of best practice. We will continue to support all of those means. We will also continue to look at what we need to do to plan for the future and to adapt the information tools we have to make them as effective as possible, and that applies to the Prüm Convention as well, although I have to say, in direct response to a direct question, that right now, as of today, we do not have a proposal on Lisbonisation. That question remains open, and if that can help effective implementation we will certainly examine it. You, the European Parliament, continue to play an absolutely key role because, as today’s debate has shown, you rightly point the finger at areas where further improvement is needed, and that helps maintain pressure. It maintains pressure on the Member States, as we have been discussing, but, frankly, it also maintains pressure on the Commission to continue the important work on implementation that we have all agreed is at the heart of making progress.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner, for the disciplined manner you expressed yourself, but these discipline requirements do not apply to you.Thank you, however, that was very kind of you.Minister, the time restrictions do not apply to you either.

name: Ian Borg

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Information sharing is a fundamental pillar of the Union's internal security strategy. It is already a commonplace, unfortunately, to recognize that Member States' cooperation in this area is still far from perfect. However, the Union is possibly undergoing one of the most intense overhauls of its information systems, with changes to SIS, VIS and EURODAC, alongside the creation of the new entry and exit system and ETIAS. In parallel, although ideally it should be upstream, the High Level Group for information systems and interoperability will publish, in May this year, the results of its work. It is clear that the PRUM decisions and the Council Decision for the sharing of information in the context of terrorism must be adapted to the new challenges and the new legal framework of the Lisbon Treaty. However, caution is advised. Any changes must be made taking into account the entire landscape of information systems - only in this way will it be possible to ensure effectiveness, proportionality and necessity. Otherwise, we will not be protecting our citizens.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. - The quality of the dialogue between EU Member States and the exchange of information within the relevant instruments must be continuously ensured to ensure an adequate level of internal security in the EU. It is imperative that information exchange instruments be made even more efficient and that any existing gaps be closed. The definition of terrorism is not closed and should already be expanded now. The European Parliament should also unequivocally advocate increasing the effectiveness of its actions, seeking to strengthen the confidence of citizens. The method of Community decision-making should aim to use, in this context, the possibilities provided by the Lisbon Treaty. However, the exchange of information itself is not everything, it is necessary to react and coordinate effectively, otherwise it will be difficult to construct an efficiently functioning network of entities from different EU countries with access to clear and unambiguous data generated for use by various units related to security. Intensive work of representatives on the forum of international organizations is also needed, as well as further strengthening the Common Foreign and Security Policy, caring for peace and development in the EU's neighborhood and promoting the best democratic principles and values.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Mady Delvaux, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, with recommendations to the Commission on civil law rules for robotics (2015/2103 (INL)) (A8-0005 / 2017).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, robot, artificial intelligence, internet of things: so many concepts with which we must familiarize ourselves. They are not science fiction: all kinds of robots are already on the market, new, more autonomous robots are being developed in laboratories. It is therefore urgent that the widest possible debate takes place and that it not remain compartmentalized in the circle of scientists and engineers, because it is a question of organizing, for the good of man, the interaction human beings with these new increasingly autonomous machines. I would like to clarify two points at the outset: firstly, robots are not humans and there is no question of equating them with human beings, and secondly, European robotics industry and research are very efficient and we let’s support them. Robotics and artificial intelligence are sectors of the future. It is important that Europe remains competitive in the global market. This is why the time has come to set out principles that will serve as guidelines and a framework for the development of robotics. Regulate, without excess, when necessary. First of all, there is the question of civil liability in the event of damage caused by a robot. There are two options: either strict liability or risk-based management, but the main thing is that there be redress for the damage caused. Standardization must be accelerated. To ensure the highest level of security possible, protocols must be established. As for testing, why not create areas in Europe where all kinds of robots can be tested in real life in real life? The biggest challenge is the enforcement of data protection regulations. Robots collect and receive masses of information of all kinds: who owns this data, who has access to it? The report proposes an ethics charter, a code of ethics for programmers, because we want robots whose actions serve the well-being of humans and which respect dignity, privacy and freedom. We stress the need for transparency, for robot actions to be explained and explainable, and understandable to ordinary people. The deployment of robots will have an impact on all aspects of life and therefore on work. Studies diverge: some predict a massive destruction of jobs, others are less pessimistic and believe that the jobs destroyed will be offset by the creation of new jobs. However, it is clear that our ways of working will change and that our education systems will be faced with enormous challenges in ensuring the retraining of those who are in work and training young people in professions that do not yet exist. The report is not technophobic, it identifies the positive contributions: robots can perform dangerous or arduous work, they will facilitate the work of many professionals, they will promote the integration of people with a disability. But no one can predict whether robots will destroy more jobs than they create. On the other hand, I listen to my fellow citizens and I hear great concern from many of them. So I think we have to take them seriously, prepare for different scenarios and think about possible solutions. If, indeed, work becomes scarce, we must ensure that all our citizens have sufficient income to live a life of dignity. This is why I am arguing for a rational debate, supported by expertise and studies, on the option of a universal income and, of course, how to finance it by seeking alternative sources of finance. I don't want the debate to be killed before it has begin.In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleagues who made it possible to enrich this report, the secretariat, the services of Parliament and above all the STOA team who have accompanied us in this wonderful adventure.

name: Michał Boni
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, (inaudible) opportunities of robotics. Let us take the most recent ones. Firstly, the fast development of learning machines requires rules, European harmonised standards and the possibility to register all artificial intelligence and have it monitored. Secondly, ethical principles and respect for fundamental rights are crucial. This should begin from the moment constructors start the work with algorithms on privacy and security, to make those by default. Thirdly, it is crucial to raise awareness and avoid, through ethical guidance, the emotional dependency of humans cooperating with robots. Fourthly, this is not the time for strong regulation. It is better to use the soft-law principles approved by all stakeholders in the Code of Conduct, using existing laws and adjusting them to the new challenges. Fifthly, this is not the time for new taxes, but we have to continue work on the liability problem. Sixthly, we need transition-period programmes for workers so that people can adjust to the new challenges both mentally and professionally. This is better than a general basic income. Now it is time to hear from the Commission.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Mister President! The subject we are dealing with here today is very far-reaching and very groundbreaking. I believe that we cannot yet estimate the dimensions that will affect this from our current point of view. This development has the potential to change our lives in a lasting and big way. It's not about replacing human capabilities, it is about complementing human capabilities. This will not only affect the area of ​​traffic, it will not only affect the area of ​​health services and rescue services, but it will affect many areas of life that we are not even thinking about today. I had the opportunity to draft the TRAN committee's opinion. This was also adopted by a large majority in the committee. Of course, traffic is a topic that is particularly affected by the automated sector. This is not just traffic as we know it today, in the air, on water and on land, but everything that can be imagined that there will or can be in the future in the field of traffic. I am particularly interested in this topic because in my hometown of Graz in Austria the first attempts are already being made with two automobile developers regarding automated locomotion. The subject - as I said - will keep us busy for a long time. It's actually still in its infancy. All the more exciting and all the greater are the challenges that are still waiting for us and that are to come.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Věra Jourová let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Delvaux, and all the MEPs involved. This is a crucial report on all the legal questions related to development of robotics and artificial intelligence. This House, to my knowledge, will be one of the first to have a clear and comprehensive position on robotics and artificial intelligence, a topic that is getting great public attention, and rightly so. Your text highlights the challenges and opportunities of this sector, and points towards a clear need for a coherent European approach. You are also calling for Europe to have a strong presence and investment in its technology in order to maintain leadership. In the European Commission, we have long recognised the importance and the potential of robotics and artificial intelligence, and the need for significant investment in these areas. We have set an ambitious public and private partnership for robotics in Europe: Sparc. This partnership not only brings the academic and research institutions, industry and business together, but also looks into questions related to ethics and law. Sparc is by far the biggest civilian research programme in this area in the world, with EUR 700 million from EU funding from Horizon 2020 to be leveraged up to EUR 2.8 billion by private investment. Ladies and gentlemen, for a very long time, robots were a kind of a futuristic idea. Today, they are a fact of life. They are operational in our industry and used in many sectors of the economy and life. Robots in the internet of things are going to be the internet of the intelligent things, and they will move beyond manufacturing and industry into areas such as transportation, medicine, care for the elderly, and financial services. As Mr Mayer said, they will complement human skills. And let me tell you that this is only the beginning. Without doubt, we need to frame and facilitate the technical revolution brought by autonomous systems, because we all want Europe to remain the leader in this field and make sure robotics and artificial intelligence continue to bring benefits to European citizens, industry and especially SMEs and start-ups that are active in this sector. As Commissioner for Research, Science and Innovation, I recognise that we have to further invest in scientific understanding of the technical aspects of artificial intelligence and of its socio-economic impacts, as well as of its consequences for the rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy. But let me stress that moving forward in this area needs to be guided by an ethical approach based on principles and values enshrined in the Treaty on the European Union and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Let me now comment in particular on your request for the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal on civil liability for damage caused by robots. First, as you know, we already have EU legislation applying to robots. The Machinery Directive, the General Product Safety Directive, the proposed legislation on medical devices, and the regulation on common rules in the field of civil aviation currently under revision also includes concrete measures to ensure the safe operation of civil drones. And the new General Data Protection Regulation that will also be fully applicable to any kind of processing of personal data, which includes artificial intelligence and robots. Second, we are obviously looking at any need for adjustment of the current legislation. And third we are well aware that legal certainty on liability is of paramount importance for innovators, investors and consumers, providing them with the legal certainty they need. But the complexity of digital technologies makes it particularly difficult to determine who is liable and to what extent in case of failure. That is why the Commission has put in its communication and presented a communication last month on building up a European data economy. We are consulting with a wide range of stakeholders on the new challenges in this field, covering the liability questions relating to autonomous systems. Simultaneously, we are evaluating the Product Liabilities Directive with regard to emerging technologies. Fourth, testing and experimenting will be important as will gathering data and gaining experience. This in turn will then help us with designing a suitable legal framework. On the communication on building a new European data economy, we included plans for cross-border corridors to test connected automated driving. My fifth and final point on the question of legislation is to underline the importance of smart legislation, technologically neutral and future proof when dealing with technologies and jobs. As Ms Delvaux said, we cannot even imagine what they will be in the future. Honourable Members, I agree with you that the impact of digitalisation on our societies and our labour market needs to be closely monitored and anticipated, and we have to improve our understanding of this phenomenon. The different studies that have assessed that evolution reached diverging conclusions from catastrophic predictions on the labour market to a positive impact on job creation. In 2015, the Fraunhofer Institute indicated that EU companies which are intensive users of robotics are less likely to offshore production to low-cost regions because robots improve their cost production so much that they can stay in high-wage regions and create other jobs. We all know that technological change will not only replace or change existing tasks, but it will, as Mr Mayer said, create new jobs in services, it will complement human skills. Robots are also used in many areas with labour shortages such as healthcare, farming and even manufacturing. Many robots do tasks that are repetitive and dangerous for humans, such as inspecting oil tanks or welding metal parts. Far from replacing humans, robots allow the workforce to focus on other more economically useful, creative or social activities where robots cannot and will never replace us. The Commission is fully aware of the challenges ahead and has already launched concrete measures to address them. We adopted a New Skills Agenda for Europe, the Digitising European Industry blueprint and, last December, we launched a Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition, which aims at equipping the workforce at large with the necessary digital skills to thrive in a digital workplace. Ladies and gentlemen once again, I would like to thank the European Parliament for this timely and comprehensive report and for the support for our activities. The issues raised and the measures proposed will need broader consultation and an in-depth analysis of their impact and consequences before we can draw conclusions, including on the possible legislative needs. Thank you for attention and I’m looking forward to our discussion.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner!It is with great satisfaction that I note your speech in response to Mrs Delvaux's appeal or the quotation of Mr Mayer.That means we are having a debate here.Thank you very much for that, Commissioner.

name: Ádám Kósa
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - Ladies and gentlemen! Thanks to a year and a half of working together, the rapporteur, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, is taking the initiative to examine whether the proliferation of robots alone brings prosperity and development at a time when we already see that human work is often not needed in traditional ways. production and service structures. In the short to medium term, robotics and artificial intelligence do promise benefits, but it is feared that the number of jobs appearing in this area will not grow as much as the number of jobs expected to be lost. The next generations need to be educated to meet these challenges through appropriate education. An answer needs to be found as to what happens when people with superpowers appear through the artificial or genetic enhancement or supplementation of existing human capabilities. The report could be the first step towards the European Union and the Member States taking these issues seriously.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, books and movies are very good starters for emotional discussions about robotics, but they are not very good to be basing our decisions on. Our role as decision makers is not to get emotional but to look at the facts and shape our serious and forward-looking EU policies on robots and artificial intelligence. If we think about robots in terms of Star Wars and Terminator, we get it wrong. Robots and artificial intelligence are already here in our daily lives, helping us to solve complex tasks. I said ‘helping’ because robots need to compliment humans: both need to, and can, work as a team. Our role is to drive policy that makes individuals active consumers of robots rather than passive ones. We cannot, however, have active and empowered individuals if we shift all the responsibility onto robots or manufacturers if something goes wrong. This is the problem with the strict liability approach or an electronic personality for robots. Last but certainly not least, we should not forget that developing autonomous robots and putting them on the market requires risk-taking investment and vision. So let us focus not only on precaution but also on innovation. Introducing a tax on robots, for instance, will simply kill innovation and drive the engineers developing robots elsewhere, and we will be left using the robots instead of creating them. Forward-looking and pro-innovation EU policy should exist not only in words but also in action.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, unlike the fears raised in the report, we should limit ourselves to the current realities of robotic systems and what is needed to help develop the regulatory environment to allow their increased used and manufacturing in Europe. As legislators we need to keep our vision closer to the ground. While I am honoured that the report makes note of the important role of the Czech nation in the creation of the word ‘robot’ and in our literature as a Czech, I believe it is wrong to mix science fiction and a real need to address issues like liability. We must reject the belief that robots are going to steal everyone’s job. This is simply not true. We must reject that we are creating ‘electronic persons’: I am sorry, but robots are not humans, it is pure science fiction to think otherwise. We must reject attacks on robots, and a new EU agency. The bottom line: go and see the robots that exist today and those in development. They are already transforming our industry and society and I believe for the better. This transformation is not something to fear. By 2025, in less than 10 years, robotics could add more than EUR 1 trillion to our European economy. The benefits far outweigh any risks. But if we are to succeed in this field, we must ensure that the rules of the single market apply fully.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, medical robot devices already provide better diagnoses and better insight into treatment, care and rehabilitation options, and will move forward the boundaries of medicine in the future. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety focused in the opinion on the importance of keeping the patient-doctor relationship as regards to diagnosis, treatment and follow-up. We also focused on the importance of medical education and the training of health professionals: human care-givers will still be needed and will continue to provide an important source of social interaction. We emphasised, too, the importance of minimising the possible environmental and ecological footprint of robotics and maximising the potential for making processes more resource efficient. Assessment of the long-term moral and ethical implications of new technologies before and throughout their development is imperative. And, last, but not least, we need safety safeguards and standard safety certification procedures, and adaptation of the legislation on patient privacy, medical professional secrecy and data protection in the area of public health. The provisions on the aspects mentioned above were adopted with a large majority in the Environment Committee and I was happy to see that Ms Delvaux took these ideas on board in the final Committee on Legal Affairs report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –  Mr President, working on this report has brought me in touch with several people who are passionate about using robotics to address daily challenges and to continue to increase knowledge of our world. We should be proud of this European industry and we should give it a reliable European framework within which it can continue to grow. Robotics and connectivity go beyond borders: innovation is carried out by experts from several Member States working together. This collaboration requires our support.  The report starts a debate on robotics and brings to the fore different possibilities and solutions. The report is prescriptive only on one element: robots are not human; no matter how autonomous and self-learning they become, they do not attain the characteristics of a living human. Our work discusses solutions to liability for damages caused by robots. Who will be responsible? How will any legal solution affect the development of robotics, those who own them, and victims of the damage? The current legal framework on liability may not entirely work for robotics, so we need to consider the impact of different solutions to make sure that harm caused to persons and to our environment will be addressed. Ethical considerations also need to be made, so we can set an ethical framework within which robotics will develop. In all of this we have to understand how robotisation of industry and professions will affect our workers and our professionals, and find ways to provide the right skills and support. Allow me also to thank Ms Delvaux and all the rapporteurs who have worked on this report. I think that together we have managed to produce a report which deserves a plenary vote in favour.

name: Virginie Rozière
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this fascinating report, which leads us to think about the future and to go beyond our vision of the world as it is. It is also a courageous report, because sometimes we are a little dizzy at the extent of the field we have to clear. It is true that it might be more comfortable to look away and imagine that if we refuse to look at these questions, they will disappear on their own, or else to rely solely on the industry and think that from a strictly economic point of view, it will find solutions. On the contrary, I believe that a secure legal framework, based on the values ​​of the European project, humanist values, is both an asset for European companies and a guarantee of well-being and security for European citizens. What are these questions that we face? Legal questions on liability, security and intellectual property; ethical questions on respect for private life, bioethics and democracy, on the transparency of decisions; and then questions about the very organization of society: what distribution of wealth and what impact on the labor market? In conclusion, I would like to relate to all those who refuse the debate, who say that those who ask the question know nothing about technology, the words of Elon Musk, who knows a little bit about technological innovation. . Two days ago, he said: “There will be fewer and fewer tasks that a robot cannot do and better than a human being. It’s not something I wish for, it’s something that is very likely to happen and a universal income of some sort will become necessary. ” So, my friends, let’s not shy away from the debate, we have a lot to think about and debate together to invent the solutions of tomorrow.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I still have reasonable doubts about this report as a whole. My doubts are of a moral, ethical and any other nature, and I am hesitant to recommend a negative vote on my group's report. I agree that robotics and artificial intelligence are very fast-moving technologies in some sectors, and it is necessary to discuss the issues that arise from this. But let me reiterate my concerns, especially when it comes to this legislative proposal. Not only are there issues related to ethics, morality and social impact that need to be addressed in detail, but there are also much more important, more fundamental issues, such as the application of the so-called A "universal approach" on this issue. Furthermore, ladies and gentlemen, the difference between technological progress in the Member States of the European Union's central and peripheral regions has not been taken into account in the document in question. Last but not least, the burden will fall on consumers. This proposal, which at some point could become European Union legislation, has the ability to oblige citizens of all Member States to pay even more insurance, costs that will fund a new robot insurance scheme such as the Robotics Agency. and artificial intelligence. Neither insurers nor the industry itself would support this early initiative. I firmly believe that the legislative proposal is too early at this stage, and I believe that more in-depth research and discussion is needed.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, by 2025 more than 20% of European citizens will be over 60. While increased life expectancy represents a significant resource to EU societies, it will also demand fundamental reforms of the health care sector as well as [engendering a] need to tackle a higher prevalence of injuries and diseases. Cyber physical systems (CPS), so-called healthcare robots, will incontestably be part of this solution. Robots and smart devices will be more and more incorporated into diagnosis, treatment and care at hospitals and healthcare centres. The development of new technological devices will lead to healthier societies and quicker recovery times, and will decrease the number of medical errors. Furthermore, CPS is a growing market in healthcare, and will create numerous jobs and businesses in the medical field. I therefore take a positive view of the major positive outcomes for the healthcare sector throughout the EU.  I therefore also support the report even if I found it sometimes fearful. In particular it mentioned the future discussion that will need to be had on the costs of medical secrecy, legal liability and patients’ privacy.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the word robot and robotics was given to humanity by the great Czech writer and playwright Karel Čapek. And even ninety years ago, he estimated what problems humanity would encounter with robots and robotics. Advancing automation is a reality in front of which we cannot stick our heads in the sand. We find ourselves in a situation similar to that of the workers in the manufactories, when their work began to be replaced by machines. Even today, we should be mainly interested in the impact of the development of robotics on the labor market. While the European Commission envisages € 8 billion in investment in support of robotics in its SPARC program, as it should help create as many as 240,000 new jobs in industry and other sectors by 2020, there are also studies showing the opposite figures. up to catastrophic. For example, in the Czech Republic alone, up to 140,000 people should lose their jobs by 2025 and a number of fields should disappear. Whatever the outlined scenarios come true, it is evident that for many the time is coming to an end, when one job, one profession, has become a livelihood for life. The field of education in particular will have to respond, the emphasis must be on education in new, creative and future-oriented fields. As the rapporteur rightly states in her report, we will have to find answers not only to legal, but also to ethical and social issues related to robotics. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – You referred to the industrial revolution and machines taking over the jobs of humans, but don’t you agree that actually the machines took over the really back-breaking jobs that humans did and the humans could then do something else?

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Undoubtedly you are right and I could answer with a quote from Karl Marx that when machines release a person, then the person will have the most valuable thing, it is his own time.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! Yes, we are at the beginning of future-oriented legislation on the whole subject of robotics, and Ms. Delvaux's report is an important first step towards a debate on the question: What regulations are necessary, what questions do we have to answer? But robotics and artificial intelligence are no longer science fiction, they are taking place, and they are already among us. There are robots among us. The question of which rules are needed, especially with regard to liability, especially with regard to safety standards, we have to answer now. I am a bit surprised at how reluctant the European Commission is to point out what problems there are and how complicated the questions are. We are of the opinion that, especially when it comes to questions of liability, the question of responsibility, that behind every decision made by a robot or an intelligent machine there must of course be a natural or legal person, that there must be no liability gaps and that we Impact assessments and technology impact assessments must be made mandatory, we must also require that there is a framework for how, for example, the precautionary principle is firmly anchored in this question. These are important areas of regulation that must now be answered. And there is also, for example, the question of security standards, liability for missing standards. If someone hacked into the intelligent self-driving car and slowed it down to zero at 70, 80 things on the freeway, then that's a problem we have today. And now we have to find answers to that.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the great advances in robotics and the possibility that artificial intelligence surpasses human intelligence require ethical and moral reflections which we cannot avoid. Ethical issues do not only concern man-machine interaction, but also ontological problems relating to personal identity, with reference to bionic interventions aimed at recovering or strengthening the sensorimotor and cognitive abilities of human beings, and the issue of responsibility, which it presents itself in all its drama, especially with reference to drones for military use. Who is responsible for the humanitarian violations committed through their use? And again the theme concerning the ability to make choices in extreme situations, where the ethical component represents a determining element of the choice. How would a car without a driver behave if it had to choose, in the event of a sudden skidding, between the safety of the passenger in the car and that of a group of people at the edge of a road. The report on robotics addresses these issues, charting a possible path that deserves to be further explored.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, intelligent robots have become a reality. These are machines programmed to make decisions, like, for example, driverless cars or some surgical robots. The Delvaux report is right to be concerned about this, because their intelligence will, in the near future, exceed the intellectual capacities of human beings. It is therefore necessary to frame their use by ethical principles, such as respect for private life and human freedom. In terms of liability, alas, the Delvaux report recommends dangerous solutions, because it does not limit itself - as it should have done - to recommending the establishment of a compulsory insurance scheme and a fund. warranty. It envisages, in effect, the creation of a legal personality specific to robots, which would amount to considering robots as - and I quote - "responsible electronic persons". I object to this prospect for two reasons: first, because it would exonerate their manufacturers and users of all liability, which would undoubtedly delight powerful lobbies; secondly and above all, because I believe, like Jacques Maritain, that the human person has a spiritual superexistence to which no artificial intelligence can be compared.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Delvaux, and all the colleagues in the JURI Committee who took part in this report. I also enjoy it personally, because in my country, the Czech Republic, a lot of effort is being put into this field. After all, the word robot was given to us by the Czech writer Karel Čapek. This report does not correctly make legislative proposals, but raises fundamental issues that will need to be addressed by legislation. The aim of the report is to ensure that, on the basis of it, the legal order can continue to fulfill its basic function, namely to provide legal certainty to producers and users. By launching the debate, we will give the European Union a chance to become a standard-setter in the field of robotics. I support this report as a whole, but on some points, especially with regard to the creation of a special legal status for robots or basic income, I will support the amendments. I think that would be too far from a predictable reality.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this document which defines the rules of civil law on robotics. The importance of this report is given by the real trends in European industry and economy. In recent years, sales of robots have increased by an average of 17% per year, while in 2014 alone, we are talking about an increase of almost 30% generated by the latest developments in the field of vehicles. In fact, annual patent filings for robotic technology have tripled in the last decade, and many countries, such as Japan, the United States, China and South Korea, are considering regulatory measures related to robotics and artificial intelligence. The report defines the general principles regarding the development of robotics and brings regulations that make economic activity in this field predictable and coherent both for industry and especially for workers and users. An important aspect highlighted in the report is the possibility of creating a European agency for robotics and artificial intelligence. I support this approach which can help relevant public actors to have a clear perspective on opportunities and challenges. I would obviously like this agency to be created, why not, in my country, Romania.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Dear colleagues! Do you know what that is? Yes, a cheap dime novel. Do you know what that is? The Delvaux report on robotics. The difference: none! Except for the fact that the latter was made to become law. I'm not just referring to the robot behavior rules that my colleague copied from a science fiction novel. No, your proposal for a legal personality for robots is much worse, even if you keep denying it. This is a bioethical no-go. Dear Mrs Delvaux, if you say that you do not plan to do this, explain paragraph 56 to me and I quote: “It is necessary to create a special legal status for robots so that a status as electronic person can be established for autonomous robots. “This is nothing more than a personal right for robots. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, please support our amendments four to eight. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- (The speaker speaks without a microphone.) ... is a legal person, has legal personality.Many other forms of society also have this.When there is talk of robots, Mrs Delvaux put them at the top and, as the report shows, it is clearly machines.Did you actually read the report?

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, of course they are robots.But there are always passages in it that clearly claim otherwise.I think these are gaps that we have to close again so that some car doesn't get a legal personality and the manufacturer is not made liable for it.That's exactly what we want to avoid.That does not mean that the entire report will be called into question.But there are passages that simply have to be corrected.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we have identified several gaps in the report. On the one hand, it does not advocate that the development of these areas be subject to national interests, supported by public investment, research and development policies. At the same time, it takes a very restricted approach to the impacts on the world of work, namely the increase of precariousness, impoverishment, unemployment and the liquidation of labor and social rights, omitting the interests of capital in its development, to increase exploitation with with a view to maximizing profit. Incomprehensible is also the absence of any reference and condemnation of the relationship between robotics and its use for military and security purposes. We distance ourselves from the approach of legislative harmonization in this matter and from the creation of yet another agency that contributes to conditioning and limiting the capacity of each State to develop on the basis of its best interests. The scope of areas of influence and intervention in the development of this sector confirm it as being of enormous complexity, requiring prudence in the discussion and that we continue with further reflection.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: - (FI) Mr President, perhaps the greatest public concern has been the question of how robotisation affects employment and social policy.It is clear that this will certainly involve a huge loss of jobs, but also the opportunity to create new jobs.In order to ensure that robotisation does not lead to growing inequality and social exclusion, it is necessary to proceed exactly as set out in paragraph 44 of the Delvaux report.An inclusive debate should be launched on new employment models and the sustainability of our tax and social security systems, based on an adequate level of income, including the possible introduction of a general basic income.This is the kind of debate that is needed in the Member States of the European Union and in the EU institutions now, because otherwise it may be that the threats will outweigh the opportunities.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ever since we lit the first fire, made the first arrow and developed agricultural techniques, technology has been one of the drivers, perhaps the most powerful, of change. Billions of people have in their pockets devices like this so ubiquitous, fast and connected, unimaginable only a few years ago. Yet there are still many things to be regulated in ICT, despite the fact that the World Wide Web spread over twenty years ago. To name a few topical here, geoblocking, online privacy, liability and intellectual property. As legislators we should intercept changes in advance and define regulatory frameworks quickly that do not come to approval already old and inadequate. So it is our responsibility to intervene before the future glimpsed today quickly becomes a present without rules. Artificial intelligence, in fact, is already capable of self-learning and the consequent evolution of cyber-physical systems will very soon generate enormous social, productive, economic and cultural changes, both positive and negative. Among the negatives awaits unprecedented rapid technological unemployment. The Bank of England estimates that one in two jobs in Britain will disappear by 2020. By the same year, according to the World Economic Forum, 7 million jobs will be lost in the 15 most industrialized economies of the world of work, replaced by just 2 million of new jobs. We know well how the spending power of citizens and the tax revenue that supports the public welfare and health system derive from work. Added to this picture is the growing concentration of global wealth. According to Forbes, in 2010, 388 people owned the wealth of 50% of humanity, in 2014 it became 85, in 2016 62, to reach 8 people, according to data cited in Davos a few weeks ago. We cannot escape from facing the issues cited, so capitalized and related.We will strongly support this resolution where it addresses the sustainability of our tax and social security systems, considering the introduction of a general basic income.The Delvaux report is the most lucid and forward-looking text I have read and in which I have had the honor of collaborating in the European Parliament in these two years.I hope it will not be upset tomorrow in the vote.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF).
text: - Madam President, giving legal personality to non-humans, qualified as technically more efficient electronic people, in the very short term grants them rights that are inevitably superior to those of potentially fallible humans. This is already a reality in the United States, so it is very late to ask questions. In the United States, there are clearly plans to stop insuring humans in the event of an accident with autonomous vehicles, the very ones being built under the leadership of Uber, associated with Google. Ultimately, then, there would only be autonomous vehicles giving Uber, once again, a monopoly on motor vehicles. Very serious forecasts predict more than 400,000 job losses among North American heavy truck drivers. In Europe, already hit by massive unemployment, millions of jobs will probably be lost and a universal income will not be enough to cushion the rise in poverty. It is essential to move towards progress, but to embark on this legal path is truly suicidal for our workers.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! I thank the rapporteur Mady Delvaux for this legislative own-initiative report on this very important subject of robotics and artificial intelligence. I would also like to thank our EPP rapporteur, Therese Comodini Cachia, for her efforts and efforts, which we believe have made the report even better. How can competition principles actually be secured in the new digital world? A systematic look at the business models and infrastructure actually shows where the social market economy is at risk. We also have to realize that human skills are being replaced more and more by algorithms and that our legal system is simply not prepared for this due to the increasing delimitation in this area. Of course, I also don't like it when robots somehow make judgments in the future. Nevertheless, we cannot really ignore this change of times. Digitization is advancing at a rapid pace here, and we have to react to that. Basically Europe is waiting for regulation while other regions of the world have long been in the fast lane. New challenges also offer new opportunities, and we understand that people or our citizens must be at the center of development. For this we need the security of data, the security of our infrastructure, the security of our ideas and a competitive economy that continues to offer jobs that in turn enable individuals to live in dignity. That is why not all topics such as the basic income are needed, which is a bit difficult to discuss here.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that important and even decisive evaluations and reflections for people's lives, for the economy and for the work that will be intertwined in our discussion, within an ethical and moral framework that reminds us also to our responsibilities as decision makers. While we welcome the introduction of robotics, in the field of health and care systems, rehabilitation, taking care of fragile people and with limitations of personal autonomy, we are convinced that the use of new technologies, especially in the field health, will improve the performance of the system, even with an evident and not negligible impact on the costs of the public system, we draw attention to the essential value of the doctor-patient, operator-patient relationship, as a further element of guarantee, convinced that the man-machine combination constitutes an extraordinary opportunity to improve the quality of life and well-being of people. Finally, the spread of the use of intelligent machines will unfortunately lead to the decimation of employees with low-skilled profiles, to the need to build others with more refined skills. For this reason, it will be necessary to equip themselves in time, with adequate investments both for the training of new skills, and to support those who will inevitably be expelled from the world of work in a conscious and responsible welfare system.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, robotics is often seen as a threat, not least because it is thought to take up work in many sectors. Personally, however, I believe in the adaptability of societies, as we have already survived three industrial revolutions, so why not survive a fourth. The coexistence of human and automated work will require new skills from both employees and management and an upgrade of our training system and contract system. However, I believe that we can approach this ongoing change with curiosity and optimism. We need a European regulatory framework that supports the development and exploitation of automation, artificial intelligence and robotics. The most important thing is to take responsibility for ensuring that change is managed and managed and that training and employment opportunities for the workforce are provided. I want the EU to be a pioneer in this matter and not to react too slowly to a position where others dictate global conditions and standards.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it took thirty years for politicians to finally deign to consider the legal framework for robots. Thirty years of Hollywood telling us all about the promise of innovation - think Back to the Future - as its potential dangers - think Terminator. Thirty years that robotization, our fellow citizens live it on a daily basis: for the better, when it makes their life more practical; badly, when it steals their jobs. Transport is concerned and this raises many questions. Think of the autonomous car: innovation, we need it to reconvert the European automobile industry, to pass to cars, trucks, electric buses, connected and autonomous. But who will be responsible in the event of an accident? The constructor? The car? The passengers? This obviously goes for drones too. We know that builders cheat on pollution tests, so how can you be sure that they don't cheat on certain compliance tests? How do we anticipate aspects relating to cybersecurity and data protection? How can you be sure that a human hand can regain control at the slightest problem? All of this makes it essential to put the precautionary principle at the heart of our work, for innovation, but above all for all of humanity.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Delvaux and those who have worked on this report for their efforts. Today we are witnessing an industrial revolution in which artificial intelligence and robotics have become the most important technological trends of the century. Their development has led to an increase in the efficiency of economies, but also in the level of security in the commercial, transport, medical services and education sectors. No less important is the fact that jobs have been created in the field of technological development, research and innovation being encouraged. However, the Commission and the Member States have a duty to be concerned with ensuring the efficient transfer of research, marketing and widespread use of these technologies, while ensuring that safety is fully respected. However, the new achievements in robotics have shown that there is a need for a current legal framework to determine the continuation and development of research in the field, but also to ensure effective protection for people who interact with such robots. We thus emphasize the need to develop a set of legal rules that are in fact anchored in civil liability for damage caused by robots. It is important, therefore, not only to talk about efficiency, but also about transparency and, above all, consistency in achieving legal certainty throughout the European Union, for the benefit of both consumers and businesses. And in this context, it is also important that the work of robots and artificial intelligence systems complies with Union law on data protection, but especially on the privacy of citizens.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President! We are currently experiencing an almost inflationary spread of robots, decision-making machines that can communicate with one another. 1.7 million are said to be already active, that is almost the population of Latvia. Many people are concerned about this. Of course, the development cannot be stopped, but it can be controlled. That is the position of the Social Democrats. We want to see digitization as an opportunity and help shape this process. That is why we are proud of the work done by Mady Delvaux, who achieved a great success with the report. The own-initiative report calls on the Commission to present a draft law that formulates principles of civil law. Such questions can no longer be regulated by nation states; global standardization is required here. If the European Union acts together, it is possible that global standards will follow European requirements. There is this European lever, as we saw with the data protection package, for example. But the use of robots also raises a whole host of ethical and socio-political questions. I welcome the fact that the report does not omit these questions either, but rather that it addresses a constructive basis for discussion.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur because it was not easy to start this report. I still have a number of issues with me. I will address two of them. The first is the use of words and words mean something, both in French and in English. In Articles 36 and 38, when we speak of “repair”, at the medical level, that does not pose a problem for me, but when we speak of “improvement” or “enhancement”, there we are on a subject that not related to. What does this mean? This reflects the project that is also developing very strongly in the United States: the project of transhumanists, of augmented man. On this point, I think we need to be very firm. It is for this reason that I would like that tomorrow, during the vote, to remove this notion of "better man". In my opinion, this is fundamental. The second problem is the question of law. On this point, like the other colleagues, I also think that the use of words is dangerous because, until now, human rights only affect humans or groups of humans. So I think that part should be removed as well.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I personally welcome the fact that we are debating a report here today on the civil law aspects of robotics. I think that in the future some relationships will really need to be adjusted, such as the question of the liability of autonomous robots for the damage they cause, the question of a possible insurance system for the damage that can be caused by these machines. On the other hand, I find the report too extensive. There are a number of things that, in my opinion, are not related to this topic. I think that issues that are social in nature, such as the introduction of a universal basic income, are things that are unrelated to the civil law aspects of robots, and perhaps it raises a problem for me to support the report without further questions. I would also like to say that I have a problem with the already mentioned status of an electronic person. In short and well, European law, which derives from Roman law, has distinguished between a natural person and a legal person for two thousand years. It is clear, it is a given, it is our basis of civilization. And to create another form of person now seems to me to be an absolute and fundamental revolutionary intervention in the European concept of civil law, and without any further wide-ranging debate, I really consider it something I would not want to juggle too much here, ease to write this report.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to start mainly from the opposite position compared to the previous speaker. I think that maybe as this report is so systemic, so comprehensive in all of this area, it is showing us how many unsolved issues, new ideas and new concepts we clearly need in order to come to very specific implementation as the legislation.  I am also very glad that Commissioner Moedas, who is responsible for research, is here because this report also shows that there is an area of research which is most vital and which is underdeveloped – the area of research dealing with technology-society interactions. We have neurosciences dealing with this interaction at a micro level, but we have very little research dealing with technology-society interaction at the macro and middle level.  I insist that the Commission really should do what the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is also proposing: to have special grants, money and focus in research on this horizontal, comprehensive, holistic approach uniting humanities, social sciences, technological sciences and real sciences.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you must never be afraid of technology, it has allowed the world to evolve. Of course, technology has historically reduced the number of jobs and often profoundly changes the ways in which work is performed. But it is up to politics to use the wealth that technology creates to make up for these gaps. It is our job to govern and manage the process, it is not automatic. For this we must do very specific things, which concern economic policy, training, research, but woe to hinder and oppose technology. It would be wrong and regressive behavior. I would add that the legal and ethical dimensions concern people and not machines. It is difficult to identify the responsibilities of the machines, but this should not lead us to confuse the two roles. I believe that ethics is about humans. So it is those who create the machines who must be subjected to a criterion of ethical responsibility, certainly not the machine, it would be misleading.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Robots open up wonderful possibilities, they do our work for us. And that is why it is important to distribute the productivity gain - that is, what we now somehow positive from them - of the intelligent helpers appropriately. Let's call it robot control, let's call it machine control - whatever. A basic income is also an option. But we should just see the whole picture and share this profit appropriately so that we can secure our social systems for the future. We in Europe now have the unique opportunity, but also the obligation, not to take a position on these legal and ethical issues, but it is a task for you, dear Commission, to do something accordingly on the liability issues, But above all on the ethical principles, which I consider to be particularly important when developing robots, such as - as the report provides - to provide a code of conduct for robotics engineers or an ethical framework that is based on our principles and values ​​as defined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Congratulations to Mady and everyone who worked on it. But now there is a lot of work ahead of us.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would really like to say thank you to Mady Delvaux and say it twice. The first is because this report is one of the most interesting that I have ever worked on and that it is - I will come back to this - in the foresight. Now, what do we expect of politicians, of the leaders that we are, of elected officials, if not precisely to try to foresee and anticipate in order to best respond to the changes which will obviously befall , if we ever do nothing, on our fellow citizens? The second reason why I would like to thank her is that her report has highlighted the European Parliament, since in France it has been debated a lot and has indeed raised awareness on these subjects. I would like to say that those who are afraid, in particular, of the paths which are being drawn on the question of universal income or the scarcity of work should read the report carefully. It does not say that they must be put in place, but simply that they must be thought about and that the Commission must be a watchdog to make proposals. If we ever take that out of the report, then we're going to weaken it considerably. It is by no means a question of obligations, but of a perspective of debate and we must therefore support this entire report, with all that it entails.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, it is indisputable that robots are the future and that they will greatly facilitate our work, they are already doing so.However, what worries me in this report, and which is why I submitted the amendments thanks to the support of colleagues, is the creation of the legal status of an electronic person for robots that make autonomous decisions and act independently of humans.Right comes from life.Robots are the product of the human mind and human hands, but they are objects, not persons.There is no life in them and we cannot give them the status of an electronic person.We cannot put humans and robots on the same level.Creating legal status for robots causally would mean waiving the responsibility of their manufacturers or owners.This would be a legal precedent that no one knows would be feasible at all.I invite you to vote for our amendments, and against the creation of a legal status for robots, and to make it clear that robots are not equal and equal with humans.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the development of robotics and artificial intelligence will certainly contribute in the near future to a considerable improvement in our quality of life in various sectors such as medical care, transport and industrial production. However, the probable large-scale diffusion of these devices requires us as legislators to define a legal framework that regulates their implications and ethical and legal implications without hindering their development and taking into account the fact that technology evolves very quickly. Many of the proposals included in the report are absolutely acceptable. However, I would like to focus on the relationship between robots and children. In fact, already today the interaction between minors and technologies, such as smartphones, computers and video games, sometimes leads to cases of addiction that could be accentuated by devices equipped with advanced artificial intelligence. The future legal framework must therefore take into account the possible risks deriving from an emotional attachment between robots and children such as dependence, isolation, social marginalization, also considering the provision of educational processes aimed at providing young people with a capacity for critical reflection towards robots. .

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, first of all I wish you every success in your duties as Vice-President of our House. In the period 2010-2014 it is estimated that the average increase in sales of robots amounted to 17% per year while in 2014 alone sales increased by 29%. The field of machine intelligence offers tremendous economic and social development, improving living conditions. Despite the undoubted advantages offered by the robotics industry, its future applications may bring about significant changes in the labor market and necessitate a different approach to education, vocational training and social policy. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to adopt legal provisions or legislative changes from now on, in order to take into account the forthcoming applications of these technologies. At the same time, we must be careful so that the impending development of robotics does not lead to a high concentration of wealth in the hands of a few.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, obviously this report is a compromise product, but it generally allows for employment rights and access to decent work and retirement. Determining the use of robotics should neither aim nor undermine the improvement of the physical human condition. It must be ensured that the existing trends of the economy and the productive process will continue to serve society as a whole with up-to-date rules and safeguards. I avoid the possibility of increasing inequalities in the distribution of wealth and envisage replacing human labor without completely filling the lost positions. The delay in pension contributions threatens the future of employment and the viability of social welfare and insurance systems. However, the possibility of imposing a tax on the robotic work performed or the imposition of an end-use and maintenance fee per robot to finance the support and retraining of unemployed persons, whose positions have been reduced or abolished in order to maintain social cohesion and prosperity, is welcome.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President!Robotics is advancing faster and faster than ever.That's good news in my opinion.It is a growing market for products and services in almost every field.Innovative solutions in the field of robotics make the reality we live in change very dynamically and although it opens up the potential of new opportunities for our citizens, it is also a huge challenge.Therefore, we will face changes on the labor market.In order to be able to adapt to them well, we must first of all have reliable analyzes and data on the impact of robotics on demand, individual positions and competences in the labor market.It is also important that our employment and social policies are flexible and able to respond to these changes in such a way as to provide employees with a good quality of work while maintaining an adequate level of social security.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the ethical development of robotics, which has the potential to transform our lives. However, I would like to issue a word of warning so that we can begin to prepare for what will inevitably be a huge amount of enforced leisure time for millions of people across the globe. When robotics do most of the work, how will we spend our time? Vegetating in front of a screen in passive mode, watching poor quality TV, or engaged in life-enhancing activities that promote personal and community development, and connect us with the wider world? I would like to propose that we embrace the concept of occupational literacy now, and take steps to train ourselves and future generations through innovative life-long learning, and promote active engagement in arts and sport, so that co-existence with robotics will be harmonious and of benefit to the human race, not a curse for future generations. The idea of occupational literacy also relates to citizenship. If we are not taught the processes of government, or critical-thinking skills, we do not have the occupational literacy to effectively engage in democratic processes.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank-you.I am sorry, but due to time constraints I cannot give the floor to everyone who has contacted me.There are still a few who have contacted us, but I ask for your understanding that it simply does not work.We also have to move forward on our agenda.(End of the catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for the inspiring discussions tonight. We have touched really upon a very broad array of complex issues: technology and society – Ms Lauristin brought us that issue which for me is fundamental in terms of research; jobs; regulation, with Ms Charanzová; and education, there we had Mr Maštálka, Mr Kósa and Ms Kyllönen who brought us the big changes that will have to take place in education. Also Ms Rozière with la valeur humaniste, very important for our debate, and also sectors like health – Mr Buşoi and Mr Selimovic brought these to the table. So there was a really fantastic discussion with so many ideas for the future. But one thing that was clear from our discussion is that we all agree, and I think Ms Kallas was the first to say it, that we want to promote innovation, we do not want to stop innovation, and that has to be very clear and I was very happy that we agree on that.  But there is a political choice to make, to think what we want for the future and I think we agree that we don’t want robots to replace us; we want robots to get us to be better at doing things that we can’t do alone. We want them to really augment our abilities and get us to a better place. Not so long ago in real time the following experiment was carried out: experts, medical experts, looking at scanners of lung cancer compared to machines, looking at the same scans. The results were staggering: machines were 50% better than doctors. But more than that, the false negatives – meaning when you miss cancer and you put someone in danger – was zero for the machine and 7% for great medical experts. That changes the profession but changes it in a good way, because the machines will never be able to relate the whole human body and the different diseases; they will be very good at this specific task and the doctors will be good at the other task, which is to relate all the tasks [to each other].  So robotics changes jobs, it is true, and makes us better, to focus on what we are good at. I believe that we can digitalise everything but we cannot digitalise experience, we cannot digitalise the experience of life, we cannot digitalise the experience of what we do. So I believe that we will have a better future, it will be a future that will entail complex policy changes, and that is why this report is so important. That is why we need together to shape this process and create the framework which allows robotics and artificial intelligence to create all the desired advantages – and there are so many –while safeguarding the fundamental values of our society and important features of our economy, striking the right balance between all the interests at stake.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, I would like to thank all the speakers. Above all, today's discussions have shown, like those we had in committee, the multitude and complexity of the issues that arise from a legal, ethical and also societal point of view. I would simply like to say that the report asks the Commission to come up with regulations to regulate what should be, in particular liability. Moreover, this is a report that wants to start a debate. Today we are not at the end of history but only at the beginning, and we need to think about the world of tomorrow. With everything I've discovered, I say "yes" to innovation. I have full confidence in the creativity of our researchers and scientists. But I can't ignore the fear and fears of the people I meet and I don't have the arrogance to tell them that their fears are not justified because all will be well in the best of all possible worlds. We must take them seriously and give them answers. It is for this reason that I am calling for the opening of the debate. I would also like to emphasize the annoying question of legal personality. The report does not say that robots should be given legal personality. If you read it correctly, in this report we ask the Commission to explore, analyze and consider the implications of all the legal solutions that are under discussion with regard to the legal personality of robots, as regards concerns liability, and therefore compensation for damage suffered. On the other hand, I am surprised that a parliament refuses a debate on ideas which are in the intellectual world, which are published in books and which represent schools of thought even before this debate has taken place.
