Therefore, all I ask is that we watch calmly, argue, listen and decide afterwards.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 February 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report presents the issue of robotics as something unlimited and independent of our will and that we can do nothing but regulate. In recital Q, it is stated that there is a possibility that in the long run artificial intelligence will overcome human intellectual capacity; good, but "artificial intelligence" is created by human capacity and, therefore, as all technology will not be neutral, it will be at the service of the ruling classes. I understand that the first step of this regulation should be to put the limits on how far and how we want to use this technology, because after all, technology should be an instrument to seek well-being and facilitate activities for people, but never to replace it. them. And, certainly, we cannot allow the advances in robotics to be used so that a few can dominate the world with this process of concentration of wealth through the spoils of natural resources and the dispossession of the popular classes. It cannot be used to destroy and precarize employment; to continue with wars; or to dehumanize medicine or care and care for the elderly, for example. I agree, we need to regulate, set limits to protect society.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: written. - Robot technology, the digital networking of man and machine, brings new levels of automation and thus a change in the working world. To do this, we need comprehensive analyzes of employment trends. You should describe how digitization affects the world of work, both quantitatively and qualitatively. Previously applicable standards must be transferred to the digitized world of work and new forms of work. This includes: social security, working hours, co-determination and occupational safety, freedom of association, further development of employee data protection. The robot-human relationships must be included in both employee data protection and health protection. The rapid development of technical equipment and its possibilities also make it necessary for lifelong learning to become a central element of digitization. There must be a right to training for workers to ensure that people can keep up with the demands of the job. Ultimately, rules on the liability of robots must also be adapted. Regular involvement of the social partners is essential when adapting the regulatory framework for robotics and the digital economy.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - Driverless cars, industrial automatons, personal support robots, sex robots, ...: robotics has become an important component of our daily lives. Today, we are voting for a European framework on the rules of robotics. This is a European and probably world first in order to officially take robotics from science fiction to reality. Even if the theme is exciting, it should not make us forget the issues related to employment and the fight against inequalities. Anticipating changes is the best way to control them. The issue of employment must be placed at the center of priorities in order to defend workers' rights and support them in these changes as well as the methods of financing social impacts. We also ask, through this text, that the issue of inequalities be addressed and highlighted. Indeed, without supervision, the development of robotics could result in a significant concentration of wealth and power in the hands of a minority. Europe has a role to play on this aspect as well.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the Commission's approval of Germany's revised plan to introduce a road toll (2017/2526 (RSP)).

name: Pascal Arimont
text: Author. - Madam President, my dear Evelyn, congratulations on my part on the position of Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! Dear Commissioner, I am going to ask you two simple questions tonight, and I think you would actually like to answer no to those simple questions. But I ask the first question: Is this German car toll compliant with EU law? At this point I would also like to quote a proven expert on these issues who said: A road user charge is only in conformity with EU law if it does not discriminate on the basis of nationality. I am not saying that, you said that, Commissioner Bulc, at the start of the infringement procedure in June 2015. Let us therefore start from this principle. Has this discrimination been eliminated by the alleged agreement? Not in my opinion. As a result, foreigners from the EU are still more burdened than German nationals. Or to put it simply: a Belgian driver with a Euro 6 car pays the toll, a German driver does not. Hence the answer to the first question “Is the new German toll model compliant with EU law?”: No, it is not. I come to the second question: is this toll a symbol of good European cooperation? Here too the answer: No, it isn't. There is currently no European toll system. This toll violates the fundamental principles of our Union, which you and the Commission must protect. There must be no feeling that our European partners finance Germany's roads at the expense of our neighbors. Because what would be the result then? The long-term consequence would be that we are shaking up the basic principles of the internal market and coexistence in Europe. That is why this toll must not have a place in Europe, especially not in our time when so many doubt the EU. Ms. Bulc, you so have it in your hand.The case is currently on hold.I therefore make an urgent appeal to you: continue the infringement procedure, otherwise Member States will sue.And don't doubt it: this idea is gaining more and more support, because it is about more than the toll, it is about the basic principles of our European Union.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for giving the Commission the opportunity to clarify its position on the German road-charging reform. I know this issue has stirred up a lot of emotions, in Germany as well as in neighbouring countries, and this is why I would like to focus today on facts.  First, the Commission has consistently promoted, and continues to promote, road-charging in line with the ‘user and polluter pays’ principle. In our view, this is the most sustainable and fairest way to ensure infrastructure financing, and this is clearly referable to taxation.  Secondly, there is at this stage no specific EU legislation on road-charging for passenger cars, only for heavy goods vehicles. There is also no EU law on vehicle taxation of passenger cars. Both remain national competences. This being said, it is vital that Member States respect the EU Treaty. This includes, of course, the principle of non-discrimination based on nationality, and yes, I still stand for that. So let me be very clear: foreign drivers cannot be discriminated against. Thirdly, the Commission has been in discussions with the German authorities on their road-charging reform for several years. Since the beginning, the Commission has raised several reservations concerning the German plans. These reservations were only partly taken into account by the German authorities while drafting the first version of the laws. This is the reason why the Commission was able to react only a week after the adoption of these laws by starting an infringement case. The launch of this infringement case had the immediate effect of Germany suspending implementation of the PkW-Maut. The Commission had two main concerns relating to discrimination against foreign users. First, the one-to-one vehicle tax compensation of German vehicle owners, and second, the excessively high prices of shorter vignettes, purchased mainly by foreign vehicle—owners. The launch of the infringement case did not stop discussions with the German authorities. The Commission indicated repeatedly that it would continue, as is often the case during infringement procedures, to try to find a solution without having to go to court, and on 1 December Minister Alexander Dobrindt and I were able to announce publicly that we had reached a political understanding on the way forward. That’s it.  I am very pleased that the German authorities recognised the need to amend the two laws to meet the following principles. Firstly, the German vehicle tax law should be based on environmental logic and avoid one-to-one compensation of all German-owned vehicles. Secondly, the prices for short-term vignettes should be reasonable and proportionate to ensure that foreigners, who usually buy these vignettes, are not discriminated against in favour of German users, who would, in general, buy annual vignettes.  On this basis, the German Government issued new legislative proposals just three weeks ago on 25 January. These proposals will now have to be examined and voted on in the German Parliament.  In the meantime, the infringement case is still there and, as you know, infringement cases are matters strictly between the Member States and the Commission and therefore I cannot discuss the details of the case. I am fully aware of the concerns of neighbouring Member States which believe that the amended German PkW-Maut and vehicle tax law may still be discriminatory, but it is way too early to reply to these concerns as the new laws have not yet been debated and voted on in the German Bundestag.  When these new laws are adopted, and only then, will the Commission assess them and decide on further actions. The infringement case will be closed if, and only if, the Commission is convinced that the German laws do not discriminate against foreign drivers. It is very important for me and the European Union that Germany now agree to put their road-charging reform in the context of a future EU-wide system. As you know, the Commission is currently preparing a revision of EU legislation on road-charging as part of the road initiatives. The plan is to adopt them this spring.  On road-charging we are considering proposing rules that underpin non-discrimination of foreign vehicle-owners and pave the way for an EU-wide system. This could include for the first time passenger cars, excluded so far, and remove obstacles for operators to provide EU-wide toll services. This would ensure equal treatment of all vehicles – passenger cars and heavy goods vehicles – and better services to users related to payment of tolls, especially for cross-border traffic. It will also represent a major step in delivering on our low emission strategy adopted last summer.  I will now be more than happy to reply to all your questions and hopefully clarify all your doubts related to this case.

name: Claudia Schmidt
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The German toll plans show us the problems we have in Europe today. First, the Commission seems to have problems applying the same yardstick to large Member States as it does to small ones. As a reminder: In Europe, the strength of the law really still applies and not the law of the stronger. Second: Following the submission to the Bundestag, Commission President Juncker personally announced in May 2015 that the toll would be checked due to considerable doubts under European law. In September 2016, the Commission decides to refer Germany to the European Court of Justice, and an agreement is surprisingly announced on November 3rd. Commissioner, what has changed? I still pay more with the same car on the same route, just because I have an Austrian license plate, regardless of the emission class. Discrimination remains discrimination. Third: Although Transport Minister Dobrindt deserves another European thistle in his collection, I would also like to break a lance for the German approach. If there is a European solution in the course of the revision of the Eurovignette Directive, then national taxes must go down. But if - as in the present case - only the neighboring countries should bear the relief for German taxpayers, then that is not acceptable. The Commission is called upon to watch. Cross-border mobility should not and must not be punished. Drivers of any nationality are not fair game for finance ministers and populists - see Article 18. I hope the Commission will reconsider its position. (Applause)

name: Ismail Ertug
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam Chair! Nice to see you there. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for the introduction. Dear Commissioner, As the representative of the European Commission, you are the guardian of the Treaties. I know, my assertion, that all of this is not all right for you, that you are here today. But you must now represent what was ultimately bagged at the top level - between Mr Juncker and Mrs Merkel - in order to smoke a pipe of peace within the Federal Government, within the CDU and the CSU, and at least one problematic area, namely the foreigner toll to clear away. Nevertheless, Commissioner, the fact remains that the questions that Mrs Schmidt has just asked are still on the table. I would like to remind you that at the beginning of this period, when this proposal was on the table, we spoke to each other repeatedly. We have discussed all these components that they would ultimately still not contribute to making the whole thing that began as a foreigner toll on the part of the CSU in the end in conformity with European law. It is still the case that you have just admitted that there will be no one-to-one compensation for German drivers. And you continue to admit that it ultimately has to comply with the user and polluter principle. I ask myself: Where does this proposal correspond to this user and polluter principle? And I would also like to ask you, Commissioner: what did the European Commission get in return? Is it true that the European Commission bought or at least bought in the approval of the Federal Republic of Germany for the EETS legislation? Is that right? Yes or no? And besides, say quite frankly: Why did this statement, or at least this one, in the end exactly in the week in which the CSU party congress took place in Bavaria Deal taken place?All of this stinks to high heaven, and that is why this foreigner toll is not compliant with European law for various reasons and also for that reason.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the Commission is fighting very strongly, in some cases, against keeping the rule of law in certain Member States. It is not always the case but it reminds me of a point famously made by George Orwell about equality: I do not want to see it here. I think we all understand that there could be only three reasons why the Commission put the infringement procedure on hold. Initially, you said, Commissioner, that it would be better to negotiate with the German Government before the measure became law; now, when it has become law, you are waiting to think what to do. I think there is a contradiction in that statement. Other possible reasons could be that the Commission made legal mistakes when it started infringement proceedings – and if that is not the case, I would like more information about the changes – or that the German Government has made enough political statements to remove discrimination against car owners from other countries and drivers of environment-friendly cars? If there is some other reason, then we need to understand what that reason is.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! I have an article here, of course you can't see it down there. But it says: Together against the toll. This is an article from Lower Saxony and the Netherlands in the border area in common. It is the case that our state government - I come from this part of Germany - is totally against introducing this toll. It is like this: we have a Euregio region right now in the border area with the Netherlands. It was deliberately set up in order to have cross-border traffic to work. There are many people who live in the Netherlands and work in Lower Saxony. In Lower Saxony there are more jobs, so there are more people there who can fill the jobs. This is being massively undermined. There is too little public transport, you have to rely on the car and that means that only some people pay and others don't. It is also the case that with the German toll, if you have an environmentally friendly car - which is basically nothing bad, Euro 6 - you can even earn money from the toll. Mr Dobrindt is still saying today: The Germans no longer pay. That means: who will pay for it then? From a German point of view, the question is of course: Is there enough income at all? Isn't that a zero-sum game? But we have to discuss that in Germany. In general, I actually think that this principle of user pays, polluter pays, is of course good. It would be best if we had no road tax at all, everywhere in all European countries, and only paid whenever you were driving. That would be the fairest and the best. Of course, that is not possible at the moment, because we cannot simply say: Everyone must abolish the vehicle tax. Only, what we have on the table now is actually not a good blueprint. Lastly, it's not mile-based either, it's not that you pay for every kilometer.There are still different sections - month and so on.That is not what we need and that is far too bureaucratic.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, certainly no one can question the fact that Germany has the right to introduce tolls on passenger cars on its motorways. However, I firmly believe that we must demand from the German side - and I ask you to do so not only in words, but in concrete actions on the part of the Commission - so that this is not done in a way that is discriminatory against drivers from other Member States. I consider the concept of German tolls to be discriminatory, because it means that the cost of tolls will be largely reimbursed to all Germans, and de facto fees will only be paid by foreigners. I would like to state here that, if it is confirmed that there are negative discriminatory effects on the Member States, this issue should also be discussed by the court, and not just by the European Parliament. We only demand fair conditions that will be the same for all parties. After all, as directly elected representatives from the 28 Member States, we have a moral obligation to ensure that all citizens are treated equally, and we should not look out for some being pulled out of their pockets while others are not. You have known about this problem for a long time, and unfortunately you have not done anything for a long time. Now is the time that if you do nothing, it will get worse and worse, and you will only prove to European citizens that the European Commission, if it has, does not and only watches. I think it would be a shame and I believe you in what you told us it would be different.

name: Michael Cramer
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The car toll for foreigners is not a first. As early as 1990, the then Minister of Transport, Zimmermann, wanted to enforce the truck toll and lower the vehicle tax for trucks. Did the Commission say no? In 1992 the European Court of Justice said: This is anti-European. With that it was buried. In 2004, the then federal government wanted to try the same. The Commission said again: this is anti-European. It was introduced anyway. Now Alexander Dobrindt comes with the third attempt. I always say: mistakes make one smart. But two were not enough for Alexander Dobrindt. Why is it so? The toll is anti-European, it prevents cross-border traffic. It costs. Only the foreigners pay - not the Germans. That will not do. In addition, the vignette is unecological and unsocial because those who drive 10,000 kilometers a year pay exactly as much as those who drive 200,000 kilometers. That has nothing to do with the user and polluter pays principle. That is why it has to be stopped, and I cannot understand why the Commission said at the beginning: This is anti-European, and afterwards, after Juncker met with the CSU in Bavaria - by the way past the Commissioner - that everything should then be legal . That will not do. The Bundestag has yet to decide. But if he decides that, then I think, because that's anti-social, then not only the SPD, but also the CSU would have to delete the S in the name because it is totally anti-social.

name: Georg Mayer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! Illegal, this deal is clearly illegal. This deal is illegal on several levels. I am only saying: hidden discrimination - we have already heard that today - the polluter pays principle. Commissioner, you are definitely the wrong person to talk to now. I would have liked the negotiator of this deal to be here to answer our questions. This is a deal, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, which is at the expense of many motorists and at the expense of many Austrian commuters who commute to Germany. This is a deal - and you know it very well - that was negotiated in the back room in Brussels at the Old Boys Club. This is a deal that we have seen so many and so often in this European Union. Some are just the same and some are just the same. The line runs through, that's understandable. The line is also implied and at the end of the day understandable from the point of view of the European Union and those who are responsible for it. You are breaking - and not bending - your own rules that you have decided just because it is politically opportune. I can tell you that that certainly does not create trust in this Union. If this toll goes through like this, if the Commission actually lets it pass, then I can tell you that we will definitely implement a similar regulation in Austria.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: - It turns out again tonight that toll is a sensitive topic. Citizens in Europe want value for money and do not want border restrictions. As has already been said, the user pays and the polluter pays. Those are good principles. In that respect, the start of the German toll discussion is incorrect. We at the PPE do not oppose the charging of tolls, just as we do not want a toll in the Netherlands, that should be clear. But compensation for only German citizens leads to discrimination and that is contrary to European law. Offsetting green cars, that's fine, but then also green cars across the EU and not in the way that is currently indicated in the German proposals. It is not clear to me why the Commissioner has closed the infringement procedure. She does not want to say anything about that as the negotiations are still ongoing, but the sensitivity makes me ask this question. And finally, the lack of a single European toll system will lead to more national systems and that is disastrous. So please hurry to establish that system.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! There simply cannot be a toll that only foreigners pay in the European single market. That is not showing solidarity, it is unfair and violates the basic principle of non-discrimination. But I would also like to point out that nobody wants to prevent Germany from introducing a toll. But they should pay everyone who uses the German roads, regardless of the license plate. As a social democrat, I advocate the polluter pays principle at EU level. That means: Anyone who uses roads by car - whether private or commercial - should pay for them. For the wear and tear, for the pollutants emitted and for the proportion of the traffic volume. In the European Parliament, we have succeeded in getting a cross-country and cross-party resolution under way with the aim of respecting the principle of non-discrimination and strengthening political cooperation in Europe. The European Parliament and the German bordering states jointly advocate that the same law must apply to everyone in Europe. I therefore ask you, Mrs Bulc, to reconsider your position.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Of course, no one doubts that the expenditure on modernization and construction of infrastructure consumes huge amounts. It is borne by each Member State and it is fully understandable that the responsibility for the good condition and safety of roads as a result is partly borne by their users. It is therefore worth emphasizing that the mere introduction of road tolls is not the subject of this debate. The problem we are discussing here is discrimination and a system that clearly puts only citizens of one Member State in a privileged position. We can deal with a situation in which drivers who most often use these roads will be exempt from paying these fees in Germany, and the costs will be borne by foreign drivers, including mainly Polish drivers. It is difficult to understand the behavior of the Commission, which, despite the first appropriate reaction, stopped the procedure of clarifying objections as to the compliance of this idea with European law, although the main objection is still valid. We expect clear answers as to under what conditions the Commission has suspended the infringement procedure and how it intends to protect drivers traveling through Germany from discrimination on the basis of nationality.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I have a few words of appreciation to the Commissioner. You acted quickly at the beginning, Commissioner, and I think that was decisive. Secondly, I also appreciate your intention to submit European legislation to the Council and Parliament. I have one comment: at this time, it is not just about the Maut. You talk about the internal market, and we hear much rhetoric about completing the internal market but, at the same time, we are creating more and more obstacles at national level. The issue on which we differ, and where we have certain reservations, concerns where we are today. We all know about, and have spoken unanimously today about, the deficiencies of the new proposal. We know what the position is, so we do not need to wait for an explanation by the Bundestag. You know what it is, and at this stage you have two options: either, with the support you have heard in this Parliament, and it is a majority support, you enter into negotiations with the Germans and/or you utilise the infringement procedures that you have available. There is no other option because we are heading towards a dead end.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: - Commissioner, colleagues! The planned motorway toll is a prestige object of a German minister. Incidentally, this is precisely the person who would have liked to have kicked Greece out of the euro years ago. As is generally known, his German regional party, the CSU, does not think much of German integration. Quite apart from that, the toll will ultimately cost the public sector more than it brings in. This is confirmed by all previous calculations. In the end, the whole thing is a bad election campaign gag, which also shows national egoism. Commissioner, please explain to us in a credible manner what convinced you overnight that the foreigner toll, as it is called everywhere in Germany, is suddenly in line with EU law and that it is also perceived as non-discriminatory. It is also about this signal. Should Germany of all things stand for the fact that it requires entry when crossing the border? We wanted to open the borders in Europe, right? My Bavarian colleague Ertug has already mentioned the most important questions. We are waiting for an answer.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! To be honest, I can't understand all the excitement about the introduction of the German car toll. First: There are toll systems in many European member states, so we can introduce a toll system in Germany too. Second: What we are doing with the toll in Germany is exactly what has always been prescribed by the Commission and Parliament for financing infrastructure at European level, namely that the user pays. Third: the amount of the toll. This is based on the pollutant emissions. Well, you and the Greens should actually be happy, dear Mr Cramer, that that is the criterion for the amount of the toll. And now to the alleged discrimination. I cannot see them, and the Commissioner rightly said: every user of our German autobahns should pay in future, and I emphasize: every user - regardless of their nationality. The tax issue has also been raised. The reduction of road tax is a matter for the Member States. In Austria there is also the commuter allowance. There, too, tax breaks are provided for drivers driving in Austria. That's fine. That’s okay with us. One last word about our Austrian friends. Dear colleagues, when I drive from Munich to Bolzano at the weekend, I only pay around 40 euros for road use. I have to pay the Austrian ten-day vignette, I pay for the Europabrücke, I pay the Italian toll. So if I compare that with our ten-day vignette, which costs from 2.50 euros to a maximum of 20 euros, then it's almost a bargain. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Ms. Niebler, do you know a country in Europe where a toll has been introduced that only foreigners pay?I do not know that.That is the main principle.Only cars with foreign license plates are checked in Germany, but not the Germans.That is double discrimination.We can not permit that.This is anti-European and you are laying the red carpet on those who are against Europe.They finally have a reason to be against Europe again.That's why we have to defend ourselves against it.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - Come down and leave the church in the village, please. I can only say: You just don't want to understand it. They just don't want to understand. Every driver who drives on German roads will pay the toll, regardless of their nationality. So every Austrian, every Swede, even every German will pay the toll in the future when it is introduced. I cannot see any discrimination in this. Tax relief has already been given with the introduction of other toll systems. When the truck toll was introduced in the UK, the tax on trucks was naturally also reduced. So, you turn a mosquito into an elephant. I would like to emphasize once again - there are road collection fees in almost all European countries and I think that we Germans also have the right to introduce them. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam, you probably know that discrimination - even if it is dressed in seemingly non-discriminatory categories - if it is intended to affect some users, remains discrimination.The state essentially refers to a national logic, which would be entirely justified had it not been for our agreement not to apply it.You demand from others to give it up, and then suddenly you say: for Germany, defending its own interests is something completely natural, and we will apply it.Either we think in European terms or we don't!

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure - Well, we will continue the discussion on a European solution. The Commissioner announced today, and has already proposed several times, that we should also consider European solutions. But again: the fact is that we have road tolls in many European countries, in over 20 countries there are different types of collection. And in this respect it is also fair for Germany to introduce these. It has been checked up and down, corrections have been made, the procedure has not yet been completed in Germany. I can only say: I do not see any discrimination in our German toll. If you think so, please bring an action to the European Court of Justice, and then we can be sure of the form in which road tolls can be levied in Europe. But I'll stick with it: Our toll ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, one of the fundamental principles on which the functioning of the European Union is based is non-discrimination on the grounds of nationality.Germany has put forward a proposal to create a road charging system that has raised concerns about discrimination against foreign drivers.Despite the change in the originally proposed laws, the possibility of deducting the toll from the annual motor vehicle tax is to be guaranteed only to vehicles registered in Germany.That is why I, too, would like to ask the Commission, which is considered to be the guardian of the Treaties and counterbalancing the interests of the Member States, whether a political agreement with the German authorities is really fully in line with European Union law.The Commission's credibility in measuring the same meter for everyone also depends on the answers, and I am not convinced of that.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: –I am in favor of a kilometer charge for motorists. It is logical that users co-pay for the infrastructure they use, but that charging must be done fairly. Germans and non-Germans should be treated equally. When, for example, Germans are compensated through the motor vehicle tax, that is pure discrimination. That is a cardinal sin in the European Union and that is the core task of this Commission. The Commissioner has to find out absolutely. It is also essential that the German toll is collected in a smart, customer-friendly way. A vignette is an outdated system. I thought that the Germans were always so modern and more for digitization and things like that. And then they come with a vignette from the last century! Then use a system of GPS registration, then you can differentiate based on kilometers and type of vehicle. A simple, green and above all fair kilometer charge, I have no problems with that, not in Germany and not in the Netherlands. But the Commission has to check that ball.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE). –
text: Commissioner, Mr Ertug has already said it, you are the guardian of the European treaties, but a deal seems to have been struck here, not on legal grounds, but on political grounds.You are convinced that the new German toll plan is in accordance with European law.Then why not send an in-depth legal analysis to the European Parliament?A second point - and I will quote from your own low-emission strategy - there is a need to switch to road tax on the basis of kilometers actually driven everywhere in the European Union.I agree, but the German toll plan is at odds with that.There is no connection whatsoever with actual kilometers driven.This German toll scheme is discriminatory, it is bad for the environment, it is bad for Europe.It is not the infringement procedure that should be shelved, but this German toll plan.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I co-signed this oral question because I find it difficult to understand how this new toll on German roads complies with European law, while the Germans themselves are exempt from it.This injustice is particularly poorly understood in border areas.What can we say to the 30,000 Alsatian border workers who cross the border every day or to these occasional travelers who cross the Rhine?That you have to pay, while others don't.The toll as such is not the problem.Germany is tax free.The difficulty is that once again, the inhabitants of the border areas will suffer further administrative and financial hassles, this time coupled with a deep sense of injustice.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: - Congratulations! Congratulations, Madam President, on your first presidency. Commissioner, I really appreciate you very much and I know that you also have a lot of energy, but the time has come to hit the table and be taken seriously. Because, of course, it is happening: there are more and more national rules, each time they are more discriminatory and obstructive rules. Now it is the culmination, that is, the last straw, because it is already by nationality and, moreover, in Germany. And I think you have to impose yourself. Here, you see, you have the full force of Parliament. It has to serve him, because, of course, we cannot continue in this situation. You have to impose yourself because, if not, everything we have been building is going to be undone based on discriminatory rules by nations and by countries, and also behind the Commission's back. Because I don't understand how Mr. Dobrindt has the nose to tell you one thing and then he goes to his Congress and says the opposite. He says yes, yes, German citizens are not going to pay. So he has to clarify that for us. Therefore, I ask you two things: if the appeal for infringement is suspended or not, and what timeframe do you foresee for the solution.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Do you know Pippi Longstocking? “I make the world the way I like it.” Our German Pippi is called Alexander Dobrindt. His greatest madness: the toll, developed as an election campaign idea at the Bavarian regulars' table, maybe after four or five beers, when Dobrindt was still general secretary and kneebiter of the CSU. A year later, however, he is Minister of Transport and responsible. He bent the illegal original idea beyond recognition. In the end there was a yes from Juncker among friends, without a legal basis. It was a yes for the minus toll. Thanks to Dobrindt, we Germans are working on a toll that snubs our neighbors, disadvantages families and, according to ADAC, brings in a loss of 250 million euros. One minus, yes! I cannot explain that to any citizen. Therefore, I would like to ask all of the colleagues who have just mentioned a lawsuit: Please complain! You save us Germans a lot of nonsense and hundreds of millions of euros. Even better: let's show solidarity and fight together in Parliament for a toll-free Europe!

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the legal basis that brought this issue to the European Court of Justice was nothing less than non-compliance with Articles 18 and 21 - non-discrimination on grounds of nationality and free movement of goods and services - of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. More than a bilateral agreement, which does not seem to solve the underlying problem, the definitive solution depends on the expected European road pricing system that prevents and avoids this bankruptcy, a rule that must guarantee that this direct route of financing infrastructure is shared and progressive , linking contribution and intensity and frequency of use and the quality and conditions of the infrastructure. Its implementation and the capacity it can have to reduce the deficit throughout the Union and decarbonise transport can also be a stimulus to invest in the equipment we need to turn European roads into a global reference as a smart and safe space . In this framework, a European electronic toll system is equally unavoidable. Individual solutions are not worth it.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, an infection of national egoism is causing the creeping erosion of the European Union's internal market.The German toll proposal contributes to this.The Commission should be the guardian of European integration, and I therefore believe that it will demonstrate the ability to play this role in this case as well.According to the settled case-law of the Court of Justice, restrictions on the freedoms of the internal market are inadmissible, not only discriminatory but even those which make the exercise of the freedoms of the internal market less attractive if disproportionate.And I'm afraid this is also the case with German tolls.We also need to think about making cross-border cooperation work well.I am afraid that the German toll proposal is an obstacle to such good functioning.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! As a German MP I represent the citizens who live in the border region with the Netherlands. Europe does not come to life here in the European Parliament, but on the ground, where people live together across national borders. The toll plans of the German CSU transport minister make Europe less fair and less open. I am convinced that I reject that here - like most of my colleagues. For people living in the border region, it is most normal in the world to drive across the border. Cross-border networks in this region, such as the Ems-Dollart region or the Euregio, show the deep interweaving of German-Dutch relations. My constituency benefits enormously from a Europe of free movement and non-discriminatory road use between the Netherlands and Germany. I consider the toll to be a brake on the economy, as it makes it less attractive to drive across the border, go shopping or go on a weekend trip. Jobs will also suffer from the toll, and it discriminates against foreigners in contrast to German citizens - even if the CSU colleague does not see it that way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we have a classic case, a glaring case of violation of the Treaty on European Union because we have discrimination on grounds of nationality in the exercise of the rights of citizens of the Union, such as the right to free movement and the right to work. So this is because the vignette imposed on cars without German license plates may be the same as, as you said, the one imposed on cars with German license plates, but cars with German license plates take back a portion of this amount which they have given. So we have an indirect discrimination against cars that do not have German license plates. This is a classic case of breach of the Treaty on European Union, and I am addressing Mrs Bulc and telling her that it is not the Commission's right to decide, whenever it wants, and to refer a state to the Court of Justice of the European Union. There is already a decision by the European Ombudsman that this right of yours is being checked and is being checked for maladministration ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will speak on my own behalf to tell you that I do not understand you. I’m going to stand up for Germany once. The Germans paid for their highways with their taxes. The difference is there: foreigners did not pay for these highways with their taxes. The only thing to do is equivalence. I take the example of the French. They paid for their highways first with taxes. Then there were concessions: they pay twice. That is why, in our program, we want to give the French back their highways. The only thing, in fact - and I say this as an Alsatian - is that it is quite normal that when I benefit from German infrastructure, I pay for it. The only thing is that, when you benefit from French infrastructures, you also participate in them. The pity is that the trucks that no longer want to pay on the German side come from the French side and that there they are not made to pay.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - European leaders in European capitals are talking about European cooperation and the removal of barriers. Nevertheless, in practice we see every day that more and more new obstacles are added at the borders and it is mainly residents of border regions, such as in my own beautiful Limburg, who suffer as a result. People in border regions who in daily practice constantly cross borders to work, to live, to shop, to go to the doctor. These people now face discrimination and are further discouraged from crossing those boundaries. We must ensure here that we break down borders and that we do not create new ones. Border regions are the testing grounds for European cooperation. If we deal with that in this way, I see the future of the EU gloomy. That is why I say to you, Commissioner, continue to oppose this German toll as long as it involves discrimination, even if only a very small part. In any case, we from the European Parliament will continue to do so here.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I do not think you have had the opportunity to see such a large majority supporting, from left to right, the same issue. The problem is not with tolls - of course, we had two exceptions, but I think they did not read our question well - it is not the problem of tolls, but how to charge. I want to suggest to you, Commissioner, because I trust you, to record this evening for Mr Juncker, so that he can understand and thank his colleagues in Germany, no matter what political group they are from, for understanding what Europe means. Give Mr. Juncker the record tonight, because you have the hot potato in your hand. You cannot solve it alone, but this unity and solidarity tonight can help you solve the problem. We do not have to have such a case and a precedent and we are waiting for answers to all the questions. Thanks to all the colleagues who supported this question.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to express my thanks for all the comments and for the opportunity to have this very extensive debate about the PkW-Maut here in the Chamber. I hope that this debate has been as useful for you as it has been for me. Let me once again reassure you that the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, will ensure that there is no discrimination based on nationality. For now, we will have to wait for the outcome of the vote in the German Bundestag on the PkW-Maut and the vehicle tax. When this has taken place, the Commission will assess the law and will take a final decision on the case. I would like just to stress that currently the infringement procedure is not closed, but on hold, to allow time for revision of the law. This practice has been used before in different cases and I see no reason why it should not be used in this case.  Let me reply to some of your many questions and concerns. Is the Commission satisfied with the outcome? The Commission strongly favours road-charging in line with the ‘user and polluter pays’ principle. There is no doubt about that. Therefore it is positive that Germany is moving towards road-charging for passenger cars as many other Member States have already done in the past. It is also positive that the German authorities agreed to amend their legislation as requested by the Commission. This should ensure a fair treatment of EU citizens and should incentivise the use of cleaner vehicles, but, at this point, I cannot speculate on the final outcome of the law. The Commission will only be able to comment after the law has been presented and confirmed.  As far as the questions relating to the European Court of Justice are concerned, let me explain that the aim of infringement cases is to bring national legislation into line with EU law. It is not the aim, per se, to bring Member States to the European Court of Justice. But also let me stress once again that the Commission will not close the infringement procedure until German legislation has been satisfactorily amended in accordance with EU law. I would also like to say very clearly that all infringement procedures are managed by the Commission in the collegial manner. The PkW-Maut procedure is no exception.  Regarding the Commission apparently changing its position, allow me to comment on that as well. The Commission did not change its position at any stage of the process. The infringement case was launched based on the identification of very clear breaches of EU law. The political understanding which was reached between Minister Dobrindt and me in December specifically addresses these same breaches. I would like to underline that the Commission always, and consistently, acts as the guardian of the Treaties.  You also speculated that the talks with Germany were kept secret. Infringement cases are matters strictly between the Commission and the Member States in question. It is usual practice for the Commission to have bilateral discussions with Member States in order to find solutions and Germany is no exception here. But let me say that the Commission has been as transparent as possible in its proceedings, including with public statements. When taking further steps in the infringement procedures, this was also publicly announced and, on the day of the political understanding, this was announced in a press conference by Mr Dobrindt and myself. I was very clear in that press conference about the position of the Commission.  Let me also stress that, in the absence of EU legislation on charging and vehicle taxation for passenger cars, we have to ensure that Article 18 of the Treaty, on non-discrimination, is respected. As I said earlier, we believe that one way to avoid discrimination is to apply charges and taxes based on different criteria, for instance on environmental performance and the infrastructure use of vehicles. This is precisely what we expect from the new German law.  And what about the claims made by neighbouring Member States? I am very attentive to the voices of Member States. I have been listening to them and this underlines the need to establish, as soon as possible, an EU-wide system for road-charging. I am glad to say that we have already taken many of your comments on board and they will be presented soon. I am also aware that the Committee on Transport and Tourism is preparing a resolution on the PkW-Maut, which will be voted in plenary in March. I look forward to seeing the resolution and hope that the debate today has been informative in this regard. Before I conclude, please allow me to restate what is at the heart of our forthcoming road initiatives. We want to take decisive steps towards decarbonisation, promoting a well—functioning, fair, social and efficient internal market, favouring innovation, digital solutions and investments. Any debate on road-charging has to be placed in this perspective. I can only hope that I can count on your support for an EU—based tolling system.

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much indeed. May I just emphasise what you said at the end about counting on our support. Yes, I think the whole debate was guided precisely by that objective. The debate is closed.  The vote will take place in the March II session. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - I think today's debate has completely lost its title and subject. For two reasons. In the first place, this is just a draft, the application of which has not yet begun. Secondly, the draft toll model presented cannot be called discriminatory in any way. What I think some colleagues are worried about is the issue of registration tax, which is a national competence. What is clear, however, is that things should not be washed up. At the same time, we are not debating the very existing and applied national legislation, which is present in more and more Member States and clearly results in the fragmentation of the European internal transport market, often making it impossible for businesses, especially SMEs, to jeopardize the European economy. strengthening of road transport. If we are already debating, we should be doing things that are relevant and truly European. Thanks!

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that the levying of tolls for the use of motorways is the exclusive competence of the Member States. There is also no doubt, however, that these charges should be imposed in a non-discriminatory manner, fairly charging all road users. Germany's original proposal to charge only foreigners for tolls on motorways was clearly inconsistent with EU law and was rightly referred to the Court of Justice. The new proposal, which is the result of a compromise between the German government and the European Commission, is better than the original one, but in my opinion it does not remove the basic objection, which is discrimination against motorway users who are foreigners. German drivers will receive a reduction in road tax, which in fact will be a compensation for the need to purchase a vignette. Therefore, in my opinion, the compromise concluded is unfortunately only an attempt to cover up a problem and not a solution to it.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: in writing.- Ladies and gentlemen!The road toll collection system proposed by Germany violates the principle of equal treatment of the inhabitants of the European Union.It cannot be agreed that drivers from other countries are to pay certain amounts for the journey, while German drivers are to have a tax reduction.As a result, only foreigners will pay tolls through Germany.At the same time, the attitude of the Commission, which seems to allow this type of solution, is disappointing.I would like to emphasize that every country has the right to introduce tolls, but wherever they operate, they cover the same level of residents of a given country and foreigners.Finally, a sad reflection - the actions and attitudes we are talking about today discourage and disappoint EU citizens.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - Any system of direct or indirect reimbursement based on nationality is wrong and contrary to the European principle of freedom of movement. That is why I consider the German government's decision to introduce a vignette for cars in Germany to be discriminatory and distort the transport market throughout Europe. It is clear that car owners registered in Germany receive a tax deduction after paying the vignette, those in other Member States are at a disadvantage, and this directly affects the competitiveness of foreign companies. In this context, I expect the European Executive to be firm in its adherence to the principles set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and to rule as soon as possible on the legality of the vignette for cars traveling in Germany. At the same time, I believe that we need a common legislative framework at European level, as well as an efficient taxation system that, on the one hand, reflects the Union's ambition for the environment and, on the other, take into account the financial possibilities of the different Member States.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Jerzy Buzek, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the European Cloud Initiative (2016/2145(INI)) (A8-0006/2017). In order for there not to be any delay, as I understand that Mr Buzek is not yet with us and in order not to keep us waiting, I propose Commissioner, if you agree, that we will start with your introduction and hopefully in the meantime Mr Buzek will arrive.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, last year on 19 April the Commission launched the European Cloud Initiative with the ambition of ensuring that science, businesses, public services could reap all the benefits of the so-called ‘big data revolution’. Today we produce 2.5 billion – billion – bytes of data per day. That is, as someone once put it, four Eiffel Towers of Blu-ray discs per day, so the fundamental question for us tonight is really how we should deal with it, and the Cloud Initiative is part of the answer to this question. The Communication proposed the creation of an inclusive, European, open science cloud, deploying an efficient European data infrastructure to address such enormous data flows and opening up the user base to the public sector and industry. As Commissioner for research, science and innovation, I have followed very closely the work of this House and it culminated with the adoption of the report in front of us today.  Let me say a word of gratitude to the Chair, Jerzy Buzek, for stepping up as a rapporteur, and to Mr Boni and Ms Maydell for their work in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO). I knew from the beginning that the contribution of this Parliament would be a valuable support for our strategy for an open and trusted cloud-based data environment geared to the scientific community.  We are now deeply committed to engaging with all relevant stakeholders to ensure that the European Cloud Initiative can achieve its objectives. We are now discussing sustainable funding and implementation instruments with the Member States, research infrastructures, scientific communities and other key players. But let me assure you that we are here to tell you that your advice will be followed, that the Commission has already started to implement the initiative very much along the lines that you suggest.  First, on the European Open Science Cloud the Commission is preparing a roadmap for governance and financing to be presented to, and discussed with, the Member States in the course of 2017. Our aim is very simple. We want our 1.7 million European scientists to have the best services for text and data mining, the best data management plans and the best training programmes. We made open data the default in Horizon 2020, starting in 2017. In other words, we kind of transformed an exception into a rule simply because we intend and we believe that the Commission should lead by example. We will fund a pilot project on the European Science Cloud to ensure that the governance in the European Open Science Cloud is truly representative of European science, that it create synergies amongst existing and future initiatives of this kind.  Over the year, we will do more. We will define a governance board before the end of 2017 and we will work on making all our research data fair; findable, so scientists can identify each piece of data in a unique way; accessible, so it can always be obtained freely; interoperable, because science is today at the intersection of disciplines; and reusable, because you cannot lose important data after you have used it, you have to be able to use it in different disciplines at different times. So if we want better research, if we want better science and if we want better innovation, it is essential to be able to set these fair principles of data as the global standard, so we all speak to same language and we can advance in science.  After addressing you on the Science Cloud, let me now give you some information about the European data infrastructure, a European high performance computing strategy under development with Member States and European industry. This includes a pooling of the necessary investments at all levels to create a world-class pan-European high performance computing and big data ecosystem by 2023.  We want this ecosystem to be built on two exascale computers. That means a billion operations per second, which is basically one thousand times faster than today’s supercomputers. The Commission agrees that the take-up of high performance computing services by businesses, consumers, public administrations and scientific sectors requires seamless user-friendly access with appropriate levels of data protection, security and services to ensure trust and confidence in their use. I believe the key for the future in terms of data is about exactly these two principles: trust and confidence.  And so in this context, on 10 January last, the Commission adopted the Communication on Building a European Data Economy. That deals with additional big data issues. It advocates reducing barriers to the free flow of data. It looks into questions of ownership, access to data, liability in the context of data-driven processes and autonomous systems. It puts emphasis on measures necessary to ensure an open and competitive economy without unjustified lock-in effects. As regards widening the benefits of the European Cloud Initiative to industry, the Commission is considering several proposals on the supply and demand side and on the extension to SMEs.  Let me finish by reiterating that the Commission is fully committed with you to supporting science, industry and public authorities in Europe, access to world-class data infrastructures and cloud-based services as they become the decisive factors for success in this digital era. In a recent visit to Heidelberg I saw how the Institute of Bioinformatics generates more than EUR 1.3 billion per year of value just by having made one very simple choice: scientific information freely available to the global science community. That is the way we are going. That is the way we will have to go, thanks to your report.

name: Michał Boni
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank my colleagues, shadow rapporteurs from the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, because I was a shadow there and rapporteur for the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, for the great cooperation which has resulted in us getting this report into a positive shape. We need open science followed by open innovation in Europe. We have to overcome all institutional and mental barriers to create a good background for the European Open Science Cloud initiative. It is key to use the Horizon 2020 sources more strongly and faster, to speed up modern science developments, especially to start with the European supercomputer, to attract scientists to be more open, to ensure interoperability and technological support for the secure cloud, to involve all partners in the data computing processes. We need to share data and the results of research under conditions of security, privacy protection and modernised intellectual property. Open access to data, based on clear rules, better usage of text and data mining possibilities are the new drivers. Open data-driven science and the Big Data-driven economy are two sides of the same coin. Opening the data is the future. Locking up is the past.

name: Eva Maydell
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, this initiative enables Europe to open a new page in the history of our continent so that we can prove we are a continent of innovation, of places where it can happen, a continent open for business. In the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection we want to put forward three key points, and I would like to thank our colleagues in the Committee on Industry Research and Energy for taking them on board. First of all, the initiative should deal with what the sector is willing to do and wants to do. Second of all, it has to have a regional approach: newer Member States also have to have a key role in the discussions in bringing forward this initiative. Third, we need European legislation to guarantee the free flow of data. We want the free flow of data to be the fifth freedom in Europe. I really hope that the European Cloud for Open Science could become one of those key successful projects in Europe, just like projects such as Erasmus, the abolition of roaming or the European Fund for Strategic Investment. I would like to thank everyone who pulled together on this text and ensured that we managed to fight the populist approach and that it did not block our way in pushing the initiative forward.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs for the effort they have made, and especially my colleague Michał Boni, because the circumstances in which the position of the ITRE Committee has been shaped have been particularly complex and difficult , and we have had, in the end, a magnificent position, a magnificent document in the ITRE Committee. The data economy is emerging as the main engine of growth and competitiveness throughout the world, including in Europe. Until now, practically, the generation of data had a profile and was a source of an essentially personal nature, linked to social networks, also linked to electronic commerce. But now we are facing an emerging situation, and increasingly crystallized, where the data that comes from the machine-to-machine connection is being converted and will end up becoming the heart of the knowledge economy, of the data economy. Given the strengths that the European manufacturing industry has - its export capacity, etc. - we are facing a huge new possibility and, in that sense, this cloud computing proposal for open science, but also to apply it later to the industry. and to other sectors, it seems essential to me.

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's initiative in the field of cloud computing as part of the implementation of the Digital Single Market Strategy and the European Industry Digitization Package, thus supporting the growth of the European digital economy, contributing to the competitiveness of European businesses and services; strengthening its position on the world market. As the benefits of cloud computing are key to sustainable growth, job creation and research, it is important to reduce the fragmentation of digital infrastructures, ensure proper governance and funding for the European cloud. The development of 5G technology and the new rules to be established by the European Electronic Communications Code should make the European cloud for open science more attractive, providing high-quality internet services and new, high-quality infrastructure. Also, the development of clear standards for interoperability, data portability and service level agreements in the field of cloud technology will ensure a greater degree of certainty and transparency, both for the benefit of users and cloud service providers. Commissioner, the report adopted by the ITRE Committee, which we are discussing today, I think enjoys great support in Parliament and also from the Commission. To ensure the success of this initiative, I would like to ask you what measures the Commission is considering to stimulate the participation of European SMEs and the private sector in the production of equipment, software and for the European data infrastructure, and also how we can provide the necessary financial resources for this initiative.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The ECR fully supports the idea of ​​sharing all scientific data produced under Horizon 2020 via the European Open Science Cloud. But we have doubts about the role and value of the European Commission participation in shaping the future of this sector in terms of infrastructure development and resource use. We believe that it is imperative that such work is carried out by the industry sector and takes into account the realities of the market. The European Commission should not interfere too much in the operation of the market in this regard. The Commission's 'one size fits all' approach is not the right solution. In addition, according to the Communication, the European Cloud Initiative should back up funding under Horizon 2020, but also states that additional public-private investment of € 4.7 billion will be required over a five-year period. The Commission does not state on what basis it determined that investments of this size would be necessary.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - I would first like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and in particular Mr Boni for the good cooperation on this report. I call for a strong signal from the European Parliament on this European Cloud Initiative. I would like us to be able to say: we are “proud of the Cloud”. Because it is crucial for our international competitiveness that Europe has an ultra-modern digital infrastructure as soon as possible. That is actually a no-brainer when you consider that all sectors of the economy are digitizing. Data flows are growing explosively due to the internet of things. When we consider that 80 percent of the data that is now stored has been collected in the past two years, you can see how fast that will go. This initiative bridges the gap between data and digitization, especially through the Open Science Cloud. By seizing this opportunity, we can create additional growth and jobs. The Open Science Cloud will give millions of scientists in Europe, regardless of national borders or specific research areas, access to a lot of new data that they currently cannot easily access. But of course other users should also be able to benefit from the Open Science Cloud. Companies must have cheap and easy access to big data, which enables them to develop new innovative products. By using the cloud, they can reduce their IT costs by an average of 20 to 50 percent. So, our digital infrastructure must be of the highest quality and I am pleased that the Commission is committed to three critical areas: supercomputers, high-speed connections and mass storage of data. I am particularly pleased with the billion euros that the Commission is making available for quantum research, because this new generation of supercomputers will be able to handle all current computers. We must ensure that Europe remains in the lead and I am pleased that the Council is also taking this seriously. For example, I may also be present tomorrow are at a conference in Malta about the quantum computer.

name: Marisa Matias
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - In the absence of servers in the European Union with sufficient capacity to store research data, this means that researchers have to resort to other places and to store outside the European Union, without data protection being safeguarded. The same applies to access: there are access problems because we do not have this capacity within the European Union. This project that is presented today is an ambitious project, but for it to work to its fullest, it is necessary, first of all, that the system be kept in the public domain, guaranteeing the use and access to the whole community, from researchers to small and medium-sized companies and other industry sectors; second, to ensure data portability and interoperability; thirdly, to protect personal and research data under the legislation we already have and not to give up even a millimeter. The European cloud initiative is a fundamental project for the digital society, but we cannot allow private interests to overlap and, therefore, we can even end public-private partnerships. I believe it would be a mistake, in terms of access and what should be the background of this project, which I believe to be extremely important. And lastly, lastly, especially for the Commissioner and for his adviser, Alfredo Sousa Jesus, imagine the society in which we would live today if Marx had had the opportunity to share all his work in the cloud.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. –A few years ago we could still say that Cloud computing was something for the future. Now it is actually normal to store your data outside of your own hard drive. But we very often store that outside the European Union and that is not good, because outside our jurisdiction we cannot protect governments, companies, scientists and citizens. American companies should let the NSA watch and let's not talk about Russian companies. And that is not good, because protecting personal data is extremely important, especially in the times of Trump and Putin. So this Cloud Initiative - and I don't say it often - is a real win-win opportunity. We can turn our backlog in cloud computing into a head start. That is good for our wallet and good for our privacy. But then I would like to ask you, Commissioner, to stop listening to companies like Hewlett-Packard and Amazon, American companies eager to have a monopoly on the cloud. We reduce that risk by enforcing open standards. By enforcing our data protection laws very tightly, also in the cloud, we have an offer also for companies from outside the European Union. Then I see very good opportunities.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, this report was originally my report. My concern had been to: control the sector, both software and hardware at the level of European companies, that is to say truly European companies having their headquarters in Europe, manufacturing in Europe and having capital Europeans; master security with security keys that allow it and, among others, quantum keys; master the notion of openness, because openness must not be just one-sided and not only serve foreign powers, while the United States or China protect themselves with the notion of 'opening; control the ownership of the data on the principle that it truly belongs to the person providing it. I was surprised. I surrounded myself with a team of 25 specialists and 5 coordinators, also specialists in this sector. We have discovered, Commissioner, that some companies - the first in Europe - had not been consulted. We have found that you are putting huge amounts of money into supercomputers, but also abandoning quantum, for example, or other areas like microprocessors, which are 20 times the market for supercomputers. We have discovered that your policy is primarily that of foreign lobbyists. These facts - I have given all the work to the Commission - my colleagues refuse. Reality is postponed. Unfortunately, Commissioner, I fear that this policy will be a failure and I therefore want to tell you that if I had not already had reasons to leave this Europe, now I would have one more.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, I do not wish to be a spoilsport, but may I just introduce a dose of reality to this particular debate? This project is forecast to cost EUR 6.7 billion, which includes a 4.7 billion financial shortfall. That means that no one has defined where almost EUR 5 billion of the costs will be found. Secondly, there is no explanation from the Commission as to how or why this concept will work any better than existing readily available storage systems. Thirdly, there is no road map to show how national governments might be persuaded of any of the benefits, given existing global and fully international alternatives. Fourthly, there is no impact assessment on national legal competences such as posting of data and spectrum issues.  Now everything points to the sort of debacle that even the United Kingdom has had with big IT projects, and I have to admit that; with the huge costs involved with all of the aspects that have not been addressed, I really do feel that giving the green light to this tomorrow is not going to be the right decision, and I ask that the rapporteur takes these points on board and asks the committee to look at it again.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: -  Mister President! I would like to thank Commissioner Moedas very much for this initiative, which will strengthen Europe. Colleague Boni put it in a nutshell that it is about protecting personal data in a certified European cloud. We know that the Cloud Select Industry Group has endeavored to develop a code of conduct that will set standards for Europe. We need these standards globally so that the European cloud industry can play a strong role in this area. ENISA and ETSI are key players here, and I can only congratulate the two organizations on the fact that this initiative will bring really sustainable European successes for small and medium-sized enterprises as well. Of course, we also need a cloud computing compliance control catalog system in order to set standards here that will enable us to eliminate the mistrust and the crisis of confidence that exists in this area. We need a European cloud seal of approval that ensures data storage by European cloud providers also in European data centers and the full source code is accordingly available in Europe. We need European law and European data protection regulations to implement this cloud seal of approval. Then taxes and duties will also remain in Europe, and IT services will be able to contribute to our infrastructure.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Mister President! European clouds help safeguard Europe as a business location and, especially when a high level of data protection is guaranteed, also represent a competitive advantage. I said that in this House four years ago during a debate. A lot has happened since then. The data volume has multiplied and the technical possibilities have improved significantly. But little has happened in our field. The Commission's initiative is therefore to be welcomed. But it should not stop at announcements and gossip. To prevent this from happening, we need more funds - significantly more funds and quickly - and we should also make the European competitive advantages clear. This includes the high level of data protection on this continent. We should be aware that a European cloud initiative should not only focus on research, but should also address the needs of private users.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Europe has a magnificent research and innovation ecosystem, 1.7 million researchers, 70 million professionals in science and technology. But there is always a but". We are good at inventing new digital technologies but we fail to commercially exploit these ideas. We are good application developers but for third party platforms. Europe is the world's largest producer of scientific data, but once again, fragmentation and inadequate infrastructures prevent us from harnessing the full potential of this data. The European Cloud Computing Initiative is imperative and urgent. We need a virtual environment to store, share and reuse the data generated by this universe of researchers and technologists across disciplines and across borders. We need to gain supercomputing capacity and that requires economic resources to make it possible to deploy supercomputing capacity, ultra-fast connectivity and high-capacity cloud solutions through a European data infrastructure. And to make it possible for all regions of the European Union to participate, there are no new gaps. I, of course, support and encourage the Commission and the Member States to make these objectives a reality, putting the necessary financial resources to finance initiatives in which we risk being or not being the global competitiveness of Europe.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, we are experiencing a time of acceleration in data access and processing. The digital society that is emerging in today's world is designed on a magma made up of ever-increasing amounts of data. The European Union needs a robust infrastructure for its storage, high-speed connectivity and transport capacity and computers with high processing capacity and, from here, we have to define priorities, we have to invest in the innovation of services for citizens, in the integration of small and medium-sized companies in the value chains and, with that, we have to be able to improve responses in areas such as security, protection of privacy, health and the qualification of people.
