The Wifi for EU initiative, which contributes to universal and high quality access to the Internet, regardless of economic condition and geographic location, can be used to test the promotion of inclusion associated with this initiative. I leave you, Commissioner, this challenge. And we also have to improve connectivity to other areas of the globe. The submarine cable between Europe and Brazil is also important for the success of this initiative.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I welcome this report on the European Cloud Computing Initiative and I am confident that Parliament's position will be taken into account by the Commission. The cloud industry is growing very fast and is estimated to reach almost 45 billion euros in 2020. In fact, it is enough to look at the fact that 25% of European companies already use the cloud to store emails or documents, and a one third of them also use financial or cloud management applications. However, almost half of companies still consider the cloud a significant security risk and justify not using the technology due to a lack of skills. In fact, if the European Union really wants to invest in this technology, it must provide the necessary money. We are short of € 4.7 billion to fund the initiative. We have only 12% of the European Fund for Strategic Investments directed towards digital and we want to have solutions. We need to act directly, quickly in education, in the public sector, in the education of companies, in order to have a European cloud. Commissioner, you have the support of the European Parliament for that, be strong.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, as you well know, the data economy is the inevitable or irrevocable step in the digital economy.I welcome the call that is made in the report to open science, for the advances that it will bring about in knowledge and in the economy itself.For this we need an infrastructure, such as iCloud, which must be ambitious and, of course, with sufficient funding.I believe that coordination by the Commission is key to its success.I also believe that public and private participation is essential to be able to take advantage of all the advances and opportunities that are offered to us.For this, I believe that this participation should be in the sense of access to information, and also in the support of this infrastructure.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to say to the Commissioner that this is a really timely proposal. In the past, when we talked about the cloud development, we missed the bus and came too late. Here we have an excellent Horizon 2020 programme, we have excellent universities and we have all those campuses all over Europe specialised to combine them and to enable them. So I would like to congratulate you. The second thing concerns the human resources that we need to make this happen, to make this fly. In my region, in relation to the big data initiative you have just mentioned, there is now a new academy, which started last year in combination with big data, science, ethics and entrepreneurship. So you can see that, from different angles, this might be a very powerful and timely initiative, not repeating the last years where we lost out to the United States, as I heard a minute ago.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, cloud computing is about storing, processing and using data from remote computers that provide Internet access and help users save time and money. Cloud computing enables users to have almost complete flexibility in terms of storage space and the tools they use. It is estimated that cloud computing revenue in the European Union could reach EUR 80 billion by 2020. However, it is recalled that the protection of personal and sensitive data must take precedence over the free flow of data. Finally, any cloud computing policy initiative in Europe must meet the needs and benefits of small and medium-sized enterprises and, above all, consumers at European, national, regional and local level.

name: Carlos Moedas
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for this interesting debate and all the questions which we received and which we have discussed. I will start by quoting Mr Boni, who said that open data is the future and locking up is the past. We have the opportunity not to miss this boat of open access, open data, open science and openness to the world. So I really warmly appreciate your calls during this debate to speed up implementation, to invest in a world—leading capacity, to set up a governance structure with a membership that is truly representative of European science, to protect people’s data and privacy, and to ensure that European industry and the public sector benefit fully from it. The Commission knows that it can count on the European Parliament as a true partner to realise these objectives in full. Thank you very much for this discussion and for your comments. I am a great believer that this is the way to go. This is the way to go so that we can have better science. Our scientists, whom I meet every day, tell us that they want to have this cloud. They need this cloud. This cloud is about being better, being able to mine text and data better than others, and having access to information that can create ideas. Those ideas can create companies and those companies will create the jobs of the future.

name: President. –
text: Commissioner, I would like to express my appreciation of your efforts in terms of entering into debate. It is not always the case that Commissioners react to the questions that have been posed, and that is what I would like to encourage so that the European Parliament is an arena of real debate.

name: Michał Boni
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his explanation and his determination to establish a European Open Science Cloud because this really is our future. I would also like to thank all my colleagues, who have mentioned many issues here. I think that we can conclude by talking about five conditions for open science data, for the development of the Open Science Cloud Initiative.  Firstly, infrastructure – how to make the infrastructure much more adjusted. We need to develop 5G, we need to have this European supercomputer, and we need to develop and have a network of European high performance computing centres. Secondly, principles: we need a much more secure cloud and we need to implement the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and privacy protection. We also need, I think, to discuss how to use anonymisation in processing the data.  Thirdly, cooperation of all partners, because I think it is very important to involve scientists, to involve universities, to involve business and to involve citizens. Fourthly, we need to promote this solution because there are many mental barriers, including in our universities among our scientists. And last, but not least, we need to discuss financial resources for the development of those issues because this is very crucial, so we need to discuss how to use money from Horizon 2020, but we also need to discuss now what will happen after 2020.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - With my question of December 2014 "Internet and universal services" I assumed that ICT services are considered fundamental public services in the Digital Agenda. In two years, the increasing need to guarantee data privacy and maximum inclusiveness, speed in network installation, suitability of backup plans and respect for the environment on the internet has made this definition more and more current. I am pleased with the response I received in February 2015 from Commissioner Oettinger as the Commission reiterates its commitment to the objectives of the Digital Agenda for Europe and that broadband is essential for new online services to reach critical mass. However, recent social, economic and technological developments require EU institutions to review the content of universal service at EU level to protect publicly accessible services. Cloud is a universal service for me and as such it must be guaranteed. It is no coincidence, in fact, that the creation of the best possible environment with high quality data, data analysis and secure services makes our SMEs increasingly competitive.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Cloud Initiative emerged as an attempt to respond to the challenges of the digital age. The data economy is becoming one of the major economic engines in today’s world. Data, instead of being purely local in nature, is now gaining global reach. This cloud initiative is mature and is likely to help effectively address data storage, processing and exchange issues within the EU, while increasing the competitiveness of the European Union's economy. One of the goals mentioned in the document is the development of the digital economy. An open cloud project will serve not only science but also the private sector. I agree with the statements made in the document about the protection of personal and scientific data, using existing EU legislation, but a balance must be struck between the public and personal interests. Cloud computing is not just a set of technical solutions. These are European information security issues themselves. In order to avoid data fragmentation, it is necessary not only to harmonize the legal framework for the free movement of data in the EU Member States, but also to review and modernize copyright issues.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Lambert van Nistelrooij, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on investing in jobs and growth – maximising the contribution of European Structural and Investment Funds: an evaluation of the report under Article 16(3) of the CPR (2016/2148(INI)(A8-0385/2016),  – the oral question to the Commission on delayed implementation of European Structural and Investment (ESI) Funds operational programmes – Impact on cohesion policy and the way forward by Iskra Mihaylova, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (O-000005/2017 – B8-0202/2017) (2016/3008(RSP)).

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij
text: rapporteur. –  Mr President, thank you for having us here at this timely moment: I see that the Commissioner has just arrived and I especially want to address her.  Mr President, Commissioner Crețu, let us carry out a sort of mid-term balance on how we are performing. How are we performing in this cohesion policy, in the regional policy? I thank the Commission and all the colleagues for all the facts and figures and materials that we got on this Article 16(3) report. There are a lot of positive numbers in terms of growth and jobs. We support 150 000 startups. We have the creation of more than 500 000 jobs. This is substantial, and we also see a real shift from the infrastructure – roads and roads, bridges and bridges – of the last period to a knowledge-driven economy, to applied science, ICT, the green economy and social cohesion.  This renewed policy definitively leads to more local and European added value. We see commitments in the social field, especially for younger people to bring them to a job. The ex-ante conditionalities we have formulated lead to a more integrated policy and a better structured and targeted result. We initiated a package of simplification synergies with other funds and performance-based budgeting. It was something new in this House. The practical reflection and the relation with the European Semester is established. Cohesion concerns three-fourths of the country-specific recommendations, and we made a performance framework as an example, as I said, of this performance-based budgeting.  And on this basis we had studied and debated, I asked the Commission to come with three points of action. First, a cohesion master plan rescheduling the 2014-2020 period on the basis of the approvals of the operational programmes and the consequences for payments in the next years. N+3 has not helped to speed things up, and the austerity on the national level brought serious constraints in the co-financing. We need a new payment plan until 2023. I ask you to include three aspects in this cohesion master plan: taking away the hindrances to the expenditure in the Member States; clarifying the effects of the late start-up in the 2017-2023 period, not having this great backlog of bills in the next years to come; and clarifying the effects of the late start for the next years: N+3 will lead to performance payments in the years until 2023. Does this materially extend the period 2014-2020? Will the experience of 2014-2016 be repeated? Member States were still working to finalise the programmes and came with very late agreed programmes for the new period. Let us learn from these consequences. I can just mention two other points. In Bratislava, the informal meeting on cohesion had a very positive assessment on how we have changed our methods, but there was also a proposal, an initiative from you, Commissioner, to present another way of communication, to come forward with a new communication plan. On the communication plan, let the European star shine, I mean the projects and those people in it. My last point is territorial cohesion. I want to underline this smart specialisation approach and the wish of Parliament in my report to come forward with a bigger envelope in the total cohesion amount for this cross-regional and cross-country cooperation.

name: Iskra Mihaylova
text: author. – Mr President, this is not the first time in this House that the Committee on Regional Development has asked the Commission to respond to the issue of slow implementation. Just last year we adopted a similar resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy. Three years have now passed since the start of the new programming period and we are still seeing delays. They have resulted in significant setbacks to project implementation at local, regional and national level, as well as a considerable decrease in payment appropriations compared to last year. We are concerned that this situation will lead to high levels of decommitments in the years to come. It also calls into question the goals and targets of cohesion policy and the smooth implementation of all the projects and operational programmes. While new requirements, such as those on thematic concentration and financial management, ensure increased performance they have also slowed down the implementation process. With this in mind, we underline the importance of simplification. We also encourage the Commission to increase flexibility in relation to the priorities in its operational programmes and to improve coordination between European structural and investment funds and other financial instruments, particularly the European Fund for Strategic Investments. We welcome the support provided through the Taskforce for Better Implementation but we believe more can be done to assist the managing authorities and speed up implementation.  The Regional Development Committee therefore calls on the Commission to present an implementation action plan in the first quarter of 2017. This should assess the cause of the current delays, and it should be drawn up in close cooperation with the Member States, with the aim of accelerating the implementation of operational programmes. The Regional Development Committee wants to know how the Commission will increase flexibility and avoid decommitments. This is the first part of our question. Secondly, how will the Commission ensure the full implementation of the payment plan by 2023? Thirdly, we are asking how the Commission will increase technical assistance for the managing authorities. We ask the Commission to come forward with the solution to these issues in the Cohesion Forum and the 7th Cohesion Report. We urge the Commission to address these questions and deliver an implementation action plan in order to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy for this period. We hope that the lessons learned from these delays can inform the debate on the future European structural and investment funds post-2020. Bearing in mind the importance of this debate, we need to follow the situation with regard to implementation in the current planning period, and it is extremely important to encourage Member States to take special measures to improve implementation, otherwise we will have a not-very-successful period, which will lead to more debates concerning the future of the core of cohesion policy and the core results of the policy. When we talk about the delay in payments and the delay in implementation, we are actually talking about delay in pursuing the main goals of cohesion policy: making the European economy more competitive and creating jobs and growth around Europe.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, firstly I would like to express my sincere appreciation to the rapporteur Mr van Nistelrooij for his truly constructive collaboration and partnership in including in the report important Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) considerations. Regarding the objective of maximising the contribution of European Structural and Investment Funds, I would like to highlight two issues of particular concern. One is the serious concern and disappointment of EMPL about the late adoption of the European Social Fund operational programmes due to the considerable novelties introduced for the 2014-2020 period, which has led to administrative difficulties despite efforts for simplification, thus bringing about the urgent need for both the Member States and the Commission to accelerate the implementation of operational programmes. And second, the request of EMPL to the Commission to ensure that the specific objectives of ESF programmes relating to Europe 2020 headline targets, and to the earmarked budget of 20% of the ESF for spending on social inclusion, are fully achieved by closely monitoring the correct implementation of the actions on the ground.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honorable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, good evening. I would like to thank the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development for this oral question. Thanks to Mrs. Mihaylova. I would also like to thank Mr van Nistelrooij for his own-initiative report on the impact of cohesion policy and the way forward. Your comments, of all, are very important to us. As you know, the Working Group for Better Implementation is working hard and will continue to work for the period 2014-2020. Also, cross-border cooperation, to which Mr van Nistelrooij referred, is very close to my soul and we will come in the coming months to show a study on the impact of these cross-border policies. I think that these studies are very important, at a time when we are trying to show that we want to build links between countries, and not walls that separate the citizens of the European Union. As for the oral question, it comes, I think, at the right time. A number of Members of Parliament expressed concern about delays in investment through cohesion funds. Of course I understand these concerns you have expressed. I, for my part, have repeatedly expressed it to the Member States, because cohesion policy is, as you know, the European Union's main investment force. As Mr van Nistelrooij points out in his report, cohesion policy investment is now needed, more than ever, to boost growth and create jobs, reduce disparities between regions, and address a personalized to the specific needs of all our regions, in which 500 million citizens live. But let me assure you that this is exactly what is happening on the ground, where it is needed and where it really matters. The value of the selected projects, which are currently being implemented, gives us a clear picture of what cohesion policy really does. So far, more than € 176 billion has already been invested in the real economy in 2014-2020, which will soon be reflected in payments made by the European Union to Member States. This is exactly what happened in 2007-2013. More than 315,000 projects are underway in all regions of the European Union, providing support for 140,000 businesses, tens of thousands of households that will benefit from access to broadband, more than 8.5 million citizens who will enjoy appropriate wastewater facilities, improved infrastructure for thousands of researchers and - we work closely with Commissioner Moedas in this regard - new schools for thousands of students in the European Union. We have many examples of projects that are a symbol for the European Union. I would not like to draw your attention to them, because I know that in every region, in every Member State, you have examples of this kind. I believe that the success of cohesion policy investments should not be quantified by how many invoices are sent to Brussels and paid, but rather by how the programs are actually implemented on the ground. I agree with Mr van Nistelrooij, because, as I have said many times, quality must prevail over speed and the results must be good in terms of absorption, but we do not do absorption just for the sake of absorption. We want concrete, quality projects that respond ex ante to conditionalities, to respond to structural reforms, to make this transition you were talking about, from infrastructure to research, development, competitiveness, supporting small and medium enterprises, which is the column the backbone of any economy. With regard to your report, the Commission welcomes and appreciates, as I said, the opinion of Mr van Nistelrooij, and we want to assure you that we are doing everything we can to further reform this cohesion policy so that it becomes more effective by strengthening support. towards the knowledge-based economy, by creating tools such as the performance framework, preconditions for efficient investment, e-Cohesion, for the designation of authorities that ensure the regularity of expenditure and guarantee legal certainty. However, we must remember the responsibility of the Member States. After all, it is a shared responsibility. It is up to the Member States and regions to make use of these possibilities that the European Commission makes available. They are primarily responsible for selecting and implementing projects. Of course we need to work together to strengthen administrative capacity. As I said, in many cases, administrative capacity is more important than money, because, look, we are in a situation where we have money in Brussels, but we do not have contracted projects, quality projects and adequate administrative capacity. Thank you very much. I wish I had more time, but I want to assure you that we are closely monitoring the implementation of the programs in the 2014-2020 programming period, to ensure that payments are in line with commitments. I agree with you that I have made a big mistake in recent years, because I have not communicated enough about what cohesion policy has done, how it has changed the lives of citizens for the better, and thus I have ignored all attacks on the European Union and we have reached this situation, where everything that is bad comes from Brussels and everything that is good comes from the Member States. I think we need to emphasize more what we do and each assume the part of the responsibility regarding the implementation of the projects.The money exists.We expect contracts from the Member States, quality projects that meet the needs of the citizens of each region.

name: President. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner. I am sure we will have an opportunity to listen to your closing remarks and we will have more time then.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής
text: Author of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Mr President, speaking of the Investment and Structural Funds, Commissioner, we must probably explain that cohesion policy has not really existed since 2014. From a development pillar to expressing European solidarity, it has become another public service tool for extremists. adaptations and austerity policies of the European Union. The Structural Funds and the Investment Funds have entered into a framework of strict financial rules. Their paralysis was instituted, on the one hand, with the threat of suspension and freezing of aid when a country does not comply with macroeconomic conditions, and on the other hand, with the insufficient financial framework for the period 2014-2020, reduced by 8.4 %, in an already low Multiannual Financial Framework. It is not possible, Commissioner, to tackle the problem of employment and unemployment and to have real convergence when that is a condition - in order to get that money - to implement austerity and unemployment deregulation policies ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Viorica Dăncilă
text: Rapporteur for opinion Opinion Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Structural and Investment Funds must be used to promote lifelong learning and quality qualification systems that facilitate the adaptation of work to the changing realities of the professional environment, as well as the creation and promoting quality jobs, with a focus on rural areas where women and young people are the most affected by unemployment. I believe that the Union must work closely with the Member States to ensure that the gender dimension is fully integrated into the implementation of rural development programs, and that particular attention is paid to youth projects. On the other hand, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development plays an important role, especially if we consider the degree of flexibility promoted at European level in order to respond as effectively as possible to specific territorial needs and achieve the 3 cross-cutting objectives on innovation, environment and climate change mitigation.

name: Daniele Viotti
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, having worked on this dossier on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, I would particularly like to emphasize the dimension and financial implications of the evaluation of the Structural and Investment Funds. The critical issues are well known. There are often difficulties in designating the managing authority and, for some European regions, absorption rates remain very low, often shamefully low. Furthermore, the high risk of accumulation of payment requests for heading 1b of our budget risks making financial implementation very difficult, as foreseen by our Multiannual Financial Framework and it is therefore necessary that the three institutions work together to better define the closure of the 2016-2020 period. This programming also saw a marked increase in financial instruments. Also in this case, it is necessary for the Commission and Parliament to be vigilant to the utmost, always bearing in mind the principle of budget unity and democratic control of expenditure made with public money. Mr President, I close by recalling that the revision of the regulations on the structural funds was supposed to be an opportunity to improve the efficiency of the rules and not an attempt to change for the worse the philosophy that underlies our great regional policy.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The European Structural and Investment Funds are an extremely necessary and important tool. The positive effects of using these funds are visible at every step, especially in the new Member States, such as Poland, where they were an impulse to accelerate the development of my country in many areas. Are the ESI Funds working perfectly? Of course not. We must take better care of the synergy between various funds, better identification of the spending targets and removal of further administrative barriers to access to these funds for local governments and small and medium-sized enterprises. As responsible for drafting the opinion of the Transport Committee, I would particularly like to highlight the role of ESIF in the infrastructure building process. Without a shadow of a doubt, it can be said that without these funds it would be impossible to complete the TEN-T network in its final shape. A change in the model of the functioning of structural funds is necessary because development challenges are constantly changing, but placing too much trust in various types of financial instruments may harm the achievement of their main goal - leveling out differences between EU countries and regions.

name: Andrey Novakov
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in my opinion, cohesion policy is no longer just a policy. It is part of the common values we share and it delivers more results than many of our other policies combined. 15 million people were supported by the Social Fund; 10 million people gained internet access because of structural funds, 5 000 new roads were built, 30 000 were rebuilt, 1 000 miles of railroad network were created, 100 000 start-ups were supported, and I can go on and on with these statistics. However, the late implementation of that policy will harm not just certain projects, but our entire image in the Union. Therefore, a grand master plan is needed. Firstly, Member States are lagging behind in the schedule. We should explore the possibility of extending the programme period for some operational programmes. We should explore the benefits of having a monofund, keeping the same share of different funds, but operating under a single rule book. This would cut red tape and increase the absorption rate. Last, but not least, managing authorities should go to the beneficiaries, not the other way around. Such mobility would increase the absorption rate and keep the error rate low, especially in mountain regions, remote regions and rural regions. We have to speed up, we have to promise and we have to deliver. Our citizens deserve it.

name: Constanze Krehl
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We have often discussed in this Chamber that the European Union is in a difficult situation. Unfortunately this is nothing new. But I think we have a treasure in hand with cohesion policy. More than 350 billion euros, which we can invest in the future of the regions, in the future of the citizens. Lambert van Nistelrooij's report gives us the chance to take a look at the current state of cohesion policy and what needs arise for us, how we can and must react to challenges in the future. One thing is clear to all of us: we have to be very careful with cohesion policy, with the tax money that is available to us. I believe that Parliament did that by negotiating the legal framework and thus also significantly reforming cohesion policy. We have urged, together with the Commission, to implement results-orientation. We said we want to focus the money we have on a few priorities. We made sure that the local partners were involved in the entire work. The operational programs have now been installed and project work begins. But we also have to make sure that we communicate carefully. After all, how often do local citizens not even know that the European Union is supporting them financially in many projects in their immediate neighborhood? We have to talk about it if we want citizens to support the added value that the European Union brings to them. How many of the many young people to whom we have given work through our youth initiative have given qualifications, then know that it is the Europeans who support it to have?Of course, we need flexibility for unexpected challenges.But I believe we have to find a balance between the challenges and the objectives of the cohesion policy itself, namely social, economic and territorial cohesion.Financial instruments in the right place and at the right time can be well suited to pursuing these goals.But they are not a panacea and cannot be used everywhere and for everything.The European Parliament has to weigh that up again and again and decide, for the benefit of all European citizens, for the development of all European regions.We should support that in this report by Mr Lambert von Nistelrooij.I think we are on the right track for future cohesion policy.

name: Branislav Škripek
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, the Cohesion Fund has been a welcome help for the Eastern Bloc countries for years. In addition to criticizing the EU, we must not forget to appreciate the effort to close the gap between Europe's regions. As the ECR's shadow rapporteur, I appreciate the work of the honorable Member in this resolution, which seeks to find ways to improve our citizens' access to these resources. Such an approach must also include the ability to reflect on problems that have arisen in the implementation of payment programs. The report asks the Commission for a plan to speed up and facilitate the implementation of operational programs. Difficult access to Eurofunds due to the late conclusion of contracts between the Commission and the Member States complicates the situation in particular for applicants. Subsequently, the funds are insufficiently drawn. One possible solution is to reduce the administrative burden with which applicants are burdened. Eurofunds should be simpler, the programming system more transparent. Electronic cohesion is a good tool, but it is still not fully functional. I speak mainly for young ambitious projects in Slovakia. Their development is stifled by bureaucracy, the ubiquitous corruption. We will create such controlled conditions for them in which they will work well and will not have to fear corruption, then they will not have to leave their homeland for better conditions abroad. The aim of all those involved in drafting legislation for the use of cohesion funds must, above all, be to maximize the benefits of specific projects financed by common European money. We will achieve this by simplifying in all respects, and not complicating the lives of the recipients of these funds. Thanks for paying attention.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - First of all, I would like to comment on Mr van Nistelrooij's excellent report on investing in jobs and growth. I am very pleased that this report makes a very strong link between cohesion policy and the European Semester. Country-specific recommendations, structural reforms and investment must go hand in hand. In some European countries, the many years of use of European funds have unfortunately not led to the desired success, and this is often because too little reform has been done. Investing in European jobs and growth will only pay off if the foundations are in order, if Member States take their responsibility to reform their economies and their labor markets. If necessary, the operational programs should be adapted in the future precisely to bring them into line with the country-specific recommendations. I would like to hear from the Commissioner what her opinion is on this. Then a point about the delays in the implementation of the operational programs. In fact, this is about the problem of payments that is now re-emerging, and about the prevention of problems after 2020, with the new cohesion policy. The European Commission must very quickly come up with an action plan for tackling the payment ceilings, in order to avoid an increasing payment backlog at the end of the current programming period. Above all, we must also learn from the past with a view to the future. So let us all, Commission, Parliament and Council, ensure that the legislative process for the adoption of the next multiannual financial framework is now completed in good time. Then, too, the regulatory framework for future cohesion policy can be established soon after, and then we can finally start without delay, this time on 1 January 2021.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, simplifying the rules and procedures is a necessity. We all agree. But if the programming of funds is delayed, this is also due to the fact that there is no coherence of all European policies because you know that austerity policies have hampered the ability of States to co-finance . That is why I want to stress this need for consistency in Community policies. In addition, we must be careful that all the attempts at cohesion, which are sometimes unjust, do not weaken the policy which very concretely tempers the disastrous effects of the crisis and the policies implemented. Basically, the more the crisis sets in, the more the crisis worsens and the more we need a major effective cohesion policy. This is what we are working on, especially in the post-2020 period.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: On behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - I do not know whether the agenda makers should be thanked for bringing together two similar, very important issues concerning the delays in the European Structural Investment Funds and their impact on growth and employment. Each of them deserves a separate discussion, even though they use similar arguments. As shadow rapporteur for the Greens, I thank both rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation. In our view, both reports are not bad, but they both show the same bad trend: very high and vague, vague hopes for 'new forms of flexibility' between priorities and between operational programs. We have reason to suspect that this could lead to a pumping of funds into more investment-intensive but less cohesion-related projects. The same goes for the great admiration for the possibilities of financial instruments. These instruments run the risk that the funds allocated to them may not become real investments at all, but remain in the financial sector. And the fact that there are delays in launching at least a third of the Structural Funds programs should not be a basis for justifying such 'innovation' here. We need a broad cohesion policy geared to the needs of the regions, not the ability to focus European investment on the most easily implemented areas or investment in the financial sector.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the report by my colleague Van Nistelrooij contains a comprehensive analysis of the current state of cohesion policy and the challenges that await us from now to the post-2020 negotiation. There are several aspects that can be shared, such as the clear criticism of the EFSI, the importance of the absence of data on the effects and results produced by financial instruments or the weak link between these and the general objectives of the European Union. The parties are also positive about the need to strengthen administrative capacities and the quality of spending. I welcome the acceptance of one of our amendments, which underlines that in the future there is a need for a faster absorption of the available funds but with a more balanced progression of expenditure during the programming cycle. This is also to avoid the frequent use of retrospective or coherent projects, often aimed at avoiding automatic decommitment at the end of the programming period. However, there are two very critical issues, namely the close link of cohesion policy with the European Semester and the mention of structural reforms, subject to possible modification of the operational programs of the Member States in the post 2020. This is also important because the reform support program structural reforms will subtract EUR 142 million from cohesion policy to be used for structural reforms. With respect to the delays in cohesion policy, the late conclusion of the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and the late adoption of the regulations on the European Structural and Investment Funds are unfortunately known, which in turn slowed down the process of implementing the agreements partnership and operational programs. It should be noted that some regions only saw their operational program approved in October and some even in December 2015. It must be admitted, however, that several delays stem from Member States and regions. These need to strengthen their administrative capacity and demonstrate the real usefulness of the projects that are implemented. Here too we find the negative aspect given by structural reforms and their specific weight on the shoulders of citizens. Not to mention that there are open questions that require urgent answers. Who are responsible for the delays in the designation of managing, certifying and audit authorities, resulting in delays in the submission of payment applications? Who is responsible for the dizzying acceleration of payments in 2016, almost nine years after the start of programming? Is it only useful to avoid disengagement? We are in favor of a strong and severe criticism of absurd rules such as the Stability Pact and structural reforms, but we are in favor of a Europe of citizens and solidarity. Also tomorrow, when we discuss the dossier on natural disasters, we will see who really takes sides, not in words, on the side of European people and values.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dozens of reports, debates, trilogues and exchanges of views to come back to the same question: why do the 454 billion euros from European funds not always allow not reduce regional disparities? No matter how much communication campaigns - with public money - to try to convince the peoples of Europe of the usefulness of the European Union, the facts remain stubborn. The thematic concentration, designed to avoid the sprinkling of funds, abandons rural and peri-urban areas in favor of large metropolises. The administrative complexity inherent in the bureaucracy discourages many beneficiaries and project leaders from resorting to European funds. Finally, the introduction of ex ante criteria conditions the allocation of these structural funds to the implementation of ultraliberal austerity policies in the Member States. Remember, just a few weeks ago, you were discussing the suspension of funds intended for Spain and Portugal, which did not meet their public deficit targets, you pretended to be indignant and to oppose it, But the damage is done. This sword of Damocles has definitively discredited the ESI Funds, used to force member states to comply with Brussels injunctions. The only way out for these European funds remains their re-nationalization for the benefit of our compatriots who need them more than ever.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! There is probably no political field or policy in the European Union with which European cohesion and European solidarity can be made more visible than with cohesion policy and the structural funds. Nevertheless, I think that the two reports that are before us, as well as our question that we are making, will be made at the right time, because we are in the middle of the actual implementation period of the new funding period. We have to state, however, that many member states are still busy processing the old funding period, which expired in 2013, that new projects have not yet started and that we are facing considerable delays in cohesion policy. It has thus fallen into a slanted position that makes it urgently necessary to talk to us about how we can proceed here. Firstly, in the acceleration of what the Structural Funds are also intended for, namely in the implementation of European goals and content. This includes a debate that we should start now about whether the Europe 2020 strategy is still the strategy on which the implementation of the structural funds is based, or whether there are new challenges in the meantime which require greater flexibility . And at the same time we have to start the debate on how things can continue after 2020, firstly in securing the financial shares for the structural funds, but also in developing the legal basis.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteurs for the documents they have presented to us and the indicators they give us for the future of Cohesion Policy. These reports show that Cohesion Policy is not spending money, it is an investment policy. It must be assumed that GDP cannot be the only indicator for the distribution of funds. Unemployment rates, poverty, skills, geographic and structural constraints are also key indicators. When it comes to governance, it is clear that the local government is involved in the logic of the ILLD. This power must and must be heard as it is the closest to the citizens. But I also believe that we should create a mechanism for supervising smaller projects as some of these projects do not add value to the European Plan: this is the case of the destruction of bridges and historic walls in the city of Funchal with the money from the Cohesion Fund. The experts were not heard or the population was heard and I have no way of explaining to the citizens of that region that there is European money to be used to destroy what belongs to everyone.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, during the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy has changed radically, which now requires a change in mentality and working methods at all levels of governance, including horizontal coordination, stakeholder involvement and, as far as possible, community-led local development. Unfortunately, at the beginning of each new programming period we face the same, ie old problems, such as slow start of some programs, lack of management capacity for complex projects, administrative burden in Member States, over-regulation and, of course, errors in public procurement procedures. Therefore, I welcome the introduction of common indicators, which would make it possible to measure the results and compare them with the standard. I believe that work on the indicators must continue, in order to improve the evidence of funding from ESI funds and optimize the selection of projects. Member States, regions and local communities need to be provided with technical, professional and practical support when applying for funding.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the diversion of resources from the Union Funds to the real economy faces, in my view, three major obstacles. The first is that there is accounting and not efficient management of resources. In other words, there is a simple achievement of the goals in numerical level, which often does not correspond to the inflow of resources into the real economy. In Greece, for example, there is € 1.6 billion in spending for 2016 and you, as the Commission, are happy and the government is talking about exceeding the target but companies, start-ups, educational and research institutions are looking to find where they are. the money. The funds are committed but not channeled directly to the real economy. The second obstacle is the poor performance of the European Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative. If the numbers gave jobs, then it would not be youth unemployment at 45%. The report presented by Mr van Nistelrooij points out the shortcomings in the implementation of the European Social Fund programs. What is certain is that we need sustainable jobs for young people after education or apprenticeship and this must be done immediately. The third problem is delays in the implementation of programs, delays that lead to inefficient management of European taxpayers' money, which is a pan-European issue. We must respond with sustainable jobs resulting from Cohesion Fund funds, in cooperation with and by co-financing with tools such as the European Strategic Investment Fund of the Juncker project. We have to give answers with real work. This is our mission and I am sure you will work for it.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, cohesion policy is at a turning point, caught up in a debate between evaluating the innovations introduced by the latest reform and the need for revision and change. But it is an essential policy, because in Europe there are huge differences in development between different regions. Reflection on the future of regional policy should take greater account of the fact that cohesion policy is at the same time a victim and a better ally of the territories, which with their specific characteristics determine its implementation. Giving proper prominence to projects carried out through the structural funds is important because it brings citizens closer to European policies and encourages other administrations through the exchange of good practices. However, there is a need to evolve along two lines: flexibility and simplification. It is not possible to follow only the logic of respecting the zero point rules. For example, instead of thinking about suspending payments for Spain and Portugal in budget deficit, cohesion policy should be suspended for those countries that do not show solidarity and refuse the relocation of migrants.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mrs Crețu, the German state-owned company Fraport bought 14 regional airports in Greece instead of a lentil plate. According to what he signed, he had to pay 1.2 billion EUR but he had already received a "dowry" of 520 million EUR, after the NSRF projects of the current value of 520 million EUR had been executed at the airports of Thessaloniki and Chania. The Structural Funds regulations prohibit the privatization of NSRF projects for at least 10 years. After all, this is also prohibited by the provisions of Article 107 of the Treaty on State aid. Fraport then incorporated its plan into the Juncker project, from which it will receive an investment of EUR 400 million. It also seeks to receive EUR 300 million in loans from the European Investment Bank, the EBRD and a guarantee from the Greek State. Admire, then, how a company utilizes the Structural and Investment Funds and acquires, with a whirlwind, the 14 regional airports in Greece. I want an answer to this question. I will stay until the end of the debate, because what is being done is illegal, because NSRF projects cannot be privatized.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I greet the Commissioner and congratulate my colleague Van Nistelrooi first on his excellent report. I congratulate my colleague Novakov on relaunching the resolution on accelerating cohesion policy. We had a similar one in May last year. Even then, we warned that there would be cuts in payments in the European budget for cohesion policy, and everything really came true. In 2016, 7.2 billion less, and in 2017 a reduction in the budget for payments by 25%. These are large, significant funds that are currently needed by all our Member States, regions, cities, municipalities, rural areas for very concrete development projects, employment, growth and development. We want to accelerate economic growth. These are the means for these purposes. Unfortunately, they have shrunk by a quarter. Commissioners, last year, in that resolution, we asked you to draw up action plans, and then to monitor their implementation together, to work with you and to work with the Member States to speed up implementation. We asked for analyzes of reports of specific problems by Member States and then actions related to trainings to be carried out in Member States. Unfortunately, according to that resolution, we did not receive any document, no action plan, no report. I hope that this will not be another debate and that we will receive all the requested documents under this resolution.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur, my colleague Van Nistelrooi. Investments from the European Structural Investment Funds are crucial in reducing the economic, social and territorial inequalities of European regions. In the previous budget period, GDP per capita in the so-called convergent regions increased by 2.2%, and 600,000 new jobs were generated. It is the most important, and often the only, instrument of public investment in the Union, so maximizing the effects of these investments must be a priority. Any further delay in the implementation of operational programs would negatively affect the planned achievement of the goals of sustainable growth and development. It is equally important to ensure that members achieve the same level of capacity to work with financial instruments and additional flexibility. In doing so, the Commission should provide the necessary technical assistance and advisory services. I welcome the proposed return of the withdrawn funds to the budget of the European Union. Cohesion policy reflects one of the Union's most striking values, solidarity, and needs to continue to make more efficient use of available resources, thematically focused on better urban-rural relations, simpler procedures and better communication with citizens.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What does the European Union currently need more than ever? One simple question, one simple answer: Right - the EU needs success stories! But we don't have to invent these success stories or artificially add marketing to them. No, these success stories are right in front of us, under our noses. I am thinking of the new cycle path, the cultural hall in the village, cross-border hospital structures or the neighborhood where the unemployed are integrated. Europe is supposedly so remote from its citizens that it stands on every marketplace, on every corner, but is constantly overlooked by most passers-by. Thanks to EU regional policy, European money flows into thousands of good and concrete ideas right on the doorstep of every European. All this and much more would not exist without Europe, but unfortunately the citizens often do not know that. Europe is tirelessly at work everywhere, but remains largely invisible. Something has to happen here! The European idea must and can be told better. In the area of ​​regional policy in particular, Europe has so many positive and encouraging things to offer, and the Commission must do more to help. The mentioned delay in the acceptance and implementation of funding programs is a major obstacle in this context. The EU regional policy has to change on this point in the implementation: faster, better, less bureaucracy and better told. Then we will be able to inspire many more people with good ideas for good projects.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D).
text: - Mr President. European funds are the main investment vehicle in many EU countries, accounting for 60 to 80% of total public investment. For this reason too, I agree with the rapporteur that every innovative project that has received EU funding for its implementation must be made known to citizens. I also agree with the thematic focus, because it is a targeted policy that creates new jobs, adds value, helps lagging and disadvantaged regions. Here I would also like to give a specific example of support for backward regions, which we are already implementing in my country, Slovakia. At the beginning, action plans were drawn up for each of the lagging districts separately, and mayors, mayors, entrepreneurs, educational institutions and civil society were involved in drawing them up. This was followed by external negotiations of the Government of the Slovak Republic in the given district, where they were also approved by the Government in the presence of the drafters of the action plans. I consider it important that the competent people from a given region decide on what Eurofund funds and government support will be used for, how many jobs will be created in specific municipalities and cities, and also that such targeted support is provided by the inhabitants of the region. informed at the beginning but also during. Well thank you.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Lambert on his tireless support for cohesion policy. Today, the European Union is going through a difficult period economically, socially and politically, and populism and extremism need firm and immediate answers. Cohesion policy, along with other policies, is the foundation of the European Union. Today, more than ever, there is a need for an effective investment policy, capable of generating economic growth through employment and, in particular, close to the citizens. The development of research and innovation, which will enable the stimulation and strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises, must remain a goal for all of us. At the same time, we must continue to consider combating social disparities, unemployment, but above all we must add value to increase citizens' confidence in the European Union. There is also a need to increase the visibility of cohesion policy, which is a driver of GDP growth, including in net donor countries, through investment in convergence regions. I thus emphasize the importance of involving and involving citizens in the design and implementation of cohesion policy, and the beneficiaries must be the true ambassadors of these policies. There are also realities that cannot be ignored, and here I am referring to the difficult public procurement procedures that are currently the main obstacles to the implementation of cohesion policy. In this regard, I recommend that we give particular priority to simplifying and eliminating unnecessary procedures, but also to creating a regulatory framework based on the specific needs and challenges facing regions.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the REGI committee has raised this question because it is extremely concerned about the delays in the implementation of operational plans under the ESI Funds, because this delay translates into the failure to reduce regional disparities which can contribute to undermine the social, economic and territorial cohesion of the European Union at the basis of cohesion policy itself. Delays in the designations of managing authorities translate into delays in interim payments which, as of 30 November 2016, were well below what was initially expected. The ESI funds are aimed precisely at reducing regional disparities, generating smart, inclusive and sustainable growth, also aimed at creating quality jobs in our territories and improving the quality of life of citizens. However, our concerns go further and also concern the search for causes. The local and national capacities to implement effective and timely policies appear to be different. Among the main factors that have determined this disparity, above all, those of a purely regional nature: the availability of human capital, the innovative entrepreneurial capacity, the quality of local institutions. To these are added those of a macroeconomic nature at the national level - the state of public finance, tax systems, labor costs - which are added to those of a supranational nature such as budgetary rules. Commissioner, our concern is also more generally about the future of cohesion policy. Any debate on the future of cohesion policy cannot ignore certain key points. It is of fundamental importance that the new cohesion policy is maintained, defended and innovated, making it more immediate, more effective and simpler in its procedures in the general architecture. That is why, Commissioner, we ask you, and therefore the Commission, to present an acceleration plan for cohesion policies, simpler and clearer rules to allow for a faster and more effective implementation of operational plans, a results-oriented approach to truly respond to needsterritories and people.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, my congratulations to my colleague, the rapporteur on this important document. I have a few questions to ask the Commissioner. I ask you if you knew that, in 2016, there are more than 13 billion euros that have not been paid and that, therefore, have not been implemented, only in cohesion policy. European Strategic Investment Funds are essential for competitiveness, economic growth and employment. But who are responsible for this non-execution? Is it the Commission? Are the Member States? Is it bureaucracy? I have no doubt that we have to cut red tape. I also have no doubt that we need to accelerate: we are already in 2017 and the financial framework ends in 2020 (the cohesion policy funds). We also have to do something else, which is to promote synergies. I am the rapporteur for the Juncker Plan of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. It is essential that there is an articulation between this Fund, the Juncker Plan and the Structural Investment Funds, namely the cohesion policy funds. I give you another piece of information: as of January 31, 2017, 127 management authorities were still to be appointed out of a total of 564 management authorities. This is unacceptable! 127 unmanaged management authorities? Whose fault is this non-appointment? Without the appointment of these authorities, there will be no payments and it is essential that the amounts of the European Union budget and these funds reach the economy.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, with a budget of 351 billion euros for the period 2014-2020, cohesion policy constitutes the main expenditure item of the European Union and allows the realization of many crucial projects for the development of our regions. However, the late conclusion of the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the complexity of the management rules for the Structural Funds have resulted in many delays in the adoption of operational programs. As you know, the late implementation of these programs runs the risk of automatic decommitment, a regrettable event when many regions, still hard hit by the crisis, have a real need for this funding. The mid-term review of the MFF offers an opportunity to simplify both the management and accessibility of funds and improve their efficiency. Nevertheless, I call for great vigilance with regard to increasing synergies between structural funds and financial instruments, on pain of witnessing a financialization of cohesion policy.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for years European cohesion policy has, through the Structural and Investment Funds, played a significant role in fostering the social, cultural and economic vibrancy of both rural and urban areas across the EU, including the UK. Loss of these funds would therefore be a real blow for local economic growth in communities. In my region, Greater Manchester’s programmes for supporting people into work are underpinned by European money. Since early 2014, its Working Well pilot programme has so far engaged 4 000 residents who are on employment and support alliance to help overcome their barriers to work. The initiative will run until 2020 and is reliant on GBP 12 million yet to be received from the EU to help a further 15 000 who are on out—of—work benefits or in low—paid work. Brexit provokes many questions, including whether the UK Government will replace EU funds lost to the regions beyond 2020. It is imperative that Theresa May presents us with a long-term commitment to secure investments at a local level.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for your contribution to our debate today. I am very glad that, despite the many criticisms I heard, it is clear we in this House all care about cohesion policy. As Mr Zeller and many of you put it, this is the most visible policy we have that has changed people’s lives over the past 40 years since the creation of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). I think this debate could not be more timely. I heard a lot of comments about delays. They were referring to the limited amount of Commission payments but, in fact, spending and project selection rates in 2016 are similar to 2009 levels in the previous programming period. Once all the designated authorities are in place, I am sure we will have invoices and we will have a flow of reimbursement of contributions by Member States which are now paying from their national budgets. As I said, the reality on the ground is completely different. We have 315 000 projects already up and running, raising investments to over EUR 107 billion. We have action plans for all operational programmes and, as I said, it is not just about quantity, it is also about quality. The recent reformed cohesion policy, to which the European Parliament contributed so much, introduced a range of tools that made this policy more effective. Of course we know it is sometimes hard to accept the preconditions, but they are very important for efficient investment. That is why, in the last parliamentary term, you approved this new reformed cohesion policy. I am convinced that we can do even better. When we spoke here before the Committee on Regional Policy the key word was simplification, but when I go to the Committee on Budgetary Control the key word is control, and we have to find the right balance because both are right. We need simplification and, at the same time, we need better control over how taxpayers’ money is used. You are right, honourable Members, about simplification but I would like to tell you, Mr Fernandes and Mr Buda, that shared management also means the sharing of responsibilities between the Commission and Member States. You know very well, for instance, Mr Buda, that in many Member States, including the country we both know best, there are many requirements that are not EU requirements. It is also about red tape, gold-plating, adding requirements at national level, and we also have to convince Member States about simplification for the beneficiaries. As you said, and you are right, the beneficiaries should be our ambassadors – the presidents of regions and the mayors – because this is the only policy which is working hand in hand with local citizens’ representatives. So please spread the word among your colleagues in this House. Maybe you come from a town where people do not know how many things were done by the European Union. I do not know how many people in Naples know that the metro was funded by the European Union. I do not know how many people in Athens know that the metro there was funded by the European Union. And, by the way, provide us please with all your requirements because we are ready to address them. We pushed hard on the Greek authorities to accelerate the implementation of the metro in Thessaloniki. I think it is unacceptable for a country in which we have invested EUR 80 billion since 1981, where everything – the provision of thousands of schools, hospitals, highways and bridges – has been accomplished with European money, then to say that cohesion policy does not exist. In Greece, 75% of all public investment is provided by the European Union, so we have to be honest with ourselves. Look at the picture: how was Greece before 1981 and how is Greece now? (Inaudible interjection by Mr Marias) Please send me a written letter. I would just like to say that the cohesion policy works, it delivers and it really changes people’s lives. I am very glad to hear that we need technical assistance but we cannot give technical assistance without knowing the requirements of the Member States. We have so many European instruments which are not used by the Member States and they do not ask for these instruments to be activated, which are subsidised 100% by the Commission We have very few requirements from the Member States and from the regions. We are here to help. We are here to improve this policy, and I am here to fight for this policy post-2020. All the political groups know that we are already working together with the Committee of the Regions, and with you, for a better and more effective European policy.

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much indeed for making an effort to answer the questions. I would like to emphasise that we, as parliamentarians, have opportunities to do that too. And, vis-à-vis the national parliaments, you made the point about gold-plating and the need for simplification. I think that we share these objectives and that every single institution could still do more.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij
text: rapporteur. –  Mr President, it is an honour to hear this broad debate today, with all the contributions. Let me highlight three points.  The first point is about the effect of this kind of debate. As Ms Maletić said, we had already had a resolution before, and there was not really a follow-up. Tomorrow this House will agree on a resolution. In the resolution is a clear request, without any doubt, and you could also hear it today, that you want to have a master plan on acceleration. And this is not a theoretical thing. The last subject we debated was about the cloud, wasn’t it, the science cloud? But this is not a cloud, this is an agreement between the Commissioner and Parliament to come with an acceleration plan. And this means that you look and tell us honestly: what does it mean if you start three years later? What is the effect on bills? Because we don’t want to have again the backlog of bills that we had last time. It was a shame for Parliament and the other European institutions.  My second point: you heard several contributions about, as they say in Germany, Bürgernähe, it means closeness to the citizens. If the Member States don’t like to show that they could perform better with European money, go directly to those who act in the programmes, the youngsters who get these qualifications, etc. It was Juncker, exactly in the place where you sit now, who said we need the story of normal people, the volunteers, but also those in real programmes. So let the star shine, I mean with those who really feel that Europe is important for them, and bypass the Member States. So do not just say it but modernise and change your communication policy. My third point – it’s late but not too late – I don’t want to have these type of debates repeated and repeated. Maybe in the omnibus we can find a little loophole to get some legal restrictions so that we can throw them out, for instance, in the interest of this better communication. Thank you very much for being here so late, all of you.

name: President. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(1). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Structural and Investment Funds have become one of the main sources of public investment in recent years. In some Member States, more than 60% of investments were financed from this source. They seem to have fulfilled their role, especially during the fiscal crisis. Today we should consider how to make them more effective and add value. A fundamental problem in many Member States is high unemployment, especially among young people with mismatched qualifications. Currently, however, infrastructure problems are often a barrier to finding employment. Therefore, it would be good to think how to effectively reconcile the needs related to the development of infrastructure necessary for a modern economy, e.g. increasing the availability of broadband Internet in rural areas, with the need to adapt education and training systems to the requirements of a modern economy. The situation on the labor market is changing very dynamically and we must find appropriate response mechanisms also at the EU level. It is necessary to simplify and make the availability of funds from the funds more flexible. The changes introduced in recent years have had quite the opposite effect, for example delays in the actual implementation of cohesion policy. It is good for the Commission, the Council and the governments to learn the lessons of the current programming period and not to make similar mistakes again. We cannot allow ourselves to weaken the effectiveness of one of the few instruments for stimulating economic growth and creating new jobs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - We are at a critical moment for European regional policy. Not only because the funds available are hardly sufficient for the needs of regions devastated by unemployment and precariousness such as those of the southern and eastern peripheries of the EU. But because the orientation of these funds corresponds less and less to the objective needs of these regions and to their dependent integration in the Single Market. Furthermore, their growing combination with financial instruments such as the EFSI and the effects of economic governance, which contemplate the suspension of funds if cuts in public spending are not applied, are turning them into another lever for the financialization and deregulation of the economy. We must rethink regional policy as a redistributive policy, of solidarity between regions and development of the production model in the peripheries. Otherwise, many regions of Europe will be condemned to poverty and emigration.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The present Europe, difficult in many respects, brings to the fore the need for an emotional approach to its policies, namely to base them, more than ever, on meeting the needs of European citizens: secure jobs, a high standard of living, social cohesion, reducing unemployment, by capitalizing on its financial instruments. Achieving the Europe 2020 targets is possible by maximizing synergies between the Structural Funds, European Investment Funds and other EU instruments, which will help to increase the effectiveness of related programs and projects. But the basis for maximizing these synergies is given by the set of mechanisms and extended institutionalized cooperation platforms, which must include the achievements of cooperation programs and projects, success stories, thus contributing to increasing their visibility and public awareness of the importance of contribution. those financial instruments for community development and increasing investment in job creation and security / safety.
